resources.string: Tomi regards you with narrowed eyes for a long moment. "It's taken me a while to realize it, but I'm thinkin'... you look a lot like this <lad/lass> who owes me a whole lot o' coin."
"An old friend. Blonde hair, green eyes, rugged complexion, wild eyes. Never did pay me back, neither." His expression grows even more suspicious.
"So ya admit ya owes me, then?"
Tomi frowns deeply. "Ya know, ya don't *have* ta keep saying that." With that he turns away, muttering to himself.
"Right." He glares at you for a long moment, as if considering his option, and then finally turns away, muttering. "I'll be watching you."
"Is it? What if ya came ta Waterdeep and changed yer appearance?"
"Ha! That's what *<he/she>* said, too!" He gives you one last withering glare before finally turning away, muttering under his breath.
"I said ya looked a *lot* like <him/her>... not *just* like <him/her>." Tomi gives you one last withering glare before turning away, muttering suspiciously under his breath.
He eyes you suspiciously. "Are ya sure? I never forgets a face, ya know."
"I got a question for ya: ya ever run into a halfling fella named Sammy? Anywhere along yer travels?"
"Aye, he's got a last name. Bumbleheart! Samuel Bumbleheart! Me lifelong nemesis!" He shakes his fist at the heavens suddenly, as if cursing the gods for his ill luck.
"My childhood friend, he was, and constant companion... until he betrayed me!" Again Tomi shakes his fist at the heavens.
"Well, it can't be said enough! Me whole life I've been tormented by that bugger!"
"Well maybe not me entire life, then, but enough o' it! I'd still be safely tucked away, a legendary thief in Calimshan if it weren't fer him!"
"Oh... and if ya sees him, it's important ya don't listen to none o' his blather about his wife. Or that time he got arrested. Errr... or that other time he got arrested."
Tomi thinks for a moment. "Or that time he accidentally got sold into slavery. Don't listen to none o' that."
"Ya don't need ta *slaughter* him, per se... on top o' bein' me nemesis, the poor fella just seems ta have this urge to rush at me screamin' with a dagger in his hand. Unnerving as all hell."
"Aye, well... let's get back to yer business, then."

"Well, don't you go believin' any of it. Damn fool has gone crazy... on top o' being my nemesis, he has this urge now to rush at me screamin' with a dagger in his hand every time he sees me. Unnerving as all hell."
"That's not important. What's important is that he did." Tomi looks at you indignantly. "Damn unprofessional of him, I tell ya. And ungrateful, too."
"And now, on top o' bein' my nemisis, he has to come rushin' at me screaming with a dagger in his hand every time we meet. Unnerving as all hell, that is."
"He's tormented me fer me entire life, that's what!"
"Not really. Me whole life I've been tormented by that bugger!"
"I'm just wonderin'... you're the same <lad/lass> that was mentioned in that book, aye?"
"Yeah, I don't blame ya." Tomi shakes his head and whistles appreciatively.
Deekin stares at Tomi with confusion, scratching his head. "You, ummm, you wants Deekin to writes book about you, now?"
"Naw. I get plenty of character assassination from other sources, thanks. Don't need it none in writin'."
Tomi scrunches up his face, looking entirely like he's about to broach an unpleasant subject. "Yeah, well... I was just wonderin'... did ya ever actually read the thing?"
"Well that would explain it, then. Ya see, there was somethin' a little... strange... about it..."
"Ya did, aye?" He looks mildly surprised. "Ya didn't find somethin' a little... strange... in it? Not at all?"
"Well, ya see... there's this 'tension' that develops between the hero and <his/her> 'erstwhile kobold companion'..."
"Is that so? Don't ya remember when the kobold gave ya flowers?"
"And then he says, you know... how yer the best boss *ever*..."
"Aye, but then you go on and on about how *grateful* and *appreciative* you are fer him..."
"I knew it! Damn bloody books... can't trust 'em! Full of lies, they are!"
He looks apologetic. "I had ta ask, ya know."
"Maybe." He shrugs, looking apologetic. "I had ta ask, ya know."
"Right! Dropped it is." He looks apologetic. "I had ta ask, ya know."
He shrugs. "I dunno. It just seemed, to me, that the book strongly hinted that you an' the kobold were *really close*."
Tomi looks like he is about to continue, but then purses his lips and decides against it. "Well, alrighty then. Let's just move along, shall we?"
"That's what the book says, it does."
"Ya know... tension. Like as in an attraction, aye? Like as when two folks like one another?"
"Err... I'm not talkin' about *that* sort of tension."
Tomi stares at you, his jaw dropping open. After a moment, he remembers to close it again. "Right. I, ah... ahhhhh... right."
Tomi stares at you, his jaw dropping open. After a moment, he remembers to close it again. "Maybe this little partnership will work out better than I bloody well thought," he mutters.
"Oh. Right. I knew that."
Tomi looks away, whistling innocently. A moment later he sprays something into his mouth that smells faintly of mint...
"What do I have ta do, grow scales?" He pouts. "Blast it, anyway."
"That doesn't bother ya?"
"Well, *I* would be mad, I would. Tomi Undergallows has a reputation to maintain. But if you don't mind," he shrugs. "Let's get on with it, then. Got ta provide for the sequel, right?"
He rolls his eyes. "Oh, ho ho. Yer funny, ye are. So ye're aware of the 'tension' between the hero and <his/her> 'erstwhile kobold companion', aye?"

"It did?" For a moment he looks confused, then he just shakes his head. "I'm not talkin' about that. Ya see... there's this 'tension' that develops between the hero and <his/her> 'erstwhile kobold companion'..."
"Oh, you know... the little thing that kobold fella wrote. Urinetide somethin', I don't know."
"Ummm... Deekin is right here, you knows..."
--------- Random Conversations begin here ----------
"I think I know how to get by that portal, if ye're interested."
"Supposedly, whenever ya go through that doorway, the chains pop off an they go to other places around this level. Then ya gots ta collect 'em up again an' put them back on the door."
"Sounds like someone just wanted t' make it a bit harder to move through the dungeon. I tell ya, that wizard bloke who made this place is a real nutter."
"Yeah, well, if I meets up with one more puzzle my head's goin' ta crack wide open, I tell ya."
"Naw. I didn't get all that far in here, remember?"
"The drow mentioned it, they did. They had one o' the chains an' were tryin' to figure out where the rest went."
"Suit yerself. I've got better things t' do, anyways... like watchin' for some more halfling-killin' drow, that's what."
"Brandobaris's hairy feet! There's more thrones in here than in a bloody Calimshani urinal!"
"Heh... well, Tomi does his best thinkin' on more than just his feet."
"Come to think of it, I do remember hearin' about this place. It's, errrr, the Hall of Sleeping Kings or some such. Or that's what this drunk bloke once told me."
"I guess the wizard who built this place has a fondness fer collectin' ancient northern Kings an' such. Puts 'em on display here, I guess."

He shrugs. "I dunno. You human folk got all sorts of Kings an' Queens lyin' around, maybe the wizard scooped up a few extra. All I know is I wouldn't go ticklin' them any... they don't look *that* dead to me."
"Oy! Watch where yer flingin' accusations like that! I'm hurt, I am."
"Good. I don't think they're the giggling type anyhow."
"Anytime, mate!"
"None that I can see, but I wouldn't go an' tickle any o' these fella either. They don't look all *that* dead, if ya ask me."
He shrugs. "How should I bloody know? Just don't go an' tickle them or anythin', that'd be my advice."
"You know, I think this is what they call the Hall of Mirrors. Bloody famous, this part is."
"Alright, fine. Have it your way. Tomi'll just stay out of sight and a bit further away, if it's all the same to you."
"Alright, fine. Have it your way. Tomi'll just keep out of sight, if it's all the same to you."
"Could be because of all the mirrors lined up. Just a thought, ya know."
"I might be. What's it to ya?"
"Hey! Hey! Let's not get personal-like, all of a sudden, aye? Tomi didn't mean anything by that comment. Just warnin' ya about these mirrors."
"Right. Respect. Got it, aye. Now about the hall...?"
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> Tomi rolls his eyes visibly, sighing. "Right. Anyway, do ya want to hear about the hall, or don't ya?"
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Tomi looks at you and he gulps audibly, obviously unnerved. "Ummm... aye. I didn't mean nothin' by that, no offense. Just warnin' about the hall, is all."
"Well, I've heard tale of a place in Undermountain where there's rows of mirrors... some of them magical, some of them not. Some of them are real dangerous like, or so the stories go."
"Had a friend who said he looked in one of the mirrors and his image just bloody well stepped out and attacked him! Don't like the idea of another Tomi runnin' around, myself."

"Oh... one other thing: my friend also said that he broke a bunch of mirrors and found good treasure behind some of them. Ended up with a lot o' bad luck, though. Seven years per mirror adds up, ya know."
"An' that's a lot." Tomi scratches himself. "Poor fella. Ended up stabbed, he did. I really had no choice, though."
"Speaking of which, ya want me to stay outta sight? Just in case?"
He looks at you dubiously. "Well... alright. I got a bad feelin' about this, though."
"Right! Good luck to ya!"
He nods, grinning. "Aye, that's what it was called. It ain't the only magical mirror here, either, so you've got to be cautious."
"Ho ho ho. Ye're too bloody funny, ye are."
"Right. Well, I don't exactly like the idea of having another one o' *you* runnin' around, either, so let's be careful what we look into, aye?"
His thoughts wander for a moment on that subject, and then he suddenly smiles broadly. "But enough o' that. Ya need me ta join up with ya, I expect?"
"You brought me back just ta leave me here? Not that I'm complainin', but that seems just silly."
------- This line must be placed at the end of inter-party banter ---------
"So I hears tellin' that yer some kind o' talespinner, Sharwyn. That true?"
"It's true enough. I'm a bard, after all."
"So ye've heard of the great Tomi Undergallows, then, aye?"
"No, sorry. I've only heard of famous people."
"Oh! Stabbed right in the gut, that one!"
"If it makes you feel better, I actually have heard of you."
"Ya have?"
"I've heard you're an utter pig."
Tomi thinks about it for a moment, and then grins. "Better'n nothin'."
"So-oooo... Sharwyn, is it? That's a pretty name fer a pretty lass."
"Don't even think about it, halfling."
"What? I didn't even hardly say nothin'! Why are ya gettin' all defensive?"
"You think I'm not aware of your reputation? For such a small man you are certainly a huge misogynist."
"Really? Well... I'm bloody glad ya noticed."
"What exactly do you think a misogynist is?"
"Ya just want me ta say? Out loud an' everything?"
"Oh, never mind..."
"Daelan? I gots a question I need ta ask ya. Don't mean to offend ya none, though..."
"With you, that practically guarantees I will be. But go on."
"Well, it's just that... I've met a few half-orcs in my time, ya know? And ye're the first one in all me life I've ever met who wasn't... you know..."
"A complete moron?"
"There ya go."
"You're right, Tomi. How could I possibly be offended by such a question?" Daelan sighs heavily. "What, exactly, do you wish to know?"
"Well..." Tomi taps his chin thoughtfully. "I just want ta know one thing... does yer smarts give ya an easier time with the ladies... or *worse*?"
"Tomi..."
"Yeah, big fella?"
"Perhaps it would be better if you focused on the adventure at hand."
"Right-o! Focusing."
"Hmmm. Ye're a rather large fella there, aren't ya, Daelan?"
"Your point being?"
"My point being that large folk such as yerself need to be kept entertained! Let Tomi do a trick for ya! How about you hand me that ring of yours?"
"Very well. I want this back, however, halfling." Daelan removes his ring and hands it over. "You understand, yes?"
"Heh heh... would I try to trick you? That's not very fair of ya, is it?"
"Perhaps not, though it is sensible."
"Err... yeah. Anyhow..." Tomi takes the ring and passes his hand over it a few times. Some flashy hand movements and he tosses the ring up... only it has vanished! "Ta-da!"
"You have three seconds to return the ring, halfling."
"Ye're not much of an audience, is ya?" Grudgingly, Tomi reaches into a pocket and fetches out the ring, handing it back. Daelan grins broadly but says nothing in return.
"So... I've been watchin' ya fer a little while, Linu..."
"You're a thief. I hate thieves. I'm not listening to you."
"Well, I was thinkin... ye're always goin' on about how clumsy ye are an' such. I don't think that's the case at all."
She looks away from him. "I'm still not listening. I won't let your insults and jibes get to me."
"I'm just tryin' to tell ya that I don't think ye're clumsy at all. In fact, I think ye're graceful just like every other bloody elf I've seen."
"R-really? You... you mean that?" Linu's smiles in disbelief, her eyes tearing.
"Naw. Ye're pretty much clumsier'n a troll with two left feet."
Linu sighs and glares at Tomi. "I hate you, you little fiend."
"Correction: *dextrous* and *agile* little fiend! Ha ha ha ha-ha!!"
"Linu, ye're a healer, right? I've got some... aches... from old battles, hurtin' somethin' fierce!"
"Oh, that's terrible, dear! Where does it hurt? Maybe I can help."
"Oh, all over. I think I need some hands-on attention, if ya know what I mean..."
"I think I do, yes."
"And?" Tomi waggles his eyebrows at her, grinning.
"AND I SAY I HATE THIEVES!!" Linu suddenly grabs Tomi's earlobe and pinches it hard. "Rotten scoundrels, all of you! And especially you!!"
"OW! OW! Hey, what's yer problem?! Sheesh!"
"You think I would forget that YOU were the one that stole my holy chalice? The one that forced me to travel all the way to Neverwinter in the first place?"
"Oh... that."
"Yes. THAT."
"Heh... I guess a little healin's out o' the question, then, eh?"
"Just pray I'm never in a position to decide whether or not you need to be raised."
"Ya know... I was lookin' through yer notes, Deekin. The ones fer that book ye're writin'."
"YOU gots Deekin's notes? Gives them back!"
"Oh, you can have 'em back. I'm just wonderin'... what's with all the doodles?"
"That be none of mean halfling's business."
"All the hearts an' such, an' some of 'em looked a little... ummm... risque, if ya ask me."
"Deekin not asks you, now gives Deekin's notes back!"
"And what's with that writing? I could barely read it... it looked like a dyin' man writin' out his will or somethin'..."
"BO-OOOSSSSSS!!"
"Alright, alright, have yer damn notes back, ya big baby."
"They is all here? Good."
"And, ummm... let me know when you finish the chapter..."
"Hmmm... so tell me, kobold... just how tall are ya, anyhow?"
"Is that why you keeps lookings at Deekin?"
"Just tell me how tall ya are, dammit! Come here, let me measure ya..."
"You smells like cheese! Boss! Bo-oossss! Smelly halfling is bothering Deekin again!"
"I am not, ya bloody liar! Can't ya answer a simple question?"
"Bloody squealer."
"Nyah nyah!"
"I just want ta bloody well know! Why's that so hard ta understand!"
"He just mad 'cause Deekin is taller."
"That's it! Ye're in fer a world o' hurt now, ya scuttling lizard thing, you!"
"Oh... sorry, boss."
"Hah! Serves you right!"
"You could always buys taller shoes, maybe."
"Oh, shut up."
"You gets the boss mad. You is awful henchman."
"I'm going to kick yer bloody arse, just you watch --"
"Sorry, boss."
"Yeah, sorry."
"Never mind."
"I think we need to part ways."
"No, never mind."
"Wait here until I return."
"I need to go."
"I want to change your tactics."
"I don't want to change anything else right now."
"I want you to leave any traps that you see alone."
"I want you to disarm any traps that you see."
"I want to move faster and not bother with searching or stealth."
"I need you to be stealthy right now."
"Don't help me if I fail to open a locked door or chest."
"Help me if I fail to open a locked door or chest."
"I want to change the distance you stay away from me."
"Stay a long distance away."
"Keep a medium distance."
"Stay close."
"Go ahead and attack as soon as you see enemies."
"Defend me and don't attack until I do."
"I want to adjust your equipment."
"Can you identify my equipment?"
"Can you summon one of your shadows?"
"I need you to blend into the shadows."
"What was it you wanted to say earlier?"
"Let's stop and talk a moment."
"We're done talking."
"No, nothing else."
"How is everything?"
"I wish to discuss your training."
"Go back to splitting your time up between rogue and Shadowdancer."
"Continue with what you're doing now."
"Focus on being a Shadowdancer."
"Focus on being a rogue."
"What's a Shadowdancer?"
"Do you have plans for what you're going to do after all this?"
"Icewind Dale? What kind of vacation is that?"
"Good plan. I might just have to join you."
"And if this drow proves to be too tough for you?"
"I think I did hear that somewhere."
"You're a very odd little halfling."
"So what happened after you helped save Neverwinter?"
"Suddenly I don't want to know..."
"Yes, before that."
"What misunderstanding?"
"I see where this is going..."
"So he kicked you out of the city?"
"What kind of businesses?"
"You started a thieves' guild."
"I don't need to hear any more."
"It's no wonder Lord Nasher kicked you out of the city!"
"And how did that go?"
"Who's Lord Nasher again?"
"And you had a misunderstanding with him?"
"You said you came from Neverwinter, correct?"
"I was in Hilltop when that happened, yes."
"So you must be very popular in Neverwinter."
"Why am I not surprised?"
"So I'm told."
"How is Neverwinter now?"
"Tell me about this Lady Aribeth."
"I thought I heard someone else was responsible for curing the plague?"
"What happened to this hero?"
"Who is this Lady Aribeth?"
"Poor lass? You mean Lady Aribeth?"
"What happened to her?"
"No, stay here for the moment."
"Yes, come with me."
"Not right now. I'm busy."
"You don't need to be rude, you know."
"Maybe later."
"That's better."
"What is it, Tomi?"
"Gold? Not much."
"Gold? I have lots of it."
"Lemons?"
"Enough, Tomi. I'm not interested."
"A sour fruit? Who would want such a thing?"
"How is this an investment, exactly?"
"Maybe you could make some kind of juice drink out of it, even."
"About what?"
"Sounds great."
"I'll get back to you on that."
"Ri-iiiiggghht."
"That's a rather rude question."
"Why do you need to know?"
"You can ask, but I don't have to answer."
"No, you can't."
"Why do you ask?"
"And who is this <lad/lass> who owes you money, exactly?"
<StartAction>[Sigh.]</Start> "And I never will, either."
"Sounds like me, alright."
"That doesn't sound anything like me. That's stupid."
"You can try to collect, but I wouldn't recommend it."
"Perhaps I should have left you dead where I found you..."
"I admit to nothing."
"Sure thing. Bring it on, short stuff."
"That's ridiculous."
"You're insane."
"Fine, you got me. I thought I had you fooled, too."
"If I look different, then how could I look just like this person?"
"No, I've never been to Calimshan."
"I don't even know where Calimshan is."
"You think we've met before?"
"I'm quite certain I've never been to Calimshan, yes."
"Sammy? Does he have a last name?"
"No, I've never met anyone by that name."
"What, he owes you money?"
"Dare I even ask?"
"Right. He's your enemy. I got that part."
"I thought you said he was your childhood friend and companion?"
"Slaughter him on sight. Got it."
"I bet."
"Are you kidding? I'd love to hear what he has to say, suddenly."
"Why did he betray you, exactly?"
"What did he do, exactly?"
"A bit overdramatic, aren't you?"
"Why are you asking?"
"I don't really want to talk about that."
"Mentioned? It was a chronicle of my adventure."
"Hardly. Why would I?"
"No, I never got around to it."
"I have no doubt about that. What's your point?"
"What are you talking about?"
"Yes, I did."
"No, nothing strange at all. Why?"
"I'm sure you're imagining things."
"What about it?"
"So? He says that stuff all the time."
"Well, that's just a big lie!"
"Hmph. I agree."
"I think you're reading too much into it, anyway."
"Let's just drop the topic, all right?"
"What are you trying to say, Tomi?"
"You're insane. Now drop it."
"We were friends. I still don't understand what you mean."
"I *was* grateful and appreciative of him."
"I *am* the best boss ever."
"Deekin never gave me flowers. That's silly."
"So what about it, then?"
"I don't understand. What are you talking about?"
"Tension? Well, I did find him annoying."
"Oh, that. Well, he *is* one cute kobold."
"I was joking."
"If you're lucky."
"You're no kobold, Tomi."
"So? So what?"
"Why would it? Deekin is one cute little kobold."
"It's not true, so I'm not concerned."
"It's just a book. What do I care?"
"I'd hate to think what you'd consider strange."
"It had completely atrocious grammar."
"Other than the fact a kobold wrote it?"
"Mentioned in which book?"
"Tell me what you know, then."
"Chains. Got it. Just a simple puzzle."
"Do you know where the chains are?"
"How do you know about that?"
"I don't need help with that, thanks."
"If you don't have anything useful to say, be silent."
"Who do you suppose these skeletons are?"
"That's pretty gross, Tomi."
"What northern Kings?"
"You just watch your sticky fingers here, halfling."
"I don't plan on tickling them."
"Gee. Thanks for the advice."
"Any traps that you can see?"
"Do you think they'll come to life?"
"I don't need to hear about it, Tomi."
"Why do they call it that?"
"Are you mocking me?"
"I don't need this. Keep your comments to yourself."
"Nothing at all. Now... let's talk about your treasure share..."
"I'd like a little more respect if we're to travel together."
<StartCheck>[Intimidate]</Start> "Do you want to die now, halfling?"
"Fine, fine. What do you know about it?"
"I meant why does it need a special name, smart mouth?"
"Right. I'll be careful."
"No, stay in sight."
"Sure, do that."
"There's a Mirror of Duplication in here?"
"It'd be nice to have a back-up for the next time you die."
"I don't like that idea, either."
"You know something about it?"
"Yes, let's go."
"No, just stay here for now."
"Tomi..."
"Leave him alone, Tomi."
"Why do you want to know, Tomi?"
"Don't taunt him, Deekin."
"He's taller, Tomi. Get over it."
"Stop it, you two!"
"Enough!"

Mask of the Skull

A recent decision by Archmage Szass Tam has led to the creation of these masks, which all necromancers in the borders of Thay are required to wear. Those wearing the mask have access to powerful magics, but are also subject to Tam’s control. Any wizard caught practicing necromancy while not wearing such a mask is killed and turned into a ghoul to serve Tam in death better than they did in life.
Spellchain

Drow spellswords often wear this light armor. It is formed of an unusual, lightweight metal, that makes the armor more flexible. These properties reduce the difficulty for arcane spellcasters to cast spells while wearing these suits.
Full Plate +6
Large Shield +6
Large Shield +7
Shield of Prator

Dethin Prator was a hero of Unther, who led one of the most successful uprisings against the new Magocracy, run by the Mulhorandi conquerors. His rebellion lasted two months, during which time his army swelled to total over 1500 men. His army came to the attention of a dissatisfied Unther mage, who began to supply his army with magical assistance, including this shield. When the army was finally destroyed, Prator was found dead, but his shield was gone.
Chaos Shield
Small Shield +6
Small Shield +7

Tower Shield +7
Bulwark of the Great Dragon

Darson the master smith constructed this mighty shield out of the bones and scales of an ancient wyrm. While Darson, never afraid of bragging, claims he slew the beast himself, few believe it. Most likely he came upon the corpse of the great beast and salvaged what he could. Whatever the truth may be, the protections on this shield are formidable enough to please the bravest of knights.
Lathar's Last Belt

Lathar was a wizard of little renown who thought himself worthy to test a powerful archmage in a magical duel. Knowing his rival's penchant for death magic, Lathar crafted this special belt to grant himself immunity against such wizardry. The day of the duel came and the two wizards squared off against each other. The archmage flung nasty fingers of death and invoked powerful power word kills left and right and all the while Lathar laughed. "Do your worst!" Lathar said, mocking his rival. The archmage frowned. Then with a clever smile he snapped his fingers and summoned forth a dire bear which promptly swallowed poor Lathar in just one bite.
Fiendforged Plate

This malevolent armor tingles as you run your hand over it. It is not uncommon for lesser devils or demons to be bound by a higher entity into armor or weapons. One such servant of evil is trapped within this finely forged armor and his will is now bound to the wearer of this armor. He is able to anticipate the wearer's movements, decreasing the chance of arcane spell failure.
Souldrinker's Sire

Thirsting for fresh blood, usually only a warrior intent on death and destruction wields such an evil blade. Some warriors claiming to be doing good have attempted to master the souldrinker and use it for noble purposes, but more often than naught, they are found surrounded by carnage and death too horrible to bear. One such warrior was found in a cathedral, surrounded by the corpses of priests and resting on the end of his own blade, where he had thrown himself in a fit of guilt.
Cleric's Robe
Armor of Faith
The silver in this armor seems to shine with a soothing light.
Created in a forge blessed by unknown gods to match the resolve shown by the wearer this armor almost glows with its own light. Worn by zealots and kings it is a symbol of the righteous and the bold.
Bindings of Blood

This clothing is worn only by warriors of exceptional skill, who survive by agility and luck. Anyone wearing this armor is extremely difficult to hold in one place and is able to move more swiftly than is natural.
Casiel's Soul
There is something unwholesome in the black spikes and muted glint of this armor that is disturbing.

The plates of blackened steel are fashioned with a slaver's cruelty to fit only those who seek the foul things of the world. This armor was known to be worn by Lord Casiel the Vile in his campaign against the Purple Dragon Knights of Cormyr. Upon Lord Casiel's death the armor was said to be destroyed.
Dancer's Silhouette
A collection of dark hardened leather held together with soft joints and cushioned padding.

This armor was created to allow for quiet work while still affording protection against a dagger in the back. Movement in this armor is utterly silent due to the ingenious construction of the joints and links holding the pieces together.
Fletcher's Friend
A delicate set of armor that has been made for a specific occupation.

There is no doubt this delicate suit of armor is made by the skilled hands of the Elves. It is specifically designed to add modest protection to the warriors that have fused the arcane ways of magic with the deadly work of the bowman. Each piece is fashioned to afford protection without sacrificing any movement required for the art of the bow.
Last Words
A set of dark clothing that fits snugly over the skin.

This is the uniform of the assassin elite. Only one very sure of his abilities would even dare to wear such a costume in public. Most will not recognize this mark of a trained and professional killer but those who do will heed its message.
Shiver-ring

This ring is warm to the touch. When worn it will accelerate the body's natural warming process. This increase in shivering makes the character a little more clumsy and also weakens their constitution. However, the ring keeps out all but the coldest cold, so the side-effects of wearing it may sometimes be worthwhile.
Robes of the Dark Maiden

The members of the Order of the Dark Maiden are devoted to the service of the Drow goddess Eilistraee. The monks of the Order promote peace and harmony between the Drow race and the races of the surface world, but will repond to evil with swift and deadly action.
Shifter Tunic
This clothing would afford little protection, and seems to be designed for some specific purpose.

The blood of the wild runs through the veins of those that would wear this unassuming clothing. The crack of bones and the sliding of flesh is the common state for one who can assume any shape of nature and clothing is of little value.
The Gilded Defender
This is a very finely crafted suit of armor with inlays of gold and brass.

The ring of metal against metal seems to cling to this ornate suit of the very finest armor. Hammered into the most intricate of shapes by the finest dwarven smiths, this armor speaks of the dwarven culture's most honored companions: the Defenders. None shall pass their shield wall, and none shall withstand their charge.
The Iron Skeleton
This armor seems to be a collection of metal bones over leather.

It is not clear what darkness possessed the talented smith who created this unsettling armor. The steel seems to slither along the wearer's limbs; reshaping itself into a new suit with each new wearer. It acts as protection against the darkness but also seems to call to the shadows themselves.
Volkarion's Robe
Fists of Balance

An old legend tells of an order of monks who lived within a castle of ice submerged beneath a sea of fire, a symbol of balance and stability within a chaotic world. Though many have searched for this fabled contradiction, for the most part, only rumors have been recovered. Yet a few crazed adventurers have stumbled into this tavern or that tavern clutching a pair of these gloves -- keeping the legend from fading away and the curious searching for the elusive order.
Lichskull

Hans Kludgen spent his life assisting the arch-mage Cledos. He traveled for many years across the world to hunt for arcane components to assist Cledos in the wizard's many rituals. Cledos rewarded Hans one fateful day by decapitating the faithful assistant and through a rare ritual, transformed the half-orc's skull into this powerful helmet. Hans -- always the dutiful assistant -- had delivered his final components to his master.
The Regal

This bronze helm was last worn by a hero of little fame who led a crusade into the Underdark. His goal? To eliminate the drow. His mission sadly failed, the hero lies in an unmarked grave. His helmet was taken as a trophy by the drow who slaughtered him.
Platinum Helm
This helmet hums with electrical energy. Capable of absorbing and discharging energy, this helmet is unpredictable, but when used properly, very powerful.
Crown of Thorns
A demon with no name crafted this macabre helmet from the flesh of a planetar he slew. It still pulsates with the blood of that long dead planetar.
Lesser Ioun Stone: Blue
This flawless gem radiates strong magic and seems to glow from within. The exact nature of the gem's enchantment remains a mystery.

Ioun stones are well known to possess different powers depending upon their color. When activated they orbit around the head of their owner. Only 1 lesser ioun stone may be activated at a time. The blue ioun stone increases your wisdom by 2 while active.
Lesser Ioun Stone: Deep Red

Ioun stones are well known to possess different powers depending upon their color. When activated they orbit around the head of their owner. Only 1 lesser ioun stone may be activated at a time. The deep red ioun stone increases your dexterity by 2 while active.
Lesser Ioun Stone: Dusty Rose

Ioun stones are well known to possess different powers depending upon their color. When activated they orbit around the head of their owner. Only 1 lesser ioun stone may be activated at a time. The dusty rose ioun stone increases your AC by 1 while active.
Lesser Ioun Stone: Pale Blue

Ioun stones are well known to possess different powers depending upon their color. When activated they orbit around the head of their owner. Only 1 lesser ioun stone may be activated at a time. The pale blue ioun stone increases your strength by 2 for while active.
Lesser Ioun Stone: Pink and Green

Ioun stones are well known to possess different powers depending upon their color. When activated they orbit around the head of their owner. Only one lesser ioun stone may be activated at a time. The pink and green ioun stone increases your charisma by two while active.
Lesser Ioun Stone: Pink

Ioun stones are well known to possess different powers depending upon their color. When activated they orbit around the head of their owner. Only one ioun stone may be activated at a time. The pink ioun stone increases your constitution by two while active.
Lesser Ioun Stone: Scarlet and Blue

Ioun stones are well known to possess different powers depending upon their color. When activated they orbit around the head of their owner. Only one lesser ioun stone may be activated at a time. The scarlet and blue ioun stone increases your intelligence by two while active.
Adamantine Helm
Adamantine Full Plate
Beholder Properties
This is a a blank scroll of the kind spellcasters use to scribe magic scrolls. A spellcaster with the scribe scroll feat can cast a spell on this scroll to scribe a magic scroll of that spell.
Magical Potion Bottle
Bar of Adamantine
This incredibly rare metal is usually found deep beneath the surface and is as dark as the skin of those who mine it.
Bolt of Cloth
This bolt of cloth holds enough material to make a set of clothing.
Bar of Iron
Melted down and poured into shape, iron is used to make many weapon and armor components.
Ironwood Planks
This very hard and dense wood is used to create shields, quarterstaves and various other items.
A tanned hide such as this is used to make light armor and various weapon components such as bowstrings.
Bar of Mithral
Very light but strong, mithral is usually found worked into the best weapons and armor.
Plank of Oak Wood
Oak is a very strong and durable wood, that can be used to create weapons such as clubs or weapon parts such as the body of a crossbow.
Bar of Steel
Steel is a combination of metals, much stronger than iron. Most weapon and armor components are made of it.

Cloak of the Bat

Known only by his nickname, Stiletto the thief became renowned for his amazing skill at burglary. He claimed he could get in and out of the most secure, heavily guarded treasure rooms without ever getting caught. Once, on a dare, he snuck into Zhentil Keep and stole a ring from Fzoul’s high chambers. Getting in seemed to be easy, but escaping turned out to be more difficult. When Stiletto found himself surrounded by multiple guards, the secret of his career was revealed. Stiletto turned into a bat and flew out through a window.
Cloak of Epic Spell Resistance

Vhaerun, the drow god of night and thievery, had a run in with Mask, the human god with the same portfolio. Attempting to work his magic against the other god, Vhaerun found his energies deflected from his target. As each god studied the other, Vhaerun realized that Mask wore a cloak that tied into his spell resistance. Eventually the two gods formed an uneasy truce, and Vhaerun put some of his talented followers to work making similar cloaks.
Mantle of Great Stealth

It was a duergar scout named Barnund Dokenhand who discovered the ancient hall of Verik, filled with wondrous, ancient magical items. As the hall was icy cold, the dwarf grabbed an old cloak and draped it around his shoulders. When he returned to his party, he was amazed to discover how close he was able to get before they noticed him. He reported that he had found nothing but this old cloak. When Barnund decided to return on his own, he was discovered by a suspicious mage, who ended Barnund’s life and took the cloak for himself.
Cloak of Fortification +4

Great Wyrm Gauntlets

These bulky gauntlets were stitched from the flesh of a great wyrm slain many seasons ago. The slayer, known only as Redshadow, was a dragon disciple, rumored to be the child of the slain dragon. Their epic battle thundered across the skies over the Dragonsfire Mountains. When the great wyrm fell the ground shook in outrage. Redshadow made these powerful gauntlets and wore them till her own death at which point they disappeared, becoming just another part of the legend lost to time...
Epic Minotaur Axe
Amulet of Vitality +2

When Jacin Maltis, a petty lord in Sembia, paid for the crafting of an amulet to increase his health, he expected a tasteful necklace with a small, but precious gem mounted in it. When he placed the necklace around his neck and the diamond turned a gaudy blood red, he refused to pay the wizard who created it. The wizard simply smiled, and loosed a spell that instantly destroyed the noble. Copies of this amulet were found circulating months later in the distant city of Waterdeep.
Amulet of Vitality +4
Amulet of Vitality +6
Amulet of Divine Radiance
Said to have been created by the hand of Lathander himself, these amulets shine brightly with divine power. The divine light streaming forth is said to paralyze or even destroy the undead.
Necklace of Fireballs

When Szass Tam was a living mage, he faced a competitor who was famous for his skill at evocation. Not wanting to be outdone by someone from another school of magic, Szass Tam came prepared to the duel. He threw twelve fireballs in a row, much to the consternation of his opponent, who came ready to face the powers of a necromancer. When the Necklace of Fireballs was used up, Tam began to actually cast his own spells, while his opponent had already used most of his up.

Potion of Ironguts
This potion protects the wearer from poison, granting a +4 circumstance bonus on Fortitude saves against all poisons.
Potion of Death Armor

Drinking this potion will cause a magical aura to surround the caster.
Any creature striking the caster takes 1d4 points of damage +1 point per 2 caster levels (maximum +5).
Ring of Major Acid Resistance

Under the direction of Druxus Rhym, these rings are created by the Red Wizards of Thay and are sold in their enclaves across the realms. Cheap and easy to make, this magical protection from certain elements is a huge source of profit for the enclaves.
Ring of Major Cold Resistance
Ring of Major Electrical Resistance
Ring of Major Fire Resistance
Ring of Major Sonic Resistance
Ring of the Ram

Pal Verbosh was the deadliest pirate of the Nelanther Ilses. While other pirate ships would work together to capture large, heavily guarded cargos, the Tight-lipped Sailor would wait and watch, then steal in and pillage from the other pirates. No one except Verbosh’s own crew ever lived to tell about it, because Verbosh put them all to the sword, then sank their ships. Finally, Verbosh and his fellow cutthroats bit off more than they could chew and were sunk by a fellow pirate, whose magical ring punched a hole in the Tight-lipped Sailor’s hull that sank the ship in only a few minutes.
Ring of Elemental Acid Immunity

Under the direction of Druxus Rhym, these rings are created by the Red Wizards of Thay and are sold in their enclaves across the realms. While these rings are far more expensive and difficult to make than their lesser counterparts, they are still a huge source of profit for the enclaves.
Ring of Elemental Cold Immunity

Ironskin Ring

The Nimbral Lords are powerful mages whose accomplishments usually remain hidden, for fear of drawing the attentions of jealous powers. Of the creations that have escaped the isle, this ring has a tragic story that could make even the most jaded bard’s eyes well up in tears. This tale of love and death, revenge and unsuspected discoveries is a favorite amongst the most romantic and chivalrous knights in the realm.
Ring of Universal Elemental Immunity

Druxus Rhym, an important Red Wizard of Thay created only a few of these spectacular rings. His allies among the tharchions and zulkiers have earned theirs by helping Druxus amass even greater power than before. A few others have been used to bribe ruling lords, who were attempting to stop the growth of the Thayvian enclaves. Some mages have speculated whether Druxus might have some darker purpose in distributing these rings, but so far, no proof has been offered.
Major Ring of Universal Elemental Resistance

Venom Halberd
This magic weapon has an enhancement bonus to attack and damage, and its blade has been coated with an unknown poison, but it doesn't bear the hallmarks of any specific maker.
Rod of Thunder and Lightning

Xkehrmensh the Destroyer was a kobold chieftain whose tribe laid waste to a vast Underdark city of goblin-folk with lightning and thunder, uncommon forces in the depths. To this day, goblins terrorize their young with the sounds of drums and flashes of light; telling them that the kobolds are coming with a "boomstick" to kill bad little goblins and bugbears.

Drider Spear +2

Hellish Whip
Used usually by the hellish Erinyes, these whips inflict fire damage on hit.
Stormwalker

Ancient armies, their names and deeds lost to legend and mystery, fought and died not far from Forest of Mir, their bodies slowly covered by nature's tenacious grasp. Among their numbers were the Stormwalkers and each warrior of that faction carried one of these blades into battle. Every few years a farmer recovers one of these remarkable weapons while working his fields.

Warlord's Breastplate

Centuries ago a warlord called Golgemir ruled the lands called Damara. His warriors wore light armor and rode incomparable warhorses known as the dark steeds. Those lands his army conquered swore it was impossible to kill the savage ruler who kept his magical breastplate wrapped in the skin of those he slew. Eventually several neighboring countries allied to destroy the warlord and his hosts. The warlord died like any other man, but only after killing over 300 men single handedly.
Lesser Golem Armor

When Poderik Strind survived his first attack from a golem, he was struck by a thought. If a person could harness the same magical energies that animated a powerful golem, and put them on a suit of armor, that person would be a walking death machine. Such a warrior would be better than either a golem or a regular warrior, since he would have the strength and toughness of the golem, but the flexible mind of a man. The design disappeared with Poderik when he went to test his armor in a haunted cavern and never came back.
Robes of the Shining Hand +6
Robes of the Shining Hand +7
Mantle of Epic Spell Resistance
Only very few epic wizards are known to be able to create an Epic Mantle of Spell Resistance. This embroidered garment grants the wearer a spell resistance of 32.

Relic of the Reaper

You discovered this artifact many years ago when you were briefly trapped in the Plane of Shadows. Ever since you first picked it up, it has refused to leave your possession. Drop it, throw it away, crush it... always it immediately reappears in your hand, pulsing warmly with power as it ever does. Its main ability that you know of is that it can teleport you to a pocket dimension ruled over by a mysterious being that calls itself the Reaper. The Reaper's dimension is a nexus of sorts. The Reaper, not an unfriendly sort, allows you to use the relic to "bind" a location to a door in the dimension, allowing instant transportation back to that point. The Reaper will also teleport you to the dimension upon the moment of your death, saving you. The relic may only be used in this fashion, however... to bind a point or save you from death... if you have a Rogue Stone in your possession. The Reaper uses the power inherent within the gem to power the relic, destroying the gem in the process. Naturally this makes Rogue Stones even more valuable to you than they would be otherwise. Where the Reaper comes from or how the relic stone was created has never been revealed to you. You suspect that one day it's mysterious history will catch up with you. For the moment, however, it has been far more of a boon.
Rogue Stone
Stoneeater's Ring
This ring can turn stone creatures to flesh. There is more history to this item, but it is irrelevant and distracting.
Sequencer Robe
The fabric of this robe bristles with magical energy as you run your hand across it.

The fabric of this robe is woven from thin strips of a mysterious material that is capable of storing magical spells. A caster need only cast a defensive spell upon the robe. The robe will then store the spell so that it may be cast at a later time, instantly. This robe is capable of storing one spell, though there are rumors that more powerful robes exist.
Greater Sequencer Robe

The fabric of this robe is woven from thin strips of a mysterious material that is capable of storing magical spells. A caster need only cast a defensive spell upon the robe. The robe will then store the spell so that it may be cast at a later time, instantly. This robe is capable of storing two spells, though there are rumors that more powerful robes exist.
Isaac's Sequencer Robe

The fabric of this robe is woven from thin strips of a mysterious material that is capable of storing magical spells. A caster need only cast a defensive spell upon the robe. The robe will then store the spell so that it may be cast at a later time, instantly. This robe is capable of storing three spells.
Renewal

Thomas Alvanthorn led the Circle of Flame, a group of druids dedicated to the use of fire as a tool to replenish the forests. Their actions often led them into direct opposition with other, more traditional druids, who strive to keep the forest free of flame. Still Alvanthorn perservers and many druids wield his Renewal sickles, spreading both flame and the cause.

When the heroes of Neverwinter became famous, the dwarven smith of Neverwinter crafted a special axe in honor of their deeds. During the crafting of this weapon, a fever consumed the smith and drove him to work such magical forces as he had never crafted before. Afterwards he claimed that a god had come upon him and blessed his work. Mysteriously, the weapon disappeared while on display in the Halls of Justice and has never been seen again.
Greataxe +6
Greataxe +7
Stonefire Axe +8

The head of this great axe is hot to the touch, which explains why the shaft is made of ironwood and is immensely long. Though the origins of this axe are long forgotten, the power inhabiting the axe is obviously that of a master craftsman.
Handaxe +6
Handaxe +7
Ice Reaver +8

When the barbarian tribes north of Icewind Dale encountered a fierce band of fire giants, lost and alone, their Ice Reaver hand axes made short work of them. Finding a vast sum of gold on the giants, the chieftain commemorated the battle by having new, more powerful reavers crafted for his warriors. Over time, most of these axes disappeared, and occasionally a young warrior will set off to quest for one of the legendary items.
Club +6
Club +7
Gladiator's Club +8

Jorag Muthkik was the champion of the gladiator pits in Chessenta. His owner, a mage of dubious reputation, made certain that Jorag always had the latest in equipment. He made this club as a gift when Jorag’s win made the mage a fortune in bets. Jorag eventually retired and became a teacher at one of the top gladiator schools in Chessenta. His club was a feared disciplinary weapon.
Heavy Flail +6
Heavy Flail +7
Reaver +8

The chaotic nature of the denizens of the Elemental Plane of Fire has led to an increased interest in these icy weapons. Despite the dangers of handling such weapons, the increased damage makes reavers perfect for assassinating rivals. Merchants who travel the planes have made massive fortunes smuggling the much-coveted flails.
Light Flail +6
Light Flail +7
Foundation +8

The High Inquisitor of Auril was a bitterly cold woman with a penchant for crushing her enemies’ skulls with her magical mace. This diabolical fetish led her to hunt for better, more effective weapons, until she found the Foundation mace. Armed with the ultimate mace, the inquisitor led her soldiers in an attack on a clan of ogres who refused to work for her army. While the mace destroyed many ogres, it disappeared along with its owner, when she was taunted into following an ogre mage into the caverns the ogres called home.
Light Hammer +6
Light Hammer +7
Storm +8

In the city-states of Chessenta, a mythic war hero called Cevalias figures prominently in the rise of the city Cimbar, as the nation’s capital. Legends claim that Cevalias with his sparking war hammer became the champion of the city when he fell in love with the ruler’s daughter, a young woman called Saphia. Saphia quickly learned to manipulate the champion, and with her father’s guidance, turned him into a tool of destruction who killed over ten thousand warriors of other cities.
Izu's Hammer of Fabrication

The blind smith Izu passed away during a particularly brutal winter in the Silver Marches and it was only after his death that his family discovered his connections with the Harpers. For years Izu toiled on his forge producing weapons and magical equipment for the Harpers. This hammer was given by Izu's heirs to a young Harper Scout whom Izu had been fond of. Sadly, the scout disappeared while mapping the upper reaches of the Underdark.
Warhammer +6
Warhammer +7
Rune Hammer +8

Glittering with silver runes, capable of absorbing powerful spells, this mighty war hammer was the holy artifact of a dwarven tribe known as the Broodhull Clan. For centuries the Broodhulls ruled the mountains of Vilhon Reach. Then, in only a single year, the entire clan of over two hundred dwarves disappeared entirely. Only their empty halls remain, although some claim that the ghosts of the past can still be heard, echoing through what became their tomb.
Fiendfoe

A divine champion of Selune, Ashen Harcall, wielded this warhammer against the fiendish forces of darkness many times. His last mission sent him into the bowels of the Underdark, searching for news of a possible outsider invasion. No word of him has reached the church and they fear him dead.
Mace +6
Mace +7
Mace of Disruption +8

The bane of all undead, the mace of disruption, interferes with the magic animating undead. Sometimes this means that it does increased damage to undead, while other times it destroys the creature entirely. These weapons are often highly sought after by the priests of Lathander, who hunt undead with great zeal. Those who distinguish themselves as undead hunters are occasionally rewarded with one of these powerful maces.
Morningstar +6
Morningstar +7
Drone +8

The deaf master, Vondin Clatch, was a ruthless warrior who learned to use his infirmity to his advantage. The glowing, vibrating morningstar he used would create a magical warping of its immediate area to create a sonic burst that could stun enemies it hit. The piercing sound could also cause damage to those around him; a problem that was not fixed until the master’s apprentice inherited the weapon. Being unable to use the weapon, he paid a wizard to focus the sonics to only damage those who were hit.
Longbow +6
Longbow +7
Composite Longbow +6
Composite Longbow +7
North Wind Bow +8

These bows seem primitive at first glance, but behind the crude sinew and hide is a powerful weapon. They are most often found in the far North, but unfortunately, they are also most often found in the hands of a devotee of Auril, the Icemaiden. Most observers will get a good look at the point of the arrows before ever seeing the bow.
Forever

This elegant bow quivers with magic when touched. Engraved, ancient elven runes tell the tale of the arcane archer Meadow Everleaf and how she found this bow growing in the forests of Cormanthor. She plucked this gentle weapon and carried it with her but could never find any material to string the bow with. One fateful evening trolls attacked her and she soon depleted her arrows. Tossing away her mundane bow she pulled out Forever...and saw a magical bow-string appear. Knocking an imaginary arrow she let loose and slew the trolls. The bow has been kept in her tomb since her death but rumors suggest that drow thieves may have taken it.

Battle Legion Bow

No one remembers much about the mighty battle legions of ancient Unther, but if this bow is a representative of their armament, then it is no wonder the Mulhorandi feared them so. Now that time has passed, and Unther is weak, these bows are rarely found within her borders. Occasionally one turns up in the black markets of Mulhorand, where it will sell for as much as a legion of modern mercenaries.

Sling +7
Bane of the Undead

One of Kelemvor's first gifts to his church was this sling, a mark of favor for priests who showed ability at hunting undead. While these slings are protected and treasured above all earthly treasures, the risk involved in hunting the undead has caused the disappearance of a small number of slings. The church of Kelemvor offers large rewards for the return of these powerful and holy weapons.
Heavy Crossbow +6
Heavy Crossbow +7
Crossbow of the Seer

Taigen Bladekin became a master assassin in Calimshan when she proved to be able to anticipate where her competitors would be and how they would try to kill her. Though great at her job, her social skills were weak, since she never went anywhere without her powerful crossbow. Employers frequently were too nervous to meet with her in person and sent contacts to set up jobs. The contacts would soon grow wary of meeting with the deadly young woman who stroked her crossbow as if it were a loved one, rather than a weapon.
Light Crossbow +6
Light Crossbow +7
Crossbow of Lightning Strike

"Load faster! Aim faster! Fire faster!" These are the words that haunted the dreams of Lord Bishik, whose training in the militia seemed a never-ending nightmare. Putting all of his energies into overcoming his slowness in combat, Bishik finally accepted a magical solution to his problems. The mage who created Bishik's crossbow appeared from nowhere, gave the weapon to Bishik and disappeared into the night. Only the powerful magic of the crossbow was left behind to prove that Bishik hadn't simply dreamed up the wizard.
Double Axe +6
Double Axe +7
Axe for the Tall Kin +8

The warriors of Rashemen have a legend of a giant king called Kirsk, who carried an axe that could split a mountain in twain. This axe was supposedly lost when the king split a mountain that held back the sea and all of the giants were drowned. It is commonly agreed in more civilized lands that the warriors of Rasheman are a very strange lot.
Dire Mace +6
Dire Mace +7
Ironwood Mace +8

Legends of this mace being used to crush a dragon’s skull may have been exaggerated by the bard Duss Dorien. According to his "Song of King Ethos", the king was battling a ferocious black dragon and had lost his spear to the dragon’s thick hide. When the king cried out to Torm, a dire mace appeared in his hands, and Ethos brought it down on the dragon’s head with a very satisfying crunch.
Quarterstaff +6
Quarterstaff +7
Aiedo Wither-Stick +8

From the Lhespenbog reed-fields of east Shaar come Aiedo Wither-Sticks, the craft of Meng Aiedo. Though accustomed to working with tall grass bamboo, this eastern craftsman traveled across the inner plains plying his trade with whatever local materials were available. Swamp products tend to be darker in nature than his usual fare, however.
Fiery Power Quarterstaff

Rumors tell of Baalzebul forging a deal with a wizard of Faerun, which traded minor demons for large numbers of innocent mortal souls. Each demon was captured in the magical wood of rare, ancient fire oak trees. Their spirits give birth to the blazing powers of these weapons. Whether this tale is true or not, the power of these quarterstaffs cannot be denied.
Thornshield

This heavy staff was hand-carved by Winh of the Ivy Lake, an ancient shifter who was truly the master of a thousand shapes. Thousands of thin, barb-like thorns from an exotic vine that grew in Winh's protectorate grow along this wooden staff. The thorns snare and deflect any attacks made against the staff's wielder. Winh died fighting a horde of drow skirmishers who were invading his lands some time ago.
Two-Bladed Sword +6
Two-Bladed Sword +7
Uthgardt Ceremonial Blade +8

When he returned to his tribe, Daelan Red Tiger crafted a weapon that could match his power and skill as a warrior. When he was finished, he lay down beside his forge to rest, but when he awoke, instead of one sword, he found ten. Thanking the gods, he gave each weapon to the mightiest warriors of his tribe. Each of the warriors then set out on a quest to improve themselves and strengthen their tribes. So far, only a few have returned.

This sleek coil of hardened leather slithers in your grasp and reeks of dark magic. The previous owner used it against his own undead minions, healing them through the negative damage the whip delivers.

Axe of the Dwarf Lord

This waraxe was created in ancient times for the dwarven lord Grundy Ironfist. He had trouble leading his troops into battle, they grumbled at his orders and laughed at the way his knees knocked together. Once this waraxe was placed in his hand, his troops saw Grundy in a new light and he went on to be a celebrated hero of his clan.
Harvest Axe

Its name suggests that this waraxe was for peaceful chores. This could not be further from the truth. It is known as the Harvest Axe because it has a penchant for harvesting the heads of its enemies. Some swear that the waraxe itself controls the weilder, and not the other way round.
Spellsmasher

The Battleroarer family maintained an inn alongside the river Delimbiyr, frequented mainly by adventurers. A trio of red robed Thayan wizards blasted the inn and all within it to dust over a disagreement resulting from the Battleroarer's refusal to offer service to the distrustful wizards. Hagan Battleroar, just a young dwarf at the time, was tending to the family's herd of sheep on a nearby hill and saw the massacre. Hagan abandoned his family's peaceful ways and with steadfast perseverance became a dwarven defender. He crafted this weapon to aid him in a vendetta against all users of magic, specifically Thayans. His clan recently began asking for news of Hagan's whereabouts, after he disappeared recently tracking several red wizards near the mouth of the Underdark.
Withering

This ghastly magical staff is the legbone of the evil Khonderous Vilemoth, a wickedly evil Pale Master who lost this limb and his life to a brave but nameless paladin. Vilemoth's pupils took the limb, polished it and enchanted it with the magic of their master.
Halberd +6
Halberd +7
Ravager +8

The guards upon the walls of the evil fortress, Darkhold carry halberds of ancient, demonic creation. The halberds were purchased from the forges of hell in trade for the souls of captured heroes, so each halberd is a valued possession. Those who wield these weapons outside the walls of Darkhold do so at their own peril, for the master of the hold is said to be linked to each one.
Scythe +6
Scythe +7
Sea Reaver +8

Legends tell of how the mighty hero, Igulik, was blessed by a visit from the great water spirit of Lake Ashane. The stories tell of how the warrior was given the holy Sea Reaver to defend his people from an evil wizard, who sought to enslave the tribes of the north using summoned elementals. In the traditional fashion of Rashemi legends, the hero was successful, but died valiantly after killing the treacherous wizard. When he died, the holy weapon was returned to the water spirit, to return when another hero was needed.
Spear +6
Spear +7
Fey Spear +8

During a recent crisis, when the Spirit of the Neverwinter Woods was wounded, several dryads and nymphs worked together to create a weapon, which they hoped would help them protect their home. Before they could find a hero to give this weapon to, the crisis was ended, and the fey folk forgot about their weapon, leaving it lying in the woods.
Kama +6
Kama +7
Imaskari Kama +8

A palpable aura around this item marks it as tainted, perhaps rightly so, for all that is known of the Imaskari civilization points to a depth of depravity unmatched in modern times. Of course, such condemnation has had many years to fester, and while a goodly number of Imaskari may have been involved in necromantic studies, it is likely that their vilification springs from later societies elevating themselves through the slandering of others.
Kukri +6
Kukri +7
Cutting Star +8

These blades are occasionally brought to civilization by adventurers, along with tales of ruined temples and the gods of old. Likely this weapon fell under the domain of a sun- or star-worshipping sect, and while possibly far-reaching in their day, no official record detailing their practices has survived.

Sickle +7
Golden Sickle +8

In recent years, powerful druids have quit their groves and begun searching for the golden sickle. Once considered merely a legend, rumors say that the weapon has reappeared in the realms. Having been hidden by the goddess Chauntea, many centuries ago, no one knows what its return might portend. A prophet of the druids claims that the one to bear the Golden Sickle will restore balance to Faerun.
Bastard Sword +6
Bastard Sword +7
Bloodletter +8

Forged in smoldering brimstone fires and cooled in the blood of its creator, a Bloodletter blade is a typically evil weapon, the kind of sword that has inspired more than a little diabolical laughter while being waved in the face of one or another virtuous knight. It is possessed of thoroughly heinous life-stealing energies, but if the fates of its previous owners are any indication, its major characteristic could well be the attraction of "comeuppance."

Risktaker

Damien Oneknife, an assassin of great skill who traveled the breadth of Faerun to claim his targets, refused only one quest. A man known only as the Dockman, sent him against the legendary Drizzt. Damien knew he was not the equal of the famed drow warrior and declined. The next day Damien received this dagger from the Dockman as a gift with a gentle request to reconsider the offer. His facilities clouded by the dagger, Damien accepted the offer. He died, never even reaching Drizzt himself, but falling instead to the ranger's loyal companions.
Greatsword +6
Greatsword +7
Harbinger Kin +8

The illithid brain known as Kwukgixrin sent its followers to scouring the Underdark for an artifact that it discovered when it absorbed the mind of a powerful human warrior. The warrior had hidden the sword when he realized that he was too wounded to survive another attack from the illithid thralls. Before the illithid thralls could find the sword, the warrior’s twin brother discovered it. The twin was in strong health and he made short work of the thralls and many illithids before leaving the Underdark.
Katana +6
Katana +7
Sword Saint Legacy +8

With death being the ultimate challenge for a great warrior to overcome, powerful and noble warriors have begun to sacrifice their physical bodies, so that their spirits can inhabit an ancestral Katana. The more powerful the warrior was in life, and the more noble his spirit, the more powerful the sword. It is told that the great Master Kendai Kousra inhabits a weapon so powerful that a god claimed it as his weapon of choice.
Radiant Death

This finely crafted katana belonged to the renowned swordsman Viromoto, a weapon master from the East who fought a hundred duels before finally dying. The keen blade shatters through any opponent's defenses, but it is so sharp and light that it is difficult for even a master to wield. Viromoto gradually became distrustful of the weapon and for his final duel he favored a different weapon -- only to fall in battle, his first and only defeat.
Longsword +6
Longsword +7
Aramil's Blade

Aramil the Triumphant was a gladiator famed for his great strength and his brutish lack of grace. Near the end of his career, the fading champion requisitioned the creation of a special sword on the eve of what was to be his final match, even contributing a vial of his own blood so that the weapon's magic would draw upon and amplify his own legendary strength. However, Aramil's scheduled opponent - Unferth the Cunning - convinced the wizard crafting the blade to use the blood to imbue the weapon with *all* of Aramil's traits, including his oafish clumsiness.
An awkward combatant at the best of times, the sword's drawback turned Aramil into a stumbling buffoon and he was easily dispatched by Unferth. The poor performance left an ugly stain on an otherwise glorious career, and Aramil - along with the magical blade that had been his downfall - was quickly forgotten.
Astral Blade +8

On an exploration into the ruins of Northkeep, the bard Leldor claimed to have found and identified this powerful magic longsword; yet he could offer no proof of its existence. According to the fanciful tale he wove, the ghosts of the original defenders came to him whilst he slept and claimed the sword belonged to the Lady of the North. When he asked who this Lady was, a beautiful apparition appeared, and Leldor immediately fell in love and returned her weapon.
Holy Avenger

The dream of every paladin is to claim his own Holy Avenger. These blessed weapons are found only amongst the most elite paladins, whose lives have been fully dedicated to the pursuits of their gods. One famous paladin described his weapon as his best and last friend in every situation. When peace fails, the Holy Avenger becomes the embodiment of the law.
Rapier +6
Rapier +7
Namarra (Neversleep) +8

Feckle Raspude was considered one of the most unusual gnomes of his generation. A swashbuckler with a flair for attracting attention, Feckle drove the young, gnomish ladies wild, with his lopsided grin and impudent behavior. Many a young glory-hunting gnome challenged Feckle to a dual, but the magic of his rapier quickly dispatched his naysayers into gentle slumber. A consummate prankster, Feckle humbled his opponents with practical jokes that were simply unbeatable.
Scimitar +6
Scimitar +7
Desert Wind +8

If rumors of Calimshite ancestry are true, then this scimitar is likely the product of the genies that founded the city long ago. All of the raging heat of the desert seems to be captured within the blade of the sword. Tales of enemies surrendering after merely a scratch only seem untrue until one has tasted the blistering pain the Desert Wind causes a wound.
Short Sword +6
Short Sword +7
Feyduster +8

The twisted mind of Nolls the evil enchanter, created the Fey Duster short sword. His masterwork was made by crushing the bodies of captured pixies to gather the dust that enhances this weapon. While it is widely believed that the dust itself causes some opponents to fall insensate, some druids claim that it is the death screams of the mutilated pixies, overpowering the minds of those struck down.
Shadowsilk

During one of her frequent sojourns into the realm of shadows, Cendra -- a shadowdancer who could slip in and out of the shadows even during the brightest of days -- became ensnared on the webs of a wraith spider. Luckily for her, if being captured in the first place could be considered lucky, she found this shortsword stuck beside her. With a dexterous tug she pulled the blade free and punctured the wraith spider's belly with it. She used the keen blade to shave herself free of the webs. She and the blade were lost when she joined an expedition into the Underdark.

Waterdeep
Waterdeep - Yawning Portal - Makeshift Shelter
Waterdeep - Yawning Portal - Second Floor

Since before the founding of the city of Waterdeep, an infamous dungeon known as Undermountain has existed beneath it. While full of many dangers, Undermountain has never threatened the city... until now.

For reasons unknown, Waterdeep is now suddenly under siege from forces originating within Undermountain. A call has gone out for heroes to deal with this mysterious threat, and it is to this call that you have responded.

Upon your arrival in Waterdeep late in the night, you were ushered to the Yawning Portal, an inn which holds access to Undermountain itself. Here you and other adventurers are to meet with the proprietor, Durnan, to organize yourselves for what is to come.

However, you have a choice to make before you sleep for the night. You have enough experience to become a 15th level character. You may choose to let your package -- chosen when you first created your character -- level you up, or you can level yourself up manually.
Very well. Rest... and when you awake your adventure shall begin...
Very well. Rest... and when you awake your adventure shall begin...
