"I thought... I thought I was capable of handling anything, even the terrors of Undermountain. But it turns out I'm no match for the drow."
"Maybe a hero of your stature can survive in Halaster's dungeon, <FirstName>. But I've learned my lesson. I'm staying right here in the inn. I'm not going anywhere near Undermountain."
Dark days stalk this city. I feel as if someone is walking across my grave.
I wish I could tell the drow about the love of my goddess, but I fear their evil minds would not accept the faith.
May peace find this city soon. So many lives are wasted in war.
So much death in this city, it is a shame I wasn't here to help.
I don't mind the waiting so much, but I look forward to practicing the healing arts when I have the chance.
I long to spread the teachings of my goddess in the Underdark.
"I came here to prove myself in Undermountain, but those drow made short work of me. If not for that priestess I would still be nothing but a corpse."
"Maybe... maybe it's time for me to give up my adventuring ways and settle down. At the very least, I won't be using that well of Durnan's to go into Undermountain."
Don't bother me. No one's getting in to the well room till Durnan says its ok.
"Squawk, squawk."
The raven has been watching a chicken with a bit of a limp. She wishes the stupid beast would hurry up and die.
The raven wonders why any rational creature, would want to live in such a dark and desolate place.
The raven is unsure if the number of corpses to feed on really makes up for the lack of flying room here in Undermountain.
The raven insists that it is fully in keeping with the laws of the universe that a raven can hover in one spot.
The raven hurriedly tells you that something has happened to the sky and it expects you to make the problem go away... now!
The raven is rather confused about a pun involving foul and fowl. It decides that puns must be some kind of foolish earthbound humor.
"Hello raven."
Help, help, a monster, a monster!
I'm scared. Do you think the armies will come again when it gets dark?
I never got to be in the fighting, but I bet I could have killed a bunch of duergar.
If I kill a drow, I'm going to steal his sword and become a powerful warrior.
Can we play a game? I'll be the soldiers and you be the drow. That way I get to win.
Do I have to play in here? I want to go outside.
My dad was wounded in the fighting. Are those monsters coming back?
You look more like a monster than a hero. I'm still glad you're on our side though.
I'm so glad to see a hero here to help. We'll need every weapon we can get when the armies return.
You look like a true hero. I feel safer already.
I wanted to go out and visit a temple, but with the streets closed I guess I'll have to pray right here.
When my home was destroyed, this was the only place I could turn to. Thank the gods for this refuge!
They came in the night and left before morn. How can we stop the darkness?
Durnan has always been a great man; surely he will save us. I hear you are a hero too. You should help him.
They burned down my house. We should invade their caves and burn them all out.
I'm not sure who you are, but I'm trying to get a look at the new hero Durnan summoned. Please excuse me.
You could shatter my heart with a smile. You must truly be a hero.
Like staring too long at the sun's beauty; I am blinded by your handsome features.
With the face of an angel he comes, the hero of our fair city. My chest heaves with a mighty sigh; oh, that he could love me.
The sweetest face in a crowd always belongs to the <race> people. Good to see you, friend.
How many <race> adventurers are there? Well, there can never be enough, I always say.
How heartening to meet another of my race. I am glad to see I am not alone here.
Never trust <race> adventurers! That what my mother always taught me.
Oh look, another <race> adventurer! I always love meeting different races.
Another <race> adventurer? I was really hoping for another of my kind.
Don't wave your weapon in my face. There's enough danger around here without you adding to it.
I know it's hard to know who to trust, but you can probably put your weapon away in the inn.
I hope you're gonna use that weapon to teach those monsters a lesson about invading Waterdeep.
There is a time and place for everything, but this is neither the time nor place for removing your clothes.
I've heard of the heat of battle, but it's not really warm enough to run naked through the streets.
This is no time for games of pleasure. This is war; go put some clothes on.
The monsters are back! Mommy help me!
I could hear the fighting from my bedroom. Mommy hid me in the closet, but it was scary in there.
Are you a hero? I have a friend who's a hero. He's invisible!
I want my mommy! Where did my mommy go?
Mister Durnan will save us. He's letting us stay here.
My doll's name is Snaffy and she isn't afraid of any dark monsters.
My mom says that daddy isn't coming back. Where did he go?
You're a nasty looking <lad/lass>. I hope I never get on your bad side.
I hope you know how to fight. We're going to need all the help we can get.
I have heard great things about you. I hope they were not lies.
I feel trapped in here. I hope they open the streets soon, so that I can go rebuild my home.
Durnan and Mhaere are good people to take us in when we have lost everything. I only hope I can someday repay their kindness.
They must pay for their savage crimes! We should invade and destroy them utterly!
My home was destroyed, my family massacred; who shall stop this dark tide?
You have quite the reputation. I hope you are here to help us.
Life has become so dark and the future, so clouded, that hope seems lost.
We huddle in here, while the streets are patrolled by the guard, but who patrols the dark passages beneath us?
I've heard that Durnan has called for a powerful hero to save the city. Have you seen one?
I would die for a woman like you, if I wasn't such a coward.
The most beautiful flower becomes plain in the company of your stunning looks.
You stole my breath when I saw your fair face. Can such beauty be revealed in the face of a hero?
We <race> folk must stand together. Good to see you, friend.
How many <race> adventurers are there? Well, there can never be enough, I always say.
Glad I am to meet another of my race. We shall stand together against the enemy.
Didn't see too many of you <race> folk until the Lords of Waterdeep announced that big reward!
Hmph, another <race> adventurer. Don't expect me to protect your back.
Don't get that many <race> adventurers these days. I suppose every <man/woman> helps.
Don't wave your weapon in my face. There's enough danger around here without you adding to it.
You are obviously well prepared for battle, but you don't need to wave your weapons at me, good <man/woman>.
You just about hit me with your weapon. Please put it away.
There is a time and place for everything, but this is neither the time nor place for removing your clothes.
I've heard of the heat of battle, but it's not really warm enough to run naked through the streets.
I love the sight of a beautiful naked body; in a brothel, not here.
A dark frown covers this woman's face as she surveys her displays of weapons and armor. As you approach her, she cocks her head to the side and arches an imperious eyebrow.
She pauses and examines your bearing. "Great pardon. Now that Argali looks upon you, she sees that you have more of the look of an adventurer than a common looter."
"How can Argali Silth be of assistance today?"
"Ah, the famed adventurer Durnan spoke of. How can Argali Silth be of assistance today?"
"Argali's Arms will be open to you whenever you return."
"Although Argali's purpose is the making of money, she does make time to assist those who have need of information."
"Yes, Argali doesn't blame you for wanting to know more about her. Argali's father was Typhonus Silth, former Pasha of Calimshan, and a wealthy merchant."

"He taught Argali that thinking one is the best is part of actually becoming one of the best. Typhonus Silth was a great man, but a great man has enemies. It was these enemies who brought Typhonus down.
"Argali lost everything when her father fell - everything but her pride. Though poor, she still knew she was the best, and she vowed to build herself up again."
"Argali left Calimshan and came to Waterdeep. Argali became a merchant, like her father the great Typhonus. She started with nothing but pride, but now Argali is as wealthy as her father ever was."
"Calimshan is full of corruption and greed. Argali was only ten when her father's cousin poisoned him."
"Typhonus held her hand as he died and told her to be strong and calculating; to trust no one, not even kin. The only one Argali can trust is Argali herself."
"Argali learned her lesson well. She is now wealthy, healthy and most importantly alive."
Argali sneers at you before replying. "It was hard, but now Argali has all she was ever striving for. Her father would be proud."
"Now enough of this topic, Argali does not want to speak of it anymore. What can she do for you?"
"Argali has strong guards and powerful defenses, so no raiders get into her shop. But Argali is angered by this war on her city. She wishes to help those who defend her."
"That is why she stays open, even when business is bad."
"Special items? You have been talking to Mother Salinka, haven't you? Argali knows. The old wench always tries to make trouble for Argali by mentioning this to adventurers."
"Argali does have a special item. But Argali hates Mother Salinka; why should she sell the special item to a friend of the Mother?"
<StartCheck>[Failed]</Start> "Argali will not be intimidated! Not even by one as important as you, <FullName>!"
"Her guards are brave and strong and she is friends with Durnan, who hired you. If you would buy something from Argali, then do so now or leave."
<StartCheck>[Successful]</Start> She appears to be slightly shaken, but recovers quickly. "Argali's guards will protect her, but you are very powerful, <FirstName>. Argali doesn't want any trouble."
<StartCheck>[Failed]</Start> "As Argali said, fame is nothing new to her. You are free to look through my inventory and buy whatever you can afford."
"Argali thinks her selection is very good and needs no special additions to make it better."

<StartCheck>[Failed]</Start> "Argali has no secret dealings. Everyone knows Argali's reputation, they will know your lies for what they are. If this is your only business with Argali, then you should leave."

<StartCheck>[Successful]</Start> She looks at you with a calculating eye. "Argali makes no such deals. But Argali thinks you are the kind of <man/woman> who would spread lies about Argali's reputation."
"You like to cause trouble, like that she-dog Mother Salinka. But Durnan says you are important to the city, so Argali will help you anyway."

She considers your proposal for a minute. "Argali's fame is great, but it can always be greater. Yes, Argali will show you her special item, and you will tell all your friends about the greatness of her shop."
"If you have an appreciation for items that are wonderful, yet flawed, you might enjoy this magical cloak I have."
She pulls out a solid black box and opens it just slightly. A glittering, swirling shaft of light comes out of the box.
"It's a Cloak of Bedazzlement. The patterns of light distract your enemies, making it much harder for them to hit you."
"The lights can also be controlled, so that several times a day it can be used to charm your enemies."
"But, most of the time the brilliance of the cloak bothers people and makes it harder for them to like you. Argali understands this all too well."
"That is your choice of course. Argali will still have the cloak, unless she finds another worthy buyer first."
"Argali would part with the cloak for a mere 10000 gold, a pittance compared to what it is worth."
"Then Argali cannot sell it to you at this time. She could not possibly go lower in price."
"Argali hopes you take good care of this cloak. It has special meaning to her, but she no longer needs it and it should be used by one who will appreciate its value."
"Argali is sorry, but she already sold her special item to another. Perhaps once the city reopens, new items will be available."
"Argali Silth is a great merchant. She has generously agreed to keep her shop open and make her arms and armor available for purchase despite all dangers."
"It is a sad day when the streets are closed and the people too scared to flock to buy Argali's magnificent goods. Would you be interested in seeing Argali's goods? They are very high quality."
"Argali has no problem with war in general, but she has a problem with a war that comes to her home and burns it down."
"Argali would much sooner sell her goods to adventurers. Then it is reasonable to assume that her goods will be used to slay monsters and spread her fame."
"Selling to those who would murder children and other innocents does not make for a reputable arms dealer. Argali knows this is not a popular opinion among her peers."
"That is what most who sells arms and armor would do, but Argali is better than most. She does not want fame for her weapons slaying children, though there is not much she can do to stop it."
"Alas, no one, not even Argali Silth, can be positive that the use of her merchandise will be for good."
"Argali knows only that she must try. Argali has been told that some might come who would try to help the city. You are one of those."
"So, famed adventurer, tell Argali what your needs are."
"Argali sells only the best."
"Argali speaks as she does. Who are you to judge her words when she deigns to speak to you?"
"You may count yourself fortunate indeed that you have been graced by her presence and that you shall be blessed with her goods, should you have the coin."
"Should you have need for some of the finest weapons and armor in Faerun, then return and Argali shall satisfy yet another customer."
"Argali recognizes that there are some who do not care for her, but such is the price for being the best. Argali thinks that personal feelings should not interfere with business."
"While Argali does not expect all to think as clearly as she does, she hopes that you are more discerning than so many small-minded folk."
"Argali knows that when you discover a need for her powerful weapons and magical armor, you will return to sing a different tune. Then Argali shall smile."
"Now, how can Argali Silth be of assistance to you today?"
"Argali is who she is and needs to change for no one. If Argali told you to give up the adventurer's life and become a simple farmer, would you do it? Argali thinks not."
"Argali bids you farewell."
"Is that how you greet all your customers?"
"No protections could stop me, if I wanted to rob you."
"I'm not some petty thug. I'm <FullName>."
"Goodbye."
"May I ask you some questions?"
"Tell me about yourself."
"How did your father lose his position?"
"I have other questions."
"Obviously your father was a trusting fool. Good thing you learned better."
"That's a bitter lesson."
"Tell me about the attacks."
"I was told to ask about your special items."
<StartCheck>[Intimidate]</Start> "You seem like a nice person, Argali. I'd hate to see you get hurt."
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> "You can tell others that the great hero <FullName> always shops here."
"Fine. Keep your secrets."
<StartCheck>[Bluff]</Start> "I have heard rumors about some shady deals you've made. If that got out, it could hurt business."
<StartCheck>[Insight]</Start> "How about I tell my adventuring friends how good your store is?"
"Just a cloak? That's it?"
"What is it?"
"I'm not interested."
"How much do you want for it?"
"That's too much. I won't pay it."
"I don't have that much."
"Deal."
"I'm not sure. What do you sell here?"
"I thought a war would be good for your business."
"You should welcome a war. It will boost your profits."
"You make it sound noble, but how do you know they aren't evil?"
"That is a noble philosophy."
"Nothing right now."
"Let me see your inventory."
"Wait a minute - are you talking about yourself in the third person?"
"I think I'll be going."
"Well <FullName> doesn't like stuck up merchants, so <FullName> will go away."
"You're an idiot. I'm leaving now."
"I guess you have a point."
"Okay, have it your way... Argali."
"You certainly are full of yourself."
"I've changed my mind. Goodbye."
"I want to buy that cloak you mentioned before."
"Tell me about that cloak you mentioned before."
The dark skin of the drow blends her into the shadows, but still you can see the twisted hatred clearly upon her face.
She holds up a small dagger that glows with an evil, green aura... and she snarls. "Oloth plynn dos!"
You stand shivering in the chill night air, sweat coursing down your body. You were somehow woken suddenly from your slumber, leaping from your bed to face, what?

The memory of your strange dream still rings clearly in your head, along with an inner alarm that tells you all is not right. Suddenly you notice a drow elf! She appears to be trying to break into the chest with your personal belongings.
"These barricades have been erected to contain the invaders. I'm sorry, but no one may pass until the Lords of Waterdeep give permission."
"If you see one of the enemy, know that there are more about. They travel in groups, and usually have a spellcaster with them."
"Sometimes I can hear the enemy moving through the shadows. We've been told to hold these barricades, otherwise I would attack the villains myself."
"Do not attempt to cross the barricades, citizen. We must contain the invaders, by order of the Lords of Waterdeep."
"Be wary, citizen. There are things moving around out here more dangerous than your typical cutpurse."
"These barricades have been erected to contain the invaders. I'm sorry, but no one may pass until the Lords of Waterdeep give permission."
You open the chest that currently houses your possessions, some of them powerful objects in their own right gained after years of adventuring since leaving your home of Hilltop long ago.

The most powerful of all your possessions, however, is the only one you can never store. The Relic of the Reaper, an artifact that bonded itself to you during a time you spent in the Plane of Shadows, remains in your hand as always.

You know little of the stone beyond its power to transport you through the planes... an ability that allowed you to escape the Plane of Shadow originally and since has allowed you to cheat death on more than one occasion.
You rub the stone absently, feeling the familiar pulsing of its magic beneath your touch, before considering what other equipment you need for the moment.
"You're the one that Master Durnan's waiting for, aren't you? Thank heavens! Now everyone can get started!"
"They say that Master Durnan is waiting for some famous adventurer who arrived last night. I wonder who that is."
The cook swats at a fly that buzzes around a pot of soup. "How am I supposed to work in such conditions?"
The cook waves a wooden spoon in your face. "If you are the one who is filching biscuits, you had better stop!"
The cook samples a dish and then spits on the floor. "This is horrible! There is far too much garlic in here. What are we trying to do, keep away vampires?"
The cook looks at you and throws his hands in the air. "The food is not prepared yet! Go away!"
The cook, a man with a greasy apron and a long, thin mustache growls at his kitchen helpers and moves quickly from one dish to another.
He sees you and yells, "Get out of my kitchen. You're in the way!"
"We're under attack! They must have come up from the Well in the basement!"

The half-orc bristles with muscles and tribal tattoos that mark him as a member of one of the northern tribes, though you notice he is quite clean and comfortable in civilized environs. He regards you with mild annoyance as you approach.
"Indeed. The way the innkeeper has been keeping everyone waiting breathlessly for the ever-famous <FullName>, one would wonder why the rest of us came at all."
"Enough, both of you. This <man/woman> deserves our respect. <He/She> is an adventurer of worth, and the fact that <he/she> is here is a boon to our cause."
"Huh. There ain't no cause that I know about that's gonna pay me a hundred thousand gold like this one will, aye?"
"I agree with Tomi. Gold speaks louder than any cause I've ever heard of."
"That is an odd thing for a bard to say, Sharwyn. Have you no sense of the epic? I wonder if our friend here would agree with you."
"Then why do we not ask <him/her>? What of it, <FirstName>? What has brought you to Waterdeep in its hour of need?"
The half-orc relaxes a bit and nods, pleased. "I am pleased to hear that. The city of Neverwinter was once saved by one who chose to do the right thing, as you say."

He studies you a moment longer before finally sighing. "Please forgive my earlier aggravation. My temper is shorter than usual, it seems, after our long trip. I have heard much of you... Waterdeep is fortunate that you are here."

He studies you a moment longer before finally sighing. "Please forgive my earlier aggravation. My temper is shorter than usual, it seems, after our long trip. You are a fine warrior, I hear, and Waterdeep is fortunate to have you here."
"Your deeds do not require flattery, but I'll not argue the point with you."
"Then I wish you fortune and a strong arm in Undermountain."
"You may not wish to keep the innkeeper, Durnan, waiting much longer. He is most anxious to speak with you."
He shrugs. "If you wish, certainly."
"He is in the next room, I believe. He is looking for you, so he will be difficult to miss."

"It appears that the city is attacked by the forces of Undermountain every few nights. Creatures appear out of nowhere about the city, burning and killing. There has, however, been no concerted invasion."
"The Lords have closed Waterdeep up tight, so as to prevent any attacks from having access to the entire city. This has slowed the city to a stand-still as well, of course."
"Once Waterdeep runs out of supplies, I fear things will quickly become much worse. Of course, should these forces begin a true invasion supplies will be the least of this city's worries."
"I met most of my companions in Neverwinter, after the business with the plague had ended. They have proven stalwart, if somewhat misguided, though it is not really my place to judge them."
"Beware of the halfling, Tomi, for he will pick your pockets without even knowing he is doing so. The lady Sharwyn is little better, I'm afraid, though a brave woman by any measure."
"I am most fond of the elven woman, Linu. She is a woman of faith who has always provided us fair guidance."
"Perhaps I might. For the moment, however, I am committed to these companions and I will not abandon them."
"Fortunately, I have had the opportunity to participate in many noble deeds. Reward or no, coming to Waterdeep may afford me the chance to continue in that vein."
"You have not heard? The Lords of Waterdeep are anxious for this invasion to be halted, naturally. Waterdeep is the most prosperous city of the north... its danger is everyone's."
"The Lords seek information, and should someone actually prove able to halt the attacks a total of one hundred thousand gold has been offered as a reward."
"Anyone could do much with that much gold, even a barbarian such as I. To tell the truth, however, I have come for the challenge of Undermountain, itself."
"I know it is a place of tunnels that reach deep under the earth, created by the mad mage Halaster long ago. More adventurers lie dead in its halls than anywhere else in Faerun."
"How such a place of danger and monsters has lived in peace underneath Faerun's largest city for so long is difficult to say. Perhaps it was only a matter of time before this happened?"
He nods to you, obviously pleased, but says nothing further.
The half-orc avoids your gaze, scowling, but says nothing further.
He scowls ruefully. "And a half-orc barbarian, no less." He shrugs. "You are no doubt correct. I have traveled much in my years away from the tribe."

The assorted group looks at you uncomfortably for a moment. The half-orc stares at you openly before speaking. "It appears that the tales of heroes such as yourself do not always tell the truth. So be it."
The half-orc looks away and snorts with obvious derision, but does not push the topic further.
The half-orc grins suddenly, showing a full set of sharp teeth. "I read a book about you, once. It never said that you were humble."
The half-orc nods at you, looking relieved. "The innkeeper is right to wait for you, then. You are not only a hero, you also have a valiant heart."
The half-orc looks away, sighing with resignation. "A mercenary, then. Looks like there will be less money for you, Tomi."
"Bloody hell."
The muscled barbarian nods to you in quiet acknowledgement.
"Who are you?"
"Durnan called for heroes. I'm here to do the right thing."
"Save the flattery, half-orc."
"I should go."
"Can I ask you some questions?"
"Where do I find Durnan?"
"Do you know anything about what's going on in Waterdeep?"
"Tell me about these friends of yours."
"Why don't you join me, instead?"
"Tell me about yourself."
"What is this reward again?"
"What do you know about Undermountain?"
"Thank you. I appreciate it."
"Just keep your temper in check or I put you in your place."
"You're quite well-spoken for a barbarian."
"If there's a chance to kill something, I'll always take it."
"If it ever becomes your business, I'll let you know."
"To be honest, I don't really know why I'm here."
"I care what happens to Waterdeep, even if you don't."
"I'm always looking for adventure, if the reward is right."
Furiously writing away in a small tome, the small kobold is not aware of your approach. When he glances up and notices you, he smiles broadly.
"You not remembers Deekin? How you say that to Deekin, boss? Deekin remembers the great hero who save Deekin so long ago! Deekin remembers forever!"
"Deekin dead?" The kobold scratches his head, confused. "No, Deekin not be dead. Boss really think Deekin be dead all this time?"
"How can boss say that? Little Deekin be so sad now! Deekin be happy to see boss, after all! It be very long time!"
"Why boss be surprised? Deekin remember boss die once or twice, too, and that not take, either."
The kobold scratches his head, confused. "Who raises Deekin? Deekin's mother raise little Deekin."
"Is boss not happy to sees Deekin?"
"You remembers Deekin! Deekin so happy now! Deekin not sees you for so long since he writes book, Deekin think you not remember him at all."
"You try to forgets Deekin? Everyone always say to Deekin that he not so easy to forget. Not that anybody ever say they actually try."
"Yes, it has been long time, boss. Deekin be real busy for long time traveling and writing book. Deekin be famous bard, now!"

Deekin chuckles and looks away from your gaze, shrugging. "Maybe Deekin not be so famous. Most people who reads book not even know Deekin be kobold, Deekin thinks. But it not be so bad. Deekin still gets to do lots of things he never thinks he gets to do."
"Ooo! You gets book? Deekin so very pleased! Did you reads it, boss? Did you likes it?"
The kobolds shrugs, not meeting your eyes. "It not so bad, Deekin guesses. Deekin travels just like he says he would... but he not gets as far as he thinks he would. Deekin not be big complainer."
The kobold gives you a big, toothy grin. "Deekin happy, too. Deekin travels lots, just like he says he would. Deekin still not believes his eyes that human cities be so big!"
"Deekin finish his great epic story about boss, too, just like Deekin say he would! Did you sees it? Did you likes it?"
"Oohhh," Deekin's eyes go wide and he stares at the ground, crestfallen. "Deekin thought that you like epic story, maybe..."
"Good news be that Deekin work on new book, now. See? Deekin not gots title for it, yet, however."
"Oh." Deekin quietly closes up the mostly-empty tome and puts it away. "That be why Deekin come to Waterdeep, to be great hero like boss was."
He takes out a small lute and begins strumming it experimentally. "Deekin learn to play songs, lately, a little. Maybe Deekin practice here? It keeps people calm, maybe."
Deekin claps his hands together excitedly. "Yay! Deekin think you never ask, boss! This be just like old adventure... but sequel!"
Deekin claps his hands together excitedly. "Yay! Deekin think you never ask, boss! We make great team, you and Deekin, just you waits and sees!"
The kobold looks at your companions closely and then shrugs. "Deekin would be glad to help boss, but... boss got lots of help already. You not needs little Deekin."
"It not good place for nobody, Deekin thinks. Big races gets killed just as fast as small ones. Where it say that kobold not allowed to help?"
The kobold shakes his head, grinning. "Deekin not so silly! Deekin not go in Undermountain by himself, no... Deekin just get killed that way. Deekin great kobold hero, but still just little kobold."
"Deekin come and hope that he find other adventurers, maybe they takes Deekin with them. But," here the kobold sighs sadly, "nobody wants to take little kobold along."
"Deekin know lots. Deekin is bard, after all, and Undermountain be great legend."
"Deekin not only knows things about Undermountain, Deekin know plenty of things about drow and Underdark, too. Old Master Tymofarrar used to speak about it all the time."
"Deekin knows, for instance, that Undermountain was made by human named Halaster waaaay back before city was here. Was just little dungeon back then, maybe, but humans get so carried away."
"Deekin know lots about Undermountain inside, too... before Deekin come to city, Deekin collect tales of adventurers who go inside and come out."
"Deekin just try to be helpful. Otherwise some hero only take Deekin along to carry stuff, maybe, and Deekin still got bad back."
"There be call for heroes, so Deekin come. Deekin be great kobold hero, after all... and it make great plot for second epic story, too! Even better if Boss be in it."
"Ummm... no. It could be, though. Boss come to Waterdeep just like Deekin, because there be call for heroes? Second book be about Waterdeep and heroes like boss and Deekin!"
"Maybe. That why Deekin come to Waterdeep... there be call for heroes and Deekin want to be hero like boss was! It make for good book, Deekin thinking."
"You likes it? Deekin soooo happy!"
"Deekin read that! It not gots kobolds, though, so Deekin think it very boring. Dumb elven lady no substitute for good kobold."

Deekin shrugs. "Deekin and boss be in big flying city at end, remember? There be lots of, ummm, screaming and running... not so much time to take notes, so Deekin tries to remember as much as he can."
Deekin shrugs, sighing. "Lots of epic story gets cut out. Lots of stuff gets change, too, even though it not true. 'More epic', publisher say. Deekin thinks publishers be very strange."
The kobold is strumming a small lute, appearing a bit bored, but suddenly perks up as he realizes you want to talk. He quickly puts away the lute and waves to you excitedly.
He sighs dejectedly. "Okay. Deekin stay here, then, and... maybe work on book, though Deekin not gots much to write about..."
"Am I supposed to know you?"
"Nope, don't remember a thing."
"Aren't you supposed to be dead?"
"Hoping, more like."
"I do seem to recall you writing a book."
"Well, the last time I saw you you were dead."
"Yes, but who raised you?"
"No, I --- never mind."
"Not exactly, no."
"Of course I'm happy to see you!"
"To be honest, I barely remember you."
*groan* "Not you again."
"Deekin? As in that kobold bard from near Hilltop?"
"I've been trying hard to forget."
"Well, it *has* been quite a long time."
"Deekin! I haven't seen you for ages!"
"A famous kobold bard? You're kidding, right?"
"I have a copy of that book, actually."
"So has it been everything you hoped, Deekin?"
"Congratulations, Deekin. I'm happy for you."
"I hated it! What gave you the right to publish anything about me?"
"I couldn't care less about your new book."
"I should go."
"How about we join forces?"
"I don't think this is any place for a kobold."
"So you came here expecting to go into Undermountain? By yourself?"
"What do you know about the situation here, exactly?"
"You know things about Undermountain?"
"That's pretty smart."
"Is that why you're here in Waterdeep?"
"Is that one about me, as well?"
"I'm sure it will be suitably epic."
"It's about my first adventure. What's not to like?"
"It was better than this book I read about the plague in Neverwinter."
"It started off good but got rushed towards the end."
"It was a bit shorter than I expected."
"Forget it. I don't need your help."
"Sure, I could use your help. Join up with me."
"You can join me... but you do what I say, is that clear?"
"How could you be of help, exactly?"
With long dried splatters of blood across his face and an ale in hand, the dwarf looks contented... and very drunk.
"I tell ye true, I've a taste fer blood an' I'm goin' to taste more. Nothin' could hold me back from this here Undermountain."
"Soon as I'm done me drink, I'm goin' huntin! I've got a hankerin' fer some monster brains, served on me axe. How'd ye like a taste of that fare, <lad/lass>?"
"Tall tales? Every word I say is the whole, pure truth! I've half a mind to..." The dwarf trails off and his eyes roll back into his head as he succumbs to the effects of his drinking binge.
"A weak stomach serves a weak mind, <lad/lass>. Now me, I've eaten my way through a dragon's intestines to escape a delicate predicament."
"And I don't mind tellin' ye that a dragon's spleen is the juiciest meal a dwarf could enjoy, particularly while the dragon is still alive."
"And a much more enjoyable experience than havin' to eat me way through me brother's partly digested corpse, I promise ye that."
"I've no interest in yer questions, <lad/lass>, but as me ale is not quite finished, ye've got me undivided attention."
"Now ain't that the sweetest offer me ears have heard in a long time. But I'm not ready to go quite yet."
"I'll tell ye what. I'm goin' to have one more ale, and you can start down there. I'll catch up to ye soon as I finish up here."
The dwarf's eyes roll back in his head and he passes out.
"They please me well, they do! Perfect opportunity for me to show me skills with the axe. If'n I cut enough of them dark dwarves apart, it can only help me reputation."
"Some of me kin think we should try to rescue our cousins from their dark destiny. To my mind, me axe be the rescuer 'n they be saved in death."
"N'er trust a dark dwarf, <lad/lass>! Them would turn on ye fer the sound of a single gold coin. That's all there is to say 'bout that."
"Only that it is supposed to be the largest grave for adventurers in all the lands. T'would have made a fine home, but now... ah, 'tis too much for me."
"Ask me 'bout somethin' else, <lad/lass>. There be no good in lookin' to the past."
"Fine then get out of me way. I've got some more drinkin' to do."
"I should be thinkin' that'd be obvious. He ate me in one big gulp."
"Me and me family was lookin' for a new home, and we heard tell 'bout this huge dungeon, what was under Waterdeep, don't ye know."
"We figured the mage that stocked the place could use a good dwarf or two to keep things goin' so we came lookin' fer Halaster."
"Hold yer tounge, ye mangy cur. I'm almost there. Ye see, we never found the mage, as we was attacked by this big black dragon first."
"Sure, sounded like a right cozy little place to me family. Sadly we never found the mage, as we was set upon by one big black dragon."
"He ate me brother and me pa, though he refused to eat me mother; I suppose she looked right bitter to him and all. He just spit his acid and melted her on the spot."
"Finally he grabbed me and swallowed me whole. Unlike me poor family, I was wearin' proper magical armor that protected me from the dragon's acid."
"Are ye callin' me a liar? Every word of that tale be pure truth. And I don't expect to have much trouble with this here dungeon neither."
"Thank ye, <lad/lass>, but don't go thinkin' I made it up. Every word is pure truth. And I don't suspect we'll be havin' much more trouble with this dungeon here."
"We'll carve that mountain up and massacre our enemies, striking terror into their hearts with maniacal laughter."
"And I'll bet I can beat ye to the bottom, I do! I'll even let ye have a head start."
"Aye. Don't go getting' eaten by no dragons now." The dwarf's eyes roll back in his head and he passes out, succumbing to the effects of his drinking binge.
"Well, don't count on too many kindnesses, but ye seem to have some qualities about yerself worth knowin'."
"Ha! That's the attitude, <lad/lass>. Ye've some spark in ya, and I like that."
"If ye get in some trouble down there and I wander by, I might even consider helpin' ye."
"But fer now, I wish ye the best o' luck. I'm just goin' to have one more ale before I head down."
He slaps your shoulder and laughs, "Aye, I thought ye might. And call me Drezzy, won't ye? Now me, I've eaten my way through a dragon's intestines to escape a delicate predicament."
"I can't waste my time listening to a drunk's tall tales."
"That's disgusting!"
"Some other time, thanks anyways."
"I want to ask you some questions."
"I have no more questions."
"Do you want to join me?"
"What do you think about these attacks?"
"What do you know about Undermountain?"
"I really don't care."
"Start at the beginning. How did you get inside a dragon?"
"Hurry up and get to the dragon part."
"You wanted to live in Undermountain?"
"You really ate your way out of a live dragon?"
"A good tale, friend."
"Goodbye."
"That's mighty kind of you."
"I don't need a head start."
"I'll join you in that feast, friend dwarf."
Durnan studies you appraisingly for a moment before nodding. "Greetings. I trust you are here to aid Waterdeep against its attackers, yes? You wish to journey into Undermountain?"
"If so, then I'm glad. We can use all the help we can get. Is there something I can do for you?"
Durnan turns towards you as you enter the common room. A stern and solid man who is rumored to have once been a great warrior, the relief now on his face is clearly visible.
Durnan nods, his features grim. "Tamsil tells me you dealt with the drow thief swiftly enough. I must apologize to you, <FirstName>."
Durnan's smile is a grim one, belying a deep anger held barely in check. "You are kind to joke about it so, <FirstName>, but I must apologize nevertheless."
Durnan's features harden, a deep anger suddenly evident. "Aye. Tamsil told me what happened. I cannot apologize enough, <FirstName>."
"Once I would have been able to ensure the safety of my guests, but no longer. The damnable drow come and go as they please, it seems. These are dark times for our city."
"The enemies of Waterdeep must have learned you had answered our call for heroes. Given your reputation, it's not surprising that they targeted you."
"Hold on a sec, there. A drow thief came in and stole all your equipment? Ha-ha-ha! If I'd a known ye were such an easy mark I mighta nicked your stuff meself! Ha-ha-ha!"
Durnan silences Tomi's laughter with a cold glare. "This is no joking matter. The drow don't play games; I'm guessing the theft was only the first step in their mission."
"The drow likely figured you'd be more vulnerable without your equipment. A drow assassin would probably have shown up a few seconds later to finish you off in your sleep."
"Fortunately you woke up and thwarted their plan. Others in Waterdeep haven't been so lucky; there are several reports of prominent citizens slain in their beds."
"Waterdeep is under attack, its people live in fear. That's why I made the call you all responded to... we're going to do something about it."
"Yes, Durnan. Tell us what must be done."
"But Undermountain has existed for centuries. Why hasn't there been any trouble before? "

"Undermountain was built hundreds of years ago, but Halaster is an archmage. Time doesn't mean the same to him as it does to us. I'm certain he's still alive... and that he's involved in these attacks."
"Time is of the essence here, <FirstName>, but only a fool would rush into Undermountain unprepared. That's why I called you all here together."
"As many of you know, this inn is built around one of the entrances to Undermountain: a magical well that descends thousands of feet down into the very depths of that ever-changing labyrinth."
"Now, I don't intend to send anyone into Undermountain unprepared. That would be suicide. I'll offer you what advice and equipment I can. In fact, I think it might be a good idea if --"
"Wait! What's that noise, Father?"
"Eh? It's coming from the well room." Durnan listens intently for a moment... before his eyes go wide with the realization of what is about to happen...
"Anyone willing to risk the dangers of Undermountain is welcome. Waterdeep needs all the help it can get. Whether you all work together or alone is up to you, I suppose."
"It is odd that Halaster has aligned himself with the dark elves. He's never been too fond of them. But the drow are attacking through Undermountain, and that means Halaster must be involved."
"It's possible something happened to take Halaster out of the picture, I guess. But I find that hard to believe. He's a wizard of incalculable power; you don't just get rid of someone that powerful."
"The Lords of Waterdeep have their hands full protecting the city. I have experience with Undermountain, so I have been placed in charge of organizing this venture."
"Tomi's willin' to help. Just so long as that 100,000 gold piece reward stays on the table."
"The Lords of Waterdeep have offered 100,000 gold pieces to anyone who can end these attacks. That should be more than enough gold to tempt any <man/woman>, <FirstName>."
"I know that. None of you have agreed to anything. But coming here shows that you're interested in at least listening to my offer."
"That 100,000 gold piece reward the city is offering doesn't hurt interest none, either!"
"Not all of us are here because of the gold, Durnan. Some of us truly want to help. Please, tell us what must be done."
This man is obviously a veteran warrior, and he looks at you with a distracted air. "I'm sorry, <sir/madam>... we can't start until everyone's in the common room."
Looking around, scowling, Durnan's eyes suddenly turn to you and harden. "If I didn't know better, I'd have to wonder which side you're on, <FirstName>. You watch who you hurt, you hear me?"
"I really should thank you for your help, <FirstName>. I doubt me or my kin would have survived that attack, had you not been here."

He sighs, staring towards the large well that forms the inn's famous entrance into Undermountain. "It seems obvious now that whatever protections I had up to prevent this no longer work. Blasted magic."
"Please... go back upstairs and make sure there are no more enemies lurking. Inform Tamsil that she must tell the city guard about the attack at once."
"The Lords will want to know about this. I will stay down here with these other four and secure the well for the moment."
"Thank you. I'll begin checking the well... don't be gone long, <FirstName>. I need you now more than ever."
Durnan scowls deeply. "Of course I suspected this could happen! I sealed the well and posted guards down here, but it wasn't enough, was it?"
"Please, just go and tell Tamsil as I asked. There's nothing for you to do down here until I check the well, anyway."
"Not just yet. It's too dangerous until I check the well and get some more men down here. Don't worry... I'll unseal the well for you soon enough."
Durnan scowls deeply. "Argue with me later, <man/woman>, if you feel you must. Until I check the well and get some more men, there's nothing for you to do down here anyway. So go."
"Is everyone all right? Where is <CUSTOM1001>? Get <CUSTOM1003> down here right away!"
The man is obviously furious, though his rage does not seem directed at you. "Those fools! Damn them! Where is <CUSTOM1001>?"
Durnan wipes the dust off his clothing brusquely, having just recovered from the effects of the beholder's ray. His expression is a clear mix of helpless frustration and rage.
"I don't want you rushing off in a blind rage like those others, <FirstName>. You have to be smart about this: you'll need to be properly prepared before you go into Undermountain."
"You're the only one we can turn to now, <FirstName>. None of the other adventurers here can measure up to you... not even close. You're Waterdeep's last hope."
"I won't lie to you: it won't be easy. But the key is to go in prepared. Talk to White Thesta; she has some items that will help you out. And you'll need all the help you can get."
Durnan scowls. "There's the reward money, of course. But I thought you'd want to get even with whoever was behind that thief in your room. You want to get your equipment back, right?"
"I'm guessing that thief was just the beginning, <FirstName>. It's obvious you're a target... that's the price of being a living legend. They stole your equipment to weaken you, but this isn't over."
"Whoever's behind the attacks knows you're Waterdeep's only real hope. Next time they'll send an assassin. And they'll keep sending them until they finally kill you. Unless *you* stop them."
"The four that chased after the beholder will have to survive as best they can. Maybe you can meet up with them later, but I wouldn't be surprised if all that's left of them are smoking corpses."
"And after the attack on the inn here, I don't know if there's anyone who'd be willing to help you. Well, except for that kobold bard Deekin. He'd probably go with you... if you can stand him."
"That's up to you, of course. Still, it would be a good idea to have someone by your side. Even an annoying little guy like that kobold bard could come in handy."
The innkeeper gives you a strange look, trying to determine if you're serious. "Really? You like him? No accounting for taste, I guess. Maybe he grows on you."
"If I honestly thought it would help, I'd go with you. But my adventuring days are long behind me. Besides, I've a family now."
"Undermountain took what luck I had long ago, and I barely escaped. Going back would be foolish. So now I'm doing my part, and I'm just asking you to do yours. Is that not enough?"
Durnan nods, relieved. "I am glad to hear that. I truly wish I did not have to place all our hopes on your shoulders... but it appears we have little choice."
"The well will lead you down into Undermountain. Once you've talked to White Thesta and stocked up on equipment, I can help you up and down. I suspect you have many questions first, however."

"You'd be smart to stock up on equipment before you go down there, <FirstName>. There's a couple stores out in the city still up and running. Just tell Grayban I said it was okay for you to leave the inn."

"And make sure you speak to White Thesta. Her inventory of healing magic comes in handy in Undermountain. She's even got magic to raise the dead, if you need it. Of course by then it's usually too late."
"I'll be here if you need me. I've got to make sure we get some more guards set up around this well to prevent another attack."
"Just speak to me again when you're ready to enter Undermountain and I'll lower you down the well myself. Good luck, <FirstName>. We're all counting on you, now."
"Of course. What would you like to know?"
"All right. Anything else you'd like to discuss?"
"A temple? No, not one you can get to with the streets blocked off. Go talk to White Thesta if you need healing or any other temple services. I'm sure she can help you out."
"There are creatures of various intelligence that you'll encounter... some smart enough that they might have some idea of what's going on, even if you have to question them at sword-point."
"But the real goal is to find Halaster himself. He's the key to Undermountain, always has been and always will be. Until you find the mad mage we won't really know what we're up against."
"If you do find him be very, very careful. Halaster's legendary power is only matched by his rampant insanity. The mind of a madman and the power of an archmage are a dangerous combination."
"The attacks on Waterdeep? I know more than most, I suppose. What do you want to know?"
Durnan thinks about this for a long moment, his brow furrowed. "I don't know, to tell the truth. Their attack isn't a co-ordinated one. So far it's only been random raiding parties."
"It could be that they're simply sowing chaos and fear for the moment. If so, they're very successful at it. But I think they're building up to something."
"These raiding parties are probably just the advance forces of an enormous army. Thousands and thousands of drow could be marshalling in the depths of Undermountain, preparing for a mass invasion."
"Our only saving grace might be Undermountain itself. It won't be easy to march an entire army through it's narrow, twisting halls. Of course, we won't really know anything until you find Halaster."

"Easier said than done. There are numerous entrances we don't know about and, as you can see, the entrances are more than just holes in the ground. There's powerful magic involved here; Halaster's magic."
"Not to mention that our attackers seem to teleport in and out of Undermountain at will. Halaster never used to allow that to happen. I didn't even know if it was possible."
Durnan scowls deeply. "Once you enter Undermountain, any kind of teleportation doesn't work. That's the way Halaster designed it."
"Even spells that take you to the planes... even the most powerful traveling spells... none of them work. That's the way it's always been."
"Only Halaster's own devices have ever allowed someone to teleport about Undermountain... and even then, never out of it. If that's changed... well, it would be very bad."
"Three weeks, now. The first battles were the worst, as they took the city completely by surprise. The Lords have organized our forces since then."
"There's simply no way for us to strike back, however. You can lose an entire army in Undermountain easily. The same should be said for our opponents, however, so why isn't it?"
"We can only shut down the city for so long before our problems mount. The Lords estimate another two weeks, maybe, before drastic measures will be required."

"Collapsing the mountain. If we can. But that's a last resort: half of Waterdeep would be destroyed along with it. And that's assuming Halaster doesn't have some kind of spell protecting Undermountain."
"No, though it would be fair to say that they're the ones in charge of these raiding parties. They almost always seem to be leading the attacks."
"If they are behind all this, however, how is it that they are able to bring their army through Undermountain unscathed? That is something Halaster has never allowed before. Why now?"
"I suppose I'm as much an authority on that topic as one can be... short of Halaster himself, of course. Ask away and I'll do my best to help you."
"None that would do you any good. The layout of Undermountain... changes every now and again."
"Sometimes the rooms are the same but they aren't where they once were. Sometimes the traps within them have changed completely."
"I imagine it's all part of Halaster's mad scheme to keep intruders out. If you're lucky, the layout won't change while you're within. If not... well... you'll have to make do."
"Well, should you return to the spot that the well ends at, I can certainly haul you back up. It's a long way down, but we've rigged up a system to get adventurers like you in and out."
"Aside from that, getting out of Undermountain can be much harder than getting in. You can't teleport about in there, you understand... or at least you never could before."
"Aye. Any magic that took you from one place to another... even if you traveled via the planes... was completely forbidden by Halaster's magics."
"Only his own devices - magical rings and strange pads that would take you from one part of the dungeon to the other - worked inside that madman's dungeon."
"Well, then, if it works consider yourself lucky. Either its magic is more powerful than Halaster's or the protections are truly gone. Either way, you've got an advantage no one else has ever had."
"Now that's not an easy question to answer. Remember, the designer was completely insane. Even the creatures that take up the many lairs Halaster has provided change almost constantly."
"Some have been brought to Undermountain willingly... some by force. Still others are trapped within, wandering about until they are killed. I suspect Halaster gets some mad enjoyment from this."
"One thing I do know, however... while you can find every creature from the kobold to the dragon in Undermountain, things get more dangerous the deeper you go."
"Ah. Well, now, let's see... Halaster was a powerful mage who lived in this area before Waterdeep was even established. His laboratories and such were inside the mountain here."
"Some people say he grew mad and paranoid as the years passed and burrowed his treasures deeper and deeper into the mountain, placing traps and monsters in the way of intruders."
"By the time the city appeared, the mad wizard ruled over a deadly labyrinth that snakes all the way down to the Underdark itself."
"I expect Undermountain is something you have to see for yourself to truly understand. Anything else you want to know?"
"That's a bit like calling the Underdark a cave with a few monsters in it. Undermountain is as dark, twisted and deadly as its creator."
"Halaster has spent centuries entombed in there, his madness driving him to create a bizarre, ever-changing realm that sane minds can hardly comprehend."
"Elminster called it the largest graveyard of heroes anywhere. That's as good a description as any. Let your guard down in Undermountain for a single second, and you will soon be very dead."
"Aside from the odd incident, no. Halaster was content to leave Waterdeep in peace; the only real danger that Undermountain posed was to those who chose to venture into its depths."
"Obviously things have changed quite drastically. I don't know why the drow and other Underdark creatures are able to pass through Undermountain now, but you have to find out."

"They say if you go down deep enough you'll leave Undermountain entirely and you'll end up in the underground realms of the drow, though I don't know anyone who's ever gone that deep and come out alive."
"We think the raiders are originating in the Underdark and coming up through Undermountain to attack the city. In the past, however, they've been no more safe in Halaster's realm than anyone else."
"So why is it that they can pass through Undermountain now? It's a question that needs answering."
"Hmm. Most of the stores in the district are closed, seeing as there's very little traffic coming through with the curfew."
"Argali's the type who would be stubborn enough to remain open, regardless. You'll find her shop just to the south when you go outside."
"And you could probably convince Sobray to open up for you, as well. He sells wizardly goods across the street."
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> "Eh... you may be broke, but you've all the equipment you need, I'm sure. Any gold I could give you certainly wouldn't be much help with that."
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> "Broke, are you? Well, I suppose some gold to get you some equipment is only reasonable. Here's 500 gold."
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> "You're an experienced adventurer, <FirstName>... I'm sure whatever I could offer you personally is a pittance next to what you already have."
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> "I suppose it's only fair that you get something up front for what we're asking of you. Here you go... 500 gold. That's all I have on hand."
"That should tide you over for the moment, I hope. Is there any other help I can provide, supply-wise?"
"Keeping my inn safe, naturally. Overseeing the guards watching this well, trying to round up more adventurers in the city... though I have my doubts on that point."
"Don't worry, however... I won't go too far. I'll be here to bring you back up the well when you need me to."
Durnan raises a quizzical eyebrow. "A dream? What sort of dream?"
"As you wish. Is there something else you need?"
He listens as you describe the dream and the drow matron, intensely interested. When you finish, he scratches his beard thoughtfully. "Aye... interesting."
"I've never been one to put much stock in prophetic dreams, but I doubt you would be telling me this if you thought it nothing more than your imagination."
"I've seen enough to know that having a powerful ally in your corner is something to be grateful for... usually. If someone sent you that dream, it might be a good idea to find out who."
"Aye, I can only imagine. Still... if someone were to send me beneficial dreams, I can't say that I would ignore it just out of fear."
"At this point, I wouldn't turn away an ally... even an unknown one. In Undermountain, you'll need all the allies you can find."
"No? I can't claim to know much about these things, but it seems to me that if someone powerful were willing to help me I wouldn't write it off so simply."
"Well, the dream did save your life. You could chalk it up to luck, but it sounds to me like someone - or something - is interested in your well being."
"Why not? You're a <man/woman> of religious conviction, aren't you? Divine intervention wouldn't be such a hard thing to believe, would it? At least you know someone's watching out for you."
Durnan nods, relieved, though he still looks at you apprehensively. "I can't help but think I'm making a deal with a devil, here, considering your reputation."
"To rely on you so heavily for Waterdeep's future..." he shrugs, sighing. "But I have no choice. I can only hope for the best and wish you well."
He glares at you with disgust. "Why, thank you, <FirstName>. That's *exactly* what I needed to hear, how I'm responsible for all this."
"An eye tyrant, it's called. A beholder, unleashing more magic out of each of its eyes than any wizard can even dream up. And those fools have chased after it into Undermountain!"
He spits in disgust. "They're likely to get themselves killed, running off like that. I wanted an organized foray into Undermountain, not this mess!"
He considers your words for a moment, nodding. "The drow thief in your room, now this attack. Seems like our enemy has a plan: the others probably ran right into a trap or ambush."
"Okay, you have my permission to enter the well. There is a lever that should lower the shield doors for you. Good luck, <FirstName>."
"You better go speak to White Thesta first, <FullName>. She's got something she wanted to give you. Come back to me after you've talked to her and we'll get you into the well."
"The Valsharess... I'm no expert on the drow, but if I remember right doesn't that mean 'Empress' in their language? She sounds like another Matron Mother with dreams of grandeur."
"Even so, I would have thought someone powerful enough to capture Halaster would have earned a reputation even here on the surface. This Valsharess seemed to rise up out of nowhere."
"Nobody else could have survived Undermountain to bring us this information, <FirstName>. We still need to stop the drow, but I think you deserve a reward for all you've done for us already."
"The full reward of 100,000 gold pieces can only be given out once the threat of the Valsharess is defeated, but this small sum is a token of Waterdeep's appreciation."
"Of course, the city will not truly be safe until the drow are defeated or Undermountain is once again sealed against them. There is no one else I can turn to for help in this, <FirstName>."
"When you're as powerful as you are, everybody wants your help. That's the burden of being a hero. But don't forget: your fate is bound up in all this as well."
"The Valsharess must have been the one who sent that drow thief into your room. She knows about you, she's targeted you. She's not just going to forget about you after all this."
"The Valsharess is using Undermountain to attack the city. The best way to stop her is to take control of Undermountain away from her. And the person who can best do that is Halaster."
Durnan shrugs. "Once again, the mad mage is the key, <FirstName>. Undermountain is his. If you can find him and free him, he'll put things back to the way they were. At least, I hope he will."
"You have a truly noble spirit, <FirstName>. On behalf of the entire city, I thank you."
Durnan's brow furrows as he tries to make sense of this latest information. "I find that hard to believe, <FirstName>. Halaster is one of the most powerful wizards in all of Faerun."
"If he has been captured, that might explain how those dark elves have been able to come up through Undermountain to attack the city. But the drow have never had the power to challenge him before."
"I'm not saying I don't believe you, <FirstName>... but if this information is accurate, it raises more questions than it answers. Questions that can only be answered by finding Halaster himself."
"Who's in charge of these drow? How did they manage to capture Halaster? And why are they attacking Waterdeep? You need to find out more, <FirstName>."
Durnan's face turns into a scowl. "I should have expected something like this. It seems that the tougher times get, the more expensive heroes become."
"Or should I just call you what you really are - a mercenary! People are starving, the city is under assault but all you care about is your gold."
Durnan nods, though he is obviously surprised by your information. "So the mad mage has vanished, has he? But where has he gone? And why?"
"I don't like this, <FirstName>. I've got a bad feeling about this. Halaster may be up to something. This is good to know, but you need to find out more."
"Good. Let me know if you find anything more out. Now, is there anything else you need?"
Durnan sighs and shakes his head. "I had hoped you were doing this because you felt some concern or compassion for Waterdeep and her people. Are you really only in this for the gold?"
"The city is in a desperate state right now; food and supplies are expensive. Any reward I give you will only take away from all those people in the city who are truly in need."
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> "So you're just going to abandon us, then? If that's the kind of <man/woman> you are, then maybe we shouldn't be relying on you to help us in the first place."
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> "Don't abandon us, <FirstName>. Not now. You're the only one strong enough to survive in Undermountain. We need you." Durnan rubs his temples in frustration.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> "You'll learn I'm not one to give in to threats easily, <FullName>. You'd have better luck if you save that anger for the monsters down the well."
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> "You're... you're threatening me? I guess I should have seen this coming. Okay, <FirstName>, there's no need to get upset."

<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> "It's true the Lords of Waterdeep have given me the authorization to spend their gold if I think it will help. But the information you gave me isn't really that useful by itself."

*sigh* "Very well, here's a small reward. But the 100,000 gold pieces will still go to the person who actually ends this threat. Now, is there something else I can do for you?"

"The bed was hard as a rock, and I don't remember requesting the drow."

"I'll be going now."
"I'm ready to go into Undermountain now."
"I'd like some questions answered."

<StartAction>[Tell him about the dream.]</Start>
