The halfling pauses to catch her breath. "Every one of these dishes needs more spice. I am not sure what that cook is thinking."
The halfling looks serious for a moment. "I fear for Waterdeep. It is one of the few cities in Faerun that welcomes halflings."
The halfling giggles. "We call the cook big bottom, but not to his face."
The halfling glares at the cook. "He is a misery to work for."
The halfling assistant flashes you a quick grin behind the cook's back. "When the biscuits are finished we will help you snitch one, if you want."
"We're under attack! They must have come up from the Well in the basement!"
The halfling pauses to catch her breath. "The other assistant keeps adding too many spices to the food."
The halfling looks serious for a moment. "I fear for Waterdeep. It is one of the few cities in Faerun that welcomes halflings."
The halfling sighs. "I wish I could live up to the cook's exacting standards."
The halfling glares at the other halfling. "She does not appreciate the cook's genius!"
The halfling assistant smiles at the cook. "He is an artist with food. I have learned so much from him."
"We're under attack! They must have come up from the Well in the basement!"
"Be careful... there could be an enemy around every corner!"
"Greetings citizen. There are enemies about, so you should probably head back indoors."
He shrugs. "You have been warned. Use caution, citizen."
"<FullName>? I'm sorry, my <lord/lady>. I didn't recognize you. Uh... carry on then, I guess."
"I can take care of myself."
"Don't you recognize me? I'm <FullName>!"
This elven woman has a pleasant aura about her as she nods her head to you respectfully. You notice a silver amulet around her neck, marking her as a cleric of the elven goddess, Sehanine Moonbow.
"The innkeeper has refused to acknowledge the rest of us until <FullName> makes an appearance. I, for one, did not journey so far to render aid only to be ignored."
"There is no need to be unkind, Daelan. This <man/woman> deserves our respect. <He/She> is an adventurer of worth, and the fact that <he/she> is here is a boon to our cause."
"Huh. There ain't no cause that I know about that's gonna pay me a hundred thousand gold like this one will, aye?"
"I agree with Tomi. Gold speaks louder than any cause I've ever heard of."
"That is an odd thing for a bard to say, Sharwyn. Have you no sense of the epic? I wonder if our friend here would agree with you."
"Then why do we not ask <him/her>? What of it, <FirstName>? What has brought you to Waterdeep in its hour of need?"
The half-orc relaxes a bit and nods, pleased. "I am pleased to hear that. The city of Neverwinter was once saved by one who chose to do the right thing, as you say."
The elven cleric regards you for another moment. "I have heard of you, <FirstName>, but I must admit I know little in the way of details. Perhaps we will get a chance to adventure together."
She smiles ruefully. "Ah. Then I imagine you wouldn't want us getting in your way. I quite understand."
The elven cleric regards you for another moment. "I am told you are a <man/woman> of faith, <FirstName>. It will be a pleasure to adventure together and get to know you better."
"Well, perhaps once you speak to Durnan we shall have that chance. I look forward to it, dear."
"Aye. I wish you well."
"I believe Master Durnan is waiting for you in the other room, dear. Good luck!"
"Of course."
"I believe he is in the next room. He should not be hard to locate."
"Not much, no. I am hoping that when Durnan begins he will be able to enlighten all of us as to what exactly is occurring."
"As I understand it, the forces of Waterdeep have been besieged from within for several weeks, now. Creatures from Undermountain have been appearing everywhere and wreaking havoc."
"The city itself has been brought to a stand-still. No-one is allowed to move about freely... the very streets are blockaded. They cannot go on much longer like this."
"They are... not friends, exactly. At first I voyaged with them out of necessity because our goals coincided even if our hearts did not."
"They have proven themselves to be champions of good regardless of their intentions, however, so I have remained with them. It is a satisfactory arrangement."
"That is a... tempting offer, my <Lord/Lady>. But I would be leaving my companions without proper healing, and on short notice. I cannot."
"But thank you anyhow. I still hope that we will be able to assist each other once we are in Undermountain."
"No, thank you, dear. I suspect you and I would have our differences. And besides that, I cannot abandon my companions on such short notice."
"Oh," she blushes slightly. "I am no-one important, my <Lord/Lady>. My name is Linu La'neral, servant to Sehanine Moonbow. Pleased to make your acquaintance."
"My companions are good people, my <Lord/Lady>, despite how they might often talk. Unlike myself, I suspect they have mostly come for the reward."
"Would that the Lords of Waterdeep could merely make a call for champions of honor and stout heart to come to their aid at this dire hour and it would be so."
"But no, of course they must offer coin if they are to attract adventurers. One hundred thousand gold pieces to anyone who can put a stop to the menace."
"I must admit, even I am tempted to think what good could be done with so much gold. I must steel myself only to think about the threat that lies ahead in Undermountain."

"Very little, dear. They say a mad wizard has created a massive dungeon underneath Waterdeep's mountain, filled with evil I cannot even describe. How they have co-existed together until now I have no clue."
"Perhaps not, but that's no reason for us not to get along. I have always enjoyed a healthy debate between believers."
Her smile falters and she looks disappointed. "So it appears."
She nods her head. "I cannot argue with that. If you do require assistance in the dungeon, however, I hope we are in a position to give it."

The assorted group looks at you uncomfortably for a moment. The half-orc stares at you openly before speaking. "It appears that the tales of heroes such as yourself do not always tell the truth. So be it."
The half-orc looks away and snorts with obvious derision, but does not push the topic further.
The half-orc grins suddenly, showing a full set of sharp teeth. "I read a book about you, once. It never said that you were humble."
The half-orc nods at you, looking relieved. "The innkeeper is right to wait for you, then. You are not only a hero, you also have a valiant heart."
The half-orc looks away, sighing with resignation. "A mercenary, then. Looks like there will be less money for you, Tomi."
"Bloody hell."
"Who are you?"
"Durnan called for heroes. I'm here to do the right thing."
"I have my own companions to worry about."
"I'd like that."
"I should go."
"Can I ask you some questions?"
"Where do I find Durnan?"
"Do you know anything about what's going on in Waterdeep?"
"Tell me about these friends of yours."
"Why don't you join me instead?"
"Tell me about yourself."
"What is this reward again?"
"What do you know about Undermountain?"
"I don't think our faiths have much in common."
"You think I want to adventure with you? That's assuming a lot."
"I work better on my own."
"If there's a chance to kill something, I'll always take it."
"If it ever becomes your business, I'll let you know."
"To be honest, I don't really know why I'm here."
"I care what happens to Waterdeep, even if you don't."
"I'm always looking for adventure, if the reward is right."
The woman smiles at you politely and nods. She appears matronly, but has a strength and pride to her bearing that tell of a much different history.
She stares at you coldly. "How dreadful that my husband's call should bring such a wretch to our aid."
"If you wish to be a savage, so be it... so long as you deal death to the enemy and not to the innocents in our tavern."
"Now, please. I have plenty of people here who need looking after. Excuse me."
"So what? You're here to help these poor people... not get so carried away with your bloodlust that you hurt them as much as you do our attackers."
"Are you truly oblivious to your actions or do you simply choose to ignore the fact that you hurt innocents when we were attacked?"
"You could be careful, that's what you could do. Perhaps we should just be thankful that you will be going into Undermountain and away from us."
She stares at you a long moment, finally grudgingly giving you the benefit of the doubt. "Very well. Though you would do well to exercise more caution in the future."
She stares at you for a long moment, finally relenting. "The tales they tell of you say you are a good <man/woman>. I suppose anyone can make a mistake."
She nods slowly. "Very well. Perhaps you can make up for your mistake by helping with healing the injured."
"Tyr's favor to you, my <lord/lady>."
"Any of the rooms upstairs that are vacant are yours to use, my <lord/lady>. Treat this as you would your home, though I am sure it is a poor substitute."
"If you wish, certainly."
"Speak to my husband... he should have some goods to sell you. Beyond that, you might want to consider going outside."
"With the roads blockaded, you will not be able to travel far, but there are shops about. Argali's Arms specializes in armor and weapons... she will surely not close even for all this."
"Very little, my <lord/lady>. I met my husband long after he had made his last venture into that place, and he speaks only rarely of it."
"I should warn you, however... my husband and his companion, Mirt, were as powerful as you when they went there. They escaped only barely and the experience haunts him still."
"I am both mother and wife, but that does not mean I have been always so. Once I was a paladin of Tyr, my <lord/lady>, before I met good Durnan."
"What courage I have may not be the equal of your power and experience... but I will do what I must. I can no more stand by and watch my city fall than my husband can."
"They have been going on for several weeks now. Subterranean creatures of all sorts appearing out of nowhere to assault the guard."
"Some areas have been hit far more worse than here. Had you not been here, however, the attack on the inn would have changed that of course."
"My name is Mhaere, my <lord/lady>. I am Durnan's wife. I... should add my apology to his for the attack in your room. We were not careful enough."
Her back stiffens. "Indeed. Once I could have sensed any evil that crept into our inn, but now it is all around us. Still, it is good you were unharmed."
"My husband is a skilled warrior, and I was once a champion of Tyr. We are not helpless, yet these attacks make us feel so."
"Still... you were unharmed, and we should be thankful for that. Your presence at this dire hour is most welcome."
"Don't aggravate me or I just might."
"So I got carried away during the battle. So what?"
"What do you mean? I didn't do anything."
"I'm good at killing, and that's what's important."
"If people get in my way, there's nothing I can do."
"It wasn't my intention to harm anyone but the enemy, my lady. I apologize."
"I should go."
"Is there somewhere I can rest?"
"Can I ask you some questions?"
"Where can I get some supplies?"
"Do you know anything about Undermountain?"
"Did I see you fighting during the battle here?"
"What do you know about the attacks on Waterdeep?"
"Who are you?"
"Damn right you weren't."
"Don't worry about it... I'm alive."
"There's nothing you could have done."
A pretty, but quiet elf sips wine carefully from her glass before speaking, "With all that is out of balance in this age, let my hospitality welcome and comfort you."
"Times of stress and war do not exempt one from good manners; you might want to keep that in mind in the future."
"Times of stress and war do not exempt one from good manners; hold tight to this lesson and you shall find peace in the midst of conflict."
"Times of stress and war do not exempt one from good manners; a lesson I am glad to see you understand."
"My name is Parley. I am a druid out of Vaasa. And you would be <FullName>, correct?"
"Then so is everyone else in this tavern. Would you try to make me feel like a fool?"
"Good day to you, <sir/madam>."
"I have heard a few tales about you since I came to this part of the world. I used to dream of having tales told about me."
"It was another <class> such as yourself that convinced me to leave my homeland and enter this 'civilized' world."
"But I am sure you have no interest in hearing about my struggles. You must have enough of your own."
"Goodbye, <sir/madam>. May your paths be ever changing."
"I will do my best to give you the truth of things."
"I do not think so. Please do not take this personally, it is just that I had promised an old friend that I would meet him here and we would work together."
"He is late, but I am patient. I will wait for him here, rather than go rushing off into adventure without him. But thank you for your kind and generous offer."
"They frighten me, and I think that should I remain here too long, my path can only lead to death. Perhaps you have the strength that I lack; perhaps not."
"A good question, and one that strikes to the heart of my troubles. I was content to live in my forest and tend to nature, solitary, yet not lonely; until I met Faragati."
"Then I shall shoulder my burden alone."
"That is very kind. It is just such a response that is the source of my problems though. I was content to live in my forest and tend to nature, solitary, yet not lonely; until I met Faragati."
"He was a half-elf from the city who found me meditating by a small brook. I motioned for him to join me, and he sat at my side, simply staring at me."
"I see that patience is not your greatest strength. I will waste no more of your time then."
"You must have thought I had some quest or job for you, but I have only a philosophical quandary, which I am sure would not interest you."
"That is... frightening. I shall try to remember not to look at you too much."
"Once I had finished my meditations, we spoke at length. He told me how he had left the city to see the unfamiliar wonders of the forest, and he raved about the beauty of my world."
"After a time, I asked him about the life he had left behind. I thought he would disparage the city as an ugly, filthy place, but he did not. The city, he said, had its own unique beauty."
"After he left, his words stayed with me. I realized I needed to emerge from my retreat and sample the world and all it had to offer, so I came here. And you know what I have found?"
"Then why did you ask me?"
"As much as I love nature, I love the bustle of the city as well. Everyone leads a life that is as important to him or her as storing nuts is to a squirrel."
"And so I find myself in a quandary. How can I reconcile my life as a druid, to a life in the city?"
"I am not looking for an answer from you. The answer must come from within me. But thank you for your time."
"You must have thought I had some quest or job for you, but I have only a philosophical quandary, which obviously does not interest you."
"Not everything needs an outer reward. sometimes the reward is entirely internal. I am sorry to have wasted your time."
"<FirstName>, it has been a great pleasure talking to you. Please allow me to give you a small gift."
"May your travels make you wiser and your life be rich and full. For the stretch of a day, I gift you the strength of the bull. The balance favor you, <FirstName>."
"Durnan asked for your help. Some of us will stay up here in case they come from outside as well."
"Good friend, may all your tender roots find purchase, that you may grow in greatness."
"Look inside yourself and try to find improvements. Only then will you find contentment."
"I speak to those who show they have manners, not to children who have learned none."
"I heard that Durnan is going to be making an announcement soon. I hope this means I will be able to head down into Undermountain."

This pretty elf looks up at you with sad eyes as you approach. "Are you going on into Undermountain, <FirstName>? If so, I wish you luck. I, however, want nothing more to do with that unnatural place."
"As a druid I know death is part of the natural order, but I'm glad that cleric raised me back to life. I wasn't ready to become part of the natural order quite yet."
She lets out a forlorn sigh. "Perhaps my attitude is a sign that this city is changing me. Once the streets of Waterdeep are open again, I think I will return to the wilderness."
"No thanks. Goodbye."
"What do you mean?"
"Thank you."
"No. You are mistaken."
"Yes, how did you know?"
"Yes, that is I."
"Goodbye."
"I want to ask you some questions."
"Would you like to work with me?"
"What do you think of these attacks?"
"What brought you to Waterdeep?"
"True. I really do not want to know."
"Sometimes it helps to share your troubles with someone else."
"Hurry up and explain your problem."
"I kill things that stare at me."
"That would be strange."
"I don't care."
"You hate it."
"You like it?"
"I have no idea."
"That is it? I listened to all that for no reason?"
"You are welcome, I guess."
The beautiful, red-haired woman regards you with a slight smirk, sizing you up for a long moment before finally speaking.
"Indeed. The way the innkeeper has been keeping everyone waiting breathlessly for the ever-famous <FullName>, one would wonder why the rest of us came at all."
"There is no need to be unkind, Daelan. This <man/woman> deserves our respect. <He/She> is an adventurer of worth, and the fact that <he/she> is here is a boon to our cause."
"Huh. There ain't no cause that I know about that's gonna pay me a hundred thousand gold like this one will, aye?"
"I agree with Tomi. Gold speaks louder than any cause I've ever heard of."
"That is an odd thing for a bard to say, Sharwyn. Have you no sense of the epic? I wonder if our friend here would agree with you."
"Then why do we not ask <him/her>? What of it, <FirstName>? What has brought you to Waterdeep in its hour of need?"
The half-orc relaxes a bit and nods, pleased. "I am pleased to hear that. The city of Neverwinter was once saved by one who chose to do the right thing, as you say."

The human woman regards you for a moment longer, tapping her chin thoughtfully. "I don't know. It might be fun to adventure with the famous <FirstName>. A chance to see the legend in action. What do you say to that, hmm?"

The human woman regards you for a moment longer, tapping her chin thoughtfully. "I hear you're something of a tale-spinner yourself, <FirstName>. Perhaps we could swap a few stories while we're in Undermountain? Could make for a pleasant trip."
The woman chuckles. "An interesting proposal, but in all honesty I should probably stay with my friends here. I don't know what they'd do without me."
"Leaving so soon? Very well. Don't do anything I wouldn't do."
"Well, don't forget that poor Durnan is simply dying to see you."
She grins and shrugs. "Go ahead."
"Oh, I don't know. Somewhere in the other room, I suppose."
"Isn't it obvious? It is a city under siege by the forces of shadow and darkness. Drow elves, spider-men, humanoids of all shapes and sizes... all spill from Undermountain's portals, now."
"It is not constant, of course, but the carnage has been severe. And naturally the very thought of a concerted counter-strike into Undermountain is ludicrous. So enter us."
"I just wish the city streets were not closed off. I have not been to Waterdeep in years, now, and there are a number of old friends I would look up. I suppose it will just have to wait."
"Each one of them has their own story, of course, though they frustratingly keep them mostly to themselves. I'll crack them open one day."
"You talk too much, bard."
"Hmph. It's been interesting adventuring with them, but hardly the kind of epic that'll match the Shadows of Undrentide just yet, right <FirstName>?"
She laughs heartily but doesn't comment.
"A worthy offer, but I haven't given up on this group just yet. We shall have to see."
She laughs and arches an eyebrow. "The book. Written about you. Surely you know of it? Ah, well."
"It'd be interesting to follow your journey, <FirstName>... but I am here with these companions for now. Should my situation change, so will my decision."
"Me? The name is Sharwyn, dear <man/woman>, worker of arcane magics and teller of tales, adventurer and traveler both as well as a hero of Neverwinter, if you care to hear the tale!"
"Oi me, don't even get her bloody started!"
"Oh, well, fine. For those with attention spans shorter than their height, I'll just leave it there. Needless to say, I'm a bard and pleased to be one."
"Undermountain has a legend all its own, and I think this is my chance to not only see it first-hand but earn a reward while doing so."
"A hundred thousand gold to anyone who can stop the dread creatures from attacking the city, of course. And lesser amounts for good information, I suppose, but who would shoot for less?"
"Just think: not only would we be renowned as the saviors of fair Waterdeep, but we would have plumbed the very depths of Undermountain and survived!"
"I know the legend, as would any self-respecting collector of lore. I know that the mad wizard Halaster created the subterranean labyrinth long ago."
"I know that he filled it with creatures and traps enough to challenge even the mightiest hero. I know that few, if any, have returned from it."
"What I do not know, what no-one knows, is why now after all this time the evil spills to the surface. Has mad Halaster lost control? Are we defenseless?"
"One can only imagine the terror of being in a city with such a neighbor, but such is the fate of Waterdeep: City of Heroes! So much the better for us, don't you think?"
The bard grins and laughs merrily. "A-ha! Do you think we will be competing, then? What fun that might be!"
"Oh?" The bard chuckles. "You needn't go mutilating yourself on my account. Be a loner, if that's what you prefer. I should probably stay with my friends here, anyway."
"Ah, a loner type, is it? What a pity. I suppose I should stay with my friends here, anyway." She shrugs, and doesn't seem too concerned.

The assorted group looks at you uncomfortably for a moment. The half-orc stares at you openly before speaking. "It appears that the tales of heroes such as yourself do not always tell the truth. So be it."
The half-orc looks away and snorts with obvious derision, but does not push the topic further.
The half-orc grins suddenly, showing a full set of sharp teeth. "I read a book about you, once. It never said that you were humble."
The half-orc nods at you, looking relieved. "The innkeeper is right to wait for you, then. You are not only a hero, you also have a valiant heart."
The half-orc looks away, sighing with resignation. "A mercenary, then. Looks like there will be less money for you, Tomi."
"Bloody hell."
"Who are you?"
"Durnan called for heroes. I'm here to do the right thing."
"I'd like that."
"I should go."
"Can I ask you some questions?"
"Where do I find Durnan?"
"Do you know anything about what's going on in Waterdeep?"
"Tell me about these friends of yours."
"Don't remind me."
"Why don't you come with me, then?"
"The Shadows of Undrentide?"
"How about you travel with me, instead?"
"Tell me about yourself."
"What is this reward again?"
"What do you know about Undermountain?"
"I have my own companions to worry about."
"I'd sooner cut off my own ears."
"I work better on my own."
"If there's a chance to kill something, I'll always take it."
"If it ever becomes your business, I'll let you know."
"To be honest, I don't really know why I'm here."
"I care what happens to Waterdeep, even if you don't."
"I'm always looking for adventure, if the reward is right."
As you knock on the door, you hear someone grumbling and shuffling around, then a small window slides open and a pair of eyes glare out at you.
<StartCheck>[Successful]</Start> "Oh dear, I certainly never meant to offend you. No need to be getting upset. Please, come right in."
"My goodness. Please, come right in. I'll just unlock the door here... there you go. Come right inside."
<StartCheck>[Intimidate]</Start> "The name is <FirstName> and you had better open that door up before I get angry!"
"I am <FullName>. Perhaps you have heard of me?"
"Pardon me, but my name is <FullName> and I was told you might help me."
A pretty young woman rushes in, a mixture of fear and concern on her face. You vaguely remember her as the daughter of the innkeeper.
"No, I... I don't think so, my <Lord/Lady>. I only entered your room because I heard the commotion from the hall."
"The drow woman... is she...?"
"I don't think she was just a thief, my <Lord/Lady>. She probably took your equipment so you would be defenseless when the drow assassin showed up. That's been the pattern for the other attacks."
"Then you are a lucky <man/woman>, my <Lord/Lady>. Many important people have been attacked in their homes here in Waterdeep. But unlike you, they haven't survived."
"That is fortunate. Several important people in Waterdeep have been killed in their homes while they slept... though this is the first time anyone in our inn has been attacked."
"Not here at the inn, but some of Waterdeep's more prominent citizens have been killed in their homes while they sleep. Someone has been sending assassins to kill them off."
"But... how could this thief even have known that you were here? You only just arrived to the city. I'll have to tell father about this. We take pride in the safety of our guests."
"The thief must have used magic... that's the only way she could have gotten in here undetected. She must have used that same magic to send your equipment back to wherever she came from."
Tamsil frowns. "Father's gathered weapons, armor and other equipment here at the inn to help in the defense of Waterdeep. Anyone working to save the city is welcome to any of it."
"Everything is stored in the armory just across the hall. Just take whatever you need."
"I'm... I'm sorry, my <Lord/Lady>, but there's nothing more I can do. If you want your equipment back, you'll have to find the person who sent the drow thief here in the first place."
"I know the equipment in the armory isn't suitable for a hero like you, <FullName>, but it's the best we've got. Now, please excuse me. I have to go speak with my father."

"I'll tell him what happened here, but it would be best if you didn't mention it to the other guests. We don't want to start a panic in the inn. Father will take steps to see this doesn't happen again."
"Goodbye, my <Lord/Lady>. Once you have what you need from the armory please go downstairs to the main room. My father is waiting there to speak to you."
She wrinkles her nose in distaste, then quickly looks away from you. "I am not that sort of girl, my Lord. And this is not that kind of place."
Her eyes widen, and for a few moments she forgets to blush. "I... I'm sorry, but that wouldn't be appropriate."
She blushes slightly, looking away. "Oh, but I would sooner allow you to get dressed, my <Lord/Lady>. I'm sure my father could answer any questions you have."
"I... of course, my <Lord/Lady>..."
"As you wish, my <Lord/Lady>. What would you like to know?"
"He has been ordered by the Lords of Waterdeep to organize an expedition into Undermountain to try and stop the raids."
"I really... I really should let him be the one to tell you the details. There are a lot of adventurers downstairs waiting to hear what he has to say. You should join them, my <Lord/Lady>."
"Waterdeep has been assaulted for several weeks now by the creatures of Undermountain: dark elves and far worse."
"Nobody seems to know what their plan is, if they have one. The city has been in chaos. Thank the gods you arrived before the city was closed."
"The Lords of Waterdeep finally sealed the city gates and streets this morning. No one is allowed to travel anywhere except for the militia."
"If you hadn't arrived when you did, they probably wouldn't have even let you into the city. Well... maybe *you* they would have, I don't know."
"Only that you are a famed adventurer, my <Lord/Lady>, and perhaps the city's only hope."
She pauses for a moment, unsure of whether or not to continue. "I... I must admit, I was expecting someone a little bit more... err..."
She thinks on your words for a moment and brightens. "You're probably right, my <Lord/Lady>. I'm sorry for being so rude."
She smiles wistfully. "To tell the truth, my <Lord/Lady>, I am a bit envious of your life. My father would never let me face the dangers you do, however."
"No, it's not that! I... I'm sorry, my <Lord/Lady>. Please don't mind me."
"I... suppose so. Maybe. I... I'm sorry if that sounds rude."
"Oh, it... it isn't that. You're just... not what I expected. Not that it matters."
"Oh, no no, you're not unhandsome at all!" She suddenly realizes what she has said and blushes. "I... that is, you're just... not what I, ah, expected..."
"I... maybe." She blushes and looks a bit apologetic. "I suppose it doesn't matter what I think."
"Only that you are a famed adventurer, my <Lord/Lady>. My father says that your fighting skills are unparalleled."
"Only that you are a famed adventurer, my <Lord/Lady>. My father says that you are a powerful servant of nature."
"Only that you are a famed adventurer, my <Lord/Lady>. My father says that you are a powerful servant of your god."
"Only that you are a famed adventurer, my <Lord/Lady>. My father says that you are a master of the magical arts."
"We met ever so briefly last night when you arrived. I am Tamsil, Durnan's daughter. I help my father run the inn, more or less."
"I... I see." The girl looks down at the corpse again, revulsion evident on her face.
"Do I...? Oh no, my <Lord/Lady>, I would never... that is, I only came into your room because I heard the commotion from the hall."
"Is the inn under attack?"
"Nobody steals my stuff and lives!"
"I... think I was warned, actually. Something woke me up."
"I'm not that easy to kill. Trust me."
"There have been other attacks?"
"So that's it? I'm left with nothing?"
"Any idea where I could get some replacement gear?"
"I don't want your second-rate crap! I want my stuff!"
"That will be all, thank you."
"Seeing as you're already in my room and I'm undressed..."
"I could use some help getting dressed..."
"I have a few questions, if you don't mind."
"Very well, off you go."
"Answer my questions, girl."
"Indulge me, please."
"That's enough. You can go."
"I want to know what your father is planning."
"Tell me what's going on in this city."
"What do you mean 'the city was closed'?"
"What do you know about me?"
"Heroes are rarely what you expect. Remember that."
"Human?"
"Heroic?"
"Handsome?"
"Smarter?"
"Do you have a name?"
"Thank you. You can go."
"Thank you. I'll go there right away."
"Dead? Yes, I killed the thief."
"That is a drow thief! She stole my equipment!"
"Do you always barge into your guests' rooms?"
She rolls her eyes. "Uh-huh. If I had a gold piece for every time some adventurer said that to me, I'd be a rich woman."
She laughs lightly. "Is that so? I take it a little thing like a war isn't going to hamper your fun, is that it?"
She grins. "You're not the first one to say that. You adventurers are all alike. The Lords of Waterdeep have offered a hundred thousand gold as a reward... is that enough?"
She looks around. "Well, yes... but not as many as father had hoped for. They've been forced to close down the city to prevent the assaults from spreading."
"That means it's up to everyone here to do something, since no-one else can come into Waterdeep. I hope it's enough."
"At any rate, my father will be starting his speech soon. I wouldn't go too far if I were you."
She gives you an odd look, slightly perplexed. "You mean you haven't heard about all the attacks on Waterdeep?"
"Father says that the creatures have been coming out of Undermountain for weeks now, attacking everywhere in the city. It's been horrible!"
"The Lords of Waterdeep have charged him with organizing adventurers to go into Undermountain and find out why this is happening... and maybe stop it."
"I assume that's why you're here, isn't it? You look like an adventurer to me... we see a lot of them here at the inn."
"My name is Tamsil. My father is Durnan... he runs the Yawning Portal, and he's the one who made the call for adventurers. You are one, aren't you?"
Her eyes widen in surprise. "I... yes, of course. Please forgive me, my <lord/lady>. I didn't mean anything by it, it's just... he's my father..."
She nods and slowly takes several deep breaths. "Thank the gods! I've... I've never been through anything like that ever before in my life."
"We've had the occasional brawl here in the inn, but... but those horrible elves! They would have killed us all if they'd won, wouldn't they?"
"Somebody has to do something! This has to stop!!" She clenches her fists in determination, looking around as if to pick up the nearest weapon.
"Why should we leave it all up to you?! You don't even live here! Father taught me how to fight! I can go with you... I can go into Undermountain just like he did!"
"And why not?! Father taught me how to fight! I can go with you... I can go into Undermountain just like Father did!"
"Don't be foolish, Tamsil! I will not have you getting yourself killed!"
"So what should I do, Mother?! Wait here until we get attacked again?! <FirstName>, please... take me with you!"
Her face lights up. "I can? Oh, thank you! I won't disappoint you, <FirstName>!"
"Absolutely not. <FirstName> will not be able to protect you in Undermountain, Tamsil. You will only slow <him/her> down."
"Then what am I supposed to do? I want to help!"
Tamsil slowly sighs, crestfallen. "I... all right. I can do that. It doesn't sound like very much, however."
"This isn't over. I can feel it in my bones." Mhaere suddenly looks towards the stairs leading to the well room. "Do... do you hear that?"
Her eyes blaze with indignation. "I *can* fight! I won't sit around here! I'm going with you whether you like it or not!"
"Actually, I'm here see the fair maidens..."
"We'll see. It depends on the reward."
"Yes, I am. Are there many others here?"
"What call is that?"
"Your father? Who might you be?"
"Your father isn't the only one in danger here, you know."
"He lives."
"Calm yourself. We were victorious."
"That's what I'm here for."
"Slow down there, girl. Leave this to experienced adventurers."
"And you think you can do something about it?"
"You want to come along? Fine by me."
"I can't spend all my time protecting you. Forget it."
"Your mother is right. Your place is here."
"You can help by going to the city guard and telling them what's happened here."
"You think you can fight? Don't make me laugh."
"There was another attack in the well room. He's fine."
This ancient-looking man appears ready for battle, though his frail body can barely keep itself upright beneath the weight of his armor.
"Am I so old that I am of no use to anyone? I'm one of the few who has entered Undermountain and returned to tell the tale! But now they tell me I am too old to help Waterdeep against these foes."
"Yes, I suppose you have no need to listen to the ramblings of an old man like me. Goodbye."
"Goodbye, and good luck."
His body seems to cave into itself. "When they open the streets again. Then I shall go home and die."
"Now leave me be."
His eyes brighten a little. "You want to hear about Undermountain? Really? I would really love... I mean, I would be honored to help you."
"They say Undermountain is never the same, always changing. But there is one thing about that foul labyrinth that never changes: its creator, Halaster."
"Halaster is a wizard of great and terrible power. Centuries ago he built Undermountain, and he has controlled it ever since. They say he is completely mad."
"But there is a method to his madness. If you understand how the mage's mind works it is possible to enter Undermountain and survive, as I have done."
"Undermountain is forever changing; its very architecture twisted and distorted on Halaster's whim. But the nature of the dungeon always remains the same."
"Undermountain is designed to confuse and disorient you. Traps and tricks lay in wait around every corner. Never allow yourself to grow complacent, always expect the unexpected."
"I think it has something to do with the idea that death is a journey. I could be wrong."
"I would never claim to understand Halaster, not really. I just know the patterns now."
His face flushes red and his shoulders straighten with pride. "That is not the only suggestion I can make."
"Watch out for mirrors. They almost always hide something; sometimes something good, often something very bad."
"And greed is a dangerous, often fatal flaw in Undermountain."
"Then you are exactly the kind of adventurer Halaster loves to kill. He will start off by teasing you with a small treasure."
"Far more so in Undermountain. Halaster counts on adventurers being greedy. He starts by offering a little treasure."
"Often little traps will start with a small treasure, to make you think there must be more."
"Then there will be a little danger, but nothing you cannot handle. If you continue, eventually the big trap will be set off."
"That is where most adventurers die. Of course, surviving the big trap can sometimes mean big rewards. Notice, I said *sometimes*."
"Halaster is unpredictable. Sometimes he rewards courage and bravery, other times your trials will give you nothing. It's as if the wizard is making a mockery of these values."
"Farewell, <lad/lass>. May you choose your path wisely."
His eyes twinkle in a satisfied way. "Thank you, <lad/lass>. It is my duty and my pleasure to assist you."
"Tyr protect you on your journey."
"Well, that is all I can think of for now. Maybe I will remember more later."
He snorts a derisive laugh. "What world are you living in <boy/girl>? Durnan has forbidden me to go down there."
"No, I am too old. I am just fooling myself. It hurts just to swing my sword for a short period of time. I will never be of use again."
"I suppose so. Leave me to my aged thoughts, young hero."
The old paladin looks at you with a bleary, tear-stained face.
"Leave an old man to his reminiscing. No one needs me anymore."
The old paladin smiles proudly at you. "I may be too old to journey down into Undermountain myself, but at least my wisdom has served of some use against this foe!"
"I wish you luck down in Undermountain. Remember what I told you."
"I suppose if anyone can tell you about the dangers of Undermountain it would be me. I am one of the few who has entered her dark halls and emerged to tell the tale."
"Goodbye."
"You are too old. Why not just go home?"
"You could help me by telling me about Undermountain."
"Halaster?"
"Who?"
"I have always been told Undermountain is unpredictable."
"That was stupid. I was hoping for something useful."
"Why would it be that way?"
"That is a useful piece of information, thank you."
"Enough yapping, old man. I've got real business to attend to."
"My greed has served me well so far."
"It usually is anywhere."
"How so?"
"Sometimes there is nothing?"
"Goodbye."
"Goodbye, and thanks for the help."
"Anything else?"
"I noticed."
"What are you talking about?"
"You're not too old. Get down there and fight!"
"Well, I tried. If you think you are too old, then maybe you are."
"I'll remember."
"Actually, can you tell me what you know about Undermountain again?"
The halfling rogue turns and regards you with an upraised brow and a ready smirk. He boldly appraises your purse even though you are standing right there in front of him.
"The innkeeper has refused to acknowledge the rest of us until <FullName> makes an appearance. I, for one, did not journey so far to render aid only to be ignored."
"There is no need to be unkind, Daelan. This <man/woman> deserves our respect. <He/She> is an adventurer of worth, and the fact that <he/she> is here is a boon to our cause."
"Huh. There ain't no cause that I know about that's gonna pay me a hundred thousand gold like this one will, aye?"
"I agree with Tomi. Gold speaks louder than any cause I've ever heard of."
"That is an odd thing for a bard to say, Sharwyn. Have you no sense of the epic? I wonder if our friend here would agree with you."
"Then why do we not ask <him/her>? What of it, <FirstName>? What has brought you to Waterdeep in its hour of need?"
The half-orc relaxes a bit and nods, pleased. "I am pleased to hear that. The city of Neverwinter was once saved by one who chose to do the right thing, as you say."

The halfling steps forward, grinning, and pats you on the back. "Well, now that you're here I'm sure you'll want to adventure with good ol' Tomi, aye? One thing, though... if ye wants me to unlock somethin', don't stand in me way."
The halfling steps forward, grinning, and pats you on the back. "Well, now that you're here I'm sure you'll want to adventure with us, aye? Just ignore the prissy cleric lass. I bloody well do."
"Of course ya do. I'm Tomi Undergallows, after all. We'll see how things play out, o' course, but I'm always willin' to take on a hench<man/woman>."
"Oh, sure, aye."
"Aye, all right. You'd better get into the other room, anyway... that fella who runs the inn is waiting for ya."
"If ya like."
"He's in the other room, I reckon. If ya hears someone really loud, that's gotta be him."
"Nah, not so much. There's all sorts of beasties attacking the city, I hear, but nobody knows why. Probably just because they're beasties... don't know why they needs a reason."
"Guess it's gotten so bad that they've gone an' shut down the city. Ya aren't allowed on the bloody streets no more, lest the militia cut ya down where ya stand."
"I wouldn't go outside, if I were you. I did, an' even Sneaky Pete himself couldn't have gotten very far out there. Them guards got their eyes peeled but good."
"Oh, they're not so bad. Just some folks I found up in Neverwinter that all wanted to come, they did. For the reward, no doubt."
"Can't says as I knows them all very well. If you wants to know so much, then why doesn't ya ask them about it?"
"Ya know... that's right tempting, that is. Let's just see what that Durnan fella has ta say first before we make any decisions like that, aye?"

"You haven't heard o' me? Well, that's mighty strange. Name's Tomi Undergallows, rogue of renown and a bit of a bloody rapscallion if I do say so myself. I'm here for the reward, jus' like everyone is, aye?"
"Well, the city's being attacked time an' again by critters from Undermountain. Unpleasant mess, that is. They're offering a heap of gold if anyone can find out what's up."
"An' if someone can actually *stop* the attacks, it's somethin' like a hundred thousand gold they're offerin'. Who couldn't use that, aye?"
"You'd figure with that kind o' coin, every self-styled hero from here to Rashamen would've come runnin'. Guess they're all jus' afraid of Undermountain. More for Tomi, I says."
"Oh, I dunno. Not much. How bad could it be for a stout hero like me? An' you, of course. Miles of dungeons beneath the city... it's all old hat, really."
He laughs boisterously. "Yeah, they're a bit of a pain in the arse, ain't they? But they needs ya, right? So ya hang around. I know where you're comin' from."
"Ya know, that's always been Tomi's policy. The coat-tails, I says, are only for pretty lasses and tiny but determined doggies."
He chuckles briefly. "Oh, aye? Fair enough, that is. Just thought that ye might want some help, it bein' bloody Undermountain an' all."

The assorted group looks at you uncomfortably for a moment. The half-orc stares at you openly before speaking. "It appears that the tales of heroes such as yourself do not always tell the truth. So be it."
The half-orc looks away and snorts with obvious derision, but does not push the topic further.
The half-orc grins suddenly, showing a full set of sharp teeth. "I read a book about you, once. It never said that you were humble."
The half-orc nods at you, looking relieved. "The innkeeper is right to wait for you, then. You are not only a hero, you also have a valiant heart."
The half-orc looks away, sighing with resignation. "A mercenary, then. Looks like there will be less money for you, Tomi."
"Bloody hell."
"Who are you?"
"Durnan called for heroes. I'm here to do the right thing."
"I'd like that."
"I should go."
"Can I ask you some questions?"
"Where do I find Durnan?"
"Do you know anything about what's going on in Waterdeep?"
"Tell me about these friends of yours."
"Why don't you travel with me, instead?"
"Tell me about yourself."
"What is this reward again?"
"What do you know about Undermountain?"
"I have my own companions to worry about."
"Get lost. I don't need any hangers-on."
"I work better on my own."
"If there's a chance to kill something, I'll always take it."
"If it ever becomes your business, I'll let you know."
"To be honest, I don't really know why I'm here."
"I care what happens to Waterdeep, even if you don't."
"I'm always looking for adventure, if the reward is right."
Although this man looks human, faint traces of elven features reveal a mixed heritage. He appears to be meditating, but as you approach, his eyes open and he smiles in greeting.
"Good morning to you, friend. I am glad to see you up and about this morning. I believe today you and the other heroes here shall finally hear what good Durnan has planned for you all."
"Hopefully he can shed some light on the recent assassinations and the denizens of the dark that are appearing to make war on this fair city."
"May your journey expand your mind and fill your life with wonders."
"I thank you for the offer, but I am afraid not. My main role here is observation, rather than interaction. I will learn what I can from studying the enemy, not fighting him."
"I do not expect you, or any of the others to understand the beliefs of my order, but we do not involve ourselves in wars. We observe and record, that is all."
"So long as your questions do not infringe upon the strict laws of my order, I shall do my best to answer them."
"Is there anything else you would like?"
"Durnan is the innkeep and by all accounts a good man. He has shown his loyalty to Waterdeep through the years, and is well respected by her most prominent citizens."
"Because the Yawning Portal, this inn, has access to the dungeon called Undermountain, Durnan is organizing some sort of expedition. That is really all I can tell you."
"Durnan is waiting downstairs and should be making his announcement any time. I am eager to learn what he has to say so that I may add it to my notes."
"I have heard that several key citizens of Waterdeep have been found dead, with evidence that drow were involved."
"How they have entered each house is a mystery, as most were locked and well guarded. Hopefully whatever Durnan has to say will clear things up."
"My name is Cyphus, a monk of the Guarded Mind Order. I have traveled here in hopes of finding new insights into the creatures of the dark who now ravage this city."
"Very little has been written on the Underdark, and little of what has been written is verifiable. My order is interested in learning the truth of such things."
"And, if what I have heard from others here is true, you are a famed adventurer. Perhaps I shall have to put some thought into documenting your presence in this war."
"You have the bearing of one who shapes events and history. If that proves to be the case, I will have little choice but to chronicle your participation in events here."
"That knowledge is not something members of our order share. Strict rules are in place to keep our order safe."
"Simply know that I am an observer, nothing more. I wish you luck in whatever lies ahead, but I will not be a part of it."
"Hello once again. Is there something else you need of me? If not you really should go down. I believe Durnan and the others are waiting for you."
"I'm surprised to see you here, <FirstName>. With all the excitement going on, I didn't think you would have time for the likes of a simple chronicler of history like me."
"Never fear. Each and every event, including the rather unexpected attack on this inn, is being properly recorded. And I will be sure to make special mention of your actions here."
"Now forgive me, but I must return to my notes. So much has happened, I can't waste any more time. I must write it all down while it is still fresh in my memory."
"Goodbye."
"Would you like to work with me?"
"Let me ask you some questions."
"That is all my questions."
"Who is Durnan?"
"You mentioned assassinations."
"Who are you and why are you here?"
"Who are you?"
"You want to write about me?"
"Who are your masters?"
"Woof, woof!"
The dog wishes it could be your companion; running by your side as you go off into battle, and tearing out the throats of your foes. It always dreamed of becoming a dog-of-war.
The dog tells you it was talking to a rat the other day that swore it knew a secret room filled with treasure. The dog warns you to never trust a rat.
The dogs sniffs the air, then tells you that it isn't terribly fond of the smell down here. It wonders how long it has been since the floor was given a good scrubbing.
The dog wonders whatever happened to the bright, sunny place where he used to live. He gloomily concludes that it was probably destroyed when the sky fell, just like the chicken warned him.
The dog tells you that it is getting rather tired of chasing chickens and wonders why there aren't any cats around here.
The dog cannot seem to remember how it got down into this dismal dungeon. It wonders how it will ever manage to make its way home.
"Hello dog."
"They will rue the day they attacked us and forced our brothels to close, those evil fiends!"
"I am... very... tired..." <StartAction>[Yawn.]</Start>
"Why close a perfectly good brothel during a war? It seems to me that a little encouragement is what our soldiers need!"
"There will be more killings soon; mark my words! This war is far from over."
"I should go home, but I am afraid to. What if more of those dark creatures are hiding in there?"
"I miss Lacey. She left the city after the first attack. She was such a pretty woman."
They slew everyone they could reach. I even heard that they killed one of the secret Lords of Waterdeep.
We will fight for our beloved city until the last of us falls. We will never surrender!
That's it; I'm moving to Amn! The drow and duergar can have this blasted city!
We must keep the armies up here to protect us.
We must send the armies down to kill them.
Death came with the night and left with the dawn. I'm afraid it shall return tonight to end us all.
What are the Lords of Waterdeep doing to help us? Why are they holed up in the castle? Are they going to leave us down here to die?
My dog tore the throat out of two of them, but they just kept on coming. I barely escaped with my life!
My son! They took my son! Why would they take such a young innocent?
They came out of the sewers and destroyed my home. Will they come back tonight and finish us off?
"Cluck, cluck, cluck!"
The chicken wishes it could be your companion; riding on your shoulder as you go off into battle, and pecking out the eyes of your foes. It always dreamed of becoming a chicken-of-war.
The chicken eyes you warily, wondering if your appetite was sated by the fairies. No amount of discussion on your part can convince the chicken that you didn't eat the fairy corpses.
The chicken eyes you warily, then decides you are a little large for a meal.
The chicken wonders who will feed it, now that the fairies are all gone.
The chicken is rather unimpressed with Undermountain, having expected something a little less... dark.
The chicken patiently explains to you how it tried to eat one of the fairies, thinking it was a bug. It was quite distraught when the fairy gave it a swift kick in the head.
"Hello chicken."
Don't you know better than to interrupt an angry mob?
The Empty Keg Tavern is closed because of the troubles in Waterdeep.
"We'll just wait here until those reinforcements arrive."
*huff... puff* "My <Lord/Lady>. There is a small band of the enemy just around the corner. They drove us back."
"We can't handle them by ourselves. We need reinforcements."
"No, no. Of course not. Uh... we'll just stay here and wait for reinforcements."
"Suit yourself. We'll... we'll just wait here for the reinforcements to arrive."
"I hope you don't expect me to help you."
"I don't need reinforcements. I'm going on ahead."
"We'll, uh... we'll stay here and make sure nothing sneaks up on you from behind."
"Thanks for your help. I sure hope someone can figure out how to stop these invasions. The city is going to run out of guards... well, someday."
The River Gate has been sealed due to the recent attacks.
This shop is closed due to the fighting. It will probably be open later.
"Be careful out here... there could be an enemy around every corner."
A nervous guard comes running up to you. "How fares everyone inside?"
"I know, Tamsil warned us. There have been attacks all over this side of the city. Although we have been resisting them, there are still many of the enemy about."
"All roads leading out of this district are sealed and most businesses hereabouts are closed. You might be better off staying inside until we can clear the streets, my <lord/lady>."
Okay... but don't say I didn't warn you.
"<FullName>? Oh... I'm sorry. Well, I guess you can handle yourself out here, then."
"We were attacked by creatures from the Underdark."
"I can take care of myself."
"Don't you recognize me? I'm <FullName>!"
"You can't use that right now. You must wait for the gears to realign. The light will turn green when it is ready again."
"Be careful with that. It can be a little disorienting."
"Sounds dangerous." <StartAction>[Put the telescope down.]</Start>
<StartAction>[Look into the telescope.]</Start>
"Back again?"
The dwarf stops her hammering and wipes the sweat from her brow, "I really must get back to work...the Guard needs weapons and armor with which to fight our enemies."
"As do I," the dwarf says as she begins work again.
"I don't have time to answer a bunch of questions! Can't you see how busy I am?"
She looks at you oddly. "I'm the blacksmith. I don't pound this anvil all day just to look pretty."
"I make the things and Argali sells them. Of course now, most of my sweat is going towards helping our fighting forces keep the city free."
"Ha! By the looks of you, there are more important matters on your mind. Still, if you're serious I could give you a few pointers to help you along."
"I'd be willing to sell some of my crafting material too, if you're interested. So, what do you want to know?"
"That's the simple stuff!"

"I sell a few dye kits that you could try out to color your armor differently. You can also use your craft weapon or craft armor skills to reconfigure your equipment entirely, though it will cost you some gold."
She shakes her head. "That's for wizards and such. I don't care for those things. They can make potions and scrolls and wands, even, but I don't know anything about it."
"Leather armor is about the easiest of things to make. Just take some hide and craft it into a leather armor torso and then stitch some woolen cloth pads to it.
"Metal armor takes a wee bit more work, you have to find yourself some steel and form it into a chest piece that can then be worked with other material to make your armor."
"To make a sword or some such you just need to forge a steel blade and then attach it to an iron hilt. Smaller weapons can be attached to wooden hilts."
"Bows require bow strings, which are easy to make from leather hides. Attach the string to a wooden bow shaft and you will have yourself a fine weapon."

"You need a keen eye. You'd be surprised as what you can use to make into something else. Make sure you've practiced your crafting skill a bit though -- if you're no good at making things, you won't know what to look for."
"Take a door. A wooden one can be smashed about and made into arrows or weapon hilts. A metal door can be melted down and reshaped, into shields or blades."
"Chests and other furniture make great scrap wood. As well, many creatures can be skinned for their hide. The hide can then be reworked into bow strings or armor."
"Take a look, then."
"Yes... the brave men and women of Waterdeep who defend us from threats above, beyond, and below."
"You'll find them patrolling the streets outside."
"I'd like to buy some crafting material."
"I have to go."
"Can I ask you some questions?"
...more questions...
"What are you doing?"
"Could you teach me to make weapons and armor?"
"I want to ask you something else."
"I just want to change the way my equipment looks."
"Do you know how to make magical items?"
"How do I create armor?"
"How do I make a weapon?"
"How do I find materials to make into weapons or armor?"
"I want to buy some crafting material."
"The Guard?"
"Just don't touch anything yer not supposed to and we'll get along fine."
I could hear the fighting from my bedroom. Mommy hid me in the closet, but it was scary in there.
The boys won't let me play war with them.
I want my mommy! Where did my mommy go?
Mister Blackstaff will save us. He's the protector of Waterdeep.
My doll's name is Snaffy and she isn't afraid of any dark monsters.
My mom says that daddy isn't coming back. Where did he go?
This display has a number of magical items for viewing.
<StartCheck>[Failed]</Start>
"Hey you! Don't touch that!"
<StartCheck>[Successful]</Start> You slip an item out. The guard glances over at you, but doesn't seem to notice anything.
You decide to move along, before he gets suspicious.
The guard eyes you suspiciously. You had better try your luck somewhere else.
Leave it alone.
<StartCheck>[Pick Pocket]</Start>
I'm scared. Do you think the armies will come again when it gets dark?
I never got to be in the fighting, but I bet I could have killed a bunch of duergar.
I'm searching for corpses to loot. My dad says we can get lots of gold for magical weapons.
I want to be the soldiers and you be the drow. That way I get to win.
I'm not supposed to be playing out here, but it's boring inside.
My dad was wounded in the fighting. Are those monsters coming back?
A dark, overpowering voice erupts from the mouth of this foul monster.
"Touch not the items of Sobrey the Sage, lest thy life, nae, thy very soul be imperiled."
"I sure am tired of all these bloody interruptions."
"How can I concentrate on my cooking with all of that infernal noise outside."
"What to make for dessert tonight, hmmmm..."
"I knew I should have written down that recipe for Huevos Underrancheros."
"Was that one pinch of Utrech's powder or two..."
"I don't understand why my souffle won't rise!"
"Get out of my kitchen!"
The half-orc's eyes snap open wide. His head darts from side to side, seeking an enemy that isn't there. Only then does his face focus on your own, standing above him.
He narrows his eyes, trying to decide if you are friend or foe. "Ask your questions," he answers at last. "I will do my best to answer them."
The half-orc looks at you more closely. "Right. You're <FullName>, the hero that Durnan was waiting for. I'm Daelan Red Tiger, a warrior originally from the northern Uthgardt tribes."
The half-orc tilts his head to the side, searching through the shadows of his memory. "Yes. That's right. <FullName>. The one Durnan was waiting for."
"It's starting to come back to me now... there was a fight in the tavern. A beholder. We chased it down here, and I became separated from the others. I remember... dying."
"You raised me, didn't you? For that, you have my thanks."
"I will return to Durnan's inn, for now. I shouldn't have any trouble finding my way back. Maybe I can be of more use there than I was down here."
"Once again, you have my thanks for returning me to life. I was not ready to leave this world yet. Goodbye, and good luck."
"Are you sure that's a good idea? Most of my equipment is gone, and I haven't had much luck here in Undermountain so far."
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> The half-orc grins. "The truth is, I wasn't ready to end my adventures here in Undermountain quite yet. I would be honored to join up with you, <FirstName>."
"I do owe you for saving my life. I suppose joining with you now would be a way to start repaying it."
He looks at your companions. "It seems you have more than enough help already, <FirstName>. Perhaps it would be best if I were to return to the inn for now."
The half-orc's thick brow furls in concentration as he considers his options. "I've learned it's too dangerous for me to survive down here alone. I will probably go back to the inn, I suppose."
"You raised me from the dead only to kill me again? This... this makes no sense. What was the point?"
He gives you a sideways glance, trying to see if this is some type of trick. "You are a very strange <man/woman>."
"Well, I won't just roll over and die for you!"
He shakes his head, perplexed. "I am grateful for what you have done, but if you are expecting a reward what could I possibly give you? I don't have anything of value on me."
"I did notice something strange while I was wandering around. Strange even for this place. The creatures in Undermountain seem to be at war with each other."

"I'd always heard that Halaster's magic forced the creatures in Undermountain to co-exist peacefully. But either the rumors were wrong or something's changed, because I've run across a number of battles already."

"Luckily, the creatures involved seem more intent on killing each other than me. I can't be sure, but it almost seems like there's two distinct factions in the conflict, each determined to destroy the other."
"Other than that, there's not much I can tell you."
"I know they are not what they appear. Foul magic is at work here. My own... my own death was because of them."
"No. I was hoping to come across them as I wandered the dungeon, but luck was not with me. I suspect they may have gone deeper into Undermountain. I hope they fared better than I did."
"We chased the beholder into this dungeon, but we were being led into an ambush. Just when we thought we had caught our foe, a volley of arrows burst from the darkness."
"Everything happened so fast, there wasn't time to think. Our unseen attackers fled. Enraged, I threw myself into the darkness to chase after them."

"I never did catch the cowards who ambushed us, and when I finally gave up the chase I realized that I had become separated from the rest of the group. Since then I have been wandering these passages alone."
"I was careless. While searching for a way out, I stumbled onto this room of mirrors. I saw my own reflection, but I also thought I saw the reflection of glittering treasure at my feet."
"Intrigued, I approached one of the mirrors. One of the middle two on the east wall, if I remember right. To my horror, my own reflection stepped out from the mirror and attacked me!"

"I was caught off guard and instantly put on the defensive. My vile twin was able to match and counter my every move. From the condition you found me in, it's obvious what the ultimate result of the fight was."
"I don't know where that false imposter is now, however. Maybe in killing me, he also destroyed himself. Or maybe the spell simply faded in the time I have been lying here. I really couldn't say."
The half-orc glares at you, his eyes flashing with rage. "Undermountain may have defeated me, but that doesn't mean I have to sit here and listen to your insults!"
"I do not take insults lightly, but you have saved my life, so I will forgive you for your harsh words. Now, is there something else?"
"You saved my life... that is the only reason I don't meet your insults with my blade. I don't think there is any reason for us to speak again: I have nothing to say to the likes of you."
"Time to wake up, big fella. How you feeling? Any memories coming back yet?"
"Daelan, it's me - Linu. Do you know where you are?"
"Daelan, it's me - Sharwyn. Do you know where you are?"
"Yes... I know you. It's all coming back. The battle at Durnan's inn...I remember."
Daelan notices your approach and his stern features slip enough to reveal the hint of a smile. He seems to be fully recovered from the state you found him in back in the dungeon.
He nods, satisfied at your answer. "Your news will bring some comfort to the people here. I think my presence here comforts them, but we all know the true hope of ending this threat lies with you."

He seems to consider your offer for a long time before answering. "You saved my life, <FirstName>. I will gladly serve at your side, though I know this small gesture can never fully repay the debt I owe you."
He seems to consider your offer for a long time before answering. "I would, <FirstName>, but it seems you have plenty of help already. Besides, my place is here now."
"These people here need me more than you do, <FirstName>. I'm honored by your offer, but I'm certain you and your other companions will be fine without my help."
The half-orc eyes you warily, tensing at your approach. It is obvious he is not pleased to see you.
The half-orc snarls at the insult, but says nothing as he turns away from you.
The once proud barbarian bares his teeth at you as he turns away, shamed by your words and his own failure.
"You may have saved my life, but that does not mean I will allow you to treat me with disrespect. Just leave me alone, <FirstName>. We have nothing to say to each other."
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> He grunts out a harsh laugh. "You have treated me with nothing but dishonor and disrespect. A few words are not enough to atone for what you have done."
"I do not accept your apology, <FirstName>. So leave me alone and return to your more important business: saving Waterdeep."

<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> He studies you carefully, trying to judge the sincerity of your words. "Holding a grudge against you would be foolish. You saved my life, and I am forever in your debt. Apology accepted."
"May fortune smile on you, <FirstName>. The very survival of Waterdeep may depend on it."
"Quiet. I'm the one who asks the questions here!"
"You were dead. I just raised you. Can you remember anything?"
"I'm <FirstName>. I saw you in the tavern with Durnan."
"You don't remember me? I spoke to your group at the tavern."
"You don't remember me? We spoke at the tavern."
"I'll be going now."
"How about you join me?"
"That's a good point. I guess I don't need you."
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> "I could still use your help, regardless."
"I raise you from the dead and now you won't even join up with me?"
"What are you going to do now?"
"That's probably for the best."
"I'm bored with you. I think I'll just kill you now."
"Sorry. Bad joke. Go on - you're free to go."
"I just want the satisfaction of killing you myself." <StartAction>[Kill him.]</Start>
"This is all the thanks I get for bringing you back to life?"
"I guess you're right. I don't need a reward."
"Fine. I feel the need to kill you again, I think."
"Why don't you come with me, instead?"
"Is there anything you can tell me about this area?"
"At war? What do you mean?"
"Do you know anything about all these mirrors?"
"That's not really surprising."
"Do you know where your companions are?"
"Tell me what happened to you, exactly."
"How did you get killed?"
"If I knew how pathetic you were, I wouldn't have bothered raising you."
"I'm sorry. I didn't mean that."
"I don't have time for you, half-breed. Scurry back to the inn before you get killed again."
"As well as can be expected."
"I could use some help. Maybe you could join up with me?"
"Save it. I can't waste my time talking to half-breeds."
"Something you couldn't do."
"Do you have a problem with me?"
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> "I just wanted to apologize for the way I acted before."
"I should go."
The dog sniffs at you and, realizing you are not one of the attackers, pants in a friendly way.
The dog wishes you well in your fight against the invaders.
The dog tells you of a magnificent bitch that he met sometime in the past. She died in the invasion, filling the dog with great sorrow.
The dog wonders if you plan on killing all the invaders yourself, or if you could be kind enough to just wound a few for it to finish off.
The dog is enjoying the invasion very much, since its master now allows it to bite people.
The dog tells you that duergar meat tastes like chicken. Really tough, stringy chicken.
The dog tells you about all the dark invaders it has helped kill.
"Hello dog."
Diddelysquat.
"I wish I could go with you, but I suppose I'm needed here. Best of luck."
"I could do just as well as you, I'll bet. If only they'd give me a chance."
"Perhaps you really are the hero everyone says you are. Good luck, you'll need it."
"You fought very bravely. You obviously have the skills Durnan has been waiting for. Good luck."
"Get going. Durnan's waiting for you."
"Durnan asked for your help. You'd better get moving."
The guard just shakes his head and motions towards the well room.
"I don't know why Durnan called for your assistance instead of mine, but you'd better get down there now."
"Durnan has been organizing things and should be ready to explain his plan very soon."
The small, fairy-like creature darts toward you and then away again in surprise. It seems to be both fascinated and frightened by you at the same time.
"Who are you? You don't work for the ogre, do you? Oh, I so hope not!"
The small fairy zips back and forth, hesitantly. "Oooo, if only I could believe you! Maybe you here to kill the fairy queen! That would be bad."
"Ooohhh," the fairy cries, flittering about, "the fairy queen told me I was supposed to look out for new people like you, and here you are!"
"But I forget what I was supposed to do when I see you! How awful! How terrible! I don't like Undermountain! It is dark and scary and gloomy!"
"Eeek! You do work for the ogre, you do!!"
"You want me to leave? But... what if that isn't what the fairy queen wanted me to do?"
The fairy wavers for a moment, then apparently comes to a decision. "I'll go ask the fairy queen what I'm to do, then! That's it! That's what I'll do!" Without another word, she flies off.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> "No you don't! I... I would have seen you! That's right! I would have seen you! Why would you say such a thing?!"
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> "You do?" She bobs uncertainly. "But I've never seen you before. But if you say you do..."
The fairy flutters about excitedly. "Okay, I will go! But you must remember to watch for the ogre mage and his minions! They will destroy us all unless we fight them!"
"Okay!" She starts to dart away, but suddenly stops. "Wait! If... if you work for the fairy queen, how do you not know where she is?"
Suddenly horror registers on her tiny face. "No, no! This is not good! You *do* work for the ogre mage, you do! You will try to hurt me!!"
The fairy settles on a nearby stone. "You have questions? What sorts of questions? Are they hard questions?"
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> The fairy settles on a nearby stone. "You have questions? What sorts of questions? Are they hard questions?"
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> "I can answer questions, if they are not hard... but wait! No, no! The fairy queen would not want me telling things to someone who works for the ogre mage!"
She zips about with sudden fear and excitement. "And you *do* work for the ogre mage, don't you?! Oh, the fairy queen will be so angry with me, so angry! I've got to get away before you hurt me!!"
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> The fairy settles on a nearby stone. "You have questions? What sorts of questions? Are they hard questions?"
"Because he wants to rule this level. He will kill the fairy queen and anyone who tries to stop him. Plus he is very mean and smelly, or so the fairy queen says."
"Fighting was never allowed before, but now it is and there is fighting all the time. I wish things went back to how they were."
She shrugs. "I don't know. That is what everyone says. There was a time when fighting was stopped, but not anymore."
The fairy looks at you quizzically. "How do you not know of her? She has gathered all of us together to fight against the ogre and his smelly minions."
"Why we must fight now and never before, I do not know, but the fairy queen says it must be so."
"A group of what?" She thinks for a moment and then shakes her head. "I haven't seen anyone. But I just came here not long before you arrived."
The fairy ponders for a long moment. "The fairy queen and the ogre mage started fighting. They never did that before."
"I don't know. The fairy queen says the ogre wants to rule everything, but she won't let him."
"I was brought here by magic. All of us who come to Undermountain were, and we can never leave. Is that not how you come here?"
"You are very strange. I do not think I have seen a creature like you before."
The fairy bobs up and down, pleased. "Good luck to you, then, strange creature! Don't let the smelly ogre hurt you!"
"Okay!"
She shrugs. "I don't know. The fairy queen says that none of us can leave, and none of the teleporters work for us, either."
"There are places all over Undermountain that bring you from one place to the other. They do not work for us. Lately other things have been coming through them, however."
"Terrible things! Things with many eyes and evil things with dark skin. They kill you if they see you, so we all avoid them."
"I do not know why they come. And they always go. The fairy queen said they come from somewhere else in Undermountain, but I do not know where."
"No. But the fairy queen might."
The fairy shrugs. "I mean the fairy queen and the ogre mage and all the monsters who come here."
"It changes all the time. Or it used to. Now we have fairies like me and harpies and other smaller things that help the fairy queen."
"The ogre mage, he has goblins and trolls and big nasty creatures. They are very mean and smelly."
"I've never met anyone who didn't come here by magic. Does that mean you can leave, as well? How wonderful that must be!"
"Then I would fly away!" The fairy zips away briefly and then flies back, nervous. "But... you not look like monster. You not want to kill fairy queen, do you?"
The fairy flies around you nervously. "I talk about the big, mean ogre mage! He tries to kill the fairy queen! He tries to rule everything! How you not know that?"
The fairy bobs hesitantly. "This? This only be one very, very small part of Undermountain. Undermountain goes very, very deep down into the ground!"
"My name is <FirstName>, and I don't work for anyone."
"Then let me put you out of your misery." <StartAction>[Kill her.]</Start>
"Just leave me alone. I don't need any annoyances flying about."
"You had your chance to leave. Now I swat you!" <StartAction>[Kill her.]</Start>
"I don't care what the fairy queen wants. Just go."
"How about you take me to the fairy queen, then?"
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> "Fine, if you want to stay, how about you answer some questions?"
<StartCheck>[Bluff - Lie]</Start> "But I work for the fairy queen, too!"
"Now run along and leave me be."
"Now Take me to the fairy queen."
"Now answer my questions."
<StartCheck>[Intimidate]</Start> "Stand still and answer my questions! You're not making any sense!"
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> "Calm down. I just want to ask a few questions."
"Never mind. just leave me alone."
"Why are you frightened of this ogre?"
"What do you mean 'fighting was not allowed'?"
"Tell me what you know about this fairy queen."
"Did you see a group of adventurers come running through here?"
"Has anything changed in Undermountain recently?"
"Why did they start fighting?"
"Tell me what you know about Undermountain."
"I'm through with questions."
"I can't afford having you tell anyone about me. Sorry." <StartAction>[Kill her.]</Start>
"Thank you. You've been very helpful."
"Just begone and leave me alone."
"Let me ask something else."
"Why is it you can't leave?"
"The teleporters?"

"Do you know who made the magic that brought you here?"
"When you say 'all of us', what do you mean?"
"And what sorts of monsters are those?"
"Not by magic, no."
"And if I did work for the ogre? What would you do?"
"What ogre are you talking about?"
"This is Undermountain? All of this?"

"Unless you takes me 50 gold for find shield. That be all me gots left, but you deserving it."
Oh, you be the kindest <man/woman> me ever meet.

This huge, one handed half orc stares at you with a grimace, trying to decide if he recognizes you or not. "You no allowed out. There be ban on streets."
He nods and looks away at the other customers.
He frowns at you. "Me no like to say. It bad story."
<StartCheck>[Failed]</Start> "You think you threaten me? Me no be scared of you! Now go away."
<StartCheck>[Successful]</Start> "You be funny <man/woman>! Me likes you, tough <man/woman>."
<StartCheck>[Successful]</Start> "That be big lie! Me never be coward. Me just about die!"
<StartCheck>[Failed]</Start> "You just want make fun of me, like others do. Go away. Me no want to talk to you."
<StartCheck>[Successful]</Start> "Me have few friends. Guess me would like to have new friend."

"We go real deep and make lots of gold, which me spend real fast. Then one day we meet girl."
"Me trying. You be patient. It no long story."
"She pretty lady, tell us she help us find treasure if we fetch her cape. We think that good deal."

"I killed many slaads, but see me friends all die one by one."

"Durnan feel sorry for Grayban. Him hire me as guard. He is good boss."

He unlocks the door, then slips the key back inside his shirt. He gives you a big, toothy grin and waves goodbye.

This huge, one handed half orc stares at you with a grimace. "Boss want speak. Him want no one leave. You stay. You listen."
