An emaciated goblin slinks out from the shadows. He approaches you warily, ready to flee at the first hint of danger.
"No, no, no! Please, I beg, I beg! Spare me, spare this worthless creature! Grovel's not strong like the ogres, or quick like the fairies. But I'm ever so smart... let me help you. Please."
"You'll have to catch me first!"
"Yes, that's good. Good, good, good. Everyone else down here is mad, fighting and killing. But not you. No, no, no."
"Maybe you want to talk, yes? Talking is what I'm good at. Not fighting, not magic, but information is what Grovel's good at. You have questions, Grovel will help you. Better than fighting, yes?"
"Wait, wait, wait. Grovel wants out of the dungeon. Too much fighting, too much killing. You can help, yes? Maybe? Yes? You can help Grovel escape."
"No! No, no, no! They'll find Grovel! They'll punish him! Kill him, even! Grovel has to hide. Can't let them find me!"
"Yes, yes, yes! Pull Grovel up the well. Send me where it's safe. Away from here. Please. Thank you. Hurry."
You give a tug on the chain and Grovel is hoisted up the well. Hopefully Durnan gives him a chance to explain that you sent him before anyone does something rash.
"Yes. Good, good, good. Grovel very busy here. Clean and tidy, tidy and clean. That's good. Very good. Yes, yes, yes."
"Yes, ogres to the north, fairies to the south. Armies of the Ogre mage and the Fairy Queen, fighting for control. Both think they should be the one in charge now that Halaster's gone."
"Undermountain's always changing. Halaster doesn't leave it the same for long. Walls shift, doors move. Brings monsters in, pops monsters out. He's mad. Mad, mad, mad. Always playing games."
"But Grovel knows to be careful. Watch for traps. Play nice with others, stay out of the way, stay small and hidden. Not so bad, before. But now Halaster's gone, and things are bad. Very bad."
"Halaster's gone. Don't know where, no, no, no. But he's gone, yes, yes, yes. That's why the creatures in Undermountain are fighting. Halaster made us play nice, but now he's gone."
"Now everyone is free to fight and kill - stupid creatures. But with no Halaster to keep us here, we are free to escape, if we survive. Like Grovel, yes?"

"Grovel doesn't know much else. Only that Halaster is gone, and Undermountain is more dangerous than ever. Oh, yes. Yes, yes, yes. Everyone fighting for power, fighting for control, fighting to escape."
"I'm Grovel... nobody important. Not now. Grovel used to be advisor to King Bloodtooth, long ago. Back before Grovel came to Undermountain."
"We come like all the others... Halaster brought us. Nobody knows why. No, no, no. One second King Bloodtooth sitting on his throne, then poof... we all here in Undermountain. The whole tribe."
"Halaster does things like that. Crazy in the head, yes? Oh yes, yes, yes. But we not know that back then. Grovel only learned that stuff later."
"Bloodtooth says we should fight our way out, and tribe agrees. They not smart like Grovel. Grovel knows you don't fight other creatures in Undermountain. You don't make Halaster mad."
"But Bloodtooth never listens. They try to fight their way out, and now only Grovel is left. Goblins in Undermountain are nothing but food for the others - even Bloodtooth. Yes, yes, yes."
"But Grovel's still alive. Not strong, but smart. Hide. Watch. Wait for a chance, yes? Maybe. With Halaster gone, maybe now is a good time to escape, yes?"
He glances up and gives you a lop-sided grin. "Hello, hello, hello. Grovel's very busy, but never too busy for you, <FirstName>. You need something, maybe? Yes, yes, yes?"
"Questions? Questions about Undermountain, yes? Where fairies and ogres tear each others throats? Grovel knows about Undermountain. Yes, yes, yes."
"<FirstName>? Good. Maybe you can shed some light on this. I was standing watch at the well when I got the signal to pull you up. You can imagine my surprise when I saw this... this goblin."
"At first I thought it was another invasion, but he started begging and pleading for his life, so I didn't have the heart to kill him. One unarmed goblin isn't much of a threat, after all."
"He claims you sent him to us, <FirstName>. Is this true?"
"I thought as much. Take this goblin away to the prisons. He probably has information about Undermountain we can use. The interrogators will know how to get it out of him."
Grovel lets out a shriek and races for the well. "No, no, no! Not torture! Grovel won't go to prison!"
"What did you expect me to do with him, <FirstName>? Turn him loose? He may be harmless to you, but he could still cause a lot of trouble for the average person on the street."
"And even if he means no harm, people aren't going to take to his kind. Not with things the way they are. Wherever he goes, people are going to try and hunt him down."
"Looks like we don't have any other choice but to take him to the city prisons, then. Let them deal with him."
The goblin lets out a nervous yelp. "Wait, wait, wait. Grovel has better idea. Why not let him work here, yes? I not cause trouble - not with so many guards and swords around."
Durnan scratches his chin. "I don't know. What do you think, <FirstName>? Can I trust him?"
"Yes, yes, yes. Grovel works hard, follows instructions. You'll see. Grovel makes you very happy. Just say the word, and Grovel jumps to action."
"Well, with so many people crammed into the inn, it's hard to keep things clean. I guess I could use someone to tidy up a bit. But no funny business, goblin: I'm keeping an eye on you!"
"Thank you, thank you. Yes, yes, yes. Grovel gets started right away. Spic and span, clean as clean can be. You see."
Durnan shakes his head as the goblin earnestly begins picking up small bits of dust from the floor. "Don't worry, I'll keep an eye on him to make sure he doesn't get into any mischief."
"Time to die, goblin!"
"Sorry, it's killin' time!
"I might let you live... if you can give me useful information."
"I serve only myself."
"I work for the city of Waterdeep!"
"Enough yapping. I'm in the mood for a goblin-ka-bob!"
"I'll be going now."
"The only escape from here is death - and I'll be happy to help!"
"Forget it. You can stay in here and rot for all I care."
"I suppose I could get Durnan to pull you up the well."
"Tell Durnan <FullName> sent you up." <StartAction>Pull the chain.</Start>
"You mentioned ogres and fairies?"
"What do you know about Undermountain?"
"Halaster's gone? What do you mean?"
"Who are you?"
"How did you come to Undermountain?"
"What happened to the rest of your tribe?"
"What are you talking about?"
"I want to ask you some questions."
"I sent him up here so you could capture and interrogate him."
"I've never seen this creature before in my life."
"Yes. He wanted to escape Undermountain. I think he's harmless."
"Just send him to the prisons. That should solve all our problems."
"I guess I never thought of that."
"Open your eyes, Durnan! He's obviously a spy!"
"I don't think he's any threat. Might as well put him to work."
<StartCheck>[Insight]</Start> "Put him to work at your inn so you can keep an eye on him."
Do you wish to descend into the black depths of the well?
No.
Yes.
The elven cleric brushes herself off slowly, rubbing her head. She seems a little confused as she casts about, looking for something to help her get her bearings.
Her eyes grow wide in surprise at your sharp words. After a second she composes herself and says coldly, "I see. Very well, ask your questions and I will do my best to answer them."
Linu studies you for a few seconds before her face lights up in recognition."You're <FullName>, aren't you dear? The one Durnan was waiting for. I'm Linu La'neral, priestess of Sehanine Moonbow."
Linu's face furls in concentration as she struggles to recover her faded memories. "Yes, of course. You're <FullName>, aren't you dear? The one Durnan was waiting for."

"Now I remember ... there was a beholder. We chased it from the tavern and then... then we were ambushed by drow! Sharwyn went down, Daelan charged off in one direction and Tomi and I ran in the other!"
"Tomi and I managed to escape the ambush, but in our escape we lost our bearings. We were trying to find our way back out when we stumbled across these slaves. At least, we thought they were slaves."
"They asked us for help, so Tomi went off to spy on a nearby drow encampment and I stayed here to protect them. Of course, as soon as my back was turned they revealed what they really were."
"I tried to call on the power of Sehanine to protect me from those shape-shifting Rakshasa but there were too many of them and they were too fast. I remember... I remember dying."
"You raised me, didn't you, dear? Thank you. I know those words don't count for much, but I sincerely mean it: thank you."
"I imagine there are more than a few people who will have need of my healing powers back at the inn. Don't worry, dear, I'm confident I can make it back there on my own."
"Goodbye, and good luck. Everyone is counting on you now, dear."
"Are you certain that's what you want, dear? I have something of a reputation for being accident prone. Sometimes unfortunate things happen to those around me."
Linu's face lights up with a beaming smile. "Yes, I imagine my skills could come in handy in a place like this. Lead on, dear, and I'll be happy to follow."
She looks at your companions. "It would appear you have more than enough help as it is, dear. And I imagine people back at Durnan's inn have need of my healing abilities."
"Well, it's obvious I'm not going to make it on my own if I stay down here. I suppose I should go back to Durnan's inn, at least for now."
"What?? Why would you bring me back to life only to kill me again? What was the point?"
She gives you long stare, then simply shakes her head. "You have a very unusual sense of humor, <FirstName>."
"May Sehanine Moonbow protect me!"
"I've given you my thanks already, and I don't have anything else. But really, that should be more than enough. A good deed is its own reward, after all."

"There's not much I can tell you that you probably don't already know, dear. Obviously, the slaves weren't really slaves at all. If I had known that I wouldn't have been in the state you found me in."
"There is one thing that might be useful. They mentioned an encampment of drow to the south. Tomi went off to scout it out. As soon as he was gone, the Rakshasa attacked me."
"I don't know much else, unfortunately. When you're dead you tend to miss out on a lot."
"It wouldn't have helped a bit. I tried to warn you about them slaves, but you wouldn't listen to me. Instead, you sent me off to meet an untimely end at the hands of them drow!"
"Yes, and now we're both alive and well, aren't we? So really, dear, I don't understand what you're complaining about."
"I don't know what happened to Daelan or Sharwyn after the ambush. Tomi, however, was going off to investigate the drow encampment. I do hope nothing terrible has happened to him."
"He was going to look for a magical stone to help the slaves escape this place. I mean the Rakshasa. I mean, the slaves who were really Rakshasa. Oh, you know what I mean, don't you, dear?"
"We were led to believe that the drow had a djinni bottle, and that inside the bottle was a stone that would allow the owner to use the portal in the other room to return to Waterdeep."
"Of course, as soon as Tomi was gone the Rakshasa unleashed their little surprise on me and... well, you know the rest."
"Why are you asking her? She's been stuck inside a sarcophagus. She wouldn't know about anything that happened to them since the ambush!"
"Hopefully they've made it back to Durnan's inn. That's where they'll go, if they're able."
"The Rakshasa must have tried to hide me in there so they could continue their ruse. I can't believe I actually thought they were slaves and wanted to help them!"
"I told you there was something off about them, didn't I? But you wouldn't listen to old Tomi, oh no! You just kept going on and on about helping people and protecting the weak."
"Guess it just goes to prove what I always say: no good deed goes unpunished."

"What a horrible thing to say! I'm not about to let one mistake change what I believe in, Tomi. I will still do everything I can to help those in need. I'll just have to be more careful in the future."
"I see the Rakshasa are all dead now. Good. They were creatures of pure evil, and their very existence was an affront to everything I stand for. I suppose I should thank you for that, too, dear."
Linu recoils as if she's been slapped. "I understand that this is a difficult situation, and we're all feeling more than a little stress. But there's no need to speak to me like that."
"I accept your apology, dear. But I think the last thing we need right now is to be throwing harsh words at each other."
"I don't know why you're speaking to me like this, but I won't stand for it!"
Linu begins to walk off, but snags her heel on a stone causing her to take a tumble. With all the dignity she can muster, she rises to her feet again and marches off without a backward glance.
"Just give her a sec. Comin' back from the dead's a bit like waking up after a long night at yer favorite tavern. The heads a bit groggy, and you aren't sure where you are or who yer with."
"I remember this one time I had a bit too much of the liquid pleasure, and I woke up to find this ogre-looking gal lyin' beside me, snoring fierce enough like to scare a dragon."
"I woulda' made my escape right quick, but me hands were lashed to the bedpost. Not rightly sure how that happened. Anyway, I figure I may as well make the best of a bad situation, so I..."
"That's quite enough, Tomi dear. My memory is coming back to me now, and I don't think I need to hear this particular story of your exploits."
"Linu it's me - Sharwyn. Do you know where you are?"
"Sharwyn? Yes... Sharwyn. I remember you, dear. It's... it's starting to come back to me now. The battle at Durnan's inn... I remember."
"You seem to be doing much better than when I last saw you, dear. It's good to know you're safe and sound."
"It's only thanks to <FirstName> here. <He/She> found me and raised me from the dead, just like we did with you. What happened to you, Linu?"
"Everything's still a bit hazy. Let me see... I remember you getting hit by an arrow and going down. And I remember Daelan let out a war cry and raced off down the corridor without a second thought."
"Linu, are you okay? It's me, Daelan."
"Daelan? Yes... Daelan. I remember now. We were... we were all chasing after that beholder when we were ambushed! It's good to see you safe and sound, dear."
"Only because of <FirstName>. <He/She> found my body and raised me, just like you. What happened to you, Linu?"
"Everything's still a bit hazy. Let me see... I remember Sharwyn was hit by an arrow and went down, and you let out a war cry and raced off down the corridor without a second thought."
"And then Tomi scampered off in the opposite direction. An army of Drow appeared out of nowhere, and I knew I had no chance against them alone. So I ran after Tomi."
"Why did you go after Tomi? Why not follow me?"
"You're a mighty Uthgardt warrior, dear. Tomi's just a little guy. I figured he'd need my help more than you."
"I also thought it might be a good idea to keep a watchful eye on our resident rogue. It's not that I don't trust him, but sometimes he needs a little convincing to do the right thing."
"Hey, the only person I need looking out for me is a resourceful fellow known as Tomi Undergallows, get it? Tomi looks after himself, and if you ask me he does a pretty decent job of it."
"I also thought it might be a good idea to keep a watchful eye on our resident rogue. It's not that I don't trust you, Tomi dear, but sometimes you need a little convincing to do the right thing."
"You mean you just left me there? How very heroic of you."
"I'm sorry, dear, but I wouldn't have been much good to you if I was dead myself. Besides, I always intended to come back and raise you later."
"That's okay, I guess. Still, I figured you would have followed Daelan rather than pair up with a rogue."
"Daelan's a mighty Uthgardt warrior, dear. Tomi's just a little guy. I figured he'd need my help more than the half-orc."
Linu notices your approach, and her face lights up. As she gives you a warm wave, it's obvious she is suffering no ill effects from her trauma in the dungeon.
"I'm glad to hear it. I hope you don't mind if I tell people here how well you're doing, dear. They could use some good news to lift their spirits."
"I thought you'd never ask, dear! It will be a pleasure to serve at your side. And by the grace of Sehanine Moonbow, we will not fail!"
"I don't know, <FirstName>. You seem to have plenty of help already, and I don't want to get in the way. Besides, these people here need me, too."
"They're scared and hurt, and I can offer them comfort. Anyway, I know I don't have to worry about you, dear. You and your companions can look after yourselves just fine."
The elven cleric watches you with guarded suspicion. It's obvious she isn't looking forward to another conversation with you.
For a brief second Linu appears to be about to respond to your insult, but instead she holds her tongue and curtly turns away from you, ending the conversation.
"Hmph! There was a moment after you rescued me when I thought you were both noble and heroic. I see now how wrong those assumptions were. Good<day/night> to you, <FirstName>."
"No, <FirstName>, I do not. You have an evil streak in you. You aren't the first <race> adventurer I've ever met, but you are certainly the cruelest."
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> Linu's face scrunches up into a sour grimace. "Normally I'm not one to hold grudges, but I cannot simply forget everything you said to me, <FirstName>."
"You did save my life, and I'm grateful. But I was deeply hurt by your words. I'm sorry, but I cannot forgive you. Not yet, at least. Maybe... maybe in time."
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Linu's face breaks into a relieved smile. "You have no idea how glad I am to hear that!"
"I was hoping your words were just a reaction to the difficult situation we were in. I was shocked by those things you said to me. It's such a relief to find out you didn't mean them after all."
"Yes, of course. Goodbye, <FirstName>. And good luck. We're all counting on you."
"Quiet. I'm the one who asks the questions here!"
"You were dead. I just raised you. Can you remember anything?"
"I'm <FirstName>. I saw you in the tavern with Durnan."
"You don't remember me? I spoke to your group at the tavern."
"You don't remember me? We spoke at the tavern."
"Then what happened?"
"I'll be going now."
"How about you join me?"
"That's a good point. I'm probably safer without you."
"I'm willing to risk it. I could use a good healer."
"What are you going to do now?"
"That's probably for the best."
"Enough chit-chat. I think I'll just kill you now."
"Just kidding. Head on back to the inn."
"I just want the satisfaction of killing you myself." <StartAction>[Kill him.]</Start>
"This is all the thanks I get for bringing you back to life?"
"I guess you're right. I don't need a reward."
"Not good enough. Guess I have to kill you."
"Why don't you come with me, instead?"
"Is there anything you can tell me about this area?"
"Do you know where your other companions are?"
"How did you end up stuffed inside that sarcophagus?"
"You're pathetic. I should have just left you for dead."
"I'm sorry. I guess this whole situation is just getting to me."
"Go back to the inn and find a corner to pray in. That's the only place someone as hopeless as you can be of any use."
"As well as can be expected."
"I could use some help. Maybe you could join up with me?"
"Get back to your prayers. You've already proved you aren't good for much else."
"Yeah, nobody had to come drag my sorry carcass out of there."
"You don't like me much, do you?"
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> "I'm sorry about what I said to you before. I didn't mean it."
"I should go."
The beauty of this woman at her peak must have been something to behold, because age certainly doesn't seem to have had much effect on her.
"Ah, you must be <FirstName>. Durnan told me you would be coming to help out our poor city. I would welcome you to my House of Pleasures, but I am sorry to tell you, we are closed for business"
"That the City of Splendors should come to such a state as this is almost unthinkable. But my manners are lacking, how can this poor house of refuge assist you?"
"Come back when this war is over and my people will explore the mysteries of the night with you at no cost, should you prove to be the hero I hope you are."
"I will help you in any way I can. I have nothing pressing right now; other than comforting this group of refugees."
"All right. I had better get back to work. I need to see if I can make room for a few more families."
"I don't know who has remained open. Most stores are closed, but you might want to try Argali's Arms. She's a brave, if obnoxious woman, and she might just have dared to remain open."
"I haven't seen any merchants in this part of the city, which is why it costs so much for me to get enough supplies for these people here."
"No, we have our own guards and have been lucky so far. Most of the people in here have seen some of the fighting though."
"These poor folk residing here have lost everything and needed somewhere to stay. I have some experience with being an orphan so I felt I had a duty."
"Of course I never realized just how expensive feeding and clothing this many people could be. I do not know how they made ends meet at the Kettlesmith Orphanage."
"The only thing that could help me right now is gold to buy food and clothes for these poor souls."
"You cold-hearted, villainous <bitch/bastard>! Here I talk about how I can't afford to feed these helpless souls and you want to steal my gold?"
"Don't be a fool. What kind of reputation in Waterdeep are you looking for? If people know you as a hero, doors of opportunity will open. Rob from the poor and you will be despised."
"I am not amused. It was not a funny joke. Is there anything else you need?"
"All I have is the 30 gold I was going to use to buy food for the innocents. Take it and be gone with you. Darken my door no more."
<StartAction>[Sigh]</Start> "That's all right. I really didn't expect anything. Is there anything else I can do for you?"
"Dear me, but you are a sweet <man/woman>. With that kind of assistance I can probably accept a few more innocents into my refuge."
"We shall remember your name in Waterdeep, so long as I have breath to tell people of your generosity. Oh, and if you get in to see Argali ask about her special equipment."
"And if she shows you an emerald, remember that it is seriously flawed. Is there anything else I can do for you?"
"That is awfully kind of you, <FirstName>. I hope someday you will return and I can pay you back in kind. Perhaps a night of pleasures on the house."
"Or just some gentle conversation and good food, if that is more to your liking. Oh, I should tell you, if Argali's Arms is open, you should ask Argali if she has any special equipment."
"I know she sometimes has something extra hidden from her regular inventory. Is there anything else I can do for you?"
"I guess anything helps. Thanks. I'll have to see if other adventurers have something to give."
"That was one of the better places I lived, yes. My first adopted family worked me hard and nearly starved me to death."
"Then a guard caught my 'father' in a slave trade and I returned to the orphanage. I was so skinny and sickly looking that no one else wanted to adopt me."
"Life wasn't so bad at the orphanage, once I was old enough to trade favors with the staff. A little sexual offer can take you far, if you learn how to use it properly."
"That is a brusque way to put it, but suppose it's an apt description."
"With the extra food and clothes I earned, I was able to fix myself up and find a career that has been as fulfilling as I ever dreamed."
"There was nowhere for a young girl to go that was not worse than what I was experiencing. The streets are not safe for a lonely girl."
"I did indeed. With the extra food and clothes I earned, I was able to fix myself up and find a career that has been as fulfilling as anything else I have experienced."
"I was as old as many girls are when they get married. What would you have done? Asked the temples for help? Prayed for deliverance?"
"Do you not think I tried that? The temples sent me right back to the orphanage and told the headmaster to keep a better leash on his pets. And the gods? They must not have been listening."
"I used what I had to survive. These refugees: they will get better treatment from me. If I can afford it, they shall stay here in safety until the war is over."
"Come back when this war is over and my people will explore the mysteries of the night with you at no cost, should you prove to be the hero I hope you are."
"I will do my best to help you."
"I am Mother Salinka, usually the madam of this house, now patroness of the displaced. I fear that if you came to explore the mysteries of the night, you are sadly out of luck."
"My most skilled people have either fled the city or are helping me here. When the war is over, we shall return to business as usual. Is there anything else I can assist you with?"
"You even have the look of one I might have explored the mysteries with in person, but that will have to wait. Is there anything else I can assist you with?"
You see Mother Salinka eyeing one of the orphaned children with a sad, caring look.
"I see you have returned. How may I help you?"
Mother Salinka's eyes flash with anger. "I said I never wanted to speak to you again and I meant it."
"Goodbye."
"Me asks you questions?"
"May I ask you some questions?"
"Me not have more questions."
"I don't have any more questions."
"You know where me get equipment?"
"Do you know where I could get some equipment?"
"You get attack in here?'
"Have you been attacked in here?"
"Why all these people be here?"
"Why are all these people in here?"
"Could me help you, maybe?"
"Could I help you somehow?"
"Gold help me too. You give me gold or goodbye widows and orphans."
"Gold would help me as well. You don't want anything to happen to these poor widows and orphans?"
"It only a joke. Calm yourself."
"It was only a joke. Relax."
"Me no care. Give me you gold."
"I don't care. Give me your gold."
"Me guess me no help you then."
"I guess I can't help you then."
"Me could spare 200 gold."
"I could spare 200 gold."
"100 gold help you?"
"How about 100 gold?"
"10 gold help?"
"Would 10 gold help."
"That where you grow up?"
"That was were you grew up?"
"Ha! Me guess you find calling in life at young age."
"Ha! I guess you found your calling in life early."
"Why you no run away?"
"Why didn't you just run away?"
"Me guess you do what you must to live."
"I guess you do what you have to, to survive."
"That be awful. How you do bad thing like that?"
"That is horrible! How could you do such things?"
"Goodbye."
"Me gots more questions."
"I have some more questions."
"Who you be?"
"Who are you?"
"Me want help you with widows and orphans."
"I would like to help you with the widows and orphans."
A quiet voice whispers, "Pssst. Hey you. Give me a gold piece." It seems to be coming from the pedestal itself.
"I wouldn't listen to him, if I were you."
"Blast! That's so unfair!"
"I'm just experimenting with something. You just should ignore the pedestal."
"Ignore him. I've got something special to show you."
The gold piece flies up from the pedestal and catches you in the side of the head, leaving a nasty welt.
"I told you so. I'm studying a bit of the dirt from one of the streets here in Waterdeep that is cursed. And the pedestal has a wicked sense of humor."
"Hee hee hee."
"Many years ago, one of the Lords of Waterdeep turned evil and betrayed his fellow lords. He killed three of them before his true colors were revealed."
"At that time, there was a head lord, a very powerful mage. The two of them had a spectacular mage duel that raged right across the breadth of old Waterdeep."
"In the end, the good lord won, and he cursed the ground where the evil lord fell, saying that none should put a stone to commemorate the evil mage."
"Yes, indeed. Anyone who places non-living materials larger than a tiny pebble upon the dirt, finds the object flung back up at his head."
"Anyone who places non-living materials larger than a tiny pebble upon the dirt, finds the object flung back up at his head."
"I am experimenting with this dirt to see if it could somehow be mixed in with metal to create magical armor."
"Unfortunately, the dirt seems to keep the metal from becoming attached and the whole process simply doesn't work."
"That's 'cause you're a lousy mage!"
"One of these days I'm going to get rid of that pedestal. Ah well, I'd better get back to work."
"Goodbye, <FullName>. And watch out for that pedestal."
"Too many magical experiments using the same pedestal caused it to somehow gain a mind of its own."
"It's a very crude and annoying mind, but what can you do? It's all part of the curse."
<StartAction>[Leave the pedestal alone.]</Start>
"Why not?"
<StartAction>[Ignore Sobrey and put a gold piece on the pedestal.]</Start>
<StartAction>[Leave the pedestal alone.]</Start>
"Tell me about this curse."
"And this dirt is from there?"
"Go on."
"The pedestal has a sense of humor?"
"No time to chat now. We have to save Halaster."
A shadow in the corner shifts, revealing itself to be Nathyrra, the drow you met you earlier. She looks about cautiously before fully emerging from her hiding place.
"And so we meet again. You'll be pleased to know that your quest to rid Undermountain of the Valsharess's drow is nearly at its end."
"The mad mage is being held just ahead, guarded by some of the Valsharess's most loyal and powerful servants. No doubt they'll attack us on sight."
She sighs in exasperation. "I was hoping you would trust me by now. I'm not your enemy: the Valsharess is."
She throws her head back and laughs. "Ha-ha-ha! Me? The Valsharess? You are as mad as Halaster himself! If I was going to disguise myself, why would I disguise myself as a drow?"
"You want to end the threat to Undermountain, <FirstName>. So do I. The way to do that is to kill the drow in the next room so you can free Halaster."
"Halaster is imprisoned in a magical globe powered by three energy stones. If the stones are destroyed, the mad mage will be free - and he'll likely help us dispose of any remaining drow."
"You might be able to do this alone, but you'll have a better chance if I'm fighting by your side. Now let's stop talking about it, and let's go save Halaster."
Nathyrra, the drow who approached you earlier, materializes from the darkness. "We meet again. Somehow I knew we would."
The dark elf doesn't seem at all offended by your suspicion. In fact, she seems somewhat amused. "Still not inclined to trust me? Maybe that will change with what I have to tell you."
She seems momentarily taken aback by your kind words. "Uh... thank you. It's good to see you again, too. I... I have to warn you about something."
"I've been waiting for you here. I knew you'd have to come this way eventually if you wanted to free Halaster."
"I've been scouting the area, and I came across a large encampment of the Valsharess's forces near here. If you take this bridge you'll be walking right into them."
"As I told you earlier, I'm not your enemy. I want to help you defeat the Valsharess."
She smiles. "There's more. The drow have set up a pair of ballista on top of a ridge behind their camp. If you attack them head on they'll use the ballista to smash you to bits."
"But there's a way you can sneak past the camp and get to the ballista unseen. Then you can use their own weapons against the rest of the camp, and rain death down on them from above!"
"Just follow the narrow corridor to the north. It seems to lead to a dead end, but there is actually a secret passage that will take you right to the ballista."
She shrugs. "Do as you will. Attack them head on and be smashed by the ballista, or use the passage to the north and beat them at their own game. The choice is yours."
"I have to go now, <FirstName>... unless there is something else?"
A single drow female steps out from the shadows, her hands held up to show they are empty. She approaches you cautiously. "Hold your weapons. I mean you no harm."
"I understand your suspicion, but not all the drow are after your blood. Just listen to what I have to say, and it will all become clear."
She relaxes slightly; obviously she was as wary about this encounter as you were. "My name is Nathyrra. You're the one they call <FullName>, aren't you?"
She smiles slightly. "I'm afraid your reputation precedes you, <FirstName>. I know who you are. You've become something of a legend among my people."
She smiles slightly. "Your reputation precedes you, <FirstName>. I know who you are. You're something of a legend among my people."
She furrows her brow, carefully considering her next words. "Although I am a drow, I am not allied with those who are attacking Waterdeep. Me and my people are different. We are... rebels."
She frowns. "My people are drow, but they are not like the ones who have invaded Undermountain and attack the surface. We are different. We are... rebels."
"We want to help you, <FirstName>. We want to help you free Halaster so you can stop the forces of the Valsharess from attacking Waterdeep."
"The Valsharess is the ruler of House Kilath, a faction from the drow that has recently risen to prominence. The drow invading Waterdeep serve the Valsharess and her house."
"Her forces captured Halaster, giving them free access through Undermountain and allowing them to strike at the very heart of Waterdeep."
"But not all the drow follow the Valsharess. There are some of us who oppose her, and will do whatever we can to break her power."
She nods. "I can't blame you. The drow have a reputation for treachery, you would be foolish to blindly trust me. If it helps, you should know that I don't fully trust you yet, either."
"We weren't certain we should even approach you, but in the end we thought you should know that there are others who want to see the attacks on Waterdeep ended."
"At this point, I'm only here to provide you information, <FirstName>. Nothing more."
"Goodbye, <FirstName>. And good luck. Maybe we'll meet again, sometime." With those words, Nathyrra disappears back into the shadows.
"Before you go, there is some information you might find useful. To the southwest several drow overseers have captured a formian queen and enslaved her colony."
"They are forcing the formians to dig through Undermountain itself, making it easier for the drow to move about the dungeon. If you free the queen, the colony will be in your debt."
"The formians could help you against the drow here in Undermountain, and you would be wise to seek out whatever allies you can."
The drow shrugs. "Seeking the aid of the formians is your choice. I am only telling you this as a show of good faith. Whether you use the information is up to you."
"The formians were working to the southwest of here. The drow have several guards watching over them, so be careful if you go back there."
"The formians are a strange race of beings... not unexpected here in Undermountain. They resemble giant ants, but they are highly intelligent. At least, the queen is."
"The drow have enslaved the entire colony by capturing the queen. If you save her, the entire colony will be in your debt."
"Maybe not. But now at least you know the name of the enemy you face. Without our help you you might never have learned that the Valsharess was behind this."
"Ask your questions and I'll do my best to answer them."
"We're a group of rebels and outcasts. Some of us chose to leave the evil of drow society willingly, others were driven away or banished by misfortune and circumstance."
"I... I don't think I should say anymore. Not yet. In any case, you should focus on rescuing Halaster. Once free, he'll drive the Valsharess's army out of Undermountain and back into the Underdark."
"We don't know much about her. She is the matron mother of House Kilath. They were once a weak house, beneath the notice of the more powerful factions."
"No one paid any attention to plots of house Kilath. Maybe that's why they were able to rise to power so quickly. They went from nothing to the most powerful family in the city within weeks."

"The Valsharess recruited the most powerful agents from the other houses to form the Red Sisters, a squad of assassins she uses to maintain her control over those who have now sworn allegiance to her."
"To conquer it, of course. The drow houses hate those who dwell on the surface, the matron mothers would like nothing better than to see the cities above razed and their citizens enslaved."
"In the past Halaster's presence in Undermountain kept Waterdeep safe from constant raids from the Underdark. Once the Valsharess imprisoned the arch-mage, however, that protection was gone."
Nathyrra nods. "The work of the Red Sisters. The Valsharess is using them to sow fear and panic, and to weaken the city by removing its most powerful defenders."
"The Red Sisters are very good at what they do. Had you not caught that thief in your room, you would have woken to find a Red Sister with a blade standing over you... assuming you woke up at all."
"The Valsharess must have targeted you because of your reputation. You are one of the few powerful enough to threaten her plans. That's also the reason we finally chose to approach you."
"Halaster isn't far, once you get past the drow encampment. Just follow the passage to the southwest."
"I've done some scouting on this level; the wizard is being held far from here. Go through the north caverns, then head to the west once you are past them."
"There is a powerful drow war party guarding the wizard. If you want to free Halaster, you'll have to find some way to deal with them."
She shrugs. "We don't know. It must have been some type of trap that preyed on his insanity. Or maybe she used his own arrogance to trick and ensnare him."
"She's keeping him alive, that much we know. She's probably afraid of what will happen to Undermountain if Halaster dies. But she's been very careful to make sure he can't get out."

"If the wizard ever breaks free, there's no way the Valsharess will be able to maintain control of Undermountain. In his own realm Halaster is a match for anyone, and he won't let himself be tricked again."
She shakes her head slightly. "We want to offer you aid, <FirstName>, but there is only so much we are willing to do. We don't fully trust you yet, as I'm sure you don't fully trust me."
"There is only so much we are willing to do, <FirstName>. I admit, we don't fully trust you yet - just as I'm sure you don't fully trust me."
"Allies are hard to find in Undermountain, <FirstName>. You should take whatever help is offered. Any enemy of the Valsharess is a friend of yours... at least for now."
You're back. We have to hurry and save Halaster.
"Still following me? Maybe I should just kill you."
"Not one step closer, foul drow!"
"I think you're the Valsharess in disguise!"
"It takes more than that to win my trust."
"I'm sorry. I guess you've proven yourself."
"You said 'us'? Are you helping in this fight?"
"Back off - I'm not falling for any drow treachery!"
"It's good to see you again."
"How did you know where to find me?"
"Why are you telling me this?"
"Good. They're easier to kill when they're all together."
"Thanks for the warning. I'll be careful."
"Sounds like you're leading me into a trap!"
"I prefer to tackle my battles head on."
"Thanks for the information."
"That's all. Thanks for the warning."
"Is this some type of trick?"
"A drow who means no harm? I doubt that!"
"I'll listen. But don't try anything!"
"Who are you? What do you want?"
"No, I think you have me confused with someone else."
"How do you know my name?"
"What do you want?"
"Your people? You mean the drow?"
"The Valsharess? Who's that?"
"I don't trust you."
"I still don't trust you. Just leave me alone."
"I have to go now."
"This sounds like a trap."
"Thanks for the information."
"I don't even know what a formian is!"
"That's not much help."
"I guess your information could be useful."
"So you'll answer some questions for me?"
"Tell me more about you and your 'rebel' friends."
"Tell me more about the Valsharess."
"I want to ask you something else."
"Why is she attacking Waterdeep?"
"There have been several recent assassinations in Waterdeep."
"Do you know where Halaster is being held?"
"How did the Valsharess imprison Halaster?"
"Would you like to join up with me?"
"So how do you plan to help me?"
"Why would you want to help me?"
"I don't like the modern music they play in these taverns. Why can't they stick to the classics?"
"I was surviving by gathering wood for the university. I hope they get it rebuilt soon."
"I heard they burned the granaries. It's going to be a long, hard winter."
"My poor old wife had her head split open by one of those dark dwarves."
"I lost my home in the invasion. It was only a small home, but it was mine. What shall I do?"
"Oh, my back hurts and I can barely see. I think I need another drink."
A pretty, but quiet elf sips wine carefully from her glass before speaking, "With all that is out of balance in this age, let my hospitality welcome and comfort you."
"Times of stress and war do not exempt one from good manners; you might want to keep that in mind in the future."
"Times of stress and war do not exempt one from good manners; hold tight to this lesson and you shall find peace in the midst of conflict."
"Times of stress and war do not exempt one from good manners; a lesson I am glad to see you understand."
"My name is Parley. I am a druid out of Vaasa. And you would be <FullName>, correct?"
"Then so is everyone else in this tavern. Would you try to make me feel like a fool?"
"Good day to you, <sir/madam>."
"I have heard a few tales about you since I came to this part of the world. I used to dream of having tales told about me."
"It was another <class> such as yourself that convinced me to leave my homeland and enter this 'civilized' world."
"But I'm sure you don't want to hear about my struggles. You must have enough of your own."
"Goodbye, <sir/madam>."
"Then I shall shoulder my burden alone."
"That is very kind. It is just such a response that is the source of my problems though."
"I was content to live in my forest and tend to nature, solitary, yet not lonely; until I met Aragati."
"He was a half-elf <class> who caught me meditating by a small brook. I thought he might be there to harm me, but he simply sat and stared at me for over an hour."
"I see that patience is not your greatest strength. I will waste no more of your time then."
"You must have thought I had some quest or job for you, but I have only a philosophical quandary, which I am sure would not interest you."
"When I finally spoke, he told me that he once was a prince, but had decided to try living as one of his subjects."
"Once he sampled from the variety of life, he couldn't get enough. He dedicated the rest of his life to trying something new as often as he could."
"I thought about it for a long time and then decided that I needed to emerge from my retreat and sample the world. And you know what I have found?"
"Then why did you ask me?"
"As much as I love nature, I love the bustle of the city as well. Everyone leads a life that is as important to him or her as storing nuts is to a squirrel."
"And so I find myself in a quandary. How can I reconcile my life as a druid, to a life in the city?"
"I'm not looking for an answer from you. The answer must come from within me. But thank you for your time."
"You must have thought I had some quest or job for you, but I have only a philosophical quandary, which obviously does not interest you."
"Not everything needs an outer reward. sometimes the reward is entirely internal. I am sorry to have wasted your time."
"<FirstName>, it has been a great pleasure talking to you. Please allow me to give you a small gift."
"May your travels make you wiser and your life be rich and full. For the stretch of a day, I gift you the strength of the bull."
"The balance favor you, <FirstName>."
"Durnan asked for your help. Some of us will stay up here in case they come from outside as well."
"Good friend, may all your tender roots find purchase, that you may grow in greatness."
"Look inside yourself and try to find improvements. Only then will you find contentment."
"I speak to those who show they have manners, not to children who have learned none."
"I heard that Durnan is going to be making an announcement soon. I hope this means I'll be able to head down into Undermountain."
"No thanks. Goodbye."
"What you mean?"
"What do you mean?"
"Thank you."
"No, you be wrong."
"No. You are mistaken."
"Yes, how you know?"
"Yes, how'd you know?"
"Yes, me be <him/her>."
"Yes, that is I."
"Goodbye."
"True. Me no want more stuff to worry 'bout."
"True. I really don't want to know."
"True. Me gots troubles. But me likes to hear yours anyways."
"True, I have troubles; but sometimes it helps to share them."
"Hurry tale and tell problem."
"Hurry up and explain your problem."
"Him sound strange."
"That would be strange."
"Me no care."
"I don't care."
"You hate it."
"You like it?"
"Me not know."
"I have no idea."
"That be it? Me listen to you for no reason?"
"That's it? I listened to all that for no reason?"
"You welcome, me thinks."
"You're welcome, I guess."
The woman's eyes flutter open and she looks around with a great deal of surprise and slowly dawning horror. Her face goes pale as she realizes where she is.
She looks at you a bit archly and visibly bites back a response. "Ask away, then," she says curtly.
The woman peers at you closely. "Of course. You were there with us during the fight. You're <FullName>, the hero that Durnan was waiting for."
The bard peers at you closely. "Of course. You... you're <FullName>. The hero that Durnan was waiting for."
"There was a fight when we chased that beholder down here... and I was hit by a poisoned arrow and killed." She nods slowly. "I remember now. Thank you for bringing me back."

The bard seems slightly surprised and arches an eyebrow, studying you. "Are you serious? Most of my equipment appears to have been taken. I'm hardly in a state to be of much help to you, <FirstName>."
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> "Well, I must admit I didn't want to stop the adventure this early in Undermountain." She shrugs, grinning. "Lead on, then!"

"Hmm. You needn't resort to blackmail, you know... it's not as if you need to twist my arm to get me to want to see more of Undermountain." She thinks for a moment and then shrugs. "So be it. Lead on!"
She looks at your companions, grinning. "Oh, I think you've got more than enough help right now. You don't need me tagging along, I'm sure."
She frowns and thinks about it for a moment. "Well... I suppose I could go back to the inn. I've no illusions about being able to make it through Undermountain on my own."
She studies you carefully with a steely gaze. "That'd be an awful waste of good magic, wouldn't it? I'm no match for you... just let me go."
She edges away from you slowly, trying to judge if you're serious, and then slowly relaxes. "Very well."
"That won't be as easy as you seem to think!"
She arches a brow at you and crosses her arms. "What would you like, exactly? It seems most of my equipment is gone, and I haven't a spell left until I rest again. Shall I sing you a song?"
She frowns for a moment, and then her face softens and she grins. "Of course I'm grateful. Do you really think I would rather be lying there on the floor forever?"
She frowns for a moment, and then her face softens. "Of course I'm grateful." Smiling, she kisses you on the forehead. "Do you really think I would rather be lying there on the floor forever?"
"So should I go back to the inn, now? Unless you've other plans for me?"
Both of her eyebrows come up as she stares at you incredulously, now. "You can't possibly mean what I think you mean. Here? In the middle of Undermountain? With you?"
"I see." She studies you sternly for a long moment. "Please forgive me if I don't roll in the corridors with laughter. I was just dead, if you'll recall."
She stops to gather a few of her belongings which were scattered around her body. "I'll head back to Durnan's inn. I think I can find the way from here... it's not as if I got very far."
She stops to look at you seriously. "For what it's worth, you have my gratitude. I hope things go well for you down here."
"Indeed?" She appears quite flustered, not sure if she should believe you. "Just like that? To reward you for saving me? That's what you want? How romantic."
"Well, you'll just have to forgive me if I'm not ready to lie down and be ravished in exchange for your rescue. If that's all you wanted, you should have left me there."
"I wish I could help you. We chased the beholder into this area. There wasn't really time for me to look around much, I'm afraid."
"I've no idea. If my companions had been victorious, surely Linu would have raised me. They wouldn't have abandoned me here." She thinks again. "Well, Tomi maybe... but never Linu or Daelan."
"I can only assume they fled further into the dungeon... or died, perhaps." She shudders visibly at that thought. "Just some more adventurer bones to add to the pile down here. I hope not."
"I'm not certain, exactly. We were chasing after the beholder and had almost caught up to it, when suddenly it veered about and arrows started firing upon us from the shadows."
She nods. "It happened very quickly, so I did not even see who attacked us, but I think you're right. We should not have acted so recklessly, it seems."
"My name is Sharwyn, a bard most recently from Neverwinter. There were four of us... companions all... who chased after the beholder in Durnan's cellar."

She nods quickly, looking about to study the paths nearby. "I should be able to find my way back to the entrance without too much trouble." She snorts with derision. "It's not as if I got very far in, did I?"
"Well, you have my sincere thanks for saving me. This may not be the most epic moment of my life, but at least it's not the last. Good luck. If you need me, you'll find me at the inn... I hope!"
Sharwyn notices your approach and smiles warmly. She seems to have cleaned herself up considerably from the state you found her in back in the dungeon.
"It is really good to see you again, <FirstName>. I hope everything is going well?"
She nods. "Good, I'm glad. I've been keeping the folks here entertained in the mean-time... they're all a bit frightened. I hope you succeed down there."
"I can try. Let me have a look through what you have... I'll let you know if there's anything that I can tell you much about."
She grins broadly. "I thought you'd never ask!"
She grins. "I'd like to, <FirstName>, but you've got more than enough help, it seems... and these people here need me, too."
"I'm sure you'll do well enough without me, won't you? I must admit I'm flattered, anyway."
Sharwyn notices you approach and stiffens, frowning. She does not appear pleased to see you in the slightest.
She rolls her eyes and turns away from you, but says nothing.
A flush rolls up her neck and she turns away from you, silent but obviously furious.
She rolls her eyes at you. "Am I that transparent? Why don't you go back to being a hero and leave me alone?"
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> She snorts with derision. "Not likely. Just go and do whatever you have to... we've no reason to talk, anyway."
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> She seems reluctant, but finally grins. "You did save my life. I guess I shouldn't hold it against you, still. Fine. You're forgiven."
"Good luck. Waterdeep is counting on you, <FirstName>."
"Quiet. I'll ask the questions, here."
"That's not important. You died and I just raised you."
"The name is <FirstName>. You were in the tavern, weren't you?"
"You don't remember me? I spoke to your group at the tavern."
"You don't remember me? We spoke at the tavern."
"How about you join me?"
"True enough. Go back to the inn, then."
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> "I could still use your help, regardless."
"I think your assistance would be fair exchange for saving you."
"What are you going to do now?"
"Go on back to the inn, and fare you well."
"You won't be going anywhere, I'm afraid. Time to die... again."
"Go on, get out of here, then."
"I raised you, I can put you back." <StartAction>[Kill her.]</Start>
"This is all the thanks I get for bringing you back to life?"
"Fine. I feel the need to kill you again, I think."
"Just some simple gratitude would be nice."
"Other plans? You mean such as killing you again?"
"No, that's fine. Go back to the inn."
"Well... you *are* rather cute..."
"Turning me down, eh? Maybe you need to die again."
"Of course I'm not serious! Ha ha ha!"
"No, I don't mean *here*. Maybe back at the inn?"
"Why not? You should do so well."
"Well how about I settle for just a 'thank you' for now?"
"Fine, have it your way. Run along, then."
"Ha ha! I'm just kidding! You look so serious!"
"That's what I want. I don't have time for real romance."
"I can always return you to that state and leave you for the next adventurer to wander by."
"Why don't you come with me, instead?"
"Is there anything you can tell me about this area?"
"Do you know where the rest of your group is?"
"What happened to you, exactly?"
"An ambush?"
"Tell me who you are."
"I'll be moving on, then."
"Where are your companions now? Do you know?"
"Things are going well enough."
"I have some items I don't recognize... could you identify them?"
"I was hoping you'd consider joining me."
"Take a flying leap off the roof, bard."
"Seeing how quickly you drop dead, I'm surprised to see you alive, too."
"Not happy to see me, I take it?"
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> "I hope you'll accept my apology for the way I acted down there."
"I should go."
An elegantly dressed mage is busily reading from an ancient, crumbling text, but he smiles at you as you approach.
"Of course my shop is actually closed right now, but a visit from such a famous adventurer is too good an opportunity to miss. Maybe I will write you into one of my plays!"
"A connoisseur of the arts! Oh, a true hero after my own heart. Well, let me tell you, I have not yet published anything of the creative bent, though I have started many a wonderful project."
"(Sigh). It seems that I just never have enough time, what with all the work I do at the University of Waterdeep."
"Oh, well I am famous around magical theory circles. Or, at least I was famous until those cretins burned the building down."
"Oh, how rude of me. I am the mage, Sobrey, an instructor of the magical arts at the University of Waterdeep, Sage of Soothsayers Way, and proprietor of this fine establishment."
"Or, at least I was an instructor, before those cretins burned down my part of the school."
"We were one of the first places to be attacked by the drow and duergar. They were savage, brutish monsters. They put the entire School of Magic at the university to the torch."
"It was simply awful. They almost killed me, you know?"
"Um... well... no. I was supposed to be there, but I had some last minute business to attend to here at my shop."
"I got rather involved and by the time I returned, the fight had moved on and the building was in ruins."
"Well, I was not actually there at the time, but they did kill a number of my friends. You can imagine how terrible it was for me to go back and see all the devastation."
"Several of my students died in the laboratory where I taught. We found their bodies, dead and mangled around the corpse of a young cockatrice they had helped hatch only weeks before."
"I know it probably sounds strange to you, but the way they protected that creature... well... no mother could have possibly done more. And now they're dead."
"I have barely been able to sleep since. That was why I created the magical telescope, in the hopes it would help me come to grips with the attack on the university."
"Feel free to use the telescope whenever you wish to observe the details of the brutal attack. It might help to strengthen your resolve against our enemy."
"But I'm sure you have more important things ahead of you, too. Perhaps I might have something you would find useful."
"I have all sorts of magical items at my disposal, and a share of all profits go to assist the rebuilding of the university. Would you like to see my wares?"
"Ah, well, if you should change your mind, I will remain here. Farewell and may the gods watch over you on your perilous journey."
"(Oh, that is good stuff. I shall really have to write this all down someday.)"
"Good! I will take that as a promise! We shall both be famous; yes, indeed."
"Oh... well... perhaps you shall change your mind later. (Sigh) I suppose this must happen to bards too, sometimes."
"Okay, here you go."
"Wonderful! I am so glad you agree."
"You shall be famous for deeds and I shall be famous for words! And they told me I would never make it as a bard!"
"Well, I guess you are here to buy something, so I shall show you my wares."
"Okay. Good luck, hero!"
"Have a look then."
"Goodbye."
Sobrey watches your expression as you look up from viewing the battle. "It was horrific, and the powerful items they stole... I shudder at the thought of our enemies wielding such power."
"I fear that with such deadly attacks on the city, we shall find ourselves undermined and easy prey for the creatures of the Underdark."
"Of course. Goodbye."
"All I know are rumors and legends. I do know that there is supposed to be a way down into the Underdark, through Undermountain."

"That is not my area of expertise, I fear. It is a dark dungeon, created by a wizard of undeniable power and destructive insanity. If Halaster is not in league with our opponents, then he is overcome by them."
"It is the stuff of nightmares to think that one so strong as he might have fallen. If his power could be bested, then I fear for all our lives."
"The strikes against our fair city have been fast and deadly. They are obviously well planned and executed with discipline."
"I assure you, should they continue, and the war not be taken to them, Waterdeep will fall."
"Everything magical that the mages of the university had made or were studying. Most likely there were even a few powerful artifacts, though I am not sure what they would be."
"If you recover any, I am sure the school would love to have them back."
"You write plays? How wonderful. What is your name? Maybe I have heard of you."
"Oh, well, keep trying, perhaps someday you will be famous."
"Oh, well I am not really interested then. I thought maybe you were famous."
"Who are you?"
"You have the advantage of me. What is your name?"
"What are you talking about?"
"I heard something about that. What happened exactly?"
"I guess you were lucky then."
"Were you in the battle there?"
"How did you escape?"
"Enough with the stories. Do you have any goods to sell?"
"It was a monster; get over it."
"Everyone has experienced loss from this war."
"I am sorry for your loss."
"Not right now. I am not really interested."
"Yes, please, show me what you have."
"This happened during the attack?"
"Whatever. Just show me your wares."
"I do not think so. I am just here to look at your wares."
"When this is all done. I would love for you to record my deeds."
"No thanks."
"Good idea."
"No. Goodbye."
"Yes."
"Goodbye."
"Can you tell me more about this attack."
"What can you tell me about the Underdark?"
"What can you tell me about Undermountain?"
"Waterdeep is stronger than that."
"What kind of items did they steal?"
An ancient-looking man looks up at you from his chair and you wonder how he stays mobile in his full plate armor.
"Am I so old that I am of no use to anyone? I've been exploring Undermountain longer than anyone else in this city."
"I sacrificed everything to stand for justice and hunt the wickedness that lay beneath Waterdeep, and now they tell me I'm too old to fight for her!"
"What ever."
His body seems to cave into itself. "When they open the streets again. Then I shall go home and die."
"Now leave me be."
His eyes brighten a little. "You want to hear about Undermountain? Really? I would really love... I mean, I would be honored to help you."
"Everyone always tells of how Undermountain is constantly changing, but there is one secret that could help you out."
"There is one thing that never changes about Undermountain; its creator."
"Halaster is even older than I am, and he's been controlling Undermountain for centuries."
"It took me decades to figure it out, but now I can predict some of Undermountain."
"Don't get me wrong, you can't just walk into Undermountain and predict what will be in the next room; it doesn't work that way."
"But if you walk into a room and you see a giant throne and a sarcophagus, you can bet your life that there is more than undead involved in this puzzle."
"Chances are, one of those objects is a transporter of some sort, either to bring monsters in, or for you to get to another area."
"I think it has something to do with the idea that death is a journey. I could be wrong."
"I don't understand Halaster, not really. I just know the patterns now."
His face flushes red and his shoulders straighten with pride. "That's not the only suggestion I can make."
"There are some little things, like watch out for mirrors. They almost always hide something; some times something good, often something very bad."
"And greed is a dangerous, often fatal flaw in Undermountain."
"Then you are exactly the kind of adventurer Halaster loves to kill. He'll start off by teasing you with a small treasure."
"Far more so in Undermountain. Halaster counts on adventurers being greedy. He starts by offering a little treasure."
"Often little traps will start with a small treasure, to make you think there must be more."
"Then there will be a little danger, but nothing you can't handle. If you continue, eventually the big trap will be set off."
"That's where most adventurers die. Of course, surviving the big trap can sometimes mean big rewards; notice I said sometimes."
"Halaster tends to enjoy rewarding those who entertain him."
"But, I think he also finds entertainment in watching an adventurer go through a really tough fight and open a treasure chest to find useless garbage."
"Still, if you persevere, Undermountain is a great place to make a living."
"Farewell, <lad/lass>. May you choose your path wisely."
His eyes twinkle in a satisfied way. "Thank you, <lad/lass>. It is my duty and my pleasure to assist you."
"Tyr protect you on your journey."
"Well, that's all I can think of for now. Maybe I'll remember more later."
He snorts a derisive laugh. "What world are you living in <boy/girl>? Durnan has forbidden me to go down there."
"No, I am too old. I am just fooling myself. It hurts just to swing my sword for a short period of time. I'll never be of use again."
"I suppose so. Leave me to my aged thoughts, young hero."
An ancient-looking man looks up at you from his chair. "I don't understand why Durnan didn't call for my aid. Who else can he trust to fight for justice?"
The old paladin looks up at you with a bleary, tear-stained face.
"Leave an old man to his reminiscing. No one needs me anymore."
The old paladin smiles proudly at you. "None of those vermin will harm the occupants of this house while I'm on duty!"
An ancient-looking man looks up at you from his chair. "Eh, you aren't Durnan! I'm waiting for Durnan to call me to arms."
"Goodbye."
"You be too old. You go home!"
"You are too old. Why not just go home?"
"You help me by tell me 'bout Undermountain."
"You could help me by telling me about Undermountain."
"Halaster?"
"Who?"
"Me always hear Undermountain no predictable."
"I've always been told Undermountain is unpredictable."
"That stupid. Me was hoping for something me could use."
"That's stupid. I was hoping for something useful."
"Why it be like that?"
"Why would it be that way?"
"That smart idea, thanks."
"Useful tip, thanks."
"Me like greedy. It make me wealthy."
"My greed has served me well so far."
"It usually be flaw anywhere."
"It usually is anywhere."
"How so?"
"Me notice."
"I noticed."
"Sometime no reward?"
"Sometimes there is nothing?"
"Goodbye."
"Thanks for help me."
"Thanks for the help."
"You know more stuff?"
"Anything else?"
"Like what?"
"You no too old. Go fight!"
"You aren't too old. Get down there and fight!"
"Well, me tried. If you think you be too old, then you be so."
"Well, I tried. If you think you're too old, then maybe you are."
The halfling blinks several times, stares at you with wide and incredulous eyes and then looks around for several confused seconds before finally speaking.
"One of these days I'm going to bloody well piss off them death gods for teasin' them all th' time." He looks at you and blinks again. "Say, you look familiar."
"Oh, sure, sure. Everybody gots questions. Last time some old hag raised me, she sticks her ugly face right in mine and asks 'where does it hurt?'. 'My eyes!', I screams, 'my eyes!".
"Of course, then she goes and casts some spell on me to cure me of bloody blindness. That's the clergy for ya... they never quite gets it, do they?"
"Well, do ya want me to answer your bloody questions or do ya want me to shut me trap? Make up your mind, sheesh."
"Yes, that would be nice, wouldn't it? Linu keeps hintin' at that, all polite-like. Strange gal, that. Clumsier than a drunk minotaur."
"You think that's disrespectful? Gosh, I wouldn't want to tell ya about the time I hit the High Priest of Mask in the head with a giant custard. Boy, that was sweet!"
"Well, there ya have it. I rest my case."

"You says that like it doesn't happen very often. Shoot, I've found myself dead in stranger places than this. That time I died in Hellgate Keep when I was in that dress... now that required some fast talkin'."
"But anyway... you looks familiar to me, somehow. You's the daughter of the fella that runs the inn, ain'tcha? Tamsin or somethin', aye?"
"But anyway... you looks familiar to me, somehow. You's that fella who runs the inn, right? Starts with a 'D' or somethin'?"
"Right, right. And you, ummm... you're the daughter of that fella who runs the inn, ain'tcha? Tamsin or somethin', aye?"
"Right, right. And you, ummm... you're that fella who runs the inn, right? Starts with a 'D' or somethin'?"
"Wait a minute... you're the <man/woman> who's so famous <he/she>'s got everyone's knickers in a twist. I remember, now."
"Mmm. That would be a no, I take it? You should see me tryin' ta guess some lass's name the mornin' after."
"Oh, right, the famous one. Well, I guess there's a reason after all why everybody was whisperin' all excited-like that you were showin' up."
"I guess it don't get much better than bein' saved by a professional, aye? Thanks a bunch. That was real swell of ya."
"Hey, hey! Bloody well slow down for a minute, will ya? Ya can't just raise a fella and then trot off while he's still figurin' out he's got a heartbeat, ya know."
"Eh? I don't bloody know. Let's not give a fella a few moments ta reflect on the fact that he's just cheated death one more time, aye?"
"Let's not give a fella a few moments ta reflect on the fact that he's just cheated death one more time, aye? Hmph. At any rate, I know what happened to 'em... for the most part."
"How do ya think I ended up here? First there was the running, then there was the stabbing." He rubs his chest absently. "You sure there's no holes left, still?"
"You mean ya don't already know? I would have thought that's why ya brought me back ta life... ta meet the world-famous Tomi Undergallows!"
"I see ya don't have any of my friends trottin' around with ya at the moment. Didja happen to find Linu, at least?"
"You got yourself a point there, aye. Can't say I'm not just a bit glad that ya decided to rescue *me* while you were trottin' around down here."
"Huh. Well, we got away from the drow who were chasin' us, right? An' we found some human slaves down here who naturally begged for our help an' such."
"I didn't really like the look of 'em, but Linu's little heart started bloody bleedin' all over the place an' she just had to help 'em get out somehow."

"That's why I came here. According to the slaves, the drow here had some djinni that can activate a portal the slaves were at an' let them out. Don't matter to me none if ya just leaves 'em be, though."
"Oh, well that's good. Hopefully she took 'em slaves with her, too. She was so bloody determined ta help 'em it was drivin' me nuts."
"That's why I came here lookin' for the djinni the drow had, right? An' you can see how that turned out."
"Hah! So them slaves did pick her off, just like I thought they would. I warned her, ya know. Ummm... say, why didn't ya bring her back ta life if ya found her?"
"Is that so? Huh. I'd be welling to bet 50 gold that she wasn't a rak-whatever earlier. Are ya sure the real Linu wasn't somewhere near?"
"Not that it's a big deal ta me or nothin'. Linu was so bloody sure they was poor slaves she made me come here ta look for the djinni ta help them... an' you can see what came of that."
"Hmmm. I was thinkin' I might just head back to the inn. Unless ya think ya got room for a smart-mouthed halfling in your entourage, aye?"
"Right, then. Suit yourself."
"Right, then. All I need is a weapon an' some armor an' whatever else ya can spare an' I can visit some halfling death on everyone who so much as bugs ya! Ha ha!!"
"Hmmm. I was thinkin' I might just head back to the inn. Skulkin' round down here's fun an' all, but dyin' tends to take the wind outta me sails, ya know what I mean?"
"At any rate, don't let me keep ya or nothin'. I can find my way back to the inn easy. See ya there if ya needs anything from me, aye?"

"Hmph. Them elves got ears like ya wouldn't believe. Hear a feather hittin' the ground, they would. I suppose it didn't help none that I was tryin' to steal their jewelry while they was still wearin' it."
"They're in some big chamber off in the eastern part of the dungeon. There's a portal there, ya see, which they thought would take 'em outta here... if they got the djinni, first."
"Them slaves said the drow had some bottle that summoned a djinni. Said it could open their portal for 'em. Why? Didn't ya find anything?"
"Oh, so ya did find her, then. Yeah, she's determined to help 'em folks out... never mind that it's just the two of us stuck in this deadly dungeon, right?"
"I see ya found Linu. Sorry I couldn't get the bottle back to ya, luv. Does your poor human folks still need it?"
"Umm... not exactly, dear. It's a bit of a long story, however..."
"Ahhh, don't tell me. I didn't want ta hear it the first time, 'cept you were so bloody broken-hearted about them bein' stuck here an' all."
"I see ya managed to find some of the folks we, ah, kind of left behind. No hard feelings, aye? Linu and I were a bit pre-occupied at the time."
"If Linu was forced to leave us behind, I trust that there was sufficient urgency that made it necessary."
"Aye, we were a bit over-powered, ta say the least. Which all just goes to prove that ya don't need to run very fast... ya just needs mates who are slower than you are."
"I'll have to remember that. Hold still while I hobble you, runt."
"Heh heh... funny, that. Mmmm."
"Hmmm... come ta think of it, didja happen to find Linu while you were bouncin' around down here, maybe?"
"Are you saying it would be more prudent of me to remove your kneecaps, then?"
"Yes, I remember. The running, and the screaming..."
Tomi grins widely as he sees you coming. Currently he appears to be stuffing his face with a wedge of cheese and a chunk of bread as large as his head.
He shrugs. "Have it your way, I guess. Good luck down there, aye?"
"Yeah? Could'a fooled me. Hmmm... wonder if the kitchen's got more gruel, yet?"
"Ahhhh, that's too bad. You needs Tomi helpin' ya, that's what. I'm the original lucky charm, ya know... just, ummm, less horseshoe-shaped."
"Well, good! Then maybe we can all get outta this joint soon enough an' move onto better things. Keep it up, aye?"
"Quiet. I have some questions."
"Silence! I did not raise you to hear you prattle on!"
"I would expect more thanks for bringing you back from the dead."
"You should not be so disrespectful of the devout."
"What?"
"What's important is that I just brought you back from the dead."
"Do I? You were part of that group back at the inn, right?"
"I should. You were with that group I talked to in the inn."
"Don't you remember who I am? We spoke at the inn."
"Perhaps dying again would jog your memory."
"Are you kidding me?"
"No, my name is <FirstName>."
"I should move on."
"What are you going to do, now?"
"Don't you wonder what happened to the rest of your group?"
"How did you end up here?"
"Just who are you, anyway?"
"Does it really matter? I'm not here to rescue any of you."
"No, I haven't found her. Why?"
"I found her, yes, and sent her back to the inn."
"I found her, yes, but she's dead. Just as you were."
"I found a rakshasa pretending to be her."
"What are you going to do, now?"
"Not a chance."
"I don't think so, no."
"I could use your help, sure."
"So how did the drow catch you?"
"So where are these slaves you mention?"
"What's this about a djinni?"
"I found her with some slaves. She's determined to help them."
"No thanks."
"Sure, come along."
"I am not your personal savior."
"Not so well, I'm afraid."
"It's going well, so far."
"I could use your help, actually."
This elegantly dressed, well manicured, beautiful woman smiles at you.
"A list of men I need to conquer and... well," she licks her lips, "I'm sure you get the idea."
"Yes, of course. Let's get right to business: I have a gift here for you. Something to help you on your quest."
"But pleasures must be denied in such trying times."
"Sure I can, darling. I'm a priestess of Sune, Goddess of Beauty. Besides, I wouldn't do anything more than look and... heal, without your permission."
"I'm a priestess of Sune, Goddess of Beauty. Our goddess's first desire is to find beauty and make it hers. I, as her follower, must do the same. "
"But, I suppose that's not why I'm here. Durnan called upon my temple for help, so I came. He seems to think I might have items that could aid you on your quest."
"Goodbye, <FirstName>. I do hope we get the chance to meet again later."
"I've all manner of wares devoted to the healing arts. Normally I'd expect a large donation for each of them, but given the circumstances I'll just need enough gold to cover their basic cost."

"First I have something for you. A gift from my temple to aid those defending Waterdeep. I was saving it until Durnan had organized his expedition into Undermountain, but it looks like you're the only one left."
"It's a Rod of Resurrection - an item of such power it can actually raise the dead. Based on all the rumors about Undermountain you're going to need it."
"Those four eager souls who charged on ahead likely have need of its power, so don't be afraid to use it on them if you stumble across their bodies. The Rod has several charges."
"Really? You might want to reconsider that attitude. Undermountain is a dangerous place, and few are brave enough to venture into its depths."

"If you find the remains of one of those brave adventurers and restore them to life, they might be wiling to help you in your quest. I doubt you'll find many others who will accompany you into Undermountain."
"Now let me show you the rest of my items. Normally I'd ask a large donation for each of them, but since you're trying to save the city I'll only need enough to cover their base cost."
She laughs a high, girlish laugh, "Ah, so young, so eager; I do think I like you. But I suppose we really must keep our mind on saving the city rather than on more... interesting... topics."
"Of course. It would be a pleasure to answer any questions you might have."
"No more than you, I suspect. I've heard you were attacked in your own bed." She arches her eyebrows. "That's why I'm careful to make sure I never sleep alone."
"Very little. A dark and dangerous place. Normally I find both danger and the dark to be very... stimulating. But Undermountain is a little too dark and dangerous for my taste."
"You should speak to Durnan about this. Or maybe Tanarell, the old paladin upstairs. He used to adventure into Undermountain, though he's not nearly as adventurous as I was hoping."
She gives you a mischievous grin. "I spoke with him earlier and he wasn't the least bit interested in exploring with me."
She gives you a coy smile. "What an absolutely delicious thing to say."
"But I am sure there are more important, albeit less entertaining, things to talk about."
"Sune knows that beauty comes in many forms, and there's a lot to be said for experience. Unfortunately, he told me it wouldn't be proper..."
"The followers of Sune worship beauty in all its forms. We desire to possess those things we recognize as beautiful, and we aren't afraid to express this desire."
"Of course, <FirstName>. Just stand still, this won't hurt a bit. In fact, it should feel quite... pleasant."
"You know who I am?"
"Your list?"
"I don't have time for this. Durnan said you had something for me."
"Hey! You're a priestess, you can't act like that!"
"What kind of god do you follow?"
I'll be going now.
"Let me see what items you have."
"What is it?"
"If they're stupid enough to rush off, then they got what they deserved."
"Do you have anything else I could use?"
"If I come across their bodies, I'll be sure to try and help them."
"That's too bad."
"Sounds interesting. We'll have to try that sometime."
"I want to ask you some questions."
"Do you know anything about these attacks?"
"What do you know about Undermountain?"
"What do you mean by that?"
