The rat's nose twitches and his eyes blink as he looks at you, then he moves on, casually sniffing the floor.
The rat stares up at you with eyes that seem as old as Undermountain itself. Images flash through your mind in rapid succession.
You see bones and rotting flesh, glittering objects that fascinate the rat, and more than any other image or emotion, you sense the constant struggle to survive.
The rat scurries off.
A warm feeling of gratitude emanates from the rat.
You get the distinct impression that the rats wants you to follow close behind him, so he can show you something.
It squeaks in fear and starts to run away.
The rat nods and moves away.
You get the impression that the rat has what it considers to be its own treasure, but where that might be, it isn't telling right now.
You see images of a large group of creatures moving through the dungeon and killing many of its inhabitants.
The rat is obviously terrified of the army that attacked Waterdeep. It seems to think of the army as coming from east of here.
Leave the rat.
Feed the rat some seeds.
Attack the rat.
"Me will follow you."
"I will follow you."
Focus on the images of the glittering objects.
Focus on the images of death and decay.
The ogre wrinkles his brow and bares his teeth in what could only vaguely be called a smile. It is a frightening smile to say the least.
The ogre chuckles deep in his throat. "Yes, yes, I know; I am supposed to sound vacant-minded, like 'Me crush you good!'. But I only play on the stereotype to keep my enemies off guard."
"Being a powerful wizard, you'd think people would realize I'm also highly intelligent. But they see this body and assume the worst. My enemies tend to underestimate me. Except for you, of course."
"I suppose it is safe to assume that my forces have been devastated beyond repair, so it seems that oversized fairy will rule this level after all. What are your terms of surrender?"
"I've no desire to serve as your slave, my good <sir/madam>. Understandable, I'm sure. But you did defeat me, so you do have certain entitlements."
"Well, you defeated me quite handily. To the victor goes the spoils. You've spared my life, so you are entitled to certain compensations."
"So what I am proposing is that I answer any questions you have, and then you allow me to live. I assure you, I'll scurry off somewhere so that you never have to deal with me again."
The ogre sighs. "I suspected this would end in bloodshed. My luck just seems to be working out that way right now. Very well, let us duel this out to the bitter end."
Yes <sir/madam>! I lay my vast repertoire of facts and speculation at your feet in a most humble and undeserving way.
"My resources are at your disposal. What question can I answer for you?"
"I knew you were an honorable <man/woman>. I thank you for my life, and I wish you luck while you are in this twisted labyrinth of death."
"There was a passage leading down, though I couldn't tell you where it is, exactly. Undermountain has a habit of changing, you see. Things move every so often. Halaster likes to keep us off-balance.
"But the tunnel is collapsed, in any case. During one of my battles with the Fairy Queen's forces a spell I unleashed caved it in, sealing it with tons of rock."
The ogre rubs his chin in deep thought for a few seconds. "I suppose you could blast your way through the debris. Yes, that might be possible given the resources of this level..."
"You might be able to find a keg of alchemist's fire....those have quite a nice explosion. Halaster kept a few of them stashed around down here."
"Now, is there anything else?"
"Well, if you are careful to put the ingredients together in the right mixtures, there's an excellent chance the explosion could be controlled. I'm fairly confident it won't kill you."
"Undermountain is the plaything of Halaster the Mad, an archmage of immense power. As you can guess from his name, he's also a bit unbalanced. That's probably why this place is so strange."
"Halaster probably knew adventurers would flock to this place, so he stocked its halls with a bizarre assortment of creatures, traps and treasure. I imagine he enjoys watching people in his maze."
"Or, to be more precise, I should say I imagine he used to enjoy watching people. Now that he's gone I doubt he's paying much attention to events here."
"My name is Olgin Hasterean, a powerful ogre mage from a tribe in the Turmish mountains. Among my own people I was regarded as something of an aberration for my intelligence."
"The others of my own tribe were simple brutes. They feared me and my magic, and I ruled them like a king. Until Halaster brought me here against my will, though I'm not sure why I was chosen."
"Maybe Halaster felt an intelligent ogre would be a fitting addition to his menagerie of creatures. Or maybe he wanted a leader for the other ogres he had running around in his maze."
"Whatever the reason, I was transported without warning from my home in the Turmish mountains to this level of Undermountain. I've been here ever since."
"There's no escape from Undermountain. You can go deeper into its depths if you wish, but you can't actually leave. Halaster doesn't permit it."
"At least, he didn't permit it while he was around. Now that he's gone, the rules have changed somewhat. That's why I thought I could take over this level. The Fairy Queen must have thought so, too."
"Well, shatter my skull! I just assumed that you were an agent of the Fairy Queen, sent to best my army. This is a far superior situation."
"Recently Undermountain has undergone a fundamental shift in the paradigms of power. Needless to say, I sought to capitalize on this change."
"I began to recruit followers and spread my influence through this level. Apparently this Fairy Queen had a similar plan. It was inevitable our respective minions would clash."
"I had thought this war would end quickly, but her fey powers to charm and dominate have prolonged the hostilities."
"Not so much a shift, really. More like a vacuum. Halaster used to keep us all in line, but now that he's gone it's anarchy."
"Yes, he just seems to have vanished. I couldn't begin to guess where or why, but I do know that the spells he had in place to control the creatures here in Undermountain have vanished with him."
"Once I realized Halaster was in absentia, I decided to try and increase my own power by seizing control of this level of Undermountain. Apparently the Fairy Queen had similar ideas."
The ogre raises a large, shaggy eyebrow. "The fey is beaten? Truly?"
"That is good to know, though I'd rather she was dead entirely. Still, if her power has been broken I can at least take satisfaction in the knowledge she did not succeed where I failed."
"Had I only known that you defeated her, my followers would have let you past and I would have congratulated you. Instead, you've slaughtered my followers - and hers, I imagine."
"I suppose our folly has left the level quite barren now. I've no desire to rule a kingdom of corpses. Perhaps I should leave Undermountain and return to my home in the Turmish mountains."
"I want to ask you some questions."
"You're pretty well spoken, for an ogre."
"Are you sure you're an ogre? You don't sound like one."
"I think it's time for you to die now."
"I defeated you. Now you are my slave."
"What do you mean, 'terms'?"
"I'd rather just kill you."
"Answer my questions now and I'll decide what to do with you after."
"Um... sure."
"You're free to go."
"Tell me about this Fairy Queen you mentioned."
"Do you know how to get down below this level?"
"How do I do that?"
"And bring Waterdeep down on my head?"
"What do you know about Undermountain?"
"Who are you? How did you end up here?"
"Didn't you ever try to escape?"
"What fairy?"
"Don't get too excited. You are still in my power."
"Tell me about this Fairy Queen."
"You mentioned a power shift in Undermountain?"
"Halaster is gone?"
"The Fairy Queen is defeated."
"Enough. It's time to answer some questions."
"Her forces are destroyed, though I allowed her to live."
"I killed her myself."
"That will be tough, considering I plan to kill you."
"I have some questions for you first."
There is a loud clang and the door opens.
This door is presently barred from the other side but shows signs of recent use. Perhaps it can be opened somehow.
"Fight them all!"
"You will never win!"
"Back! This realm belongs to us!"
"Attack! Attack!"
"The fairy queen rules!"
"The level is ours!"
"Fight! Kill them all!"
"For the sorceress!"
"Might makes right! Fight fight fight!!"
"We will have victory!"
"This level is ours!"
"Kill! Destroy!"
"The high mage rules us all!"
"Rahhr! We rule this place!"
"Crush their bones!"
"For the ogre!"
You almost believe that you saw the skeletal hand of this dead king move... but now that you look closely, it is surely still.
Approaching the skeleton in its seat, you almost get the sense that it is aware of you... but it does not move or respond, if that is the case.
Though you get quite close to the dust-covered skeleton, it does not move at all in response.
A faint flicker of cold light can be seen deep within the dead eye socket of the skeleton... but it does not move.
There is a hushed aura to this room that whispers of kings long dead. Long enough, perhaps, that even the names of the lands they once ruled have been forgotten.
As you approach the skeleton, you get an eerie feeling that this dead monarch only slumbers... that he would quickly arise to strike down any who disturbs him.
The dust in the room has been heavily disturbed. Obviously despite the quiet and the almost tomb-like feel of this chamber, these kings have risen before. Why they are still now, you do not know...
You hear drow talking to each other in the next room. They have found one of the chains and are preparing to search for the others...

You see your reflection in the mirror, but on the ground near your reflection's feet are many tantalizing objects, almost real enough to touch.
Your reflection in the mirror seems to have a forlorn look in its eyes, but when you look again, it is gone.

You see your reflection in the mirror, but on the ground near your reflection's feet are many tantalizing objects, almost real enough to touch. For an instant, you thought you saw a strange gleam in your reflection's eyes.
This is an entrance portal that Halaster uses to trap creatures in Undermountain.
Before you is seated the remains of a great king of man.
Humanoid tracks are scattered about the ground in this area.
Tracks of four humanoids pass through this corridor. From the markings you would guess that they passed fairly recently and at great pace.

You recognize these tracks as belonging to the four adventurers from the Yawning Portal - Linu, Sharwyn, Tomi and Daelan. They seemed to be moving at a run as the passed through this corridor very recently.
Humanoid tracks are scattered about the ground in this area.
A large humanoid seems to have run off in this direction in pursuit of a larger group of creatures.

You recognize these tracks as belonging to Daelan Red Tiger. He seems to have been pursuing a group of humanoids in this direction, and from the spacing between his footprints, he seemed to be showing no regard for his own personal safety.
Humanoid tracks are scattered about the ground in this area.
A large humanoid seems to have passed in this direction recently. These tracks seem familiar to you somehow.
You recognize these tracks as belonging to Daelan Red Tiger. He seems to have passed through this area fairly recently.
Humanoid tracks are scattered about the ground in this area.
A large humanoid seems to have passed in this direction recently. It was pursued by two other humanoids, but they were driven off by a larger group of creatures - you are 90% sure they were Drow.
You recognize these tracks as belonging to Linu and Tomi. They seemed to have started in pursuit of a large humanoid, probably Daelan, and then doubled back, pursued by what look like several Drow.
Humanoid tracks are scattered about the ground in this area.
A pair of humanoids moved through this area recently. They seemed to be moving cautiously, checking the area as they go.
You recognize these tracks as belonging to Linu and Tomi. They seemed to have passed through this area fairly recently, moving slowly and cautiously.

You recognize these tracks as belonging to Linu and Tomi. The tracks move cautiously around the portal that is in front of you, but do not lead away. They must have entered it and gone who knows where.

A pair of humanoids moved through this area recently. Their tracks lead down the stairs that beckon just in front of you.
You recognize these tracks as belonging to Linu and Tomi. They must have got past the colored pillars as well, as their tracks lead to the stairs in front of you that lead down.
Humanoid tracks are scattered about the ground in this area.
A pair of humanoids moved through this area recently. They seemed to have slowed almost to a stop at this point and spent some time cautiously looking around.

You recognize these tracks as belonging to Linu and Tomi. They seemed to have stopped short at this point and taken great care with something directly in front of them. The smaller one seems to have spent a bit of time checking something at floor level.

Come back here with that chain you little toad!
Aiiieeeeeee! Get away. It's mine... mine! My brudder Ugtump said I could keep da yellow chainsie.
Now that they've been marked, we'll see what Halaster's magic will do to them.
You sense a discharge of magical energies.
You sense a discharge of magical energies.
"Uh... wait. Just wait. You don't want to kill me. I can help you. I know stuff."
"You're just like all the rest - everyone's trying to kill me! I'll show you!"
"I ain't all that smart, you know. But I'll try to answer what I can."
"Oh, okay. Well... goodbye, I guess. I'll just stay here where it's safe until my dad gets free and puts things back to the way they were."
"I used to know everything about this place. Even when Halaster changed it around, he'd pull me aside and explain what he was up to. But now... now I don't know nothing!"
"Monsters fighting and killing, armies of drow running loose everywhere. That just ain't right."
"Everyone here used to treat me real nice, but nothing's the same since dad got snatched up. Now everyone here is trying to kill me!"
"I know he made me. At least, he told me that before the drow captured him. And I got no reason to think he's lying, seeing as how he's my dad and all."
The creature seems momentarily confused. "Oh... sorry. Halaster's always telling me to watch my manners. My name's Berger. Halaster is my dad."
"What do you mean by that? Do you think I'm lying? I don't lie! Halaster is so my father. He even told me so."
"Halaster made me. Told me he sewed me together himself. I helped him run this place. Everyone used to be real nice to me. They used to smile and nod and say: Hello, Berger."
"But now things ain't so nice. Ever since dad got snatched up, the others don't take such a shine to me. Them dark elves is especially bad."
"Hey, now that's just rude! You don't gotta be all mean and such. But don't worry... I ain't gonna hold it against you. At least you aren't trying to kill me like all the others."
"That's right. My dad's in the clutches of them... them dark skinned... pointy-eared... silver-haired... no good drow! Now they're after me, too!"
"Ever since they grabbed up my dad, them drow have been trompin' around Undermountain wherever they please. That's not right. Halaster doesn't like people just marching around here."
"But they can't kill dad, or Undermountain will come crashin' down around their ears. So they keep him alive. And when he gets out, he's going to be *mad*! Then them drow'll be sorry!"
"Aww, don't say that! Halaster's all I got in this world. I'd go after him myself, but I know I don't got any chance against them drow."
"Me? Uh... no. Wait! I could... no. Oh, I know! I'll just... no. I don't got no plan. I'm not real good at planning."
"But maybe you could help! You look real smart. And tough. I bet you could just smash them drow and rescue my dad easy!"
"Huh? Oh... you mean like a reward, don't you? Uh... well, I don't got nothing I can give you. But you have to help Halaster, you just have to! He'll fix everything then."
"You will? Yipee! I know you'll do it, too. I can tell just by looking at you."
"As soon as he's free again, he'll take care of those dark elves! He'll make them sorry they were mean to me. Them and all the others. They'll all be sorry. Real sorry."
"He'll put things right, like before. Monsters in Undermountain will stay in Undermountain, and them drow will be booted back down to the Underdark where they belong!"
"Aw, don't be that way. Once dad's free he'll put things right. Undermountain will be like it was before. Monsters will stay where they belong, and the drow won't be welcome here."
"Dad's down on the lower levels. Somewhere. I really don't know where. I been spending all my time running from the drow and the rest of the creatures here."
"He ain't insane! You just don't understand him 'cause he's so smart and all. Nobody does. But if you help him, he'll help you."
"Found the chains and thumped them drow, I bet. That'll learn them. Halaster's gonna be real proud of you for that."
"You're an abomination... time to die!"
"I'm done with you. Time to die."
"Okay, I'll let you live if you answer my questions."
"I'll be going now."
"What can you tell me about Undermountain?"
"Dad? You mean Halaster?"
"What do you know about Halaster?"
"What are you?"
"Funny. You look like a flesh golem to me."
"Halaster's your father?"
"I want to ask you something else."
"Creating something as annoying as you proves Halaster was insane."
"You said Halaster was a prisoner?"
"Halaster's a prisoner?"
"What if he never gets free?"
"Do you have a plan to free him?"
"What's in this for me if I help you?"
"Don't worry - I'll find a way to free Halaster."
"Forget it!"
"So where is Halaster being held?"
"Why would I save someone as insane as Halaster?"
"I found the four chains."
"I want to ask you some questions."
You here the sound of a door being unlocked somewhere...
You...you are the one from the prophecy...my mistress must be informed.
How did you get in here? No matter, I shall make short work of you!
You should speak to Shareesh. He is our leader here.
Shareesh says the portal can lead us to freedom. But without the activation stone we have no way to use it!
The Rakshasa you killed were our captors... and our protectors. Now we are defenseless. We must escape this place before the Drow discover us.
Shareesh says the Drow have invaded Undermountain. He thinks they may have captured Halaster himself!
Halaster's magic kept the peace in Undermountain, but since he disappeared, the creatures here have turned against each other.
I don't agree with a lot of things Shareesh says, but he's the one in charge. Nobody listens to what I have to say.
Everyone says the portal will lead us to freedom... but how do we know it isn't a trap?
When Halaster was running things down here, we knew there was no escape for us. But at least we didn't have to fear for our lives!
Most of the others are glad Halaster is gone, but I don't know. Is it better to be a slave to a wizard, or captured by the Drow?
The creatures in Undermountain used to get along fine, but now that Halaster isn't here to keep them in line...
You should speak to Shareesh in the other room. He's our leader.
Shareesh says the portal in the other room can get us out of here. I hope he's right.
Stay away from that sarcophagus over there. I don't know what's inside, but I don't want to find out.
The Drow never used to come through Undermountain. But now that Halaster's gone, I guess there's nothing left to stop them.
That cleric of Lathander says she'll stay here and protect us until we escape this place. If we ever escape this place.
You should speak to our leader, Shareesh. He's in the other room.
Shareesh thinks that portal in the other room can take us right to Waterdeep... if we get the activation stone.
It's a good thing that cleric, Brit, promised to watch over us. We need all the help we can get.
Shareesh always said we'd be free one day. Now that Halaster is gone, I'm starting to believe him.
Stay away from that sarcophagus, if you know what's good for you. I get a bad feeling just looking at it.
"Hello again, <FullName>. What can I do for you?"
"I guess I could answer some questions for you, though if you want information you should probably talk to Shareesh in the next room. He's the leader of these poor slaves."
"Undermountain was created by an insane archmage... I'd be surprised if it didn't feel strange down here."
"It's not that strange. I am a priestess of Sehanine Moonbow, after all. Helping others is a duty I gladly accept. I'm just here to protect these poor slaves. Someone has to watch over them, right?"
"I know it's an instrument of great evil... and that's enough to make me leave it alone. Touching it might release some kind of demon or terrible undead creature."
"Yes, of course. But I don't want to risk innocent lives to do it. As long as these slaves are still here, we should leave the sarcophagus closed."
"Very little. If you have questions you should go speak with Shareesh in the other room... he would probably know far more than I do."
"I wish I could be more helpful, but I've spent most of my time here. There are many dangerous creatures in Undermountain: drow, rakshasa... someone has to keep watch over these poor slaves."
"Was there anything else, <FirstName>?"
"These people need my help, I can't turn my back on them. So until these slaves escape Undermountain, I'm going to stay here to protect them."
"Ah yes, the halfling. No doubt he's given you some wild story, but you can't trust him. He's nothing but a thief and a liar!"
"The truth is this: I'm staying here to watch over these slaves. Undermountain is a dangerous place. If I don't stay here to protect them, who will? Halaster's Rakshasa guards?"
"How did I get past them? Uh... well, they weren't there when I... no, I mean... uh... damn you and your questions!"
Linu steps back from you, her face twisted into a mask of inhuman rage.
"Enough of these games! We will feast on your flesh and gnaw on your bones!"
"You do? This is excellent news, <FirstName>! Quickly, you should give it to Shareesh in the other room. He will know what to do with it."
You recognize Linu, the priestess of Sehanine Moonbow, from the Yawning Portal. She seems lost deep in thought, although she does look up as you approach.
"Yes? Can I help you?"
"Goodbye, then."
Linu steps back from you, a look of wry amusement on her face.
"If you really wanted to kill poor Linu, I'm afraid you're too late. But maybe I can arrange for you to join her!"
"Oh... yes, <FullName>. Of course I recognize you. I'm just... I just have a lot on my mind. These poor slaves, trapped here; I wish there was something I could do to help them."
"Maybe... maybe you could help them, <FirstName>. I would do it myself, but I don't want to leave these poor souls all alone. I have to stay here and guard them."
"What a terrible thing to say! Look at these people... they're helpless, trapped... how can you turn your back on them?"
"These slaves could escape Undermountain through the portal in the next room, but the portal can only be opened by someone who possesses the activation stone."
"You could find that stone for them, <FullName>! I don't know where it is, but I bet Shareesh does. He's the leader of these slaves. You should go talk to him in the other room."
"I'm sorry you feel that way. But I won't abandon these poor souls."
"Then I wish you luck, <FirstName>. If you do find the stone, please give it to Shareesh in the other room. He will know what to do with it."
"Undermountain is a dangerous place. Someone has to stay here and protect these poor souls from the Drow and the Rakshasa and whatever else is out there. If I don't do it, who will?"
"I'm here trying to help these people find their freedom."
"If only we had the activation stone for this portal, these poor souls could finally be free. Maybe you could help get if for them, <FullName>?"
"I'm sick of you, Linu. Time to die!"
"I want to ask you some questions."
<StartCheck>[Intelligence]</Start> "Something doesn't feel right here."
<StartCheck>[Intelligence]</Start> "No... that's not it. There's something strange about you being here."
"But how did you get past the Rakshasa guards without killing them?"
"I guess you're right."
"Do you know anything about the sarcophagus in this room?"
"Shouldn't we try to destroy this evil?"
"Have you learned anything while you were down here?"
"What are you doing here?"
"Is there anything I can do to help?"
<StartCheck>[Intelligence]</Start> "Something's not right. How did you get past the Rakshasa guards without killing them?"
"I ran into Tomi Undergallows. He wanted me to check up on you."
"A liar? So why don't you tell me the truth, then."
"Wait a minute... how *did* you get past those Rakshasa guards out front?"
"I have the activation stone for the portal."
"I'll be going now."
"I've been waiting for a chance to kill you, Linu!"
"Don't you recognize me, Linu? It's <FullName>."
"Why should I help them?"
"You're right. What can I do to help them?"
"What can I do to help them?"
"Forget it. I don't have time to help a bunch of worthless slaves!"
"Don't worry - I'll find that activation stone!"
Why can't you find the activation stone for them?
"What are you doing here?"
"Are you okay, Linu? I was worried about you leaving you here. I thought... wait a minute! You're not Linu!"
"What... what are you talking about? Did you hit your head on something?"
"Oh, no... you're not fooling me! You can't con a con artist: I've got a nose for things that stink, and this smells worse than any outhouse I've ever been in. You're not Linu!"
"Very clever, halfling. But it's too late to save your friend now... and too late to save yourself!"
This strange looking rock seems to have a slot cut into its smooth surface.
<StartAction>[Do nothing.]</Start>
<StartAction>[Insert the Activation Stone into the slot.]</Start>
The sarcophagus before you is empty, but still reeks of decay.
The sarcophagus before you has been hastily stuffed with the mangled body of Linu, the priestess of Sehanine Moonbow.
Before you can do anything with this sarcophagus, Linu calls out a stern warning:
"Don't touch that! I don't know what evil lurks inside, but I can feel its foul presence. If you open the sarcophagus, you'll release whatever is trapped inside!"
Inside you see the mangled body of Linu, the priestess of Sehanine Moonbow. You realize something is very wrong here.
"You just had to go and look inside, didn't you? *sigh* I guess there's no reason to continue this charade any longer."
"Thank you. There are too many innocent people here, too many lives that could be lost. The best thing we can do right now is to just leave whatever's inside that sarcophagus alone."
"Of course, but these slaves are helpless! If you open that sarcophagus, you'll put every one of them at risk! We have to consider their safety first."
"I'm sure you can. But what about these slaves? You can't protect them all against whatever evil you might unleash."
Bring her back to life.
Close the lid and let her rest in peace.
Ignore Linu and open the sarcophagus.
"Sorry... I'll leave it alone."
"Don't you want to destroy this evil?"
"Don't worry - I can handle whatever's inside here!"
"Yes, my <lord/lady>? Is there something you need?"
"Please hurry, my <lord/lady>. We are only safe in this chamber until the other denizens of Undermountain realize you have slain the Rakshasa that were keeping us prisoner."
"Of course, my <lord/lady>. What do you wish to know?"

"In our time here as Halaster's slaves, we have learned something of his secrets. Undermountain is filled with traps and devices to help the mad wizard maintain control. The chains you speak of were one such method."

"The central chamber leads down to the lowest level of Undermountain. The doors to the chamber were held open by four powerful chains - without them, the doors would slam shut and remain forever sealed."

"This would restrict movement between this level and the one beneath it - a way for Halaster to seal the level in an emergency. Just one more way he could maintain control over everyone and everything in Undermountain."

"So the chains are gone, which means the doors are now sealed. I suspected as much. Halaster - or maybe one of his apprentices - must have triggered the doors to the central chamber in an effort to try and stop the drow."
"I suspected as much. Halaster - or maybe one of his apprentices - must have triggered the doors to the central chamber in an effort to try and stop the drow."

"The doors were designed so that once closed, the chains would be scattered throughout this level of Undermountain. That way, Halaster could collect the chains at his leisure and re-open the central chamber once the trouble had passed."
"Each of the four chains would teleport itself to a random section of the dungeon; I doubt even Halaster himself knew for certain where they would appear."
"But I know where one of these chains has reappeared. Of course, I will only tell you its location after you bring me the activation stone for the portal that will lead us safely to the surface."
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> The old man shakes his head defiantly, seeming to find a long forgotten inner strength.
"Forgive me, my <lord/lady>, but I will not help you until after you have given us the activation stone for the portal. This is our once chance for freedom - our one hope to escape this place."
"The location of the chain is all we have to bargain with. I will not give up my secret until after we have the activation stone."
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> "Forgive me, my lady. Maybe I've been trapped in this dark place too long, but I fear I have lost my ability to trust anyone."
"Perhaps they hope to use it as a base for an attack on the surface. Aren't the drow always trying to conquer or destroy the surface world?"

"The real question is: how come the drow are still here? In the past, Halaster had absolute control over Undermountain and all the beings who dwell here - he would never have allowed the drow to set up their camps in his domain."
"But the drow are here now, and Halaster is missing. I suspect the two are related, but in what way I couldn't say."

"I can only tell you what we have learned in our years serving him. First, he is quite mad. But despite his insanity, you cannot underestimate his power: all of Undermountain stands as a testament to his abilities."

"And I know that he has recently vanished; I heard the Rakshasa speaking of his disappearance. I don't know what happened to him, but I suspect the drow who have recently come to Undermountain are involved."
"Halaster hid the activation stone inside a djinni bottle that he kept with him at all times. But now Halaster has disappeared... and so has the bottle."

"I don't know what happened to the mad mage, but I heard the Rakshasa say that drow had overrun the southern chambers. It wouldn't surprise me to learn that they had something to do with Halaster's disappearance."
"If you want to find the djinni bottle, you should probably investigate their camp. Just be careful... the drow prefer killing strangers to answering their questions."
Is there anything else I can help you with, my <lord/lady>?
"Then I have no further use for you!"
"You have the stone? Quickly - give it to me so we can escape this place once and for all!"
The djinni bottle at your side begins to shake and rumble. Suddenly, the stopper pops free and a billow of dark smoke rushes forth, materializing into the djinni himself.
"Forgive the intrusion, but I don't think you want to give the activation stone to these... hmm, what are you pretending to be this time, Shareesh?"
"This is none of your concern, you semi-sentient puff of wind! Get back in your bottle where you belong!"
"I never liked you very much, Shareesh. I'll go, but first I think this mortal needs to see you in your true form!"
"You will pay for this, Volkarion! After I feast on this <race> fool's flesh, I will bind you to my service for a thousand years!"
"I'd be more worried about what this mortal is going to do to you, Shareesh. I'll be back inside my bottle if anyone needs me."
"Wh... what do you mean, my <lord/lady>? I have been nothing but honest with you."
"Tomi? You mean Tomi Undergallows? The halfling adventurer? He is nothing but a thief and a liar! Even his own friends don't trust him!"
"If you don't believe me, go speak to Tomi's own companion - the cleric, Linu. She stayed here to watch over us while Tomi went to try and steal the djinni bottle from the drow."
"You would be foolish to put your faith in the halfling. Linu told us he is nothing but a liar, full of spite and hate."
"Uh... you have to realize that... I mean... you see... uh... Damn your endless interrogations!"
The old man steps back and rises up to his full height, all trace of his former subservience gone.
"I tire of your questions, <Race>! The time has come to end this charade!"
"Yes, of course. Go speak with the cleric. She is in the room at the back."
"So, halfling... it seems you still haven't gotten over your distrust of us. But I assure you, we have no secrets. Go and speak to Linu if you do not believe me. She is in the room at the back."
"That's a good idea. Come on - let's go talk to Linu and straighten this out."
"Yes, my <lord/lady>?"
"I will gladly help you... if you help us escape this place. For even though the Rakshasa are dead, there are still many terrible creatures roaming the halls of Undermountain."
This old man approaches you timidly, with his head bowed and his eyes cast down in a subservient manner.
"The... the Rakshasa in the other room are dead. Did... did you kill them? Are you... are you here to save us?"
The old man recoils from you in abject terror; a pathetic, fawning creature.
"Please, we wish you no harm! We are only humble slaves - we are powerless to stand against one such as you!"
"But if you spare us, we can help you. We know things about Undermountain... valuable information. I will tell you all I know, if you help us."
The old man steps back suddenly and rises up to his full height, all trace of his former subservience gone.
"You seem determined to see blood spilt here. Never fear... we can accommodate your wish!"
"My name is Shareesh, leader of these people. Or at least, as much a leader as any. You see, everyone here is a slave, a poor soul bound and forced to serve the mad wizard Halaster."
"The Rakshasa outside were supposed to protect us from the other creatures here in Undermountain - and to make sure we never tried to escape."
"Not that we could have tried, in any case. Halaster's magic bound us to this place. But now Halaster has disappeared, and the spells binding us here have faded."
"Y... yes. My <lord/lady>. I will get right to the heart of the matter: the halls of Undermountain are overrun with deadly monsters and drow."
"I wish it were that easy, my <lord/lady>. But there are many terrible creatures roaming the halls of Undermountain, to say nothing of all the drow who have recently appeared."
"It would be suicide for us to venture out from these chambers. A few of us might escape these halls, but most would never make it to the surface alive."
"But there might be another way for us to escape this place. There is a magic portal in this section of the dungeon, a back door if you will. Halaster built it as an emergency escape route."
"The portal can only be used by someone who possesses the proper activation stone. Without it, the portal is useless - a false hope to tempt and torture us. But if we could get that stone..."
"If you bring the stone to me, I will tell you the location of a powerful magic item... one of the four chains Halaster used to bind open the doors of this level."
"As you wish, my <lord/lady>."
"Thank you, my <lord/lady>. You alone can deliver us to freedom! But if you are to help us, I must first tell you where to find the activation stone."
"In our years of slavery, we have learned much about Halaster's creations. If you agree to help us, I will tell you everything we know about the chains."
"I'll be back once I have the activation stone."
"I've decided to butcher you like hogs. It's how I get my kicks."
"I want to ask you some questions."
"What do you know about the magic chains and the central chamber?"
Do you know where these chains are now?
But now the doors are sealed.
"I want to ask about something else."
<StartCheck>[Intimidate]</Start> "You better tell me where that chain is... I don't want this to get nasty."
"Then I guess I'll have to beat it out of you!"
<StartCheck>[Persuade - Flirt]</Start> "Do I look like someone who'd betray you? Come on... you can trust me."
"Why have the drow come to Undermountain?"
"What can you tell me about Halaster?"
"Where can I find the activation stone again?"
"I have the activation stone right here."
"Is there something you're not telling me?"
"Never mind. I want to ask you something else."
"Tomi said there was something strange about you."
"You seem awfully defensive about this."
"I think I'll go speak to Linu about this right now."
<StartCheck>[Intelligence]</Start> "Hold on... how did Tomi and Linu get in here without killing the Rakshasa guards?"
"I want to ask you some questions."
"Your Rakshasa captors are dead. You're free."
"I killed the Rakshasa - just like I'm going to kill you!"
"Forget it... I just want to kill you."
"Help you? What are you talking about?"
"I'll spare you... for now. Tell me what you know."
"Why would I want to save someone like you?"
"Save you? Save you from what?"
"The Rakshasa are dead. But who are you?"
"I hope there's a point to all this."
"Great. You're free. So get out of here."
"So now that I've killed the Rakshasa, you're free to leave?"
"I'm too busy to waste my time with this!"
"I could help you find that stone... for the right reward."
"And you want me to find the activation stone?"
"Maybe I could help you find the activation stone."
"I'll be going now."
"I think I'd rather just slaughter everyone here."
"Okay, I'll try and find the activation stone for you."
"That's okay - I can find it without your help."
"Actually, I'd rather ask you some questions first."
"Okay, where can I find the activation stone?"
"What do you know about those chains?"

Instead of scampering away at your approach, this rat stands its ground and regards you with a brazen courage. It is obviously well fed.
Images of dark figures and dead bodies flash through your mind, along with faint memories of other creatures the rat finds far less pleasant.
The rat returns to scavenging for food.
You sense an instinctual panic in the rat. You see whiskers, a tail, a swiftly striking cat's paw. Before the image vanishes, you get a final glimpse of the feline hunters walking upright.
You see an image of a hobgoblin corpse swarmed by eager rats, each pushing and shoving to get their share before the bones are picked clean.
Your mind seizes on the image of a drow war party moving through the dungeon, slaughtering all they come across as the rats watch from the shadows.
You see the drow move on, leaving a pile of mutilated bodies in their wake. The rat rushes forward with its brethren to feast on the remains.
Leave the rat alone.

The strange mage brushes the dust from his sleeves before turning his wild-eyed gaze to you. He surveys you thoroughly up and down, twice, then sniffs dismissively.
Nathyrra seizes your arm and hisses into your ear: "He's an archmage of tremendous power and unstable temperament. Don't make him angry!"
Halaster cocks his head to the side. "You really should listen to your friend. Talking back can lead to a gruesome end."
"The last one to sass me was a bold orc named Grug. Ask him what happened, if you know how to speak slug."
There is a sudden flash of light and the room fills with colored smoke. When the air clears, you see not one but two versions of the mad wizard standing before you.
The first Halaster interrupts before the second can answer your question. "Wait just a moment, my identical friend. You seem somewhat confused, and I want it to end."
"You were nothing but a safety device. I created a clone, and put it on ice. I knew that one day I might get into trouble. I'm the real Halaster, you're just my double."
The second Halaster shakes his head. "I think you're mistaken, you were only a ploy. I let the drow catch you, you're naught but a toy!"
"I know how you feel, but you're not even real. You're just a double to save me from trouble! It's hard to accept, but I'm afraid that it's true. The original Halaster is me and not you."
The first Halaster throws his hands up in exasperation. "Which is the clone, which is the master? How will we know the real Halaster? I can't believe this has happened. What a disaster!"
Both versions of Halaster turn to look at you, their eyes dark with anger at the interruption. Then, they both smile as an idea pops simultaneously into their heads.
"We'll settle this later, when we're just one on one. But first the Valsharess must suffer for what she has done."
"Someone must get her, make her pay for her crime. I'd do it myself, but I can't spare the time."
The first Halaster waves his hand, and you feel the power of his spell coursing through you. It feels as if a hundred tiny hooks have been latched onto your very soul.
"Nothing much, just a spell to make sure you obey. I put a geas upon you, it's better this way."
"Down to the Underdark is where you will go. You're working for me now, you can't really say no."
Nathyrra gasps. "The geas will bind you to Halaster's service. He's compelled you to enter the Underdark and kill the Valsharess. If you don't obey him, you'll wither away and die."
"Your dark elven friend speaks words that are true. I think she could help, so I'll send her down, too."
"You have no choice but to do as I say. But once the Valsharess is dead, my spell goes away. After that I promise you'll truly be free... but don't do something foolish, like come after me."
"You're sending <FirstName> down into the Underdark? <He/She>'ll have need of my skill in battle. You better send me, as well."
"You're sending <FirstName> down into the Underdark? <He/She>'ll have need of my healing. You better send me, too."
"You're sending <FirstName> down into the Underdark? <He/She>'ll have need of my skills. You better send me, too."
"Yer sending <FullName> down into the Underdark? It's full of shadows and traps and treasure! It's like I was born for that place! You better send me down, too!"
"No, no, no - it won't work that way! It's up to me if you go or you stay. You don't give me orders here in my home! I'm sending your friend down all alone!"
"Hey! Deekin not like it when people talk to Boss like that!"
"Your kobold is brave, though not too bright. Just the kind of ally you might need in this fight."
"I'll send him with you when you go down below. He just might prove useful - you never know."
"Don't say that, Boss! Deekin not let you down! You'll see!"
"Thanks, Boss! Deekin not let you down! You'll see."
"I'll send him with you when you go down below. He just might prove useful - you never know."
"<FirstName>'s going to need more help than just that kobold down there. You better send me along, too."
"You don't tell me what to do! I'm in charge here, not you!"
"I'll send *you* back up to the top. Let Waterdeep know the invasion will stop. I'm cleaning house, the drow are no more. Undermountain will be as it was before."
"Please, Halaster. Send me down as well. <FirstName> will need help, and I have allies in the Underdark. The Seer also wants to stop the Valsharess. Please."
"You make a good point, and you asked real nice. Very well, drow, I'll take your advice. You can go, too. I won't leave you here. I'll send you with <FirstName> to the camp of the Seer."
"Enough time has been wasted, I want you to go. The Valsharess is waiting, far down below."
"Goodbye, best wishes, I bid you good luck. Go kill the Valsharess, because until then you're stuck."
"So sorry, no time, you really must go. Don't worry, it's fine, you'll do well, I know."
"<FullName> will have need of my skill in battle down below. You must send me, as well."
"If you're sending Deekin along with <FullName>, you better send me, too. My healing skills could be useful down in the Underdark."
"If you're sending the kobold down there, ye better send me too, wizard! The Underdark is full of shadows and traps and treasure! It's like I was born for that place!"
"What can I say? Everyone knows I'm insane. No doubt you'll know better if this happens again."
"Maybe I should have just left you there."
"Please tell me you aren't speaking in rhyme."
"You were expecting someone else? Who?"
"This was all a trap? You let yourself be captured?"
"Sorry, I didn't know."
"I think I'll be going now."
"I don't have time to listen to you two crackpots!"
"Maybe I can help solve this dilemma."
"Is there some kind of reward for freeing you?"
"Could you guys settle this later?"
"Stop that! What do you think you're doing?"
"What did you just do to me?"
"I guess I don't have any choice but to go after this Valsharess."
"I'll find some way to break this geas!"
"You can't force me to serve you!"
"I'd rather not have Deekin go with me."
"At least I'll have some help."
"I'm ready. Send me down."
"This isn't over, Halaster."
"Wait. I need time to prepare myself."
"I want to ask you some questions."
"This is the thanks I get for helping you?"

This formian communicates with you via telepathy. "Follow me. I will take you down the passage as our Queen has promised, and we will fill in the tunnel behind you so it cannot be used again."
You receive an urgent, telepathic message from this creature: "Protect the Queen! Protect the Queen!"
Much to your surprise, this creature addresses you in the common tongue. "Thank you for releasing me, <race> creature. You are <race>, are you not? I have trouble distinguishing between you bipeds."
"As you wish, <race> creature. We will return to the hive and leave you to deal with the drow alone."
"Protect me, workers! Destroy this <race> creature!"

"I am the queen of this formian colony, and as such I have learned to master what you call speech. My workers, however, are only part of the collective mind and can only communicate through their thoughts."
"I cannot stay to answer your questions, <race> creature. A colony without a queen cannot survive; I must return to the hive before my followers wither and die."
"But know that you are a friend of the colony. You have saved a formian queen, and when the time is right the hive shall repay you. Goodbye, <race> creature - we will meet again."
"You have the gratitude of the colony, and I declare you to be a friend of the hive. You have saved me from the drow, and when the time comes I will repay your actions."
"But now I must return to the hive; a colony without a queen cannot long survive. I must return before my followers wither and die. Goodbye, <race> creature - we will meet again."

"Your kind calls us formians. I am queen of this colony, and as such I have learned the common tongue. My workers, however, are part of the collective mind and can only communicate with their thoughts."
The formian queen tilts her head forward by way of greeting. "And so we meet again, <race> creature, as we promised. The time has come for the hive to repay you for freeing me from the drow."
"To the south is a drow camp. If you enter, you will be forced into a terrible battle against the dark elves - a battle you may not survive. But we know a way to avoid this confrontation."
"In the northeast corner of this room is a hidden tunnel my people have dug beneath the earth. This tunnel leads to the chamber beyond, bypassing the drow camp entirely."
"If you wish, one of my colony can guide you through the tunnel and past the drow. We will have to fill the tunnel behind you, so you will not be able to use it to come back this way."
"As do we. They must be destroyed so they do not threaten the colony again. Very well, <race> creature: my colony will join you in your attack on the drow encampment."
"Go there and we will appear once the battle begins, striking from below. Between us, we will slaughter our common foe!"
"After this, <race> creature, the colony's debt to you is repaid. Go to the passage in the northeast corner and one of my colony will appear to guide you through the tunnel."
"While you go on through the tunnel, my colony will attack the drow. They must be destroyed so that they never threaten us again. Goodbye, <race> creature".
"The drow are defeated, the colony is safe once again. We can return to our hive."
"Our debt to you is paid, <race> creature. The hive owes you nothing; it is unlikely we will ever meet again."
"Kill the drow! Kill them! Kill them all!"
"I don't have time for this. Just go."
"Time to squash some bugs. Bye-bye, freak!"
"You speak common?"
"I want to ask you some questions."
"Is there some kind of reward for freeing you?"
"Yes, I'm <race>. What are you?"
"Forget it! I don't trust you."
"Repay me? How?"
"But I want to fight the drow!"
"I accept your offer."
No way I'm showing up when you're fighting. Hazardous duty isn't part of my contract!
What! You again! How dare you disturb my bath. Go away. I need some rest.

"You mean you do not know?" Her incredulous look quickly turns suspicious. "Or are you playing with me now? I am already defeated, you need not toy with me."
The fairy sighs heavily. "So you are here by chance, then. Yet another adventurer passing through Halaster's maze."
"So I am undone, and the ogre wins the day. How unfortunate. Do what you will with me then, I care not. Death would be welcome."
The fairy's eyes go wide in fear for a moment and she backs away from you several steps. She seems near tears. "How humiliating that an agent of that ogre could do this to me," she mumbles.
The fairy eyes you carefully for a long moment, and then smiles in a seductive manner. Her hand catches your attention as she runs in along her thigh slowly.
"There is no need for us to be enemies, <race> man," she croons. "I would gladly reward such a handsome creature as yourself, in exchange for my life..."
She smiles coquettishly. "How I do adore a man with... good sense. Very well, then, my pet. Come to me..."
A wry smile appears and is gone a moment later. "You are smarter than you seem. Very well, then. Will you at least allow me to bargain for my life?"
Her eyes linger upon you for a moment longer, then she sighs heavily. "As you wish. Will you at least allow me to bargain for my life?"
She looks at you desperately. "I am sure we can come to some kind of arrangement, if you will but spare my life."
"You don't? Then... will you allow me to live?"

"There is gold in the chests behind me... but you no doubt will take what is there, regardless. Beyond that, I have little to offer you." Her lip starts to tremble. "I simply beg you, please do not kill me."
"You are most generous. Thank you for sparing my life. I shall bother you no further."
Her eyes harden. "Then we will finish this now."
She nods slowly. "Of course, <race> <male/female>. Ask what you will."
The fairy's fear suddenly returns and she shies away once more. She nods carefully. "Of... of course, <race> one. Ask what you will."
The fairy's eyes widen, her fear returning. "And what is to be done with me? Will you allow me to negotiate for my life?"
"It is an ogre mage, a brutish thug who believes that he should be the ruler of this level. I will never submit to him, so I gathered what allies I could and fought him."
"That is all over now, of course. You have left me with nothing, even if you permit me to survive."
"What do you wish to ask me, <race> <man/woman>?"
"He makes his camp on the far side of this level of the dungeon, though he has moved his camp several times in the last weeks to avoid being attacked. You will smell him long before you find him."
"I thought you to be an emissary of the ogre mage, perhaps... or someone equally disagreeable. One does not trust anyone in Undermountain, especially strangers."
She looks at you as if the answer should be obvious. "Of course. With Halaster gone, all of the creatures of Undermountain have been free to do as they wish."
The fairy nods. "Halaster has vanished. Nobody knows what has happened to him, he is just... gone."
"When mad Halaster ruled Undermountain, he kept a strange peace. Creatures appeared or disappeared, the mountain changed around us... but none of us were permitted to get out of hand."
"And then Undermountain stopped changing and chaos ensued. It only became worse when the drow came, of course."
"They come to this level in small parties, hunting and gathering what they can. I think they come from deeper in Undermountain... but never have I seen their like prior to recently."
She looks away from you and shrugs. "Perhaps they have something to do with the mad mage's disappearance. I truly do not know."
"Undermountain has fallen into chaos ever since Halaster disappeared. I have not visited the levels deeper into the earth, but I have no doubt it is the same there."
The fairy shrugs. "I do not know. Once there were stairs near here leading down, but the dread mage moved them, as he is wont to do."
"There are teleportation portals on this level, but they do not lead down. They only jump you about the level - though I do not know if they are even working now that Halaster is gone."
She gestures around her. "You already know this area, as you have barged through it. That is all that I truly know, I am sad to say."
"Throughout the many years that I have been here, the dread mage has changed the level many times. New traps will appear, along with new creatures... and then one day they will be gone."
"The ogre mage resides elsewhere on this level, along with his forces. I believe there are teleporting portals still working, though they may be malfunctioning now that Halaster is gone."
"I am a fairy. A Fairy Queen, to be precise. And, like all the creatures in Undermountain I was brought here against my will by the mad wizard Halaster."
She casts her eyes down, ashamed. "I... I wasn't always like this. When I first came here, I was like the others of my kind: small, delicate, beautiful. Now I am a lumbering beast!"

"When I first came here over fifty years ago I used magic to transform myself to this size. I... I thought I could use my beauty to convince Halaster to free me. But the mad wizard spurned my advances."
"As punishment for trying to beguile him, he cast a spell on me, trapping me for a hundred years in this hideous, gigantic body!" She buries her face in her hands, trying to hold back her tears.
Her shoulders hitch as she chokes back a sob. "I've tried everything, but there is no magic powerful enough to break the spell of an archmage. I'll just have to wait another 47 years, I guess."
"Part of me hoped that when Halaster disappeared, the spell binding me to this form would be broken. Since it still persists, I must assume Halaster is still alive."
She wipes her eyes and gives you a wane smile. "You are a kind <man/woman> to say that, but I can see clear enough what I am."
She shrugs. "Halaster has been known to punish those who have tried to escape. However, now that he is gone I suppose I could leave if I wished. Though I am afraid he might return at any moment."
Suddenly she eyes you warily. "You have... defeated him, you say? Does that mean he is dead? Have you killed him?"
The fairy ponders this news for a moment. "I see. That is unfortunate, but at least the oaf is as weakened as I am now. I will not lose everything... if you intend to spare me, as well, that is."
The fairy ponders this news for a moment. "Then it seems we are not enemies after all. Had I known this was so, I would have rewarded you as soon as you entered my domain."
"How unfortunate this battle had to happen between us. Perhaps you might be... willing to put this behind us? Would you allow me to negotiate for my life, <race> <man/woman>?"
"The two of us have been locked in battle on this level for many moons, now. I would know his fate, <race> <man/woman>, before I meet my own."
"What are you talking about?"
"I truly do not know what you are talking about."
"You wish to die? So be it."
"I think we can negotiate on your fate, actually."
"Tell me about this ogre you keep mentioning."
"I have some questions"
"If you are referring to the ogre mage, I have already defeated him."
"Enough. Time for you to die."
"Back off! I'll have no tricks out of you, fairy!"
"What am I to do with you, I wonder?"
"Now that's the kind of proposal I like!"
"And allow you to use your fairy magic on me? Not a chance."
"Not interested."
"I don't want anything from you."
"What can you offer me?"
"Just go. I don't want to see you again."
"I don't trust you. I cannot allow you to live."
"Never mind that. I have questions."
"I'll ask the questions here, if you don't mind."
"I'm done with questioning you."
"Tell me about this ogre you keep mentioning."
"I want to ask you something else."
"Where do I find this ogre mage?"
"Why did you attack me?"
"You and this ogre mage fight to rule this level?"
"Halaster is gone?"
"The drow came?"
"What can you tell me about Undermountain?"
"How do I get to the deeper levels of Undermountain?"
"What can you tell me about this level?"
"Who are you and what are you doing here?"
"Aren't you a little big to be a fairy?"
"Quit your pathetic whining!"
"Serves you right for trying to trick a wizard."
"You're not hideous. You're very beautiful."
"You can't leave Undermountain?"
"The ogre is defeated."
"He's alive, but his forces are mostly defeated."
"The ogre is quite dead, I assure you."
"Forget it. I have no use for you."
"I want some questions answered."
"I'm willing to talk about it."
"Why should the ogre's fate matter to you?"
Before you is a vine covered basin covered in elven runes and bathed in a green light.
<StartAction>[Place the Ancient Oak Branch in the Vine Covered Basin.]</Start>
<StartAction>[Nothing you do seems to affect the basin at the moment.]</Start>
"Squeek... squeek."
The rat wonders if you might not have a spare bit of cheese on your person. Or a spare bit of drow flesh. Mmm... drow flesh.
The rats thinks that you smell well fed and wonders if maybe it should become an adventurer too.
The rat tells you that it had a pretty gem this morning, but it got eaten by a chicken. The chicken was then eaten by a cat, which was then torn apart by a pack of dogs.
The dogs then attacked a group of duergar, who killed most of the dogs. The duergar found the gem, but were then killed by a bunch of guards.
The rat then starts to tell you how the guards were eaten by dragons when you realize the rat is making this all up as he goes along.
The rat thinks that drow corpses are the sweetest tasting meat on the streets these days.
The rat wishes it could live in a flying city like its great, great, great grandfather did. Actually there are quite a few more greats in his explanation, but you get the picture.
The rat sniffs you and decides that you are not a corpse... yet.
"Hello rat!"
The strange mage brushes the dust from his sleeves before turning his wild-eyed gaze to you. He surveys you thoroughly up and down, twice, then sniffs dismissively.
Nathyrra seizes your arm and hisses into your ear: "He's an archmage of tremendous power and unstable temperament. Don't make him angry!"
Halaster cocks his head to the side. "You really should listen to your friend. Talking back can lead to a gruesome end."
"The last one to sass me was a bold orc named Grug. Ask him what happened, if you know how to speak slug."
There is a sudden flash of light and the room fills with colored smoke. When the air clears, you see not one but two versions of the mad wizard standing before you.
The first Halaster interrupts before the second can answer your question. "Wait just a moment, my identical friend. You seem somewhat confused, and I want it to end."
"You were nothing but a safety device. I created a clone, and put it on ice. I knew that one day I might get into trouble. I'm the real Halaster, you're just my double."
The second Halaster shakes his head. "I think you're mistaken, you were only a ploy. I let the drow catch you, you're naught but a toy!"
"I know how you feel, but you're not even real. You're just a double to save me from trouble! It's hard to accept, but I'm afraid that it's true. The original Halaster is me and not you."
The first Halaster throws his hands up in exasperation. "Which is the clone, which is the master? How will we know the real Halaster? I can't believe this has happened. What a disaster!"
Both versions of Halaster turn to look at you, their eyes dark with anger at the interruption. Then, they both smile as an idea pops simultaneously into their heads.
"We'll settle this later, when we're just one on one. But first the Valsharess must suffer for what she has done."
"Someone must get her, make her pay for her crime. I'd do it myself, but I can't spare the time."
The first Halaster waves his hand, and you feel the power of his spell coursing through you. It feels as if a hundred tiny hooks have been latched onto your very soul.
"Nothing much, just a spell to make sure you obey. I put a geas upon you, it's better this way."
"Down to the Underdark is where you will go. You're working for me now, you can't really say no."
Nathyrra gasps. "The geas will bind you to Halaster's service. He's compelled you to enter the Underdark and kill the Valsharess. If you don't obey him, you'll wither away and die."
"Your dark elven friend speaks words that are true. I think she could help, so I'll send her down, too."
"You have no choice but to do as I say. But once the Valsharess is dead, my spell goes away. After that I promise you'll truly be free... but don't do something foolish, like come after me."
"You're sending <FirstName> down into the Underdark? <He/She>'ll have need of my skill in battle. You better send me, as well."
"You're sending <FirstName> down into the Underdark? <He/She>'ll have need of my healing. You better send me, too."
"You're sending <FirstName> down into the Underdark? <He/She>'ll have need of my skills. You better send me, too."
"Yer sending <FullName> down into the Underdark? It's full of shadows and traps and treasure! It's like I was born for that place! You better send me down, too!"
"No, no, no - it won't work that way! It's up to me if you go or you stay. You don't give me orders here in my home! I'm sending your friend down all alone!"
"Hey! Deekin not like it when people talk to Boss like that!"
"Your kobold is brave, though not too bright. Just the kind of ally you might need in this fight."
"I'll send him with you when you go down below. He just might prove useful - you never know."
"Don't say that, Boss! Deekin not let you down! You'll see!"
"Thanks, Boss! Deekin not let you down! You'll see."
"I'll send him with you when you go down below. He just might prove useful - you never know."
"<FirstName>'s going to need more help than just that koblod down there. You better send me along, too."
"You don't tell me what to do! I'm in charge here, not you!"
"I'll send *you* back up to the top. Let Waterdeep know the invasion will stop. I'm cleaning house, the drow are no more. Undermountain will be as it was before."
"Please, Halaster. Send me down as well. <FirstName> will need help, and I have allies in the Underdark. The Seer also wants to stop the Valsharess. Please."
"You make a good point, and you asked real nice. Very well, drow, I'll take your advice. You can go, too. I won't leave you here. I'll send you with <FirstName> to the camp of the Seer."
"Enough time has been wasted, I want you to go. The Valsharess is waiting, far down below."
"Goodbye, best wishes, I bid you good luck. Go kill the Valsharess, because until then you're stuck."
"So sorry, no time, you really must go. Don't worry, it's fine, you'll do well, I know."
"<FullName> will have need of my skill in battle down below. You must send me, as well."
"If you're sending Deekin along with <FullName>, you better send me, too. My healing skills could be useful down in the Underdark."
"If you're sending the kobold down there, ye better send me too, wizard! The Underdark is full of shadows and traps and treasure! It's like I was born for that place!"
"What can I say? Everyone knows I'm insane. No doubt you'll know better if this happens again."
"Maybe I should have just left you there."
"Please tell me you aren't speaking in rhyme."
"You were expecting someone else? Who?"
"This was all a trap? You let yourself be captured?"
"Sorry, I didn't know."
"I think I'll be going now."
"I don't have time to listen to you two crackpots!"
"Maybe I can help solve this dilemma."
"Is there some kind of reward for freeing you?"
"Could you guys settle this later?"
"Stop that! What do you think you're doing?"
"What did you just do to me?"
"I guess I don't have any choice but to go after this Valsharess."
"I'll find some way to break this geas!"
"You can't force me to serve you!"
"I'd rather not have Deekin go with me."
"At least I'll have some help."
"I'm ready. Send me down."
"This isn't over, Halaster."
"Wait. I need time to prepare myself."
"I want to ask you some questions."
"This is the thanks I get for helping you?"
The sword in the skeleton's hand glitters suddenly, almost leaping out of the corpse's grip as a voice speaks from within it.
"There is no escape from the sword, now." The sword pauses for a moment, thinking. "Well, none that I know of. My soul should have disappated long ago, but I was not about to let that happen."
"Instead of properly dying I stubbornly tried to escape this sword and return to my body. Instead of being successful, I became... stuck..."

"Isn't that perfectly *obvious? I have been joined with this sword permanently now, doomed to remain attached to the weapon of some dead King who hardly needs it... or anything else, for that matter."

"Please, I beg you! Have a heart, my <lord/lady>! Take me away from this hall and use me to chop all your enemies to ribbons... at least that would be a better fate than counting the dust mites upon the floor!"
"Hmmm, yes, there is *that*, isn't there? The catch, my dear friend, is that these so-called "sleeping Kings" that occupy this room do not take kindly to having their belongings removed."
"That is how I was killed in the first place. Greedy me, and did I pay the price or didn't I? You look like a competent and tough young <man/woman>, however... how bad could it be?"

"*I* don't do anything. The sword, however, does the same thing it always does... it draws the life energy of its foes into itself, healing the wielder amongst other things. Not too shabby, if I do say so myself."
"Yes, the sword has other powers. Shall I write you a catalogue? Just take me away from here and you can examine me at length, alright?"
"Then take me away and... and sell me to some merchant in the market, for the love of Mystra! Let me be sold to some collector or some other adventurer, please!"
"Or," here the weapon's voice gets desperate, "or I have a better idea! Let me change my shape! A longsword no good for you? How about a dagger? Or a short sword? A greatsword! Any of those!"
"Coward! You call yourself an adventurer?! You're going to leave perfectly good booty just sitting about?!"
"Come on, you bucket of bones! Don't undead exist to kill off adventurers?! Do your job! Do something... do *anything*!"
"Even better! Just take me away from this dreadful place!"
"Of course, of course! Just take me away from this dreadful place and I shall change as you ask!"
"Excellent!" You reach out your hand and take the longsword from the skeleton's loose grip. A second later, however, a deep glow emits from the skeleton's eye sockets and it begins to stir...
"Excellent!" You reach out your hand and take the sword from the skeleton's loose grip. Even as your hand encloses around the hilt, its blade shimmers and transforms into a different weapon.
A second later, however, a deep glow emits from the skeleton's eye sockets and it begins to stir...
"Nonsense! You seem like a smart enough young <man/woman>, why would you believe such stories? Is your will so lacking that you're actually afraid I could somehow dominate you?"
"And besides... even if you do fear such a thing, you only need to sell me off and be done with me, no? All I wish is to be free from this timeless prison. Is that too much to ask?"
"A mage and adventurer, if you must know, though that holds very little relevance now beyond the fact that my intelligence is considerable and I... am... very... bored!"
"I'm not exactly sure, come to think of it. I didn't get sucked into a calendar, you see. Four or five decades, perhaps? Maybe more? Maybe less?"
"Yes, well... that is a long story. Just let me say that the first chap I tried to ask for help decided to leave me be and looted my corpse of everything." He sighs again. "And then the rats ate it."
"Alright! Fine! That is the whole story! When you are forced to helplessly watch indignity after indignity being visited upon your body, you can't help but become a tad upset!"
"Is this some form of trick?"
"How is it that a sword can talk?"
"Err... who are you?"
"And you seek to escape now?"
"Stuck? Stuck how?"
"What's the catch?"
"I might be interested... what do you do, exactly?"
"Amongst other things?"
"I have no need of a longsword, sorry."
"I don't trust you. You'll remain where you are."
"Perhaps remaining a longsword would be best."
"I suppose I could use a powerful greatsword..."
"I suppose I could use a powerful short sword..."
"I suppose I could use a powerful dagger..."
"Forget it. You'll stay right here."
"I shall take you, if I can." <StartAction>[Take the sword.]</Start>
"Perhaps if you became a greatsword, instead..."
"Perhaps if you became a longsword, instead..."
"Perhaps if you became a short sword, instead..."
"Perhaps if you became a dagger, instead..."
"I've heard tales about intelligent weapons taking over their users..."
"And what were you in life, Enserric?"
"How long ago did this happen?"
"Where is your body? I don't see it anywhere."
"How is that a long story?"
Before you is a small wooden keg. It appears to have a small wick, similar to a candle, coming out of the top of the barrel. What do you wish to do?
Do nothing.
Ignite the wick.
Pick up the keg of Alchemist's Fire.
Argali
Silth

This halfling has a hard, uncompromising look in her eyes. The clothes she wears and her general bearing indicate a successful merchant. There is also a pride in her bearing as she touches her merchandise.
The unusual red markings on the armor of the drow in Undermountain mark these drow as some sort of community or special clan.
Waterdeep Wizard
This is one of the powerful wizards who defend Waterdeep from invasion.
Waterdeep Militia
The militia are men, trained specifically for invasions and otehr problems that might be too much for The Guard to handle themselves.
Drezzy
This dwarf looks as if he could be a fearsome opponent in battle... if he wasn't so drunk.
Drow House Soldier
Glim
Folkor
This gnome is one of the many adventurers that has answered Waterdeep's call for heroes.
LaFontaine
This man is one of the many adventurers that has answered Waterdeep's call for heroes.
The Matron
The Matron Mother of a drow family reigns supreme. The higher a house stands in drow society, the more power a Matron Mother can command.
Pappilon
Parley
Though far from the forest, this druid seems remarkably at ease in her surroundings.
Sabine
Tanarell
Drow Handmaiden

Drow Handmaidens carry a lot of respect and power in drow society. They reign over the inferior male drow counterparts with an iron fist, brooking no insults and often killing a male simply for getting in their way.
Jyslin
Female priestesses are the pinnacle of drow society, commanding the attention and obedience of all lesser drow.
Matron Mother
Drow mages are generally considered superior to the warriors of a drow society. Of course, males don't usually outrank female drow, period.
Berger
Flesh golems are the creations of powerful wizards. This one has a gruesome smile on its face. It could just be the unusual stitching that is forcing it to smile though.
Drow Elite Soldier
The Guard
The Guard is an elite force of Waterdhavian warriors, trained and chosen by the only openly acknowledged Lord of Waterdeep.
Cyphus
Ordinae
Although this man looks human, faint traces of elven blood reveal a mixed heritage. His face is careworn, as of one who has seen and experienced much hardship through out his life.
Drow Marksman
Like their fairer cousins, some drow pride themselves on their abilities with missle weapons.
Durnan

The confident demeanor and burly muscles on this innkeeper indicate a past rooted in either military or high adventure. Durnan is one of the most reputable people in Waterdeep. This is no small feat in a city filled with famed adventurers.

This halfling moves with a quick confidence about the kitchen.

The beauty of this woman at her peak must have been something to behold, because age certainly doesn't seem to have had much effect on her.

Mhaere is the innkeeper's wife. Strong and beautiful, her noble ideals as a paladin of Tyr keep patrons in line most of the time. Her cool competence is one of her greatest strengths, and a quality that draws a better crowd than is found in most taverns.
Refugee
This is just one of the many refugees who have come to Durnan's inn seeking shelter from the attacks on Waterdeep.
Citizen
This is one of the million citizens in Waterdeep.

Though missing part of his arm, this half-orc still ably serves as Durnan's bouncer.

Although this monster looks like a brutish thug, the fact that it can cast spells would imply a higher intelligence.
Fairy Sorceress
This would appear to be the ruler of the strangely twisted and evil fey folk here in Undermountain.
Harpy Minion
Fairy Minion
Turned cruel and evil, these fairies are a far cry from their usual mischevious but mostly harmless nature.
Tree Golem

Partially divine warriors enjoy some of the powers of the celestial, while maintaining a common link to the mortal realms.

Noble Elf Mage

Noble Dwarf Lord

Malevolent Grig

Djinni Bottle

This bottle holds Volkarion, a merchant djinni, who has access to wares from different planes of existence. He is trapped in this bottle and can be spoken to for purchasing these wares. Through the use of soul gems, Volkarion can give you access to new wares.
Shield of Lies
This magic shield grants additional protection to its wearer, but it doesn't bear the hallmarks of any specific maker.

To make life more difficult for her enemies, Joaquim Theest sacrificed part of her life energy to forge a powerful shield. When used properly, the will of an opponent is sapped, leaving him dazed and confused for a short time.
Half-Blood Gloves

These magical gloves are woven from thick reeds and radiate nature magic. Daelan found them while traveling through the Cloakwood forest, a gift from a mysterious druid that Daelan speaks of only very briefly. His memories of the druid appear to be quite personal to him, and all he mentions is that the gloves were a gift, supposedly meant for the half-blooded children of two races.
Drow Note

This scroll is written in a tight, elegant hand:
"This is the equipment taken from the Red Sister's latest victim. When our mistress arrives she will want to inspect these items herself."
Inventory Note

These items are intended for use only during an emergency. Please take only what you need.
Some special notes on our more exotic equipment:
Potion of Clarity: These are useful for warding off fear effects and other mental distortions. Barkskin: Purchased these from druids outside the city proper -- they insist they will harden the skin of an adventurer. Probably most useful for those who do not wear armor. Ale: Best used only in the most dire of cirumstances.
- Durnan
Bloody Plate
Worn Book

This large tome has a rather interesting title: "Shadows of Undrentide", written by one "D. Scalesinger". Inside its pages is the full account of an adventure from earlier in your career... your first adventure, in fact. The facts seem a bit exaggerated, according to your memory, but that apparently didn't stop the book from becoming a great hit amongst the nobility in several major cities throughout Faerun. For a time, you had the unique experience of becoming a household name... people who you didn't know would shout out to you happily as you passed or treated you like a trusted friend. The fame eventually died down somewhat, which was a relief at the time, but you have held onto a copy of the book as a souvenir.
As for the author, a kobold bard by the name of Deekin, you haven't met him since those early days. Part of you has to wonder if you aren't owed some royalties...
Cloak of the Sentry

A cloak commonly found amongst the guardians of the rich and powerful, this cloak protects the wearer against attacks that could affect the mind. Since guards are often more physically strong, but mentally weak, such protection is a wise idea.

Confusion Toy
This small top is covered with delicate runes that, when spun, cause an opponent's mind to wander, making it difficult for them to concentrate on the battle. The top can be spun three times a day.
Craven Necklace
Amulets are necklaces with some form of large decoration or symbol. Most are ornamental, but some are potent magic items.

Hephanik the Cowardly was a king who constantly feared assassination. He ruled his kingdom with an iron fist, amassing a huge army, not to conquer other lands, but to protect him from his worst fear, an uprising of the peasantry. As part of his personal protections, Hephanik had his royal wizard craft him a necklace to keep him safe. Eventually, even the necklace was not enough to save him, as one of his concubines removed it and slit his throat while he slept.

The dragon tooth amulet that Deekin wears looks very much like one of the artifacts that was stolen from your mentor's home in Hilltop during your adventure involving Undrentide. When asked about it, Deekin merely shuffles from foot to foot and mumbles that it was given to him but little more. Regardless of its significance, Deekin doesn't seem willing to give it up to anyone... even you.

Honor and Death

The Rakshasha general, Kalikin, came from a long line of fierce warriors and cunning strategists. Their personal code of behavior was covered by the motto "Honor and Death". The words represented the idea that chaos led to the propogation of lesser species, and through the bounds of honor one could work effectively to strike down these lesser races and fulfill the destiny of the one great race, the Rakshasha. This two-bladed sword was the weapon of choice for striking the blow against chaos.
