An Unexpected Ally

You've been approached Nathyrra, a drow who claims to be an agent for a mysterious group of rebels opposing the dark elves attacking Waterdeep. According to Nathyrra, the armies invading Waterdeep are being controlled by a powerful drow House Mother known only as the Matron. She also claims the Matron has captured Halaster and is holding him prisoner.
If Nathyrra is telling the truth, you may have a new ally in your quest to save Waterdeep. But if she's lying, trusting her could be deadly...

Nathyrra has approached you again, this time to warn you about a drow encampment. She's told you of a secret passage that will lead you to a pair of ballistae mounted on a ridge behind the camp.
If her information is accurate, then using the ballistae could be an easy way to defeat the drow. But if she's lying you might be walking into a trap.

Nathyrra has shown up yet again. But instead of vanishing into the shadows, this time she's offered to help you in the final battle to free Halaster.
You should probably be grateful for any help you can get at this point, and she's proven herself trustworthy so far. Maybe once Halaster is free you can learn more about this mysterious ally and the group of rebels she represents.
Halaster has cast Nathyrra down into the Underdark with you. Hopefully she will be as useful an ally there as she was in Undermountain.
Daelan
You have discovered the body of Daelan- one of the adventurers you met in the Yawning Portal - on the first level of Undermountain.
You have raised Daelan from the dead, and the half-orc has decided to return to the Yawning Portal.

Even though you saved him from the grave, the half-orc doesn't seem to fond of you. The fact that you insulted his honor and genealogy probably has something to do with it. He's likely returned to the Yawning Portal, though it's doubtful he'll have anything nice to say to you there.
Daelan has refused to accept your apology for insulting him. He made it quite clear that he has no desire to forgive or forget.
Daelan has reluctantly agreed to forgive you for your previous attacks on his honor. The fact that you saved his life seems likely played a significant part in his decision.
You've decided to kill Daelan, even though you just rescued him from a similar state. Once you're done with him, however, he'll probably stay dead.
You've managed to convince Daelan to join you in your explorations of Undermountain. It probably won't take long for this battle-hardened warrior to prove his worth to your group.
Descent into Undermountain
The Yawning Portal has come under attack, the drow striking from Undermountain even as Durnan was in the middle of preparing an expedition to go in and explore the dungeon's depths.

The raids on Waterdeep are getting worse; even Durnan's inn has been attacked, as you know first hand. The drow sent to steal your equipment was likely only the first strike against you. The next time the results could be far more lethal.
Your only hope of stopping the attacks - both on Waterdeep and on you - is to go into Undermountain and discover why Halaster's magic no longer keeps those inside the dungeon from escaping to the surface.
Durnan feels the mad mage himself is to blame, but it is possible something may have happened to Halaster. And if so, what new enemy is behind these attacks? The answers await you below... if you survive.

You've learned that Halaster has disappeared, leaving Undermountain in chaos. With the mage gone, the protections keeping the creatures from leaving his dungeon have also vanished.
Durnan would be interested in what you have learned, though no doubt he will want you to try and discover where Halaster has gone, and why he left.

Durnan was interested in the news of Halaster's disappearance, and he's urged you to try and find out more. Has something happened to Halaster, or is his disappearance part of some grand, sinister scheme?

Halaster has been captured by the drow. With the mad mage out of the picture, the dark elves are moving freely through Undermountain, allowing them to strike at Waterdeep.
Durnan should be given this information as soon as possible, though he will likely want you to investigate these drow further.

To say Durnan was troubled by the news that Halaster has been captured by the drow would be an understatement. The innkeeper has asked you to try and discover more about this new enemy, including who is leading them and how they managed to imprison an archmage of Halaster's stature.
The answers you seek can only be found in the depths of Undermountain itself.

The leader of the drow invaders is a matron mother known only as 'The Valsharess'. Though you still know little about her, you should at least advise Durnan of the name of the one who is behind the attacks on Waterdeep.

As expected, Durnan has asked you to try and discover more about the Valsharess.. including a way to stop her and her followers from destroying Waterdeep. According to Durnan, the key to stopping them is finding and releasing Halaster. Once the mad mage is in control of undermountain again, the attacks should come to an end.

You've rescued Halaster from the clutches of the drow, and as a reward the wizard cast you down into the Underdark to exact vengeance on the Valsharess for imprisoning him. He also cast a geas on you to ensure your loyalty. Unless you find some other way to break the archmage's spell, the only way to free yourself from his service is to find the Valsharess and kill her.
On the bright side, Halaster did promise to end the attacks on Waterdeep.
Find Tamsil
Durnan and Mhaere's daughter, Tamsil, has gone down into Undermountain. Her worried parents want her returned safely to the surface.
Durnan and Mhaere's daughter, Tamsil, has gone down into Undermountain. Her worried parents want her returned safely to the surface. Tamsil's body has been found, but she has been turned to stone.

Durnan and Mhaere's daughter, Tamsil, has gone down into Undermountain. Her worried parents want her returned safely to the surface. Although her body was turned to stone, Durnan was pleased and went into the dungeon to save her himself.

Durnan and Mhaere's daughter, Tamsil, has gone down into Undermountain. Her worried parents want her returned safely to the surface. Although her body was turned to stone, she has been released from the spell and is returning to the relative safety of the Yawning Portal. Her parents will certainly want to thank her rescuers.

Durnan and Mhaere's daughter, Tamsil, has gone down into Undermountain. Her worried parents want her returned safely to the surface. Although her body was turned to stone, she has been released from the spell and is returning to the relative safety of the Yawning Portal. Her parents were grateful to have their daughter back.
Halaster's Slaves

You've agreed to help a group of slaves trapped here in Undermountain. They've located a portal that can lead them to Waterdeep, but they don't have the activation stone to use it.
Shareesh, the leader of the slaves, believes the stone is hidden away inside a djinni bottle at a drow encampment in the southern section of the dungeon. If you bring the stone to Shareesh, he can lead his people to freedom.
Halaster's slaves have revealed themselves to be Rakshasa in disguise. With their illusion shattered they resorted to a more direct approach and attacked you en masse.
Henchman
The lovely Talice, a drow thief/fighter has joined you as a henchman.
Krill Darkflame, a tiefling wizard/rogue, has joined you as a companion.
Your henchman has been killed. You will have to raise them from the dead before they can rejoin you.
Linu
You've discovered the body of Linu La'neral, the elven cleric from the Yawning Portal.
You've managed to convince Linu to join you in your explorations of Undermountain. No doubt her healing skills will prove useful during your adventures.
You've raised Linu from the dead, giving her another chance at life. After speaking with you, she's decided to return to the Yawning Portal.

You've given Linu another chance at life, but any gratitude she may have felt towards you has been wiped away by your cruel words. Should you wish to speak to her again you can likely find her at the Yawning Portal, though it is unlikely she'll want to speak with you again.
You've apologized to Linu for your previous actions, but she has refused to accept your apology and it's obvious she has little desire to even speak with you.
Linu has accepted your apology for your previous behavior. Her willingness to forgive you probably has something to do with the fact that you were responsible for raising her from the dead.
After raising Linu La'neral from the dead, you've decided to kill her again. This time, she'll likely stay a corpse.

Several members of your old adventuring party have entered Undermountain ahead of you. Two of the corpses have been found.

Several members of your old adventuring party have entered Undermountain ahead of you. Three of the corpses have been found and one corpse that was damaged beyond recovery.

Several members of your old adventuring party have entered Undermountain ahead of you. Two of your friends have been returned to life.
Several members of your old adventuring party have entered Undermountain ahead of you. Three of your friends have been returned to life.
Several members of your old adventuring party have entered Undermountain ahead of you. One of your friends has been returned to life, but one corpse was damaged beyond recovery.
Several members of your old adventuring party have entered Undermountain ahead of you. Two of your friends have been returned to life, but one corpse was damaged beyond recovery.
Several members of your old adventuring party have entered Undermountain ahead of you. Three of your friends have been returned to life, but one corpse was damaged beyond recovery.
Several members of your old adventuring party have entered Undermountain ahead of you. One of the corpses has been found and one corpse that was damaged beyond recovery.
Several members of your old adventuring party have entered Undermountain ahead of you. Two of the corpses have been found and one corpse that was damaged beyond recovery.
Relic of the Reaper

You have reclaimed the Relic of the Reaper - most prized of your possessions. The artifact has been yours since you found it -- or perhaps, it found you -- in the Plane of Shadows many years ago.
The Relic of the Reaper will teleport you to a tiny nexus dimension ruled over by an enigmatic being you know only as the 'Reaper'. The Reaper agreed long ago to serve you through the relic: you can use it to bind a location to one of the doors in the Reaper's realm, allowing you instant transportation there. The Reaper will also snatch you to his realm on the instant of your death. Both of these uses, the binding and the saving, cost the use of a Rogue Stone. More information can be gained from the Reaper, himself... though your strange servant has never exactly been forthcoming on the relic's true nature or even his own.
Rude Awakenings
You awoke from a troubling dream just in time to discover a drow thief. Unfortunately you were not in time to stop her from magically stealing all of your equipment.

Tamsil, the innkeeper's daughter, has informed you that her father Durnan is waiting for you in the main room downstairs. You should go speak to him once you get your equipment from the Yawning Portal's armory.
Tamsil, the innkeeper's daughter, has informed you that her father Durnan is waiting for you in the main room downstairs. You have located and spoken with Durnan.
Sharwyn
You have discovered the body of Sharwyn - one of the adventurers you met in the Yawning Portal - on the first level of Undermountain.
You have raised Sharwyn back to life. She was quite grateful to you for giving her a second chance at life.
Sharwyn has joined you in your expedition to Undermountain. No doubt she'll prove a valuable member of your team.
The Armory
Although all your equipment has been stolen, you are free to visit the Yawning Portal's armory. There you should find suitable gear to replace the equipment that was taken from you.
You've visited the armory of the Yawning Portal to try and replace your stolen gear. You can return at any time to help yourself to anything else in the armory if you feel the need.
The Sealed Passage
An Ogre Mage has informed you that the stairs down to the next level of UnderMountain are sealed with debris and garbage. The only way to clear it is to cause an explosion.
You've cleared a passage down to the next level of Undermountain.
Tomi
You have discovered the body of Tomi - one of the adventurers you met in the Yawning Portal - on the second level of Undermountain.
You have raised Tomi back to life. He was quite grateful to you for giving him a second chance at life.
Tomi has joined you in your expedition to Undermountain. The rogue's skills should come in particularly useful in Halaster's trap filled dungeon.
Trapped in the Underdark

You've been cast into the Underdark by the mad wizard Halaster. The archmage has given you a task: kill the Valsharess for imprisoning him and seizing control of Undermountain. To ensure you complete your mission, Halaster also cast a geas on you, binding you to his service.
Unless you find some other way to break the geas, the only way to be free of Halaster's power is to find and kill the drow known as the Valsharess.
Waterdeep Under Attack.
You have agreed to help The Guard clear this district of Waterdeep of attackers from the Underdark.
You have found and killed the last of the attackers from the Underdark. Waterdeep is safe - for the moment.

It is said that both you and Mephistopheles returned to the Nine Hells in the end, the archdevil ruling alongside you for a thousand years. He coached you on the treacherous ways of the Baatezu and kept you from harm, his loyalty to you secured by the power of his True Name. Together you waged many wars of conquest and for a time your influence spread throughout the Outer Planes. Legend claims that Mephistopheles would one day attempt to trick you as he did the Valsharess, but that in the end you humiliated him with defeat once more. This, however, is another story.

Though it meant a return to the Outer Planes, it is said that the great archdevil Mephistopheles was bound to your service by your use of his True Name. News from the depths of the Nine Hells is ever unreliable, but some claim that he served you faithfully, bowing and scraping before you even as he longed for your mortal life to expire. Some tales relate that Mephistopheles would attempt to trick you as he did the Valsharess, but that in the end you humiliated him with defeat once more. That, however, is another story.

It is said that the archdevil Mephistopheles abandoned his war of conquest, his desire to subjugate the mortal realms foiled by his defeat at your hands. He fled the world of Toril, never to return. Such tales rarely end so easily, however, and future stories claimed that Mephistopheles spent much of his future consumed with the desire for revenge upon the one who humbled him. Whether his plots proved successful, however, or whether you vanquished him again as you had the first time is another tale.

[MEPHISTOPHELES - FATE 2] Becomes kindhearted.
Commanded by his True Name, Mephistopheles had no choice but to obey. Every goodly act festered like a wound upon his heart, driving him to madness. Yet every good act begat another and another and threefold more until all that was devilish within him was consumed...

It is said that the great archdevil Mephistopheles collapsed into dust and existed no more. The world shuddered with his passing and all grew still for a time, but bringing an end to such beings is rarely so simple. Some tales claimed that Mephistopheles could never be completely destroyed on the Material Plane. They say his will lived on, and out of a desire for vengeance his body was eventually reformed on the Outer Planes. A day of reckoning was sure to follow someday... though that is another tale.

From the ashes of the devil's gambit, Waterdeep rose again, rebuilt and renewed with all the fervor of a vast and bustling city, its place as the jewel of Faerun reclaimed. Reunited with his family, Durnan restored the Yawning Portal to its former glory. He hung a portrait of you upon the mantelpiece and told your tale to all who sought the fire's warmth...

With your help, the havoc unleashed by the devil's gambit allowed an opportunity for you to gain power. Waterdeep was rebuilt under Durnan's guidance but other realms did not fare as well as your lust for conquest turned more and more of those cities under your thumb into a true, living hell. The legends claim that one day your power would be challenged and your terrors would become but a memory... but not now. And so you sat upon your darkened throne, pondering all the evils you had wrought...

Daelan Red Tiger returned to his homelands in the frozen north and accepted a position among the Elders of his Uthgardt tribe, finally finding the sense of acceptance and belonging he had sought for so many years. The tales say that the great Daelan lived to a ripe old age, fathering many children. He guarded the frozen northlands with a legendary sense of justice, combating many evils and seeing the Uthgardt through the most difficult times in their history. When the great barbarian breathed his last, his spirit was said to have risen and taken its place amongst the stars over Faerun, an inspiration for future outcasts to come.

After his experience in Undermountain, Tomi Undergallows left the Yawning Portal under suspicious circumstances and rumors of missing cutlery. Where he went from there is unknown, but tall tales of his exploits soon began to emerge. Tomi was said to be involved in a scheme to steal Elminster's pipe and, strangely, he was even reported to have ruled the pirate city of Luskan for a time. The truth of these tales is questionable at best and only one story is said to have any real merit: it is claimed that, shortly after leaving Waterdeep, Tomi met his end at the hand of a ragged, giggling maniac known only as "Sammy..."

As for Linu La'neral, she finally returned to her home city of Evereska. The temple there, dedicated to Sehanine Moonbow, at long last forgave her for the accidents of her past and granted her the title of High Priestess. It took only a month for Linu to reduce the temple to ruins (purely an accident, of course) and she returned to Waterdeep once more. There she was said to have been a force of good in troubled times, guiding its citizens with a sense of justice and diplomacy that, as once noted by the Sage Elminster, "held all the grace that her feet did not."

Sharwyn wrote a soulful ballad based on her experiences in Undermountain that somehow found its way to Cormyr and the ears of its Infant-King, Azoun V. Greatly enthralled, the young king insisted that she be offered a court position as Bard Laureate of the capital, Suzail. She accepted eagerly, her songs soon becoming an inspiration to the kingdom. Later stories emerged, suggesting that she fell in love with a man as gentle of heart as he was hideous in appearance. Abandoning her wealth and position, she left the security of the King's service to live in blissful poverty with her one true love. She was the beauty to his beast and their love would spawn a legend of its own... and Sharwyn, at last, would find the true happiness she so desperately sought.

Deep in the Underdark, the wake of your passing is still felt. The Seer survived Mephistopheles' pillage of the region and became renowned as a leader of her people. Her followers still scour the depths for drow seeking to escape the despair and treachery of their life, bringing those they find to a new existence on the surface. The task is not an easy one, however, as the drow matrons constantly send assassins into the fold. But the Seer still survives and still names you in her prayers. Amongst her and her followers, you are remembered as a friend to all those who sought solace from the shadows...

Deep in the Underdark, the wake of your passing is still felt. The Seer survived Mephistopheles' pillage of the region and her followers still search for those drow looking to escape the despair and treachery of their life, bringing those they find to a new existence on the surface. Thanks to the power of the Shattered Mirror that you left with her, her job is much easier than it once was. The church of Eilistraee grow steadily in strength and your name is praised as a true friend of those who seek refuge from the shadows...

Deep in the Underdark, memories of your betrayal persisted for many years. The followers of Eilistraee were all dead by your treachery, however, and none were left to curse your name. Among the drow houses, you are honored as a devious outsider who showed no mercy for the weak...

With the help of the Shattered Mirror, the illithid of Zorvak'Mur quickly came to dominate their region of the Underdark, driving back the drow and other lesser races. Under the guidance of the Overmind, many of them infiltrated secret societies of the surface world, spreading their influence far and wide even there...

With the death of their Overmind, the illithid of Zorvak'Mur easily fell prey to the treachery of their so-called allies. The alliance between the illithid and the drow died with the Valsharess. It was not long before all at the outpost were enslaved to rival drow houses, their psionic powers tightly controlled, while the rest of their race returned to their previous doctrine of war against lesser enemies.

Despite the death of the Valsharess, the alliance she forged with the illithid persisted, becoming one of the defining features of her legacy. Under the protection of the drow and the guidance of the Overmind, the illithid flourished, many of them infiltrating the secret societies of the surface world...

Enraged by the slaughter of his priesthood, the dracolich Vix'thra unleashed his wrath upon the village of Drearing's Deep. There were no survivors and the occasional mushroom is all that now lives amidst the blasted rubble. Ghosts are still said to haunt the place, however, and one of them, a lowly rock gnome, is said to cry your name out in rage and despair...

Freed from both the priesthood's brutal rule and the wrath of the dracolich, Vix'thra, the community of Drearing's Deep struggled mightily to provide a refuge amidst the many evil races of the Underdark. Countless village leaders died in battle, though their spirit was never broken. Rumors spoke of an addled but kind-hearted rock-gnome who served as the community's true leader, masterminding its strategies from behind the scenes. Whatever the case, the freemen of Drearing's Deep survived battle after battle until, in time, the city became a veritable fortress, a bastion of hope for those yet enslaved and a proud beacon of freedom for those who had recently escaped...

As for Cania, little changed. Devils continued to mine their ice for the walls of Mephistar, the Spirits of the Dead continued to arrive and slowly join the ranks of the Lost, and the vast glacial wastes continued to hold the Knowers and their secrets close, buried deep beneath the glacial ice...

As for Cania, it is said to have achieved new greatness under your rulership, at least for a time. The City of Lost Souls, long neglected by Mephistopheles, grew into a thriving metropolis rivaling that of Sigil itself. Vast armies of the fiendish dead marched under your command, their fearsome weapons forged from the glacial ice. Few would ever uncover the secret to your power, however, and any who did were quickly silenced. For to rule the Hells, you had long since realized that you must keep your enemies close... and the Knowers even closer.

As for Cania, the disappearance of Mephistopheles left a power vacuum among the upper echelons of the Baatezu. Soon all the Hells of Baator descended into a vicious bloodbath as devil fought against devil, all of them eager for the throne. Wise as they may be, the Knowers were powerless against the onslaught and soon passed away amidst the slaughter's frenzy. Only the dread Asmodeus remained uninvolved, nursing his ancient wounds, content to let his lessers fight amongst themselves...

As for Cania, Mephistopheles surrendered it to the Knowers as you had commanded him. When the last of the devils had retreated through the Gatehouse, it is said that Cania finally slipped its moorings and became a separate plane once more, no longer the frozen Hell of Baator. Some stories claimed that other devils waged a long war in the years to come to retrieve it, but whether or not it was re-conquered is unknown. The Knowers held your name in reverence for ages to come, a mystery that scholars of the planes found intriguing as so little else was known of you...

[KNOWERS - FATE 3] Meph returns or devils are not reined in.
Angered by the role played by the Knowers in their master's downfall, lynch mobs of vengeful devils began to scour the Wastes of Cania, finally hunting the Knowers to extinction. The Knower of Places was the last to be found but even she could not hide away from the world forever...

[KNOWERS - FATE 2] Freed from persecution.
Freed from persecution, the handful of surviving Knowers emerged from hiding and reclaimed their homeland, rebuilding it as a hidden plane of advanced learning and esoteric knowledge much sought after but rarely found...

[KNOWERS - FATE 1] Names & Places involved in Sleeping Man love triangle.
With the Knower of Names' newfound freedom, the long-standing tension that existed between her and her sister, the Knower of Places, soon dissolved. They resolved their differences regarding the Sleeping Man and it was rare to see one without the other ever since...

The years passed and the Sleeping Man slept much as he had for so many years before. Sometimes he dreamed of his long journey and sometimes he dreamed of yours. But most of all he dreamed of his one true love, her face and name forever hidden from him. The years passed and the Sleeping Man slept, his faith and hope eternal...

At long last, the Sleeping Man woke in the embrace of the woman he believed to be his one true love, his long dark night having finally reached its dawn. Together, they traveled the planes, their lives an endless honeymoon, free of worry or concern. Legends say they're out there still, charting a course between the distant stars...

The Sleeping Man waited patiently for your return and when you did, he loved you fully, with all of his heart. As the years passed you came to love him in return until your souls were so entwined that it was no longer possible to tell where one ended and the next began. In this way, you came to be immortal, as was he...

Robbed of the woman he believed to be his one true love, the Sleeping Man fell into a deep despair. All hope left him and slowly, over the course of generations, he was claimed by the ice of Cania, his spirit joining with those of the Lost...

The ghost of Aribeth de Tylmarande wandered the mortal realm for many years, chaos and treachery following in her wake. She eventually turned her attention to the city of Neverwinter that she had once called home and there she haunted it with every fiber of her being. Calamity after calamity fell upon the city. Aribeth's name becoming a thing whispered only in fear and despair, until finally a hero came to the beleaguered city to stand against the ghost's tyranny and was victorious. That, however, is another tale...

The ghost of Aribeth de Tylmarande reveled with you amidst the heady spoils of war. She never grew old. She never lost her beauty nor did her passion for you fade. You loved each other until you were old and gray and triumphant. As you died, she leaned close, nibbling on your ear. "I shall see you in the Hells," she whispered. She lingered on this plane for a time after your death until finally departing forever. The legends say that the two of you did meet once again in the Hells, as promised, continuing a reign of terror amongst the devils and planars...

Despite her betrayal in the final hour, you spared the ghost of Aribeth de Tylmarande a second and final death. She made no apologies but bowed low, acknowledging your prowess, before turning her back on you and departing through the city's shattered streets. You haven't seen her since but you can feel the malevolence of her spirit out there, somewhere, cruel and triumphant...

Dark-hearted and treacherous to the end, the ghost of Aribeth de Tylmarande was destroyed in the battle against Mephistopheles. As she died her second death, you couldn't help but feel a certain pride on her behalf. Even though she betrayed you, she remained true to the evil within herself...

The ghost of Aribeth de Tylmarande wandered the mortal realm for many years, eventually returning to the city of Neverwinter that was once her home. There she helped the sick, the lame, the poor until little by little, she felt the burden of her penance lifted. Some say that the Wounded God, Tyr, finally appeared to her then to welcome her at long last to the plane of Lunia. Tears filling her eyes, the ghost of Aribeth finally left this world forever. Only then did she find rest, a gentle spirit at last forgiven...

The ghost of Aribeth de Tylmarande never grew old. She never lost her beauty nor did her passion fade. You loved each other until you yourself became old and gray, and in your dying breath you promised that you would meet her on the other side. Aribeth wept after your passing and then herself faded from this world. Legend claims that she met you once more in the next life as promised, and that your love continues on... as do your adventures...

Overwhelmed with the guilt of having betrayed you in the final hour, Aribeth de Tylmarande begged for your forgiveness. Knowing that the true guilt lay with Mephistopheles, you sheathed your wrath and granted her your clemency. After that night, she remained loyal to you forevermore...

Destroyed in battle, the treacherous spirit of Aribeth de Tylmarande at last found rest. She was both fierce and fragile all at once, even to the end. As she died her second death, you could not help but feel that there was an intrinsic goodness to her, deep and at the root...

Nathyrra found a new life on Toril's surface, dwelling amongst the followers of the Seer. Using her training as a Red Sister, she served the Church by returning frequently to the Underdark, infiltrating her own kind to hold secret services within their midst and thereby spread the Seer's teachings. As a result of her bravery, many drow abandoned their foul worship of Llolth, the spider-god, in favor of Eilistraee's more enlightened teachings and one by one, she helped them make the long journey out of the enclosing darkness and into the surface light.

Nathyrra finally reached the surface she had dreamed of for so long, leaving behind the demons of her past. She returned to the Underdark many times, however, using her training as a Red Sister to infiltrate her kind and spread the Seer's teachings. As a result of her bravery, many drow abandoned their foul worship of Llolth, the spider-god, in favor of Eilistraee's more enlightened teachings. But after every journey into the darkness, she came back to you, the one she loved above all else, and together you learned to live under an open sky...

Ashamed by her betrayal of you, Nathyrra abandoned your company in the night, despite your efforts to forgive her. She returned to the Underdark and there rejoined with the followers of Eilistraee. Using her training as a Red Sister, she served the Church by infiltrating her own kind and holding secret services within their midst, spreading the Seer's teachings. Through her actions many drow were converted to the worship of Eilistraee but, in the quiet darkness of her heart she was never able to forgive herself for betraying you. She remained haunted by the memory and driven by it to the end of her days...

Nathyrra was killed in the final battle with Mephistopheles, a victim of her own doubts and failings. Unable to ever truly forgive herself for the crimes of her past, the darkness consumed her in the end...

The bards sing of Valen adventuring with you for a time, though the two of you eventually parted ways. The tales of his exploits throughout Faerun are many, but always the tiefling remained alone and apart from those he protected. Some claim that he found his way back to Sigil where he became an important figure within the city's powerful factions, unifying some and destroying others. Valen always remembered you as a friend and companion, however, someone with whom he had made a personal connection. He returned to you on numerous occasions, accompanying you in your exploits when he was not already embroiled in his own...

Valen escaped the loneliness of his blood at last, finding in you that other part of his soul that he had always missed. Though the two of you were not always together, you were also never truly apart, and more often than not you were inseperable during the greatest of your adventures. Even when the two of you returned to the planes, he claimed he no longer felt the call of the Blood War within his veins. His heart, he told you, was full enough with you alone...

It is said that Valen explored many places in Faerun after parting ways with you. In many ways, after betraying you, he became little more than a lost soul, doomed to wander alone forever, desiring nothing more than to be felled in battle. In time, he left Toril behind and returned to the planes, the call of the Blood War still pounding in his veins...

A victim of his own demonic taint and his inability to escape the powerful influence of the arch-devil Mephistopheles', it came as little surprise that Valen betrayed you in the end. He died in battle as he would have wanted, but his name was soon forgotten in the wake of your greater victory...
[DEEKIN REACHES END BATTLE - FATE 4] He lives out the remainder of his life.

Deekin would go on to become a legendary bard and adventurer in his own right, occasionally joining you in your exploits and often getting caught up in his own. He lived a good life in Waterdeep with many friends, becoming ever more famous and gaining the sense of confidence he had always lacked. He eventually returned as a celebrated hero to his former tribe in the Nether Mountains, however, becoming their first true diplomat and greatest chieftain. He led his tribe out of hiding and negotiated the founding of a permanent mixed-race settlement with a human farming community grateful for the protection they could offer. This unique community of kobolds became a valued bridge between the various groups of beasts and men who once had once known each other only in battle but now sought peace. Deekin's eventual passing was mourned by many... though you can be sure his legacy will live on in a new generation of Scalesingers eager to find their own adventures just as their father did before them...

Having fallen victim to Mephistopheles' manipulation, Deekin berated himself for months after his attempt to betray you. The guilt gave birth to an inner resolve, however; a commitment to be true to himself and beholding to the powers of the world no more. Armed by this decision, he went on to a rather successful adventuring career, eventually returned as a celebrated hero to his former tribe in the Nether Mountains. He became their first true diplomat and greatest chieftain, leading them out of the caverns and founding a permanent mixed-race settlement with a human farming community grateful for the protection they could offer. This unique kobold community became a valued bridge between the various groups of beasts and men who once had once known each other only in battle but now sought peace.

Turned against you at the end by Mephistopheles, Deekin died an ignoble death, never having the chance to taste the true freedom he had always craved. In betraying you, he also ultimately betrayed himself, choosing instead to serve the will of others rather than his own...

You became a terror on the face of Toril, legends claiming that your armies spread the darkness that was within your heart over the lands of Faerun. You were yet another challenge for the heroes of the land to face, and it is said that upon your inevitable defeat by the forces of good you swore revenge. In tales told by drunken bards, your spirit festers in a dungeon far beneath a plain that remembers your ancient battles only by the old bones still bleaching in the sun. One day your ambition will demand your return... or so the bards will claim.

Saved from the destruction that would have been visited upon them by Mephistopheles, the citizens of Toril joined together in showering you with their gratitude. A holiday was named in your honor, and in the days to come you would rise in power, becoming confidante to the lords of nations who sought counsel from the wisest of champions. Legends conflict in their claims of where you went after this, some saying you disappeared mysteriously and some saying you rose to become a benevolent ruler... the only surety is that your name is uttered alongside the greatest heroes the Realms has ever known.

Word of your hell-borne alliance with Mephistopheles spread far and wide throughout the planes. Armies trembled before the two of you, lords and ladies pandered to your every whim, and evil permeated the ground upon which you trod. Nothing could stop you and nothing ever did...

When all was said and done and an end put to the fiendish plans of Mephistopheles, monuments to your victory were erected throughout the world of Toril. Over time, tales of your heroism grew into legends, then into myths. It is said you walked the planes and some say you walk them still, sowing the seeds of goodness and hope wherever you go...

News of your escape from the Hells and triumph over Mephistopheles spread far and wide throughout the realms. Armies trembled before you, lords and ladies pandered to your every whim, and evil permeated the ground upon which you trod. In time, some began to wonder if life under Mephistopheles might have been kinder. Old, now, and wise, you smile to yourself... Yes, they were probably right...

With Mephistopheles bound to your service, you quickly grew in power and status. Bards penned songs of the Devil Tamer and, through your adventures, you came to live a long life of wealth and privelege. Some loved you, some feared you but all gave you their respect. You were the Devil Tamer, the Hero of Waterdeep, a legend in your own time...

Yet not all sat so well with you for, when you commanded Mephistopheles, you had placed your trust in a devil's word. You used no True Name to bind him, nor did you extinguish the fire that was his life. To the end of your days, you possessed a certainty that somewhere in the vastness of the planes, the archdevil was licking his wounds and waiting for you, plotting his revenge. You watch and wait for that day to come, and when it does you know that you will have to fight him to the last breath.
As promised, however, you built an inn of your own in Waterdeep and people came from miles around to torment the fallen devil that was its chambermaid...
END NARRATION. BASED ON VARIABLES SET THROUGHOUT THE GAME, THE PLAYER IS PRESENTED WITH THE AFTERMATH OF THEIR ACTIONS IN THE WORLD.
The end.
The end.
Like the other fiends inhabiting the town, this devil has the hunched appearance of a manual laborer. It probably works in the ice quarry with its fellow Baatezu.
The quarry worker looks at you in surprise, then peers over its shoulder to see if you were talking to anyone else. "Who, me?" it asks. "How come?"
"Then pike off, berk. I've got work to do."
"You want a fight? Well you've got one, then!"
"Well... That's actually not a bad reason. To be honest, I kind of like it... Now put 'em up, <mister/missus>!"
"Hmph. I'll show you evil, berk!"
"Demons? In Cania? Where!? Let me at them! I'll tear their hearts out! This Blood War ain't over yet!"
"Yeah, so? Are you going to make something of it?"
"Hmph! I'm not demon or devil. I'm a slaad! But don't you worry, I'll teach you the difference... I'm going to give you a lesson you'll never forget..."
"Hmph. The Hellbreath Tavern's on the south side of town. Should be enough to warm up by."
"Do I look like the barkeep, berk?"
"Gru'ul, the quarry boss, he does some trading on the side. Gotta catch him in a good mood, though..."
"The quarry's just east of town, through the Quarry Office. All the Grinders are down there."
"You won't find it here, berk. Head down the stairs to the Quarry proper and ask around down there."
"The one Lazy's stuck in? Just look for the one with the imp in the gears."
"Huh? Maybe ask the gith sensei. She knows about smart stuff like that."
The creature sighs impatiently. "She's with the githzerai Pilgrims. They come here every now and then to pay their respects at the temple and drown their sorrows at the tavern, all right?"
"Outa my way. Gru'ul gave me a holiday."
"Gotta get back to work. Gru'ul's orders..." the creature mentions by way of apology.
"Pike off," the creature mutters, shuffling off into the cold wind.
"Harrumph. The Sleeping Man, is it?" The creature spits a foul-smelling substance to the ground. "May he rot and freeze and rot again! The Hells have no room for bastards like him from Elysium."

The pale white flesh of this muscular creature is scarred from countless beatings. A scorched branding mark identifies it as a prisoner of the Blood War. It seems skittish and nervous as you approach.
GENERIC DEVIL QUARRY WORKER. CAN BE FOUND THROUGHOUT THE CITY BUT CONCENTRATED AROUND THE QUARRY.
"Goodbye."
<StartAction>[Attack]</Start> "Die, foul beast!"
"Ha ha... ha...? Er, I was only kidding..."
"I don't have to answer to you! Bring it on!"
"Because I feel like it!"
"Because you're evil!"
"Because you're a demon!"
"Because you're a devil!"
<StartAction>[Attack]</Start>
"Could you tell me where I might find a warm drink?"
"Are there any stores around here?"
"I'm looking for Quarry Grinder 5."
"Where can I learn the Reaper's True Name?"

Quarry Grinder 5 hums contentedly, its past troubles long forgotten.
This Quarry Grinder has had its gear assembly dismantled. Various cogs and belts are scattered about the ice, slowly getting buried in the snow.

<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> The assembly fits together in a fairly logical fashion. You snap the last belt into place and Quarry Grinder 5 hums into action, as good as new.

Doing his best to avoid eye contact, the quarry boss tries to straighten a stack of papers on his desk. His claws get in the way, however, scattering them all over again.
"Why are you always so damn polite? Honestly, that bile you're spewing gets right under my skin and just eats away. Graugh! See that? Just the thought of it is making me twitch!"

"Hey now, True Names are dangerous things. Wars have been fought over less than that, empires have fallen. I don't have what you're looking for and, even if I did, I wouldn't give it to you, so pike off..."
"Clueless berks... Welcome to the Outer Planes, you basket-weaving nitwit! The Nine Hells of Baator, to be exact!"
"This here is the City of Lost Souls, a remote outpost in the wastes of Cania, the Eighth Hell of Baator. Look up and you'll see Maladomini, the Seventh. Dig down and you'll find the Ninth, Nessus."

"How many questions do you intend to ask, you annoying pea-brained gnat!? Some of the Hells are hot, some aren't, all right? Phlegethos, the Fourth Hell, has rivers of liquid fire! What does it matter?"
"The Big M? Tall, dark, and evil? You're lucky if you'll ever be half as bad as he is, you snot-nosed spawn of a rakshasan litter! He's the one who named me Quarry Boss, I'll have you know..."
"Get on with it, then, you smelly tongue-wagger. All this talking is making my scales itch!"
"Hrmph! What does any devil want? To slay a demon in the Blood War, to sow the seeds of evil and grow in power, to defeat Asmodeus and become Lord of the Ninth! All things come down to this!"
"Ha! Do we go for tea and play a little chess while warming our feet by his fires? Gnat-brained flat-head! The Big M has no time for the likes of me! Not that I don't have my ambitions, mind you..."

"But yes, now that you mention it, there were some nasty rumors about some drow she-wench in some distant world who discovered the Big M's True Name. It seemed too far-fetched to be true but who knows..."
"Mephistopheles, Lord of Cania, the Eighth Hell, beholden to none but Asmodeus, Lord of Nessus, the Ninth Hell, who is king of them all. Like me, he is of the Baatezu, the devilkind."

"I bartered the latest shipment of ice for some goods from the capital. Them gith lightened their load with me, too. And then those damn fool spirits keep pawning off their heirlooms... Have a look around."
"Farking quasit-lipped angel lovers! 'Sleeping Man this, Sleeping Man that!' You pilgrims are giving me an ulcer! He's a planetar, all right? An angel in the Hells' own depths... Now get over it!"
Smoke rolls off of the quarry boss' scaly flesh as he paces the small office. Broken furniture is scattered about and the walls bear the dented, smoldering marks of his meaty fists.
He sighs, shaking his head. "Here we go again. What are you, some kind of paladin? Insolent pus-toad! Fine, you want a fight? Let's fight! But for crying out loud, at least tell me why!"
"So that's how it is, is it? You're worse than a monkey with a magic wand... Now get out of my sight!"
"Oooh, now you're talking big, little <mister/missus> fancy pants! That's it, you're going down!"
"Oooh, because you feel like it... Well I feel like bashing your puny little cranium into these cast iron walls, so let's get it on, you steaming pile of gorgon bile!"
"Of course I'm evil, you addle-brained fiddle-twit! These are the Nine Hells! I'm a devil! What part of this whole scenario don't you understand!? Oooh, I'm gonna teach you a lesson..."
"At least get it right, you pea-brained fleece-ape! I'm a devil! D-E-V-I-L! Baatezu! Got it?"

"The demons can go to heck for all I care, always bragging about how many more layers they have in their namby-pamby little Abyss! It's about quality, not quantity, damn it! Bloody trumpet blasters... Now where were we?"
"Of course I'm a devil, you sniveling snot-monkey! This is Baator! Are you going to try to kill every last one of us? Oooh, I ought to teach you a lesson..."
"Scum-chewing bile-monger... So what is it? Speak up, now! I can barely hear your pathetic mewling..."
"Goodbye," he says, mocking you. He turns away, drives his smoldering fist into a nearby wall, and mutters some cruel invective under his breath.

"Hey, it wasn't my idea to build a capital city out of ice and then fill it with steam baths! If this quarry doesn't stay operational, the Big M will be demoted to Lord of the Puddle! Now what's wrong with Quarry Grinder 5!?"

"Look at me. See this scaly skin? See these fiery eyes? I'm a pit fiend! A PIT FIEND, for crying out loud! I LIKE cruelty, you nit-picking quasit-lover! Now what's really the matter with Quarry Grinder 5?"
"You motherless, arse-picking, half-witted clump of meaningless flea-bait! You dismantled my grinder? You venomous turkey-gobbler!"
"Not if I eat your leathery corpse for dinner, you won't... Rock licker..."

"You can and you will! Stupid skull-draggers... It's going to cost me 35,000 gold to get a specialist down here to fix it and another 15,000 for parts. Have you got 50,000 gold kicking around, nadwit?"

"Then don't but I'll remind you, you inconsequential runt, that I run the only store in town. If you want the goods I carry, then you'd best stay on my good side... And I'll warn you, it's very small."
"You'd better be or I'll have your scrawny corpse for dinner, pus-maggot... Now go on, get out of here."
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> "Don't make me laugh, you puny little blood monkey... You bust it, you buy it, understood? 50,000 gold and I'll forget I ever hated your pathetic, pustulant guts!"
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> "Whatever! Just hand it over so I can get the damn thing repaired. Slavering lickspittle..."

"Then don't but I'll remind you, you inconsequential runt, that I run the only store in town. If you want the goods I carry, then you'd best stay on my good side... And I'll warn you, it's very small."

"There's always an imp caught in it, hell-breath! Every day, it seems I have to go down there and feed another imp through! Imps are a dime a dozen but I've only got one Quarry Grinder 5, you hear me!?"
"Horrible? Nonsense! That's commerce! Snot-buggering fiscal utopians... Have you got a better suggestion? Quarry Grinder 5 is down and, while it is, idle hands are the devils' playground."

"A playground's the last thing we need... Playgrounds lead to joy! Laughter! Children... Bah! I don't even want to think about it! We're devils, understood? Hard, mean, tough, fangs, horns, you know the drill."
"Unh? An imp in my grinder? Maggot-snakes! Feed him through, then, feed him through! I've got plenty of imps but only one Quarry Grinder 5, you hear me!?"
"A holiday? Meddling grub-zombie! Why, it'll be a cold day in hell before I ever... ever... Never mind! What reason could we possibly have for declaring a holiday!?"
"Stop wasting my time and go feed that damned imp through the grinder like I told you to! Bilious boil on my devil-in-law's bum..."
"Hrmph! Not a bad point, is it... And if the Big M's leaving Cania, that means he ain't coming back... And if he ain't coming back, he ain't going to need any more of this blasted ice..."
"There's no 'we' about it, alright? It's my management style! Mine! Welcome to the Hells, here's your sledgehammer, got it? Entry-level sludge-mucker!"
"Horrible? Nonsense! That's commerce! Snot-buggering fiscal utopians... Have you got a better suggestion? Quarry Grinder 5 is down and, while it is, idle hands are the devils' playground."

"A playground's the last thing we need... Playgrounds lead to joy! Laughter! Children... Bah! I don't even want to think about it! We're devils, understood? Hard, mean, tough, fangs, horns, you know the drill."
"That's the spirit! Rage-maddened dung-monkey... Come back when you're done. We'll wash up the blood and I'll show you what I've got in stock, alright?"

"Then don't but I'll remind you, you inconsequential runt, that I run the only store in town. If you want the goods I carry, then you'd best stay on my good side... And I'll warn you, it's very small."
The Quarry Boss glances angrily in your direction as he tries to go about his business. A sudden look of recognition crosses his face, however, and he turns back to you with a greedy look in his eye.

"<FullName>? Hell-devils! The clueless berk from the world of Toril? I've been hearing some tall tales about where you've been and what you've been doing. Can I interest you in a business proposition?"
"You back-talking, goat-kneed little maggot! What do you want, then? Did you come here just to taunt me? I ought to turn your ears into coat-hooks..."

"What do you think I'm proposing, cheese-knees!? Just a little trade... You give me the True Name of one of your precious henchmen and I give you a little artifact I scrounged up in Mephistar while you were away."
"Oooh, I hate you!"

"You fark-blasted, lily-livered, dog-throwing stat-jumper! You had the chance! You clutched raw power in your measly little hands and you let it slip through your fingers forever... I'll never understand you mortals."
"Aha! Down to business, then! Which of your thin-skinned gravy dousers deserves an eternity of slavery?"
"But we were just about to close a deal, you sweat-laden blister-hog! Go on, ask your questions, get it over with so we can return to the business at hand..."
"Hahahahahaaa! Take your little artifact, you foolish dog-licker! I'd have surrendered even more to have a True Name such as this! This quarry shall have no equal!!"

"It's a relic of the Blood War. The pig-headed demon whelps... Suffice to say it's a nasty little thing that does various nasty little things to a wide range of other nasty little things. You'll like it, trust me."

"I've got a quarry to run, squid-for-brains! Imagine a worker who never complains, who never takes a break unless I tell them to, who never unionizes... Indentured servitude: it's a boss' dream, berk!"
"No way! That artifact is bargaining power, that's what that is! Fiscal utopian dandies... There's no way I'm giving it away for free!"
Gru'ul drums his fingers on the table impatiently, his heavy claws scarring the wood.
"Why thank you, I think I will, you weasel-toed little braggart..."
"I'd like to you you try, you... you... you nose-picker!"
"You're more cunning than I suspected, you mangy little... mangy little... Ahem. Sorry about that. You were wanting the artifact were you? Grrrrr... Will there be anything else?"
"Don't play coy, you twenty-feathered mutton-head! A little birdie tells me you found the Knower of Names. True Names, berk, they're worth a devil's ransom, they are!"
"So it's true, then... You've found the Knower of Names, the pale-faced little devil-lover! How very interesting. I'm telling you, it's quite a business proposition I have for you..."
"A holiday? Yes, of course! <LastName> Day! We'll shut the quarry down, ship all the workers off to the tavern, and I'll cover the tab myself. We'll make it a monthly morale-boosting social event!"
"Was that all you wanted? Fine, knock yourself out..."
"Good!? But it's not in my nature! Why you flea-riddled, pus-eating, flower-growing, bunny-hugging, sun-shining... <sir/madam>... Blech, if I could hate you right now, I would, <FirstName>."
PIT FIEND, LEADER OF THE OF THE CITY'S DEVIL FACTION. CAN BE FOUND IN A SHACK OVERSEEING THE QUARRY WORK.
"Why are you always so foul-mouthed?"
"Do you know the Reaper's True Name?"
"What is this place? I don't even know where I am."
"Aren't the Hells supposed to be hot?"
"I need to talk to you about Mephistopheles."
"Back to my other questions."
"What is it that he wants?"
"Did he ever mention a Valsharess of the drow?"
"Who is Mephistopheles, anyway?"
"Wait, I want to purchase something."

"Goodbye, Gargelflaw."
A small imp slumps against the silent quarry grinder, his arm caught within its gears. Despite this, he seems infinitely comfortable, a huge smile playing across his face as he snores contentedly.
"Nothing going on here. Don't mind me. I'll have Quarry Grinder 5 up again in no time, I promise."

Quarry Grinder 5 squeals and rattles like a pained beast. Something is clearly wrong with it and you suspect it has something to do with the fact that the hand of a nearby imp is wedged between the gears.
"Ow! Eek, do you have to remind me? I'm fine as long as I don't think of it. Gah! As for how it got stuck, I just sort of put my hand in it. On purpose... ish... Ouch! I think I'm going to faint..."

"Yes, well... It seemed like a fine idea at the time... I was really quite sick and tired of all the quarry work, you see? I thought that if I just stuck my hand in there, I might get a... well, a moment's rest. It was quite nice, really..."
"Sure do. Can't remember a day when I didn't, to be honest. It seems they always need more ice in the capital. I'm beginning to think it's just a means of keeping us out of trouble, mind you..."
"Well, I won't be telling you my True Name, of course, but everyone here just calls me Lazy..."

"That's a tall order, I'll have you know. The Reaper's been here in Lost Souls longer than anybody, except maybe the Sleeping Man, and the only one who's ever known his True Name is probably Mephistopheles."
"Yes, he swept through here in a big hurry to see the Reaper recently. Rumor in the quarry is that he found some way to get to the world of Toril. Everyone gets a holiday but me, it seems."
"Yeah, the gith have a thing for him, it seems. Lucky bastards. I'd travel the planes on some hare-brained pilgrimage, too, if I ever got a day off. But, noooo, Mephistopheles needs more ice."
"Pilgrims. Religious folk. You'll find more of them in the tavern than the temple, though, if you ask me..."
"Definitely! Absolutely! Not a problem! It'll be just dandy, you have my word on that... I'm just getting a... a feel for what's gone wrong down there. It's all under control."

"Really? A holiday? How wonderful! It's just what I always wanted! Maybe I'll go visit my mother-in-law!" The imp attempts to flap away, apparently forgetting that his arm remains entangled in the grinder.
"Gah! My arm! I knew I was forgetting something... Golly, that's really going to hurt tomorrow. It hurts now, mind you, but tomorrow? Yikes, I don't even want to think about it..."

"No, I don't want to go back to work! Please Master Gru'ul, anything but more work... Gah!" The imp wakes with a sudden, frightened flap of his wings but his entangled arm returns him quickly to the ground.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> Some parts of the gear assembly are still spinning and you're forced to give up before you become caught in the grinder as well.

<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> It doesn't take long before you have the gear assembly apart, the various cogs and belts scattered on the ice before you. The imp's arm is horribly mangled and he wakes with a start.
"My hand! I can feel my hand! Gah, that hurts! Put it back in! For the love of all that is evil, put the hand back in! Gah!"

"Yes, of course... Don't forget to put the Grinder back together, mind you. I don't think Gru'ul will be pleased with the looks of that." With that, the imp flies off rather erratically, nursing his shattered arm.
"Ow! Eek, do you have to remind me? I'm fine as long as I don't think of it. Gah! As for how it got stuck, I just sort of put my hand in it. On purpose... ish... Ouch! I think I'm going to faint..."

"Yes, well... It seemed like a fine idea at the time... I was really quite sick and tired of all the quarry work, you see? I thought that if I just stuck my hand in there, I might get a... well, a moment's rest. It was quite nice, really..."
"Sure do. Can't remember a day when I didn't, to be honest. It seems they always need more ice in the capital. I'm beginning to think it's just a means of keeping us out of trouble, mind you..."
"Well, I won't be telling you my True Name, of course, but everyone here just calls me Lazy..."

"That's a tall order, I'll have you know. The Reaper's been here in Lost Souls longer than anybody, except maybe the Sleeping Man, and the only one who's ever known his True Name is probably Mephistopheles."
"Yes, he swept through here in a big hurry to see the Reaper recently. Rumor in the quarry is that he found some way to get to the world of Toril. Everyone gets a holiday but me, it seems."
"Yeah, the gith have a thing for him, it seems. Lucky bastards. I'd travel the planes on some hare-brained pilgrimage, too, if I ever got a day off. But, noooo, Mephistopheles needs more ice."
"That's easy for you to say. You don't have to go back to work!"
"Wait! Wait, you're right! I can't go back to work like this! I'd just be in the way! I'm a genius! Sloth has set me free! Now I can live a life of one-armed luxury! No more pickaxe, no more ice..."
With a crunch of bone and squelch of blood, the grinder hums back into action.
