"Just another dead soul like the rest of us... But now he's just another victim of Mephistopheles' devouring... So many have been taken... So many..."

"Yes, he has an army of the dead in the distant world of Toril and he's drawing on our essence to animate them... He's devoured so many of us as it is and still he needs more... Every one of us in a plume of white..."
The spirit shivers briefly in the cold, waiting for you to continue.

"One tried... She was the boldest among us, the one most full of life... She confronted Mephistopheles and, in his anger, he did something to her... It's only a matter of time before she joins the Lost..."

"The Lost Souls are spirits who no longer yearn for life... They are the ones who have given up... The ice consumes them and they are absorbed into the very essence of despair that forms the plane of Cania."

"Here is where the Scrivener has etched the names of the Lost into the ice that they may be remembered... Here, by the Gates of Cania, where spirits lose hope that they will ever be able to return home."

"We spirits tend not to use names here... Death has brought us to Cania because of the horrible acts we committed in life... It is better to leave all vestiges of that life behind... It is better to forget..."
"Only when we are Lost are our names engraved in the ice for all to know... If we reach that point, it no longer matters..."
"It was done by a creature called the Scrivener but now its former guide has been devoured by Mephistopheles... Without anyone to guide the Scrivener, no one knows what will happen."
"I'm not really sure if it's a who or a what... In some ways, it almost seems more like a pet than a person... Yet its former guide taught it to form simple word pictures, so who's to say..."

"But, for as long as anyone here can remember, the Scrivener's been the one to carve the names of the Lost into the ice... If you look close, the ice is full of them, buried deep... That's how the city got its name..."
"Just another dead soul like the rest of us... But the Dabusi are a gentle race, committed to lives of service... Their native tongue consists of word pictures that they project above their head..."
"Just another dead soul like the rest of us... But now he's just another victim of Mephistopheles' devouring... So many have been taken... So many..."

"She came here full of anger and passion and hope... She was like a fire in this cold place and all of us were drawn to her warmth... When Mephistopheles came to the Gates to announce the Devouring, she challenged him..."
"Whatever he did, it drained her of that fire... Refusing to speak, she sealed herself in the cave at the center of town... Now she dwells within it, slowly growing cold, becoming one of the Lost..."
"Yes, there is... You can put the poor spirit out of her misery... Thanks to Mephistopheles, she's already all but Lost... It's only a matter of time..."
"To help her, you must help the Scrivener... When the Scrivener carves her name into the ice, at that moment will her soul finally join the Lost... It's not peace but it's better than torment..."

The spirit shudders but you cannot tell if it is from fear or a sudden gust of chill wind. "It is a fate worse than death, worse than the Hells... To have one's soul devoured is to become nothing at all."
"Asmodeus banned the other Lords of Hell from going there because evil sown on that plane can lead to great power... Somehow Mephistopheles found a way, though, and now his power knows no bounds..."
"Yes, the Sleeping Man... In his own way, he is dead like us... Exiled and far from home... Some say it is his sorrow that permeates this place and draws us to it..."
"Why is he sad? ...Why did he leave? ...Why did he come here to Cania? The answers are all the same: His heart had known no love... That is the sorrow of the Sleeping Man."
"It's almost warm in here... Not like outside... It's almost enough to take off the chill, the clawing, biting chill... Even so, it's only a matter of time..."
GENERIC GHOST. FEMALE OR OLD MAN. MULTIPLES. CAN BE FOUND ANYWHERE IN CITY BUT WILL CONCENTRATE NEAR GATES.
"Goodbye."
"Do you know the Reaper's True Name?"
"Who?"
"What is this place?"
"Back to my other questions."

"It's only a matter of time until what?"

The creature seems happy to see you and eager to resume its search.
The odd little creature follows close on your heel, waiting expectantly for you to lead it to the proper stone.
The creature dodges your blow, apparently having already learned to expect this of you. It resumes its sniffing about, eager to find the stone it seeks.
The creature's body is covered in a hard carapace. You graze one of its razor-sharp edges, slicing through your well-worn boots and into your foot.
The creature's body is covered in a hard carapace. It feels warm to the touch, however, despite the dreadful cold. The creature nuzzles your hand, grateful for the attention.
The strange creature emits a sharp crackling noise, then runs around in a circle excitedly. It seems quite pleased that you know its name.
At the Sleeping Man's name, the creature crackles with enthusiasm. A picture forms above its head, depicting a winged man walking alongside the creature, throwing sticks for it to fetch.
The picture shifts and refocuses to show five question marks arranged in a row. The second of them pulses with a blue glow.

Images swarm above the creature's head. A snake-like creature swims through water while "1+1=2" glows brightly amidst a sea of more complex equations and a music note emerges from between closed lips.
The creature seems pleased that it was able to help, though it soon begins sniffing about, eager to find the stone it seeks.
The creature seems unsure how to express its intent more clearly. Almost apologetically, it forms the image of a rectangular stone pillar, buried in the ice amidst the city's squalor.
The creature crackles in apparent glee. It seems to enjoy this sort of game.
The creature sits on the frozen ground, patiently waiting for you to formulate your thoughts.
The creature conjures up an image of a gray, rectangular pillar jutting up from the ice amidst the city's squalor. There appears to be something written down the side.
The creature shows you a series of four pictures: A traveler's resting house, a shark cutting through the water, a close-up of a winking face, and steam rising from a cup and saucer.
The creature shows you a man on his deathbed, then two others standing side by side, then a fourth man's leg, bared between his ankle-high boots and knee-length breeches.
The creature shows you a sturdy oak, full with leaves, then a boy held in his father's arms. This second image seems to be focused on the boy rather than the father.
The creature sniffs around the base of the stone, confused. Dissatisfied, it trots back to the previous stone to re-orient itself.
The creature sniffs around the base of the stone, confused. Dissatisfied, it waits for you to move on.
The creature sniffs around the base of the stone. It crackles excitedly, grateful that you were able to lead it to the right one.
This appears to be the final stone. The creature sniffs around its base, and then heads toward one of the icy walls nearby.
Content with its handiwork, the Scrivener stands aside as you peer into the pale blue ice. There, so recently etched, you read the name "Aribeth de Tylmarande."
Peering closer at the pale blue ice, you see the recently carved name, "Aribeth de Tylmarande."
The creature seems too weary to argue with you but you can sense that it is as glad to be rid of you as you are of it. With plodding steps, it wanders off into the snow, leaving you alone.
The creature seems too weary to crackle any further but you can sense its gratitude. With plodding steps, it wanders off into the snow, leaving you alone.
The creature forms an image of the frozen woman passing by at the head of an angry crowd of spirits, leading them toward the gates. The image fades away sadly.
The creature crackles in acknowledgement. It appears weary now that its task is done.
Now the creature shows you a series of four pictures: A traveler's resting house, a shark cutting through the water, a close-up of a winking face, and steam rising from a cup and saucer.
Now the creature shows you a man on his deathbed, then two others standing side by side, then a fourth man's leg, bared between his ankle-high boots and knee-length breeches.
A small, dog-like creature paces back and forth before the cave entrance, whining in frustration. As you approach, it turns to you, apparently eager for help.
The creature dodges your blow, apparently having already learned to expect this of you. It resumes its whining at the cavern entrance.
The creature's body is covered in a hard carapace. You graze one of its razor-sharp edges, slicing through your well-worn boots and into your foot.

The creature's body is covered in a hard carapace. It feels warm to the touch, however, despite the dreadful cold. The creature nuzzles your hand, grateful for the attention, though it continues to whimper softly.
The creature stops whining and seems to focus its attention on you. To your surprise, an image begins to form above its head, illuminated by a dim blue light that seems to filter through from above.

Looking closer, you see a woman sheathed in ice and perfectly still. A look of utter despair marks her cold, blue face and only the merest breath escapes her frozen lips. The creature resumes its whining.

The creature forms an image of an icy wall, etched with countless names. The wall seems infinitely long, scrolling by in dizzying twists and turns to finally reveal a single blank space where a new one can be carved.

The image then transforms into a series of carved rectangular stones that the creature seems to use for navigation. You can sense the creature's desire to go to one of them but you can't determine which one.
A pair of images coalesces above the creature's head. The first image is that of a sturdy oak, full with leaves.
The second image is of a boy held in a man's arms. You can see a family resemblance between them but the father doesn't seem to be the focus of the image.
The creature crackles contentedly, eager to be off. It clings closely to your heels, following your lead.

The creature seems unsure how to express its intent more clearly. The images it showed you must provide some means of distinguishing between the different stones. You'll have to pay closer attention to them.
A new image begins to form. In this one, the woman's frozen statue is slowly sinking into the ice below it, subsumed into the glacial mass. In time, there is nothing left but a sense of emptiness.
Jumping up excitedly, the creature emits a series of sharp crackling noises, seemingly in confirmation to your question.
The creature ignores your question, continuing to whine at the cavern's barricaded entrance.

The strange creature emits a sharp crackling noise, then runs around in a circle excitedly. It seems quite pleased that you know its name. Glancing at the cave entrance, however, it resumes its previous whining.
At the Sleeping Man's name, the creature crackles with enthusiasm. A picture forms above its head, depicting a winged man walking alongside the creature, throwing sticks for it to fetch.
The picture shifts and refocuses to show five question marks arranged in a row. The second of them pulses with a blue glow.

Images swarm above the creature's head. A snake-like creature swims through water while "1+1=2" glows brightly amidst a sea of more complex equations and a music note emerges from between closed lips.
The creature seems pleased that it was able to help, though it soon resumes its whining before the cavern entrance.
The creature seems unsure how to express its intent more clearly. Almost apologetically, it forms the image of a rectangular stone pillar, buried in the ice amidst the city's squalor.
The crackling drops in pitch, becoming angrier, before the creature ignores you, leaving you to the cold.
The creature crackles sharply, eager to continue.
The creature sits, waiting patiently as you formulate your thoughts.
The creature seems too weary to crackle any further. With plodding steps, it wanders off into the snow, leaving you alone.
THE SCRIVENER, A DOG-LIKE CREATURE WHINING AT THE ENTRANCE TO ARIBETH'S CAVE. IT SPEAKS IN MENTALLY PROJECTED IMAGES, REBUS-STYLE.
"All right, let's carry on, then."
<StartAction>Kick the creature.</Start>
<StartAction>Pet the creature.</Start>
"Are you the Scrivener?"
"I seek the Five-Fold Mysteries of the Sleeping Man..."
"You know the Second-Fold Mystery. Show me."
"Thank you."
"I don't understand..."
"So this is a guessing game, is it?"
"Back to my other questions."
"Remind me what these stones look like."
"What stone am I leading you to again?"
"Finally. Now get lost, dog meat, I've got work to do."
"There we go. Do you feel better now?"
"Did you know her at all?"
"That's the frozen woman, is it?"
<StartAction>Leave.</Start>
<StartAction>Kick the creature.</Start>
<StartAction>Pet the creature.</Start>
"What are you whining about now?"
"What's the matter, little fellow?"
"So she's freezing to death. What's the big deal?"
"How can I help?"
"Which stone do you want me to take you to?"
"All right, off we go, then."
"So this is a guessing game, is it?"
"I don't understand..."
"What's happening to her?"
"She's in that cave?"
"Who is she?"
"Are you the Scrivener?"
"I seek the Five-Fold Mysteries of the Sleeping Man..."
"You know the Second-Fold Mystery. Show me."
"Thank you."
"I don't understand..."
"Stupid mutt..."
"So this is a guessing game, is it?"
"Back to my other questions."
A sea of names has been etched into the ice, buried between its countless layers. Many of them are so deep that you can only make out their dim outlines amidst the soft blue light.
This woman is stooped over a small bush, picking berries from it and placing them in a small pouch beside her on the ice.
"If I knew the Reaper's True Name, would I be picking nettles in Baator's depths in the dim hope that I won't freeze to death?"
"From the Material Plane, are you? Hmph. Well you can forget it, there's no going home. The Gates are closed for you and me both. We stay here until we freeze or die of boredom."
"Pfft. Do you have a better idea? Give it up, berk, you're trapped and clueless to boot."
"Who, Swift? He had plans to wake the Sleeping Man 'til the sensei put a stop to him. I don't know the details but he's not making himself any friends. The Hells are bad enough without a comedian."

"Ask him, I want no part of it. Oh, and I don't recommend trusting him any farther than you can throw him, especially where money's concerned. My gold's paid for more of his tavern bill than I care to admit."
"This here's a Velox Nettle. They've got deep roots going down to the lava pools beneath the ice and their berries store the heat. It's the only way to start a decent fire around here."
"Sure, but make it quick, it's freezing out here."
"The tavern keeper's been letting some of us pay our tabs with them so he'll have a few. The Quarry Master might have some as well. Other than that, you'll just have to find them where they grow."
"As I said, though, they like what heat they can find. If you spy a steam fissure like this in the ice, there'll probably be a Velox Nettle basking in that little bit of warmth."

"If you spy some wood, you just break the berries open over it and the heat will set it alight. A single berry won't get you a whole lot of warmth, though. I recommend a good three-berry fire if you can afford it."
"What are you, daft? It's freezing cold out here and there isn't enough room in the tavern for everybody. You've got to sleep somewhere, right? And for that you're going to need a good fire."
"Bah! Mage-fire's so unpredictable. Here one second and gone the next. It's fine for burning things but if you need to cook or make camp out here, you're going to need Velox Berries."
"Have you tried it?"
"The Mysteries? Don't bother, I'm sure the sensei made all of them up. I'm willing to bet there isn't even a Sleeping Man at all."

"We sold everything we owned to come on this Pilgrimage. We've traveled all the way from Limbo, only to end up trapped in the Eighth Hell of Baator for all eternity. And, now that we're here, she won't even let us see him."

"Not until we learn the Five-Fold Mysteries, she says. Well, I've figured out the third one and it reads like a three-penny fantasy novel. Just the sort of romantic notion that the sensei would dream up..."

"Why did he leave? Because his heart had known no love. Utter rubbish. She's created this Sleeping Man out of whole cloth and, what's worse, she's become hopelessly smitten with this character she's created."
"Goodbye."
"Do you know the Reaper's True Name?"
"I need to return home to the world of Toril."
"That's a defeatist attitude..."
"That winged chap in the tavern... You know him?"
"How did he plan to wake the Sleeping Man?"
"What are you picking?"
"Back to my other questions."
"Where can I find these Velox Berries?"
"How do these berries work?"
"Why do you need to start a fire?"
"Mage-fire doesn't work?"
"Flint and tinder doesn't work?"
"I seek answers to the Five-Fold Mysteries."
"What do you mean?"
"Romantic?"
Worry lines crease this shrewish woman's mottled, ash-grey face. You can tell that there are countless other places she would rather be than here.
Fierce-looking as he is, this man seems intensely bored. His dour expression seems well suited to the gray pallor of his face.
"If I knew the Reaper's True Name, would I be huddled around this fire right now, trying not to freeze?"
"If I knew the Reaper's True Name, would I be sitting in a smoky tavern in the depths of Baator, frittering away my life's savings on foul-smelling mulled ale?"
"From the Material Plane are you? Hmph. Well you can forget it, there's no going home. The Gates are closed for you and me both. We stay here until we freeze or die of boredom."
"Pfft. Do you have a better idea? Give it up, berk, you're trapped and clueless to boot."
The githzerai gives you a sullen glare before turning away in boredom.
"Why so perky, berky? You're stuck here just as much as we are, freezing in the cold, huddling around campfires... What I'd give to be back in Limbo."

"Sensei Dharvana came to our monastery, preaching about the teachings of the Sleeping Man. It all sounded so wonderful... We sold all our belongings to finance our Pilgrimage here, to Cania, so we could see him."
"Only now the Gates have been closed and we're trapped here and the sensei won't even let us see this stupid Sleeping Man that we came here to see. Truth be told, I don't even think he exists."
"She says the Pilgrimage is a lesson in patience. No one's allowed to see the Sleeping Man until they've solved a bunch of mysteries about him. It's all just made up anyways..."
"Well I got as far as the third one before I gave up. The sensei wanted us to know why he left his home and I got to thinking about why all of us left on this Pilgrimage."

"Our hearts had known no love. We lived this drab, gray existence in the wastes of Limbo and along came the sensei, so full of life and passion. She had found something to love and I guess we wanted that, too."
"Look, if you're that curious, go ask the sensei. I'm sure she'll tell you all about him."
"Sensei Dharvana, she's the one who got us into this mess. You can find her out in the temple with her precious Sleeping Man in the northwest quarter of town. Big ornate place, you can't miss it."
"Being trapped in the Eighth Hell with no hope for return isn't enough of a mess for you, is that it?"
"It's my home plane. I'm from Limbo, born and raised. My great great grandfather built the monastery I grew up in, shaped it out of pure chaos. Now I'll never see it again."
"Why so perky, berky? You're stuck here just as much as we are, coming in from the awful cold, drinking our life's savings away on mulled ale, suffering the jibes of that tiefling, Swift..."
"The Hells had a jester, so it seems. Thanks for putting an end to him when you did, mate. A bunch of us were thinking of doing the same."

"The Hells have a jester, so it seems. Swift hooked up with us along the way and has made a nuisance of himself ever since. He had a tiff with the sensei recently, and now he's here drowning his sorrows."
"The joker had plans to wake the Sleeping Man. I'm not saying he exists, mind you, but you don't go rubbing salt in another berk's wounds. It doesn't matter. Let him and the sensei have their fight."
"Look, if you're that curious, go ask the sensei. I'm sure she'll tell you all about him."
"Sensei Dharvana, she's the one who got us into this mess. You can find her out in the temple with her precious Sleeping Man in the northwest quarter of town. Big ornate place, you can't miss it."
"Look, if you're that curious, go ask the sensei. I'm sure she'll tell you all about him."
"Being trapped in the Eighth Hell with no hope for return isn't enough of a mess for you, is that it?"
"Who, Swift? He had plans to wake the Sleeping Man 'til the sensei put a stop to him. I don't know the details but he's not making himself any friends. The Hells bad enough without a comedian."

"Ask him, I want no part of it. Oh, and I don't recommend trusting him any farther than you can throw him, especially where money's concerned. My gold's paid for more of his tavern bill than I care to admit."
"The Mysteries? Don't bother, I'm sure the sensei made all of them up. I'm willing to bet there isn't even a Sleeping Man at all."

"We sold everything we owned to come on this Pilgrimage. We've traveled all the way from Limbo, only to end up trapped in the Eighth Hell of Baator for all eternity. And, now that we're here, she won't even let us see him."

"Not until we learn the Five-Fold Mysteries, she says. Well, I've figured out the third one and it reads like a three-penny fantasy novel. Just the sort of romantic notion that the sensei would dream up..."

"Why did he leave? Because his heart had known no love. Utter rubbish. She's created this Sleeping Man out of whole cloth and, what's worse, she's become hopelessly smitten with this character she's created."
GENERIC GITHZERAI PILGRIM, BOTH GENDERS. MULTIPLES PLACED BUT THEY'RE FOUND PRIMARILY AROUND THE TAVERN AND TEMPLE (BUT NOT INSIDE THE TEMPLE).
"Goodbye."
"Do you know the Reaper's True Name?"
"I need to return home to the world of Toril."
"That's a defeatist attitude..."
"Been here long?"
"Why so glum, chum?"
"Why did you come here?"
"Why won't she let you see him?"
"What kinds of mysteries?"
"Who's the Sleeping Man?"
"The sensei? Who's that?"
"What mess did the sensei get you into?"
"Limbo? Where's that?"
"Tiefling?"
"Why, what issue did you have with him?"

"Who's the Sleeping Man?"
"The sensei? Who's that?"
"Who's the Sleeping Man?"
"What mess did the sensei get you into?"

"I seek answers to the Five-Fold Mysteries."
"What do you mean?"
"Romantic?"
The old tiefling has his deck of cards out again. He cocks you a smile as you approach.

An elderly man with a lopsided grin casually shuffles cards at a side table, occasionally earning the scowls of some of the more dour-faced patrons. Two horns protrude from his forehead, one slightly chipped.
"Then you're a fool beyond words. So much so that I'll take a bit of pity on you and give you a second chance. Now tell me true: how much is a True Name worth?"
"Not enough, not near enough... But thank you, I'll take that as a down payment. Now tell me true, berk: how much is a True Name worth?"
"Not enough, not near enough... But thank you, I'll take that as a down payment. Now tell me true, berk: how much is a True Name worth?"
"Not enough, not near enough... But thank you, I'll take that as a down payment. Now tell me true, berk: how much is a True Name worth?"
"Not enough, not near enough... But thank you, I'll take that as a down payment. Now tell me true, berk: how much is a True Name worth?"
"Easily said for a <man/woman> who has nothing. No wits, no guile, no sense of humor... Keep your money and possessions. You bore me, you poor sod."
"Fine, fine. I've been around these old birds long enough not to be clueless and I reckon I've figured out the sensei's fourth-fold mystery, at any rate."
The man's compulsive card-shuffling slows briefly before resuming. "She and I had a little tussle, you could say."
"I suppose stranger things have been called the same. I've been around these old birds long enough not to be clueless and I reckon I've figured out the sensei's fourth-fold mystery, at any rate."

"Alright, it's a fair enough tale to spin... Long before the devils laid claim to Cania, it was home to a race called the Knowers. They were collectors, catalogers of lore and some say they're still alive out there."
"Let the sensei call it her fourth-fold mystery if she wishes but, when the Sleeping Man came to Cania, he came in search of one Knower in particular: the Knower of Places."

"Oh, an old bard gets around and lore is our specialty. Any bard in Baator can tell you a smattering about the Knowers. For a traveling man such as myself, I take a keen interest in the Knower of Places."

"Think of it: the planes are too vast to comprehend! In such a reality, what answer becomes prized above all else? The Sleeping Man was wise, I'll give him that. He knew to ask the 'Where' of things."

"There's the rub, berk. The Knowers were never warriors and the devils drove them to the brink of extinction. The story goes that the Knower of Places knew a place where she could hide and so she did."
"And who would know a better place to hide than her? I doubt the Sleeping Man ever found her. From the looks of things, he exhausted himself in the trying of it. Sorry, berk."
"Oh, long enough I reckon. Long enough to have figured out the fourth-fold mystery of the Sleeping Man, at any rate. He came here looking for someone and I think I know who."

"The Sleeping Man? Well, long ago, before the devils laid their claim on Cania, this place was home to a race called the Knowers. They were collectors, catalogers of lore and it's said that some of them still survive."
"Let the sensei call it her fourth-fold mystery if she wishes but, when the Sleeping Man came to Cania, he came in search of one Knower in particular: the Knower of Places."

"Oh, you'll find her in the temple just north of here, tending to the Sleeping Man. The sensei is the one who brought all of these pouting pilgrims here. Not a single sense of humor to be shared among them, I'm afraid."

"Oh, an old bard gets around and lore is our specialty. Any bard in Baator can tell you a smattering about the Knowers. For a traveling man such as myself, I take a keen interest in the Knower of Places."

"Think of it: the planes are too vast to comprehend! In such a reality, what answer becomes prized above all else? The Sleeping Man was wise, I'll give him that. He knew to ask the 'Where' of things."

"There's the rub, berk. The Knowers were never warriors and the devils drove them to the brink of extinction. The story goes that the Knower of Places knew a place where she could hide and so she did."
"And who would know a better place to hide than her? I doubt the Sleeping Man ever found her. From the looks of things, he exhausted himself in the trying of it. Sorry, berk."
The horned man spits and the shuffling of his cards grows all the more fierce. "If you've got questions about the Sleeping Man, go talk to the sensei. I've washed my hands of it."

"Oh, you'll find her in the temple just north of here, tending to the Sleeping Man. The sensei is the one who brought all of these pouting pilgrims here. Not a single sense of humor to be shared among them, I'm afraid."

"Just a harmless joke was all. These pouting pilgrims keep prattling on about 'the Sleeping Man this' and 'the Sleeping Man that.' The thought of waking the old guy up started tickling my funny bone."
"Needless to say, when the sensei caught wind of it, she didn't take too kindly to the idea."

"Oh, you'll find her in the temple just north of here, tending to the Sleeping Man. The sensei is the one who brought all of these pouting pilgrims here. Not a single sense of humor to be shared among them, I'm afraid."
"Oh, an old bard gathers a few trinkets along the way. There's an instrument-maker in Sigil whose trumpets are fashioned with a small portal to the Plane of Pandemonium..."

"Put your lips to it and blow and all the howling winds of that mad place blow with you. I was planning to lean up close and put it right to his ear... Nothing can sleep through such a cacophony, not even the Sleeping Man."
"Oh, it's just some of the sensei's mumbo-jumbo. She's turned the Sleeping Man into a religion for all these pouting pilgrims, and the five mysteries have become an initiation rite of sorts."

"Oh, you'll find her in the temple just north of here, tending to the Sleeping Man. The sensei is the one who brought all of these pouting pilgrims here. Not a single sense of humor to be shared among them, I'm afraid."

"You're clueless, then, are you berk? That's okay, someone's got to be clueless or the rest of us wouldn't have anyone to explain things to. You see, 'Where' is a difficult sort of question in the planes."

"Look up and maybe Limbo's way above us somewhere. Or maybe, if you travel far enough east, you'll get there. Or Limbo could be through this knothole in the wood or maybe Limbo's just a different way of seeing things."

"Don't we all. The only ones who seem content to stay are the devils themselves and most of them only because someone more powerful threatened them with worse. Welcome to the City of Lost Souls, friend."

"Who does? The planes aren't there to be understood, berk. You'll go mad trying to. The best advice is just to let go and learn to accept the planes for what they are. When you do that, you'll no longer be clueless."

"Have you no eyes? The tavern's full of them! Grey skin, dour faces, overly pious with their whispered voices, all of them led to the depths of the Nine Hells by that fool lass, the sensei. All of it in the name of the Sleeping Man."
The horned man spits and the shuffling of his cards grows all the more fierce. "If you've got questions about the Sleeping Man, go talk to the sensei. I've washed my hands of it."

"Just a harmless joke was all. These pouting pilgrims keep prattling on about 'the Sleeping Man this' and 'the Sleeping Man that.' The thought of waking the old guy up started tickling my funny bone."

"Oh, you'll find her in the temple just north of here, tending to the Sleeping Man. The sensei is the one who brought all of these pouting pilgrims here. Not a single sense of humor to be shared among them, I'm afraid."
"Recent enough." The slapping sound of the card's shuffling slows briefly before resuming. "I had me a little tussle with the sensei."

"Oh, you'll find her in the temple just north of here, tending to the Sleeping Man. The sensei is the one who brought all of these pouting pilgrims here. Not a single sense of humor to be shared among them, I'm afraid."

"Have you no eyes? The tavern's full of them! Grey skin, dour faces, overly pious with their whispered voices, all of them led to the depths of the Nine Hells by that fool lass, the sensei. All of it in the name of the Sleeping Man."
The horned man spits, never interrupting his shuffling of the cards. "If you've got questions about the Sleeping Man, go talk to the sensei. I've washed my hands of it."

"Needless to say, when the sensei caught wind of it, she didn't take too kindly to the idea."

"Put your lips to it and blow and all the howling winds of that mad place blow with you. I was planning to lean up close and put it right to his ear... Nothing can sleep through such a cacophony, not even the Sleeping Man."

His shuffling stops, the deck of cards slipping into his pocket as he reaches for another. "Nothing is free, berk, but it doesn't look like I'll be using it, not with the sensei watching me like a hawk..."
"For the price of a little entertainment, I'd be willing to let you keep the blasted thing. Are you interested?"
"Sure, sure. It's good to have questions. Keeps the mind sharp."

"Alright, I'm going to teach you a little card trick. I'll let you shuffle the deck and then I'm going to draw a card. You can ask five 'yes or no' questions about the card and then you have to guess what it is."
"Aces are low, Kings are high, and there's no Joker here but me, understood?"
"Sure thing. It's a simple card trick. You shuffle the deck and then I'm going to draw a card. You get to ask five 'yes or no' questions about the card and then you have to guess what it is."

"One more thing. Let's up the ante: Empty your pockets onto the table. I'll let you know when it's enough. If you win, you get it all back and the trumpet besides. If you lose, I sweep the table and we play again."
"They're the only ones I play by. If you don't like them, then there's no game. If you change your mind, just come back and ask me about that trumpet."
The old man paws through your belongings, biting the gold and squinting at everything in the dim light. At long last, he turns his attention back to you...
"Perfect." He eyes you as you shuffle the cards. With a disarming smile, he draws one from the deck.
"Fine, but quitters pay, berk." You watch as the old bard sweeps the contents of the table into his satchel.
"Okay, no more questions. Come on, give me your best guess, berk. What card do you think it was?"
The tiefling fingers the items on the table as he awaits your question. He seems well pleased with your ante.
The old man seems distracted, almost bored by your ponderous deliberations.
A sly grin comes over the tiefling's face as you ponder what question to ask.
Your opponent sighs heavily and readjusts himself in his seat.

"No." <StartCheck>[Wisdom: Success] You're pretty sure he's lying to you.</Start>
"No." <StartCheck>[Wisdom: Success] You're pretty sure he's telling the truth.</Start>
"Yes." <StartCheck>[Wisdom: Failure] You have no idea whether or not he's telling the truth.</Start>
"Yes." <StartCheck>[Wisdom: Success] You're pretty sure he's lying to you.</Start>
"Yes." <StartCheck>[Wisdom: Success] You're pretty sure he's telling the truth.</Start>
"Okay, no more questions. Come on, give me your best guess, berk. What card do you think it was?"
The old bard carefully keeps his face devoid of all emotion. You suspect you're not the first person he's played this game with.
"Wrong, my friend. Wrong, wrong, wrong." He tosses the card facedown onto the table where it bursts into flame and is gone. He sweeps your ante into his satchel. "Ready for another try?"
He bursts into gales of laughter and reaches over to clap you on the back. "Well done, my friend, well done! Clear the table for yourself and take the trumpet too! You'll do well in these parts."
He claps his hands and a new deck of cards suddenly emerges between his fingers. With a final wink in your direction, he busies himself with his shuffling.
A bead of sweat trickles down the old man's brow. "Heh. Coming down to the wire, is it?"
"Only two questions left, now. Keep them coming."
"You've got three more questions so I recommend you put them to good use."
The old tiefling chuckles to himself and shakes his head. "Pick up the pace a little, berk. You've still got four questions left."
"Cough up, little <man/woman>. That's not near enough. I'm looking for something on the order of 5,000 gold on that table."
"Those are higher stakes than the 5,000 gold I'd been expecting. If you want to take something off the table, I won't hold it against you..."
"I came to the Hells for a holiday, berk. I don't get scared." With a disarming smile, he draws a card from the deck.
"Aye, we're called tieflings, berk. Devils and demons being what they are, I reckon there's fiendish blood in most of us, to be honest. Angels just don't get around as much, if you catch my meaning."
"My... My True Name! How could you know such a thing!? Ack, I can feel its tug upon my soul... What do you want from me, fiend?"
"Y-y-yes, of course. Other questions! How can I help?"
"If it is fame you seek, <Master/Mistress>, fame I can grant you. The bardic services of Arden Swift are at your service from this moment to my dying day... Is there anything else you wish of me?"
"Caddisthwaite the Doomed, is it? Well I'll show the gods and the bloody tavernkeeper, too..."
"My winnings? Damn you, then, take it all! Easy come, easy go, they say... Is there anything else you demand, <Master/Mistress>?"
The bard winks at you but continues shuffling his cards. He's trying to make eye contact with one of the other patrons and apparently has no desire to talk with you any more than he has to.
The old tiefling pauses in his card shuffling, cackling with laughter as you approach.
A MALE TIEFLING WHO FELL IN WITH THE GITHZERAI PILGRIMAGE. CAN BE FOUND IN THE HELLBREATH TAVERN.
"Goodbye."
"Do you know the Reaper's True Name?"
"It's not worth anything."
"Here, have 10,000 gold."
"Here, have 50,000 gold."
"Here, have 100,000 gold."
"Here, have 250,000 gold."
"I'll give you everything I have."

"That is alright. They have little inherent value and are easily fashioned. I always keep a few on hand for new Pilgrims that come my way."
"Among the githzerai, crystals of various sorts are used to focus and amplify the thoughts of others, making them easier to read. I'm not sure if it will work for one such as you."
"Simply wear it about your neck as you reach out to the Sleeping Man. With a little luck, you will see his dreams."
The sensei smiles as you approach but her eyes remain closed in meditation. In your mind, you feel her grant you permission to speak.
"Before they can behold the Sleeping Man, new Pilgrims must answer his Five-Fold Mysteries: Who is he? From where did he come? Why did he leave? Who did he seek? What was the answer?"
"All who come to the Sleeping Man are Pilgrims on this journey we call life. Like him, we travel the planes, restless for answers. Like him, we'll someday find them."

"There are countless ways: spells, portals, vortices, shifting banks of fog or shadow. Not all work in all places, either. Here in Cania, there are only two: the Gate and the tributaries of the River Styx."

"The Gate leads almost anywhere, provided the Reaper will do your bidding. The tributaries of the River Styx, however, flow only downwards, to Nessus, the Ninth and final layer of Baator. I have not traveled them, nor do I intend to."

"Beyond using his True Name to bind him to your will as Mephistopheles has, I cannot say. Perhaps the Sleeping Man once knew. Until he dreams the answer, my Pilgrims and I are trapped here, just like you."

"The Sleeping Man dreams many things and, when he does, those dreams dance across the surface of his thoughts where I can see them. Much of what I have learned of his mysteries I learned through dreams."
"His dreams have formed the very tenets of my faith and brought my Pilgrims and I closer to our enlightenment. Through his dreams I have come to know the Five-Fold Mysteries of the Sleeping Man..."
"Who is he? From where did he come? Why did he leave? Who did he seek? What was the answer? ...All who wish to behold the Sleeping Man must learn these Five-Fold Mysteries."
"Where would such a tale begin and where would it end? The planes are as infinite in variety as they are in their number. They cannot be described; they must be lived."
"My home monastery in Limbo floats within a sphere of water that, in turn, orbits an ever-changing chunk of rock on which grows and dies an endless forest. What words can make that plain?"
"It is refreshing to see such an inquisitive mind. As the Sleeping Man teaches, until you find your answer, you must never stop asking questions. Now what is it you wish to know?"
"I am a sensei of the githzerai. I have trained all my life to read the surface thoughts of those before me."
"It is refreshing to see such an inquisitive mind. As the Sleeping Man teaches, until you find your answer, you must never stop asking questions. Now what is it you wish to know?"
"Once, long ago, we were almost human. The Mindflayers held an empire that spanned the planes and, under their vicious command, we suffered countless centuries of slavery."

"Little by little, we adapted. Our skin turned grey and mottled from lack of sun and leathery to withstand the beatings. They prized the mind above all else and bred us accordingly. Over time, our minds became like theirs."

"Slowly, we learned to defend ourselves against their mental probing and small pockets of escaped slaves emerged. A hero by the name of Gith rose up among their number and ultimately overthrew the oppressors."

"Together with our brothers, the githyanki, we are the children of that rebellion, many generations now removed. A split came between the githyanki and ourselves but that is a story for another time."
"The githyanki keep largely to the Astral Plane and the githzerai to our monasteries on the plane of Limbo though some, like myself, still travel beyond."

"There are countless ways: spells, portals, vortices, shifting banks of fog or shadow. Not all work in all places, either. Here in Cania, there are only two: the Gate and the tributaries of the River Styx."

"The Gate leads almost anywhere, provided the Reaper will do your bidding. The tributaries of the River Styx, however, flow only downwards, to Nessus, the Ninth and final layer of Baator. I have not traveled them, nor do I intend to."

"Beyond using his True Name to bind him to your will as Mephistopheles has, I cannot say. Perhaps the Sleeping Man once knew. Until he dreams the answer, my Pilgrims and I are trapped here, just like you."

"The Sleeping Man dreams many things and, when he does, those dreams dance across the surface of his thoughts where I can see them. Much of what I have learned of his mysteries I learned through dreams."
"His dreams have formed the very tenets of my faith and brought my Pilgrims and I closer to our enlightenment. Through his dreams I have come to know the Five-Fold Mysteries of the Sleeping Man..."

"My home monastery in Limbo floats within a sphere of water that, in turn, orbits an ever-changing chunk of rock on which grows and dies an endless forest. What words can make that plain?"

"As masters of mind, body, and spirit, we sensei lead our fellow githzerai both to greater wisdom and to victory over our enemies. In your language we would be known as monks though much is lost in the translation."
"We githzerai strive to be a peaceful people and have separated ourselves from others in our attempts to find that peace."
"Our brothers, the githyanki, continue to hunt us, however, and we have not yet forgiven the Mindflayers who we once served as slaves. It could be argued that our enemies have made us who we are."

"Of a sort... Your mind is like a vast library and my talents let me run my finger across the spines of its many tomes. I can read their titles and guess their contents but I can never take them down and truly read."

"Even with its limits, it is a gift I treasure for this is how, title by title, spine by spine, I have come to know the secret wisdom of the Sleeping Man. It is through my gift that I have touched his dreams."

"There are countless ways: spells, portals, vortices, shifting banks of fog or shadow. Not all work in all places, either. Here in Cania, there are only two: the Gate and the tributaries of the River Styx."

"Why do any of us journey so far from home? I'm afraid that is the third-fold mystery of the Sleeping Man. You will have to answer it yourself."
"Just as Cania is home to many sorts of devils, so too are there many types of angels, ranging from the lowly archons, to the mighty devas, planetars, and solars."
"From many places. Some say the angels are all around us, even here. As for where the Sleeping Man is from, that is his second-fold mystery and you will have to discover that yourself."

"Before they can behold the Sleeping Man, new Pilgrims must answer his Five-Fold Mysteries: Who is he? From where did he come? Why did he leave? Who did he seek? What was the answer?"

"There are countless ways: spells, portals, vortices, shifting banks of fog or shadow. Not all work in all places, either. Here in Cania, there are only two: the Gate and the tributaries of the River Styx."

"The Gate leads almost anywhere, provided the Reaper will do your bidding. The tributaries of the River Styx, however, flow only downwards, to Nessus, the Ninth and final layer of Baator. I have not traveled them, nor do I intend to."

"Beyond using his True Name to bind him to your will as Mephistopheles has, I cannot say. Perhaps the Sleeping Man once knew. Until he dreams the answer, my Pilgrims and I are trapped here, just like you."

"To know one's True Name is to know one's true self and it is said that to find the one is to find the other. As to the how of it, perhaps that is something the Sleeping Man can answer for you."

"Who is he? From where did he come? Why did he leave? Who did he seek? What was the answer? ...All who wish to behold the Sleeping Man must learn these Five-Fold Mysteries."
"Very well. Let us see if you are ready... Answer me, Pilgrim: Who is the Sleeping Man?"
"Yes, his is a pure soul with no trace of pride or vice or vengeance. In following him, we take on his beneficence... Now answer me, Pilgrim: From where did he come?"
"That he does. Elysium is a place of beauty and peace and perfection, yet he turned his back on it and never returned, choosing instead to roam the planes... So answer me, Pilgrim: Why did he leave?"

"He knew that without passion we are nothing and thus he journeyed many years in search of his true love. His journey brought him here, to the frozen wastes of Cania... Answer me, Pilgrim: Who did he seek?"

"The Knowers ruled this plane before the Baatezu claimed it as one of their Hells. In his wisdom, the Sleeping Man asked simply where his true love would be found... Tell me, Pilgrim: What was the answer?"

"I am sorry, but it's clear you are not ready to enter his resting chamber. Spend some time pondering his Five-Fold Mysteries and then return to me. As the Sleeping Man teaches, some things are worth waiting for."

"So he returned here, to the Gates, content in the knowledge that she would find him. Weary from his journeys, he fell asleep. That was all long, long ago but still he waits here, dreaming of his true love."
"You have mastered the Five-Fold Mysteries of the Sleeping Man, Pilgrim. When you enter his chambers, wear this crystal around your neck... It will help you see his dreams."
"It is refreshing to see such an inquisitive mind. As the Sleeping Man teaches, until you find your answer, you must never stop asking questions. Now what is it you wish to know?"
"Where would such a tale begin and where would it end? The planes are as infinite in variety as they are in their number. They cannot be described; they must be lived."
"My home monastery in Limbo floats within a sphere of water that, in turn, orbits an ever-changing chunk of rock on which grows and dies an endless forest. What words can make that plain?"

"As masters of mind, body, and spirit, we sensei lead our fellow githzerai both to greater wisdom and to victory over our enemies. In your language we would be known as monks though much is lost in the translation."
"We githzerai strive to be a peaceful people and have separated ourselves from others in our attempts to find that peace."
"Our brothers, the githyanki, continue to hunt us, however, and we have not yet forgiven the Mindflayers who we once served as slaves. It could be argued that our enemies have made us who we are."

"Of a sort... Your mind is like a vast library and my talents let me run my finger across the spines of its many tomes. I can read their titles and guess their contents but I can never take them down and truly read."

"Even with its limits, it is a gift I treasure for this is how, title by title, spine by spine, I have come to know the secret wisdom of the Sleeping Man. It is through my gift that I have touched his dreams."
You can feel the sensei's mind probing your own, questioning your intent. If you want to pick this lock, you'll have to wait until her attentions are focused elsewhere.
You feel the familiar probe of the sensei's mind. She smiles eagerly at your return.
"Welcome back, Pilgrim. The Sleeping Man has been dreaming of you."
"Much better now that you have opened the gates for us to return home to Limbo. Word had spread among my Pilgrims and we are all simply saying our goodbyes in time for the long journey home."
"Thank you, <FirstName>, at least for that much. As much as I appreciate my times here in the Temple, it is time for me to lead my people home."

"He dreamed of you in the face of a clock that was buried deep beneath the snow. In the icy cold, the Blood War between devils and demons that raged around you staggered to a halt, its anger fully spent."
"I'm still trying to determine what it means, <FirstName>. For what it's worth, he seemed proud of you."
"You have? Why, it's a miracle... It's the fulfilment of the Sleeping Man's dreams, a fulfilment of his prophecies. Please, you must tell me who it is."
"But his one true love! Will you not tell me?"

"A fellow angel then... A part of me had hoped that it would be a mortal. One of us. Maybe even me... If we can be loved, we can be redeemed. If the angels can only pity us, then faith is hollow... I don't know..."

"The one imprisoned by Mephistopheles following the Molikroth rebellion? He was going to ask where she was imprisoned but, not realizing she was his love, he instead asked where his love would find him!"
"The Knower of Places? Why, she was the one who told him to wait here for his love. How very strange... And to think that he has waited all this time for a woman he has already met."

"Nathyrra? I can hardly believe it! Never in my wildest dreams dared I believe that his love would come to him while I yet live. You must be extremely honored to have such an important companion in your midst."
"Aribeth? I can hardly believe it! Never in my wildest dreams dared I believe that his love would come to him while I yet live. It is a great honor to have known her."
"Forgive me, I must go and ponder the significance of this. Please, make yourself at home here in the temple as I may not return for some time."
"Lady Aribeth? The spirit? No, how can this be? She came here, she learned his Five Mysteries, she watched him sleep! But then she became one of the Lost... His one true love is gone forevermore..."

"I must go and ponder the significance of this at once, <FirstName>. He had faith that his true love would find him and that there would be a happy ending. I built my faith on his! If he was wrong..."
"You, <FirstName>? I can hardly believe it! Never in my wildest dreams dared I believe that his love would come to him while I yet live. It is a great honor to have met you."
"But you must be very weary from your travels and warmed by the thought of your love's proximity. I will leave you with him now, that the two of you may have some privacy."

"No, do not tell me, I do not wish to know it. To know it is to face the temptation of using it and to use it is to taint the purity of his will with the impurity of my own. Please, that is a secret you must carry to the grave."
"If that is your wish, Pilgrim..."

"I am glad you have come to your senses. I do not know how many other True Names you know but I pray you use only those you must. The rest, you must never tell a soul... Please, leave me to the Sleeping Man."
"Thank you, <FirstName>. You show a greater wisdom than I often give you credit for. Now please, leave me with the Sleeping Man."

"A curse on you, <FirstName>, for that is power I did not seek and now I must carry it with me to my grave. I can only pray that my will is strong enough to never use it. Now please, leave me with the Sleeping Man."
"I believe that we all have the right to pursue our own destiny, <FirstName>. Using someone's True Name against them violates that right... The Reaper has already had his True Name used against him."
"In such cases, sometimes you must use his True Name to set things right. But it is a fine line. Take care that you do not become like the very devil whom you fight."

"My... My True Name. I can feel it... But Misguided? No, it can't be! Please tell me it isn't true... I have built my entire life around my faith in the Sleeping Man. Please, <FirstName>, as a friend..."
The sensei seems grateful for the change in topic.

"His true love? I am the one he waits for? Oh, I am such a fool, <FirstName>! All these years I've wasted... No, not wasted for I have spent them loving him, but even so... I must wake him, musn't I..."
"With that fool? Very well, if that is all you ask of me, then I shall do it as soon as you are gone. He means well but he must learn someday that not everything can be a joke. Is there more?"

"How, <FirstName>? Tell me how I can do this. Tell me how you can do this to me! Without faith, without him, I am nothing... But you leave me with no choice... Farewell, <FirstName>. Farewell my sleeping love..."
"No! My love! How dare you do this to us! I will find her, I must!"
"No, <FirstName>. He must not be disturbed... It's no use, is it? You have commanded me and so I must... Very well, though I can think of no action more abhorrent that you could make me do."
As she approaches the Sleeping Man, you can feel a pulse of energy pass through your mind. Her tears landing like dew upon his face, she whispers something into his ear and he awakes.
"Who are you? Both of you... I have seen you in my dreams... Why have you woken me, woman?"
"I am sorry, my lord, for had the choice been mine, you would still be at rest... But the <man/woman> over there holds dominion over me, forcing me to act against my will."
"What evil is this? By the power of Celestia's Heavens, release this woman from whatever foul magic you have used against her!"
"But... But m'Lord, I am your one true love... <FirstName>, there, has been to the Knower of Names and swears it is true!"
"What fiendish lies are these!? Out of my sight, woman! You are no more my one true love than this <FirstName> before you is a teller of truths!"
Tears in her eyes, the sensei flees. The Sleeping Man turns his wrathful gaze towards you. "Your lying ways will be the death of you, devil..."
"It's you... I... I have seen you in my dreams! My love, my one true love, at long last you have found me here by the Gates of Cania..."
"Your one true love?"
"Is it... Is it alright if I call you that?"

"Yes, I -- But there is so much to say... But yes, yes, a thousand times yes! There is nothing more that I could want from life than that, my love, but... But my flock, my Pilgrims, they... They need me."
"The flock will find its way back to the fold, my love. They have their own lives to live. You must live yours..."
A FEMALE GITHZERAI SENSEI (MONKLY SPIRITUAL LEADER) WHO LEADS THE PILGRIM FACTION IN THE CITY. HE CAN BE FOUND IN THE TEMPLE OF THE SLEEPING MAN.
"Of course, Sensei."
"I'm sorry, I seem to have lost the amulet you gave me."
"How does this amulet you gave me work?"
"Thank you, Sensei."
"Do you know the Reaper's True Name?"
"The Five-Fold Mysteries? What are those?"
"What do you mean by your Pilgrims?"
"How does one travel from plane to plane?"
"Where do they lead?"
"How can I make the Reaper do my bidding?"
"What do you mean 'until he dreams the answer'?"
"What have you learned from him?"
"What can you tell me about the planes?"
"I need to find a way back home."
"Tell me about the Sleeping Man."
"Back to my other questions."
"How do you know all of this about him?"
"Back to my other questions."
"Who are the githzerai?"

"A veteran of the Blood War."
"A dragon in human form."
"An elven war hero."
"A celestial planetar, creature of good."
"He hails from my home in the world of Toril."
"He hails from the prisons of Carceri."
"He hails from the ever-changing plane of Limbo."
"He hails from the Heavens of Celestia."
"He hails from the Blessed Fields of Elysium."
"He grew bored of beauty and sought, instead, the horrible."
"A seed of evil grew within him."
"Perfection sickened him."
"He was cast out as a traitor."
"His heart had known no love."
"He was seeking his own soul."
"He sought you, Sensei, and hoped to gain from your wisdom."

<StartAction>[Lie]</Start> "It is the Knower of Places."
"It is my companion, Nathyrra."
<StartAction>[Lie]</Start> "It is my companion, Nathyrra."
"It is Lady Aribeth."
<StartAction>[Lie]</Start> "It is Lady Aribeth."

<StartAction>[Lie]</Start> "It is you, Sensei Dharvana."

"I have learned the Sleeping Man's True Name."
