"Fine, I won't tell you then."
"The Sleeping Man is called Celesfa'ar the Patient."
"I don't understand. Why wouldn't you want to know his name?"
"Fa'arethia the Misguided..."
"Back to my other questions."
"You are the Sleeping Man's one true love."
"Reconcile yourself with the tiefling called Arden Swift."
"Abandon your faith. Put the Sleeping Man behind you."
"I command you to wake the Sleeping Man..."
A word is carved into this stone pillar: "Elysium"
A word is carved into this stone pillar: "Coordinate."
A word is carved into this stone pillar: "Dimension."
A word is carved into this stone pillar: "Infinity."
A word is carved into this stone pillar: "Treason."
A word is carved into this stone pillar: "Alternate."
You feel somewhat unnerved beneath the dragon's malevolent gaze. Only in the outer planes, you surmise, would such a creature choose to be a tavernkeeper.
"Can I get you something?" it growls, the corners of its mighty maw curling up in what looks to be an angry sneer.

The tavernkeeper smiles the toothy smile of a true businessman. "I brew a fine Velox Berry Firewater but supply doesn't always keep up with demand... Bring me five Velox Berries and you'll have earned yourself a pint."
"I know how to run a tavern, hunt for my supper, and make a fine swill. The rest I leave to berks like you... Now were you wanting a drink or not?"
The dragon's cruel laugh reverberates throughout the tavern. You hear a tankard shatter in the room beyond. "Give it up, berk. Pull up a chair and have a drink, you're here to stay."

You spy a cold glint in the tavern-keeper's eye. "Gru'ul and I have an arrangement regarding the off-duty quarry workers so here's where they spend their coin. Some of the spirits come here, too, devil knows why."

"As for them Githzerai, they're new here and nothing but trouble, nursing their swill like it's all they have left in life. That winged fellow with them, though, he drinks it hard and fast. I just hope he's good for the money..."
The dragon's warm breath smells like a rotting carcass. You think you can see someone's limb caught between its teeth. "Sleeping, you say? Passed out, more like it..."
"Goodbye."
"Have you got anything to chase off the cold?"
"Nevermind."
<StartAction>Hand over 5 Velox Berries.</Start>
"Do you know the Reaper's True Name?"
"I need to return home to the world of Toril."
"Tell me about your patrons."
"I seek the Five-Fold Mysteries of the Sleeping Man."
<StartAction>[View Store]</Start> "What have you got?"

A brief prayer is written on this card in the Sleeping Man's graceful scrawl: As a child, I learned to Hope. When I became a man, my Hope matured into Faith. With my old age approaching, I pray my Faith bears Love upon its branches.
The Sleeping Man staggers to his feet, confused by the sudden commotion.
The Sleeping Man, now wide awake, looks to you expectantly.
The Sleeping Man squints into the dim green light, his eyes not yet accustomed to the waking world.
<StartCheck>[Saved vs. Discern Lies]</Start> "Aye, she was quick for sure. Assassins of the Blood War are constantly about, sowing chaos where they can..."
<StartCheck>[Saved vs. Discern Lies]</Start> "Aye, the Hells are full of such and they can take a thousand forms. You were right to destroy her fiendish essence."
<StartCheck>[Saved vs. Discern Lies]</Start> "Aye, the Hells are full of such. In such cases, it is often best to grant them the mercies of a second death."
"Yes, I see that now. The Githzerai are rigid in their faith, worshippers of notions and philosophies rather than the gods. Let her godless faith be her solace now, then."
<StartCheck>[Failed Save vs. Discern Lies]</Start> "Your lies betray you, mortal! I am an angel, born of Mount Celestia, and untruth withers beneath my gaze!"

<StartCheck>[Saved vs. Discern Lies]</Start> "Jealous or no, to just taste of love, even for a moment... Do you think my one true love will kill me? No, do not answer. It is not a fate I wish to consider."
"You tell the truth, I see... But what god did she worship and what is this temple she spoke of? I am still at the Gates of Cania, no?"
<StartCheck>[Saved vs. Discern Lies]</Start> "To the south, you say? The glaciers must have shifted, carried me away! But wait, I must not fret. If she is to meet me there then it will be so."
"No glacial drift can void that simple truth. Perhaps you have even seen her, my one true love, already gathered at the Gate! Maybe you brought her to me! Tell me, is she here?"
"Good, good, then all is well... But that trumpet, it would seem to me that you have risked much to sound that blast. Why so?"
"Good, good, then all is well... Yet you cut me, deep and quick, did you not? The wound heals but look, the scar remains. Why did you do that?"
<StartCheck>[Saved vs. Discern Lies]</Start> "What devil are you to have killed her then? ...No, I sense no fiendish blood in you. An evil, perhaps, but no devilry."

"You are like that trumpet that you blew: a devil's sound without the devil's lips... Fair enough, then, but for that woman's life I demand an answer: Have you seen my one true love? Tell me, is she here?"
"Yet you cut me, deep and quick. The wound may heal, but look, the scar remains. Fair enough, but in return, I demand an answer: Have you seen my one true love? Tell me, is she here?"
<StartCheck>[Saved vs. Discern Lies]</Start> "Well, if you wish to kill all the devils of Cania, you have my blessing, then. My only advice is don't burn out too young."
"I admit I have not heard of such a figure but wide are the Planes and unceasing their variety. Still, it smacks of heresy. You were right to put her down."
"Me? I can sense the truth of it but the very notion... it's horrible! Did she not see the heresy in it? You were right to do away with her before such notions spread."
"I swear, it was as if that fell trumpet blast had summoned her from some planar depths to the attack.... It would seem to me that you have risked much to sound that blast. Why so?"
"Yet you cut me, deep and quick. Why did you do that?"
"Well now that I'm awake, I must ask you: Have you seen my true love? Is she here? A part of me is almost scared to ask."
"You have run out of options so you come to me? Here I am, an angel in the depths of Cania, sleeping away the years as I wait for my one true love and you think that I have options?"
"I don't know how to help you. All I know is that I'm waiting for my one true love. Have you seen her? Is she here?"
"Well you have succeeded in that and then some. But why wake me? Why now? My one true love, is she here?"
"Very well. If I can wait for her this long, there is no harm in waiting longer... What is it that you ask of me?"

"Alas, you are not the first to have tried... Somewhere, banished to the furthest wastes of Cania, is a creature called the Knower of Names... The one portion of my quest I was never able to complete..."

"Home... I barely remember it. I have searched so long and even now, my quest is incomplete... Somewhere, banished to the wastes of Cania, is a creature I have never seen called the Knower of Names..."
"I have never heard of this Reaper of whom you speak but as for True Names, I have learned a little. Somewhere between too much and not enough, it always seemed."
"Aye, that was the sole portion of my quest that I was unable to complete... Somewhere, banished to the furthest wastes of Cania, is a creature called the Knower of Names..."
"Where? Bring her to me! I would look upon her face!"

"And I did not mean to be so overzealous. When one pins one's entire life upon a single thing, one tends to lose sight of all outside that goal. But tell me please, this time for true, is my true love here?"
"There is a malice I sense about you, Lady, though a prettier face I have not seen. You leave me unsure... Prove to me you are my true love, however, and I shall love you even in your malice."
"O virtuous woman, daughter of a thousand tears, can it be true? You are a creature of great beauty, that is sure. But are you my one true love? Bring me proof and I shall love you forevermore."

"You? But... But you are not as I had expected... Forgive me but, fool that I am, I have come to yearn for... for more, somehow... No, I cannot believe it. Bring me proof and I shall believe you but not before."
"Her? But she is dead and by your own fell hand! No! I will not believe it! You are but a devil sent to tempt me! If you wish me to believe it, you must bring me proof. All else is falsehood!"
"I know of but one proof, the sole portion of my quest that I was unable to complete... Somewhere, banished to the furthest wastes of Cania, is a creature called the Knower of Names..."
"Yes, about my one true love. Have you seen her?"

"Mephistopheles imprisoned her in the furthest wastes of Cania but the wastes are vast and I know not where her prison lies. But there is one who does and I have relied upon her services once before..."
"That said, I know a ring that will reveal the path that leads to the Knower of Places. She will answer only one question. It is vital that you ask her where you will find the Knower of Names."
"Ah, about the Knower of Names and how I hoped to learn the place to which Mephistopheles banished her..."

"It is a puzzle ring fashioned for me by a modron from the plane of Mechanus. It operates by virtue of hope. Long ago there was an answer I hoped to find and this ring forged the path and led me to it."
"The Ephemeral is also known as the permeating plane of Hope. What you hope for, it reveals. Be careful, however, as some things exist only in the Ephemeral and others not at all."
"Yes, about the ring and my search for the Knower of Places..."
"Before I slept, I built a vault to keep the ring's three pieces safe. Here, let me summon forth the gate... Oh, and forgive the guardians: it was late and I was tired."
"How can it not? It is we who shape our possessions not our possessions who in the end shape us. Though dim may be its light, hope is everywhere, even in the ice of Cania."
"It is a plane that permeates all existence. It's almost more a perspective, a way of seeing or interpreting things than it is a true plane. You cannot travel there, for instance..."

"Nor do I know of any creature that calls it home yet it is always there. It was the path of Hope that led me all the way from Mechanus to the Knower of Places here in Cania. It will do the same for you."
"Yes, the Clockwork Nirvana of Mechanus. It's a paradise of sorts for some. In that plane, there is a city called Regulus that is home to mechanical creatures called modrons."
"They come in many shapes and sizes, some of them cubes, others dodecahedrons. The one who fashioned my ring was an outcast, crippled torus, grizzled and old but full of skill..."
"I was an angel descending to the depths of the Nine Hells. If I was captured and the ring fell into devils' hands, it would lead them to the Knower of Places. I didn't dare endanger her like that."
"The ring is fashioned in three separate pieces that fit together in only one way. If I was captured, I could collapse it and they would never know the better."
"Oh, she will answer more if you ask them right. But as for her domain of knowledge, all the wheres of things, she will only answer one. I never asked her why that is but it was true all the same."
"One of the few Knowers who still remains. So much has been lost to this foolish Blood War... But she is safe, making her home in a place where even the devils will not find her."
"Why, you get to learn the name of my one true love! There is nothing more valuable in all the world!"
"An eternal paradise, then. My love and I will bring you with us when we return to Elysium!"
"Then what is it that you want? Tell me and if it be in my power to give you, it is yours!"
"Yes, let us speak of the Knower of Places. Long has it been since I last spoke to her and the words she spoke have changed my life forever."
"Then who better to seek out than his one-time lover, the Knower of Names, banished by Mephistopheles for fear she might be used against him?"
"I seek the truth and you seek a weapon. She is both! Her truth is your sword, her knowledge his bane! So seek her out and find her... If you will not do it for me, do it for yourself."
"They say there is no place like home and, if that is true, who better to assist you than the Knower of Places? Please, just go to her and all will be made well for both of us."

"No, I do not but if it is a name you seek then it is the Knower of Names that you must find! Our needs, they run in concert, our quests, they are as one... If you will not do it for me, then do it for yourself."
"Simply ask her for the name of my true love and then return to me with its beautiful sound upon your lips. I will be able to tell if you speak the truth."
"Because names are power. Disguised as one Baron Molikroth, Mephistopheles led a rebellion against his own forces to reveal those who his lover, the Knower of Names, had said would betray him."

"In the end he banished eleven of his generals and her as well for he feared that others might use her against him. He sent her away and bid all the Hells forget her... Aye, names are power here, and weakness too."

"The Knowers, or ancient baatorians, were creatures of great wisdom and equal innocence. Frozen Cania was their home long before the devils lay claim to it in their endless Blood War against the demons."
"I faced a choice, a place where I was granted only a single question, a single answer. Do I gamble everything and learn my true love's identity, with no guarantee of ever finding her...?"
"Or do I play it safe and learn where she might find me, knowing then at least that we shall have the fortune to gaze upon each other's face, unrecognized but still in love... I chose the latter."

"Yes, everyone must have one, even a fool such as I and I have searched for her all my long, long life... I have it on good authority that she will find me here and so I wait for her. So tell me, is she here?"
You return to the dais, drawn once more to gaze upon the pale green skin of this strange man. Something about being in his presence makes you feel peaceful.
Words, worn thin with age, have been carved into the dais of the Sleeping Man. "She will meet you by the Gates of Cania," they read in the room's green glow.
The winged figure of the Sleeping Man rests before you in the dim green light. Cautious, you edge closer.
As you approach the Sleeping Man, you can feel the sensei's amulet begin to hum inside your pack.
The amulet around your neck begins to hum as you approach the Sleeping Man and a dim light begins to grow within it.
The Sleeping Man's rest is a deep one that has lasted for untold centuries. You doubt that waking him from his peaceful slumber will be easy.

You draw your blade, testing its edge upon your thumb where it quickly draws a bead of red. Satisfied, you drive your knife deep into the Sleeping Man's thigh, pulling it downwards to leave a gaping wound.

Blood fills the wound, overflowing onto the dais below, painting it the most beautiful red you have ever seen. Even as you watch, the wound begins to heal... The Sleeping Man wakes with a painful groan.
The sound rings off the chamber's thick stone walls but the Sleeping Man doesn't so much as stir. You realize that it will take something far louder than one <man/woman>'s voice to wake him.

You bring the trumpet to your lips and blow. For the barest moment it seems as if the multiverse itself has fallen silent. Then, with a ripping, tearing sound, come the screaming winds of Pandemonium.

The trumpet is sucking all the breath from your lungs. You try to stop blowing but you cannot. Just when you are about to black out, the shrieking fades... Before you, the Sleeping Man stirs and wakes.
The amulet feels warm against your chest. A dim green light grows within its crystalline heart.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> The room is too cold and the worries of the world weigh too heavily upon you. You find yourself unable to concentrate on the amulet and soon give up in disgust.

<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> You focus your thoughts on the crystal, slowly letting the worries of the world slip away. At last, your soul grows still and you find yourself floating through a pale white haze.
Through the haze drift the sounds of battle. "Down with Mephistopheles! Long live Baron Molikroth!" someone cries. "Molikroth is lord of Cania!" cries another. "The battle is ours!"
The pale white curtain parts to reveal a dozen devils and a stranger, white as the mist that cloaks her. One devil, the Baron, looms above the rest, obese and toady. He clears his throat to speak.

His form stretching, growing taller and darker, the Baron thanks the generals for their assistance. They cower in fear before him as he slowly takes his true form: that of Mephistopheles, the Lord they thought defeated.
The pale woman steps forward, a single tear clinging to her cheek. "But what of me, my love? I gave you the True Names of those who would betray you and it has come to pass. Do you believe me now?"
"You are the Knower of Names, my love," he responds in tender voice, "and it is you most of all that I must banish. Names hold too much power in this place and I'll not have you used against me."
The entire maddened world seems to hang suspended in that tear. "Please," she cries, "if you love me, don't let me be banished! I'll stay with you in Mephitis."

Mephistopheles smiles wanly in return. "But, my sweet, I don't love you... I never did." With that, he sends her hurtling through the starless sky, a flaming comet headed for the furthest wastes of Cania.
The tear falls to the ice and shatters. In each shard is the image of the Sleeping Man, frost clinging to his lips, marching through a purple haze. A doorway looms before him, set into the ice.
You open the door and the Sleeping Man stumbles through, grateful to be free from the icy winds. You feel yourself being pulled through more doors, down corridors, through rooms...
Suddenly you're in a room and a voice says "You have many questions but I can only answer one." You can feel the torment of the Sleeping Man as he ponders what to ask.
"It is want for love that brought me here, Knower. While I yearn to know where my true love is today or where I might learn the name by which I'll know her, no answer you can give would help me."
"Instead I ask where it is that I will meet her. Tell me that and I shall wait there 'til she has found me. Let that be my question, Knower, and answer true."
The Knower's answer is buried in a squall of purple snow as the Sleeping Man returns to the Gates of Cania. He removes a ring from his finger and the world is white again.
When he removed the ring from his finger, it split back into the three interconnecting bands from which it was fashioned. He built a chamber for the ring below the ice, that it might be safe.

Atop the chambers he built himself a stone bed, heated from below. He waited many days for his true love. When she did not come, he slowly fell asleep, content in the knowledge that she would find him there.
Alas, the Sleeping Man has settled into a deeper slumber, void of dreams. Try as you might, you cannot reach him there.

The city doesn't seem to exist in the Sleeping Man's dream. Instead, the Gatehouse's portal lies exposed atop a plain of ice. The city must have built up around it at a later date as the Gatehouse saw more use.
The answer given by the Knower of Places still resounds in the Sleeping Man's subconscious: "She will find you by the Gates of Cania..."
A dizzying array of questions tumble through the Sleeping Man's mind. Where am I? Where do I belong? Where was the Knower of Names banished to? Where must I go?
Where will I meet my one true love? Where is she now? Where will she die? Where will I die? Where can good be found? Where can evil be vanquished? Where can I find the truth?

The voice is a female one, not unlike that of the Knower of Names from the Sleeping Man's previous dream. It's as if she had an older sister. A part of you realizes that she is called the Knower of Places.
You find it difficult to focus on the features of the room. It somehow seems to be many places all at once or maybe not a place at all. You don't know quite what to make of it.
The haze seems to permeate everything, even the ice itself. Looking past the Sleeping Man, you see a string of red arrows burning bright in the purple air, leading him towards the door.
Somehow it all seems tied to a ring he wears upon his finger, a ring that has charted a course for him through the wastelands.
He's shivering, almost dead from the cold but something, either passion or madness, still burns bright in his eyes. He has come in search of answers and those answers, at long last, are near.
You seem unable to refocus on the shattered tear and before long it fades away to nothing. It seems that dream is over and a new one has begun.
There seems to be nothing for you to focus on, no concept in the dream for you to cling to. It is as if the Sleeping Man has never heard of the Reaper.
Through the mist comes the image of a remote glacier, its surface pocked by twelve smoldering pits. The pits slowly fill with drifting snow, the banished ones buried beneath its frigid weight.
The Sleeping Man seems to consider the plane of Cania a recent addition to the Hells of Baator, with the Knower of Names somehow belonging to its previous existence.
You get the sense that other such ancient baatorians must have existed in the Sleeping Man's time, though even then they seem a rarity, hunted by the devils to near extinction.
One by one, Mephistopheles calls his treacherous generals by name, their True Name, and sends them hurtling through Cania's starless sky like meteors, wrapped in hellish flame.

"You are banished," he declares, "to the furthest wastes of Cania! May the glaciers bury you and may all memory of your passing be stripped from the Hells of Baator! By your True Names, I command it so!"

He seems younger in this dream than you remember him, yet taller, too. The arrogance of triumph swirls about him, dark and almost corporeal. There is a certain sense of glee as well, a pride in his deceit.
It seems Baron Molikroth was a ruse, a devil's deceit through which Mephistopheles was able to uncover those who conspired against his throne.
Their voices are gruff and guttural, interspersed with the gnashing of teeth. They are Generals on the devil's side of the Blood War and high-ranking ones at that.

One voice is different, though: nervous and not devilish at all. Ancient as it is, the voice seems to hold a wisdom far beyond its years. It knows too much... It knows that treachery is afoot, yet it stays silent.
The dream is all around you, each aspect so richly textured that there seems no end to its depth, to its completeness. You focus on the Baron's name and are filled with a sudden unease.
Something is wrong and you find yourself filled with a sense of impending doom. There is treachery afoot and you can sense that there is something Baron Molikroth has not told those who follow him.
The Sleeping Man's dreamscape shifts and ripples in response to your curiosity. You sense the voice of an old storyteller, the smell of sour ale, the warmth of a fire.
This must be a story the Sleeping Man had heard, long ago. A story he had sought out. A story of an uprising here in Cania, devil against devil in a war for rulership over the Eighth Hell.
You can barely discern the slow rise and fall of his well-muscled torso. His breath coalesces into small puffs in the cool air, the feathers of his wings fluttering slightly in the drafty room.
There is a sadness in his face and a weariness that hangs upon his brow but the corners of his mouth are turned upwards in a gentle smile. Something about him feels undeniably holy.
The Sleeping Man, now wide awake, looks to you expectantly.

The Sleeping Man rests atop his dais, unchanged since last you saw him. You wonder how long he's been there and how much longer he's prepared to wait. You realize that you have no means to read his dreams...
You lean close and breathe the Sleeping Man's True Name. "Celesfa'ar the Patient..." He stirs slightly at your voice as if somehow knowing, even in deepest sleep, that someone commands him.
The Sleeping Man relaxes, fading deeper into his slumber.
The Sleeping Man stirs and wakes, his eyes still unaccustomed to the temple's pale green light. "What is the meaning of this? Why have you woken me?"
The Sleeping Man stirs and wakes, his eyes still unaccustomed to the temple's pale green light.
"Pilgrim <LastName>! Why have you woken him!? What is the meaning of this?" You can sense her panic, her ill intent. You watch as her hands clench into fists and she prepares to attack.
If the sensei heard your words, she gives no indication of it. With a wrathful scream, she descends on you.
Stunned, the sensei pauses, unable to harm the one who commands her.
"But... No, I will not fight her! What is going on? This is madness!"
"You have quite the explaining to do, Pilgrim, but it appears I have no choice but to hear you out. Continue then..."
"Yes, you have quite the explaining to do indeed. What is the meaning of all this commotion?"
You nod to the Sleeping Man. "I have dreamed the name of my one true love," he proclaims amidst the celestial light that is beginning to swirl about him.
"She is a celestial deva by the name of Lavoera. I will return to my home in search of her. If she is an angel already born, then there are likely to be records... "
"It is the Knower of Names, imprisoned by Mephistopheles in some far-off and secret place following the Molikroth Rebellion..."
"It is the Knower of Places who I met once, long ago. I pray she is well..."
"She is Nathyrra, a woman of the drow. Do you know of her?"
"She is a githzerai known as the Sensei Dharvana. Do you know of her?"
"She is a spirit known as Lady Aribeth. Do you know of her?"
"It is you, <FullName>. You are the one I have waited for." He stands before you, kissing you, pulling you into his celestial embrace. "My one true love," he whispers.
As suddenly as she came, the sensei is gone, leaving you and the Sleeping Man alone amidst the echoes of her rage.
"Who was that? I barely caught a glimpse of her."
[SMAN THINKS HE KNOWS HIS ONE TRUE LOVE] "Then I thank you for your protection. Just now I dreamed the name of my one true love and I would hate to be cut down before I lay eyes on her."
"Yes, well you have quite the explaining to do. What is the meaning of all this commotion?"
"Well you woke me from a dream wherein I heard the name of my one true love," he proclaims amidst the celestial light that is beginning to swirl about him.
"You condemn yourself with your own words and have banished my one true love! You have brought my wrath upon you, you fool!"

The muscles of the Sleeping Man ripple and twist, his body contorting as if from some fevered dream. He cries out in anguish, then all is still. With your fingers to his neck, you find no pulse. His body is already growing cold.
His stirring stops abruptly, his muscles tense, as if the Sleeping Man's entire subconscious hangs upon this thread.
The Sleeping Man waits, eyes closed, still commanded by his True Name.
He smiles at the name and is at peace.
He smiles at the name and is at peace.

He turns to you, his eyes open, his mouth a warm smile. Reaching up, he kisses you, pulling you into his celestial embrace. His mouth tastes like morning flowers. "My one true love," he whispers.

<StartCheck>[Saved vs. Discern Lies]</Start> He turns to you, his eyes open, his mouth a warm smile. Reaching up, he kisses you, pulling you into his celestial embrace. "My one true love," he whispers.

A look of shock crosses his face, the mark of your hand still white upon it. His voice comes to you then, laden with confusion and regret. "I'm... I'm sorry, <FirstName>. What have I done to displease you?"
Hesitant and shy, he cups a hand behind your neck. Leaning in, eyes closed, he places the tenderest kiss in all the world upon your lips.
"On edge? What is it that causes my love so much grief?"
"My very existence? But... But you are my one true love! Am I not yours? Have I waited so long only to know the torment of your scorn? It would have been better if I had died in my sleep..."
"Farewell, then. I give you my undying love and take your scorn with me... The Hells know no torment such as mine. I can only pray the next life is not as cruel."
"Forgive me, my dear, for you are right. I fear I have built this moment up too much within my heart and now must suffer for it. Please, do not scorn me for my love."
A line of worry creases his brow. "Is something the matter, my love?"

"I... I smell bad? My love, I have traveled countless leagues to find you and have slept for millennia in the depths of the Nine Hells waiting for you to arrive! If a bath is all you ask of me I will do it but..."
You smile to yourself as the look of terror on the Sleeping Man's face widens into a broad grin. He throws his head back and laughs the richest, warmest laugh you have ever heard.
"You're right, I had almost forgotten my sense of humor in this place. It feels good to laugh again and I have you to thank for it. But tell me in truth, what worry lurks beneath your jest?"
"You don't understand. You won't find a bath in all of Cania! I doubt there are even any in all the Hells of Baator!"
"Fine, fine, I'll do it! I'll figure something out! But where will I meet you once I have?"

"My place? But I haven't been back to Elysium for eons! It's probably a horrible mess... No, don't worry! I'll bathe and then clean -- no, clean and then bathe! It doesn't matter, I'll see you there!"

"Then I will meet you there, freshly bathed, and we can talk. Maybe we can go somewhere for tea or I can treat you to supper! Do you like lamb? No, don't answer, it will be a surprise. I'll see you there!"
"Then stay! Don't move a muscle! I'll be back as soon as I possibly can! I promise you that, <FirstName>, on my love!"
"It's over? But it's barely begun! ...Fine, a curse on you and all your gender, then! May your black heart rot within you breast... I wasted my life for you. We are done here, <FullName>..."
"But you've only just arrived... What can be so pressing?"
"Will you be returning? Where shall I find you?"
"Yes, my home in Elysium. I have been long away... May the gods shine favor upon you in what you must do, then. I will prepare my home in paradise for your coming."
"Go then, my dear, and do whatever it is that you must do. If I do not hear from you within a week, I will look for you in this place you call Waterdeep."
"Then I shall wait up here in the rafters for you until your return. I pray you do not tarry long, my love, as your kiss is like a fountain in the desert and I thirst for more..."

"Then I shall wait up here in the rafters until you are ready... Do what you must, my love, but return to me before you are old and gray and your life is spent. While I will wait for you, time will not..."
"I have come to Baator itself to find you, <FirstName>, and I shall let no evil come between us. I will fight this evil by your side, in love's own name, if you will allow it."
"Love is never in the way but, if that is your wish, I will not interfere. Where shall I find you when your battle is ended, then?"
"I understand. If that is your wish, I will not interfere... When the battle has ended, however, where shall I find you?"
"<FirstName>? Do you speak true? I confess, I had dreamed of more... But at least I have beheld your face. I have heard your voice. I have tasted of your lips..."

"I have waited long for this and I would wait as long again to see you twice... Oh love, my fate is empty but my heart at least is full. The memory of you will sustain me... Farewell, then, my one true love..."
"Yes, my home in Elysium. I have been long away... May the gods shine favor upon you in the face of evil, then. Fight your battle well while I prepare my home in paradise for your coming."
"In the city of Waterdeep on the world of Toril... Go then, my dear, and with my love. I will find you there once your battle is won."
"And I will wait up here in the rafters for you to the end of time, my love... May the gods show favor on you in the face of evil."

"For you I would move the Heavens and the earth... The world of Toril, you say, on the Material Plane? Go my dear, and with my love. I will find you there and be beside you when it comes time for battle."
He tastes your lips, your tongue, becoming increasingly passionate. "I have been waiting for this moment all of my life, <FirstName>" he murmurs, tears streaming freely from his gray-green eyes.
Something in you tenses, then, some memory of the vengeance you have yet to take on your nemesis, Mephistopheles. A line of worry crosses the Sleeping Man's brow. "Is something the matter, my love?"
THE SLEEPING MAN. A FALLEN PLANETAR WHO JOURNEYED TO CANIA LONG AGO TO FIND HIS TRUE LOVE. FOUND IN THE TEMPLE THAT BEARS HIS NAME.
<StartCheck>[Lie]</Start> "I have no idea. It was as if she came out of nowhere."
<StartCheck>[Lie]</Start> "A she-devil, bent on my destruction."
<StartCheck>[Lie]</Start> "A vengeful spirit, I'm afraid."
"It was a woman of the Githzerai."
<StartCheck>[Lie]</Start> "Just a jealous lover, nothing more."
"That was the sensei. She runs the temple here."
<StartCheck>[Lie]</Start> "The Gates of Cania? No, they lie far to the south."
"You are in the City of Lost Souls, at the foot of Cania's gates."
<StartCheck>[Lie]</Start> "She worshipped Tyr, the god of goodly justice."
<StartCheck>[Lie]</Start> "She worshipped the devil Mephistopheles."
"She worshipped some being called the Sleeping Man."

"I'm not sure."
"I needed to get that woman's attention."

"Sorry, I have misspoken. I did not mean to cause alarm."
"She is right here, the Lady Aribeth."
"It is I. I am your true love."

"Then tell me of this ring."
"Back to my other questions."

"Why is she banished?"

"Your one true love?"

The Knower of Places hovers about you with her gossamer wings, eager for your attention.
Amidst the chaos of the place, you spy a woman's face, a butterfly's wings, a coquettish glance... It seems the Sleeping Man's ring has led you at long last to the Knower of Places.
"Yes, you should have asked where to find patience, you should have asked! Many find their one true love but who finds patience in this world? Such an answer would have been worth far more..."

"Your accord? It's like a ball of string, a ball of countless cords, not your own at all! You don't have his wings, you don't wear his skin but you'll ask his questions all the same. You have his ring, you see?"

"No? Are you sure? You wear his ring and there's only one, only one in all the world and here it is, you see? Here it is. You don't have his wings, you don't wear his skin but you'll ask his question sure enough."

"But come, Planetar, my friend, my only friend, my one true friend in all this world, let us talk together of old times. A million questions but none of Where. You asked that question once already, nevermore."
"Please, my precious Planetar, it breaks my heart to see you beg me so. I cannot tell you that. You know how true that is, I told you long ago."

"Perhaps not. Perhaps you come here with your own desires and needs, separate from those of my fair Planetar... But it's a pretty thing to believe that he might come back for me... Very well, two answers I will give you, then:"
"Of course I don't, my love, my Planetar. Only one question, I vowed, because I dare not have you see the picture whole. It's already clear I cannot be your one true love, don't you see?"

"I dare not leave the safety of this place, yet I know your love will find you elsewhere. Frail and jealous is my heart. Did you expect me to give you away upon a silver platter, an apple in your mouth?"

"Well, hope has led you this far, Planetar. I suppose there is nothing that can prevent it from taking you to the end... I will give you two answers to your question for it is the second you have asked me."
"Then who am I to deny you of your heart's desire? ...Very well, I will give you two answers to your question for it is the second you have asked of me."

"The first answer lies in the ring that led you here. Let its three bands of hope be tempered with this fourth band that I have fashioned from my despair. It will lead you to her prison as this has led you here."
"You are not the first to seek their prison and not the first to find it. Time is a twelve-spoked wheel and with every hour of our lives another spoke has come and gone..."

"No. Thank you, my Planetar, for everything and nothing all at once. You have made a shadow out of me... Your spoke has passed, however, and it is time you go. Pursue your quest before I fade away entirely..."
"No, do not thank me... Forget me... That would be better, I think. Yes, forget me, my Planetar and, with the passing of the spokes, maybe I will forget you..."
"It is what it is, my Planetar. Maybe with the passing of the spokes, you will understand."
"If you love somebody, set them free... For otherwise your heart shall be clutched between their teeth forevermore. Let their freedom become your own..."
You glance at the ring upon your finger. The three golden bands that have always been there are now entwined with what appears to be grasping black tendrils, frozen in place and cold as iron.
"Because that question involves a Where and I told you yours already, long ago when last I saw you. Only one, I told you then. Only one question, only one answer. I told you that, my Planetar..."

"A sister you call her? Yes, I can see why you might think of us in that way. She was the youngest of us, born after the devils first claimed the ice of Cania as their own... Young and sweet, pretty and foolish..."
"O, Planetar... She loved too much, too fast, too hard, too passionately. We were all harlots of knowledge and they loved us for our minds. Even you, even Mephistopheles, one and the same."
"We tried to warn her 'gainst a devil's heart but that only made her ardor stronger. Perhaps she thought to change him, perhaps the waters of her heart ran darker than we knew..."
"But yes, she loved him and was loved by him, or so it seems before he betrayed her and cast her out and banished her in flames to a place I cannot tell you, Planetar..."
"Hush, Planetar... See how hard it is for you to say? You never loved me but at least you believed me. Who am I to ask for more, my Planetar? Who am I to ask for more?"

"Those are pretty words to hear, Planetar, made all the prettier by your lips. But if you had loved me you would have stayed with me and if you love me now, you'd do the same. It's the deeds that speak..."

"I... I have. Oh I try not to, Planetar, I try so hard, but some questions have no answers or no answers that make sense or no answers that don't say too much or too little all at once... I try not to, Planetar."
"You, Planetar, only you, just like I told you before, only you. I've loved others in their time but I haven't seen anyone for so long now, only you. I can be true to you, Planetar. Only you..."

"Ah, Planetar, it is not a place at all. It is a noplace, a nonplace, an unplace, a place between places, a space between spaces, an intraverse where you alone have found me. Do you like it? Stay with me here."
"You are the Planetar because you wear his ring, ask his questions, pursue his quest. I, too, am who I am, an amalgam of faces and places and cases of things."
"Every time a scorpion stings, another angel's lost its wings... She'll find you by the Gates of Cania, Planetar, I told you that once already. Once and once alone, I told you that."

The Knower of Names turns to you, a sadness clinging to her pale face.
Suddenly the Knower of Names is there before you, pale, white, and triumphant. Her youthful features shine beneath the icy pallor of her skin and she leans toward you, whispers in your ear...
"Ah, True Names... Every name has its price and every price a name. The gods declare it so. Now whose True Name do you wish to know?"
"Very well. We had been discussing your True Name..."
"I have already told you that the one you know as the Reaper of Cania is called Hecugoth the Abandoned in the gods' tongue... Is there another you wish to learn?"

"Ah, I can sense that this is the name you truly seek. The gods demand a strange price for it, though... There are two items that have aided you in your quest: a ring and an amulet. You must surrender them."
"The one you know as the Reaper of Cania is called Hecugoth the Abandoned in the gods' tongue... Is there another you wish to learn?"

"The lower ranks were slaughtered in battle. The rebel generals, eleven in number, were banished to this icy prison by the one known as Mephistopheles."

"The so-called Baron was none other than Mephistopheles himself. Suspicious of dissent among his generals, he staged the Rebellion that he might identify his betrayers, even among his closest friends."
"Because that is who you are, who you have always been, who you will yet become. The gods have written it upon the stars... Your presence darkens even this dark place, Hellwalker."
"Because that is who you are, who you have always been, who you will yet become. The gods have written it upon the stars... You are a bridge to span this dark chasm, Hellwalker."
"Because that is who you are, who you have always been, who you will yet become. The gods have written it upon the stars... You bring light into a dark place, Hellwalker."
"When it comes to names, there is no mistake that I can make. That is as much my gift as it is my curse..."
"The name you speak is the one you have given yourself. The name I speak is the one given you by the gods. Guard it jealously for it has cost you much."

"I have been known as the Knower of Names among the tongues of men and the devils call me an ancient baatorian. But my True Name is spoken in the tongue of power, written upon the stars by the very gods."
"Such names are valuable and each one has a price. By freeing me, you have paid the price for your own, thus have I spoken it to you."
THE REBELLIOUS 'KNOWER OF NAMES,' BURIED BENEATH THE ICE OF CANIA'S MORE REMOTE WASTES.

Sweat beads on Durnan's face. He calls out orders, his voice almost lost in the din of battle. He seems older than you remember him and his shoulders sag with the weight of many defeats. He turns to you, surprised.

"Wherever you've been, it's good to have you back, my friend. The drow threat was just a mask for an even greater horror. Our priests say the arch-devil Mephistopheles has been let loose upon the world."

"Tamsil, my daughter, escaped by caravan to Neverwinter. Mhaere, however... I haven't seen her in days... Times are dire: the priests say the arch-devil Mephistopheles has been let loose upon the world."
"Get in line, my friend. In hindsight, the drow encroachment on Undermountain was just a mask for an even greater horror. Somehow the arch-devil you speak of has been let loose upon the world."
"There are some things I never understood about you but, dead or no, I must say I'm relieved to see your face again. The priests say the arch-devil Mephistopheles has been let loose upon the world."

"While you've been gone it seems the Hells have come for us. The drow threat was just a mask for an even greater horror. Our priests say the arch-devil Mephistopheles has been let loose upon the world."
"We fight his minions even now. Some districts have held against their onslaught but only where Mephistopheles himself hasn't joined the battle. It's a war of movement now; we fight just to survive."

"He will destroy us all, <FirstName>... All the realms will fall... Blessings upon those who die for the rest will become his slaves... Maybe there is a reason for your coming in this hour but I cannot see it."

"You would have me order my men into the very fires of the Nine Hells! Damn you, <FirstName>! You haven't been here! You haven't seen what I've seen! If you're so brave and foolish, face him yourself! I can't do it..."

"Then may the gods grant you strength. With every battle, he grows in power. We've had reports that he's on his way here. I'll order my men to pull back when he arrives... You're our only hope, <FirstName>."
DURNAN, COMMANDER OF THE WATERDHAVIAN GARRISON. USE HIS LINES FROM PREVIOUS CHAPTERS AS A GUIDE.

"Just keep everyone safe. I'll handle Mephistopheles."
Oozing blood and fire and pus from a thousand wounds, Mephistopheles lies in a crumpled heap upon the ground. His eyelids flicker open, catching you in their pitch-black depths.
Your nemesis, Mephistopheles, towers above you, burning corpses all about him. Having summoned you back down from your safe vantage point, he tosses a wicked smile toward your tiny form.
"Trust me, mortal, you haven't the style... It takes more than a sharp wit and a cruel heart to rule the world. You really must... dress the part."
"Join me? I am sorry, mortal, but this is a one-man show... I have had 'friends' before. Eleven or twelve of them, for that matter. In the end, I don't think they really liked me."
"You and which army, foolish mortal? I dare say it seems they have run off and left you alone to face me. A pity."
"My... My True Name! You've commanded me!? Where did you learn it?! Rrraugh, but I must obey! ...What... What is it you wish of me, <Master/Mistress>? How must I serve you?"
"My... My True Name! You've commanded me!? Where did you learn it?! Vengeance! Rrraugh, but I must obey! ...What... What is it you wish of me, <Master/Mistress>? How must I serve you?"

"Now... who is this you have with you, <FirstName>? Not a kobold, but a veritable dragon! Bristling with power! Tell me, little one, why do you chase after <FirstName> like some lost servant when you could be so much more?"

"I would have thought even you might have figured it out by now. I am making a bid for Lordship over all the Hells of Baator. All Ten Hells, to be precise... There's a catch, though. You see, I have run into a bit of a stumbling block..."
"What kind of Hell should I craft out of your precious world? I mean, honestly, how does one even go about decorating a place like this? Hmmm... the earth tones will simply have to go."

"How very witty! It is a shame you did not like dearest Cania, really. I thought I was being very gallant leaving it for you. Imagine: you could have been <Lord/Lady> of the Eighth. An aspiration any mortal should leap for, don't you think?"
MEPHISTOPHELES. HE'S BIG, HE'S BAD, THE GIRLS ALL THINK HE'S DREAMY...

This section of fence shows signs of wear. The wood has cracked and splintered in various places.
There seems to be enough wood here to start a fire.
As the berries break open, bursts of energy spark forth, igniting the wood near you. A large fire has been created and its warmth should stay with you for a long time.
As the berries break open, bursts of energy spark forth, igniting the wood near you. A medium fire has been created and its warmth should stay with you for a good while.
As the berry breaks open, a burst of energy sparks forth, igniting the wood near you. A small fire has been created and its warmth should stay with you for a bit.
Cania's bitter winds extinguish your paltry flame before it even has a chance to catch. You will have to find some other way to make a fire.

The passage is blocked by a cascade of ice. The misshapen fiend you just fought probably collapsed it behind him. Any creature wishing to clear the path would have to be equally large.
Intense heat emanates from the floor of the corridor, the coals sending cinders aloft. The notion of walking atop the coals strikes you as an inordinately painful experience.
"I will show those fiends a Blood War!"
"Spies! The demons have sent little ones as spies among us!"
"I will crush them, devils and demons alike!"
"The Blood War grows closer! They battle just outside the fortress walls!"
"Raaaugh! A little one! Is it a devil or a demon? I can't tell..."
You see no way to interact with this directly.
"Your suffering shall be eternal!"
"I shall enjoy your suffering!"
"You have no hope!"

You speculate on how the Sleeping Man's three-part ring might eventually fit together. Until you have all the pieces, however, it will be hard to tell.
The three pieces of the Sleeping Man's ring glitter in your hand, each inscribed with a different initial. You wonder where you should begin.
You separate the piece of the ring marked with an 'H' from the others and hold it between your fingers. It gleams softly in dim light, as if encouraging you to continue.
You jump with surprise as a jolt of electricity courses through your body. You watch as the ring disassembles itself in your hand. Apparently, you have made the wrong choice.
You attach the piece of the ring marked with an 'F' to the one marked with an 'H'. The seam between them glows warmly, then disappears as the two pieces fuse together.

You add the final piece, marked with an 'L'. The seam glows and fuses completing the ring. The three letters, 'HFL', now correspond with the journey of Hope, Faith, and Love mentioned in the Sleeping Man's prayer.
You jump with surprise as a jolt of electricity courses through your body. Apparently, you have made the wrong choice.
<StartAction>Put the pieces of the ring away.</Start>

The rat scurries about, searching for shiny gems with which to line his lair. It sticks to the shadows, avoiding the covetous gaze of the strange, grappling chest.
One of the gems seized between its teeth, the rat is slowly dragging its prize back to its lair. It sticks to the shadows, trying to avoid the covetous gaze of the strange, grappling chest.
You stumble upon some tracks half-buried in the snow but can't make heads or tails of them.
You come across some tracks half-buried in the snow. There are some smaller ones that look like they belong to some kind of dog, as well as some larger ones you can't seem to identify.

You spy some tracks half-buried in the snow. Most belong to a pack of frost worgs that likely makes its den somewhere to the west. A larger set of worg prints indicate a powerful alpha male leading the pack.
A larger set of wolf prints indicate a powerful alpha male leading the pack. Surprisingly, however, you find no evidence of pups.

Farther off, you also spy an older set of prints belonging to some form of Troll. Judging by the depth of the impression and cold climate, you suspect that a handful of Ice Trolls must call the region home.
You stumble upon a smattering of rodent tracks leading every which way in the dust.
You see some well-worn rat tracks crisscrossing the dusty floor. They must have a nest somewhere nearby.

You spy various well-worn rat tracks crisscrossing the dusty floor. They all lead back to a pile of crates in the corner where you can see they've managed to chew a small hole. No doubt they have a nest on the other side.
You stumble upon various large tracks in the snow. Whatever created them was definitely big.
You see some footprints set deep in the snow. The bulk of them appear to come from some form of giant humanoid, though there are some smaller ones that you can't quite identify.

You spy a collection of footprints set deep in the snow. Most appear to be the oversized bootprints of a band of Frost Giants, though you also spy some smaller ones that look to belong to a family of ice trolls.
Though the tracks clearly mingle, they show no signs of conflict. While you doubt the two groups met for a purely social engagement, they likely had to negotiate an end to some minor dispute.
You stumble upon some bloodstains in the well-trampled snow, but you're not sure what to make of them.
You see some bloodstains in the well-trampled snow. Some of the footprints seem to be trollish in origin.
You spy some bloodstains in the well-trampled snow and quickly ascertain that the trolls must have sent a small raiding party to capture some of the Frost Giants' hunting wolves.
Judging by the blood, one of the trolls must have been unable to contain its hunger, biting into one of the still-warm carcasses before returning safely home.
You stumble upon some chunks of ice beneath the drifting snow and wonder how they might have been formed.

You see a somewhat regular pattern of ice chunks rising out of the drifting snow. They almost seem to form a line of footprints but the pattern gets chaotic as it nears the unmistakable trails left by the Frost Giants.
An intensely hot creature, presumably some form of fire elemental, has left icy footprints where the snow that melted beneath its feet has since re-frozen.
Judging by the chaos of the tracks, there were more than one of them and they were able to surprise a patrolling Frost Giant and lay him low. The impression left by his fallen body is deep indeed.
Pools of ichor and puddles of slush are all that mark the scene of the fiendish battle you just witnessed.
Pools of ichor and puddles of slush mark the scene of the fiendish battle you just witnessed. The trail of blood leads through the shattered wall and to the battle that still rages beyond.
Pools of ichor and puddles of slush mark the scene of the fiendish battle you just witnessed. The trail of blood leads through the shattered wall and to the battle that still rages beyond.

Examining the trail more closely, you note that both sets of prints show signs of extensive weariness and past injury, as if the skirmish in which they were engaged had been raging for quite some time.
You stumble across a set of heavy footprints almost entirely obscured by the falling snow. They must be quite old, still visible only by virtue of their substantial depth and size.

You see a pair of tracks almost entirely obscured by the falling snow. Though the tracks are quite old, you can see that one is of a relatively average-sized humanoid and the other from a fairly large, misshapen devil.

You see a pair of tracks almost entirely obscured by the falling snow. The tracks are quite old but it's clear that a relatively frail human male, probably a wizard of some sort, had approached one of the nearby pits.
It appears that he must have performed some form of ritual that melted the ice and freed one of the prisoners, a heavyset, misshapen pit fiend.
A brief altercation apparently ensued, the pit fiend clearly making short work of the one who freed him. The fiend's awkward gait left its telltale trail into the battlefield.
Evidence of the recent battle is already being buried beneath a layer of Cania's endless snow.
By studying the fading tracks of the warring fiends and their countless war machines, you can almost decipher the various fronts, feints, and strategies of the recent battle.
You wonder if either side knew the importance of what lay beneath the featureless stretch of ice over which they fought...

Judging by the tracks of the warring fiends and their countless war machines, the recent battle had been waging for some time, constantly criss-crossing the battlefield as one side or the other achieved the upper hand.
The lesser fiends were clearly the first to die, followed shortly thereafter by an extended artillery barrage that destroyed the bulk of both sides' war machines.

By the time you arrived, the demons had gained a slight advantage and pushed the front into new territory. The advance depleted their supplies however, forcing them to resort to throwing the ruins of what remained.
You wonder if either side knew the importance of what lay beneath the featureless stretch of ice over which they fought...
The wolf sniffs at you cautiously, ready to dart back and regroup at the first sign of sudden movement.
The alpha wolf nods at you and you swear you see it wink before it returns its attention to the frolicking pups.
The alpha wolf howls into the windswept sky and his howl tells a story...

There were pups here once, the lifeblood of the pack. But then came giants who destroyed the den and stole the pups away to raise as hunting dogs. If only the pups could return home, the pack would be strong again.
The alpha wolf stands strong and fierce before you, snarling. You can smell the fear of the other wolves.
Growling, the alpha wolf clamps its jaws around your neck, drawing a single bead of blood before letting go. It howls into the windswept sky and the tension of the moment fades.

His howl tells a story: There were pups here once, the lifeblood of the pack. But then came giants who destroyed the den and stole the pups away to raise as hunting dogs. If only the pups could return home, the pack would be strong again.
The wolf pup bites at your heels, eager to play.
Yipping excitedly, the wolf pups flee their enclosure.
The wolf seems happy to see you.
The wolf sniffs at you cautiously, ready to dart back and regroup at the first sign of sudden movement.
The wolf remains wary of you but seems willing to let you pass. You sense that it wants you to present yourself to the pack's alpha wolf.

You cannot fit through the entrance to the wolf den.
It would not be wise to approach the wolf den in that form.
The gate is locked.
A wall of ancient crates blocks your path, bound in some strange, unknown metal. Magic swirls around the barricade, making it clear that it is not as casual as it appears.
There seems to be a small break in the magic, however, and some enterprising rats have managed to exploit the barrier's weakness and chew a hole through to the other side.
Something glints in the darkness beyond. Gold? Rat's eyes? A hidden foe? The gloom makes it too hard to tell.
Flying doesn't seem like an option anymore, as you are definitely too large to fit through the hole in your current form.
<StartAction>Leave.</Start>
<StartAction>Peek through the hole.</Start>
<StartAction>Fly through the hole.</Start>
You've socketed both ears into the previously earless statue. To your surprise, the gargoyle's mouth has opened, revealing a small switch.
You hear the sounds of three distinct gongs rung in order. Their ringing reverberates through the entire chamber.
You've socketed one of the ears into the statue, but the second hole remains empty.
On close inspection, you notice that this statue was carved without ears. Instead, small, neatly carved holes mark where they should be, as if they were designed to be socketed in separately.
<StartAction>Press the switch.</Start>
<StartAction>Place the other ear into the remaining hole.</Start>
<StartAction>Leave.</Start>
<StartAction>Place both ears into the holes.</Start>
<StartAction>Place an ear into one of the holes.</Start>
The crystal at the center of the Sensei's Amulet sparkles and glints, as if hungry for light. There is something strange about the refractions but you're not quite sure what it is.

The Sensei's Amulet holds more power within it than you initially believed. At certain angles, its crystalline center catches the light, briefly shifting your form. Little by little, you feel you are mastering these newfound powers.

Battered, weary, and surprised, you clasp the Sensei's Amulet in your hands. The light is brighter out here beyond the city's grime and somehow it seems tied to your recent unexpected transformations.
Each time you shifted form, you swear you saw a flash of light glint off the crystal at the amulet's heart. Cautious, you decide to experiment further.
<StartAction>Put the amulet away.</Start>
<StartAction>Shift into Wolf form.</Start>
<StartAction>Catch the light along the crystal's length.</Start>
<StartAction>Shift into Earth Elemental form.</Start>
<StartAction>Catch the light along the crystal's width.</Start>
<StartAction>Shift into Pixie form.</Start>
<StartAction>Catch the light along the crystal's height.</Start>
<StartAction>Put the amulet away.</Start>
<StartAction>Catch the light along the crystal's length.</Start>
<StartAction>Catch the light along the crystal's width.</Start>
<StartAction>Catch the light along the crystal's height.</Start>
The rat blinks at you, twitching his nose before returning his attention to sniffing at the floor before him.
The rat stares up at you with eyes that seem as old as these caves. Reflected in their darkened pools, you see a series of images flashing by in rapid succession.
You see bones and rotting flesh, glittering objects of desire and, above all, the constant struggle to survive.
A warm feeling of gratitude emanates from the rat. You get the distinct impression that it wants you to see its prized nest, but you aren't sure how you could fit through the hole it's chewed.
It squeaks in fear and runs away.
The rat seems very possessive of the treasure it has gathered over the course of its long life. You get the sense that it is stashed away in a safe place where only a rat could go or fit.
The rotting flesh and bones bring a sense of comfort, a sense of home. The rat seems to be using the decay from these caves to form its nest.
<StartAction>Leave.</Start>
<StartAction>Feed the rat some seeds.</Start>
<StartAction>Attack the rat.</Start>
<StartAction>Focus on the images of the glittering objects.</Start>
<StartAction>Focus on the images of death and decay.</Start>
The rat blinks at you, twitching his nose before returning to gnaw on the ankle of the corpse before him.

"But our journey isn't yet done. Are you sure?"
"Thank you, <FirstName>. May Tyr guide our steps into the future, then."
"Here? Very well, but hurry back as soon as you are able, as I will miss your warmth and company."
"I... I'm sorry, <FirstName>, it was not my intention to offend... I suppose I will return to the Gatehouse and pray for your quick and safe return."
"Yes, what do you feel would be more suitable?"
"Very well. I will try to take the changes we have made to heart."
"Very well. I will refrain from my castings and trust to my blade instead."
"Thank you. I will cast as I see fit, then."
"I will refrain where I can, though I admit it goes against my calling as a paladin."

"Good. I'm afraid this armor doesn't leave me soft of foot."
"I will attack from the shadows when I can, though I must admit I prefer to keep my battles more straightforward."
"I will do what I can to remain quiet and out of sight."
"I will leave you to it, then, and not interfere."
"I will do what I am able should a lock be encountered."
"Of course. How far do you feel is suitable?"
"I shall attempt to follow you at that distance, then."
"With Tyr's might, I shall drive back our enemies!"
"By Tyr's might, I will shield you as long as I am able."
"Have you any other tactical issues you wish to discuss?"
"Very well but I'll not let you have my armor."
"I can try. Let me sort through your pack and see what you have."
"I have several... which do you want me to use?"
"In Tyr's name."
"In Tyr's name."
"Of course. Would you prefer benefits that last over the longer term or only for the immediate future?"
"Of course. What spell should I cast for you?"
"Are you certain that is the spell you want?"
"As you wish. Who would you like me to cast it on?"
"Is there anything else I can do to help?"
"At once."
"Yes, I could use a break. It's always pleasant to sit and chat awhile."
"Is there anything more I can do for you?"
"I've been wondering why I don't try to run away from myself when I attempt to Turn Undead..."
"Is there anything more you'd like to chat about?"
"A little cold but I've been colder, haven't I..."
"I'm doing fine. Let's keep moving."
"My complexion's a little pale, don't you think?"
"I'm doing all right. It's you I'm worried about."
"No storm can stir my inmost calm."
"Healthy and hale."
"Not bad for a paladin in hell, wouldn't you agree?"
"I am well enough. And you?"
"Something blinds me. I can see nothing of this world or the next."
"I am not at my best but my form holds together well enough. I vote we continue on."
"Can you not see how much I fade? I have been worse but a chance to rest and restore my form would be appreciated."
"I have all but faded. If we do not rest soon, I may disappear altogether."
"There is a venom in me, a fearful poison."
"I feel ill, as if a sickness courses through my ghostly veins."

[POST-MIMIC] "I've put some thought into it, <FirstName>, and I still feel drawn to Neverwinter. There is a time when I would have sought to haunt the place but perhaps I can be its protector, its guide, somehow."
"Yes, the future will come in its own time. Dwelling on it now will only slow its coming."
"It has been on my mind for some time. I only hope my presence there can bring peace to my old home."

"<FirstName>? It is not for you to allow or disallow... If it is an end you do not want for me, then you should have left me in the ice and never urged me to take up the mantle of my fallen paladinhood."
"We are in search of the Reaper's True Name, are we not? Should we succeed, suddenly all things become possible..."

"It's my penance, I think. I must serve that which I betrayed in life. But it's more than that, too. I want to walk its streets once more in summer, to hear the singing in the temple... It would be a pleasant end for me."
[PRE-MIMIC] "Why I can't say I know... Not so long ago, I didn't feel I had a future left to ponder. Let me think on it a while."
"Death does something to your thoughts. They become thick and woolen. Your memories cloud over for a while... Suddenly I had doubts and I no longer knew how I felt about my crimes..."

"I was scared of hell, <FirstName>. And when Mephistopheles came, he played my confusion like a toy... It wasn't until you came that I realized hell can pose no threat to that which is still good in me."
"Of course. What is it you wish to ask?"
"Not if we persevere, no. Our quest is righteous and the gods will see us through, I have no doubt."
"And I'm happy that you did. You've set me back upon the path of righteousness and I shall not forget it, you have my word."
"Nonsense. You saw my distress and came to my aid. Despite all your gruff demeanor, I can still see the goodness you keep buried deep. It's that goodness that helped me find my own again."

"I have heard that when warriors lose a limb in battle, sometimes they can still feel it. It is as if the limb exists but by virtue of their imagination alone. That is how it is but for all of me, every part..."
"The world seems dimmer through my eyes, the sounds less full, the tastes less rich. Everything is at it was in life, though I experience it as if through cotton batting..."
"Yes, there is only so much I can tell of this afterlife that will make sense to you."
"I had no idea what to expect, to be honest. I had studied the hells in my training but it is one thing to read of Cania's frozen wastes and quite another to find myself almost a part of them..."
"Horrible? I admit I lived a fervent life so perhaps I miss the vibrancy of life more than most. But hell, I'm sure, has greater horrors yet in store for me..."
"That it could be. If this is all the punishment hell has in store for me, I would be surprised. Though maybe you have already saved me from the worst of it, <FirstName>."

[POST-MIMIC] "I... This is so hard to talk about, <FirstName>... I betrayed the ones I loved, I failed them so utterly. I led an army of evil to the city's gates and marched them in to occupy and slaughter..."
"Yes, all this talk of Neverwinter drains me. I still find it hard to put to words."

"I died on Neverwinter soil. At least I have that much to console me... One kind thing to come of all the destruction that I wrought. When the end came, it was almost merciful, as much as a violent death can be."
"I guess Cania is where the gods put a soul like mine. Or maybe it was my soul that sought it out. In the end, the snow seems rather fitting, don't you think?"
"Yes, they did. I only wish they could have done it sooner before I'd damned myself so fully. To their credit, they took me by surprise. I had always thought I would outlive the war."
"Why indeed... I ask myself that a lot. I think, at the heart of it, I was convinced that I was right and all the was wrong around me. Oh, they did some bad things, made some mistakes but..."

"If the citizens of Neverwinter could not be perfect, I considered their failings a hypocrisy. Sometimes failings are just that: failings, nothing more. I was so self-righteous, I couldn't see the difference."
"Pirates from Luskan, orc tribes, sellswords, ancient magical orders... I twisted them all around my finger and made them serve me. If only I could have done so for a more noble cause..."
"I received my powers from a crone named Morag, the last Empress of her ancient race... But in the end it was myself I served. It would be a lie to suggest otherwise."

"Oh I grew up there! I ran as a child through its streets, I knew every nook and cranny, every weakness, every strength... If only I could have been ignorant of it all. Ignorance is bliss, they say..."
"If I had been been born a simpleton, my betrayal would have meant nothing! I was too smart for my own good, <FirstName>... With an artist's eye, I knew to destroy something of great beauty..."
